fields.headline: Wanchope double wins new admirers
fields.trailText: West Ham 2 - 1 Newcastle
fields.body:
Paulo Wanchope has rarely challenged jellied eels in the local popularity stakes since joining West Ham. But a few jars will have been raised to the Costa Rican last night for an invigorating substitute appearance which earned his team a victory and left Newcastle without a win in London for 18 matches since 1997.

Bobby Robson's team looked set to end that remarkable run after dominating the first half, twice hitting the bar, and eventually taking the lead through Gary Speed. But Wanchope's introduction woke West Ham from a poor performance and after his equaliser he turned on a cross from Paolo di Canio and shot into the roof of the net.

West Ham's hopes of victory had been raised by the return of the talismanic Di Canio, and all eyes were on the Italian for more than football reasons given that Paul Alcock was the referee. The pair were coming face to face on the pitch for the first time since Di Canio's infamous shove on the Kent official while playing for Sheffield Wednesday in September 1998.

There was no sign of padding, or a panic button, beneath the gear sported by Alcock, but he might have been dismayed by an advert in the programme portraying the striker beneath the phrase "You've got to be pushy to get to the top".

To general amusement Di Canio wasted little time in getting to grips with his one-time enemy. But seeing as he was captain in the absence of Steve Lomas, the handshake was forgivable enough. The two mascots who accompanied him to the centre circle were presumably not there for protection.

It was Newcastle's goalkeeper Shay Given who looked like he might need that as West Ham began brightly. With Joe Cole running at players at pace, and showing some fine touches, West Ham looked dangerous. Frank Lampard shot over but it proved a false dawn.

Newcastle soon settled and began to dominate, passing smoothly and looking to whip in crosses from either flank. Robbed of Duncan Ferguson because of injury, they played Alan Shearer alone up front with Kieron Dyer operating just behind. Dyer buzzed about to good effect.

Shortly after he had narrowly failed to make contact with a centre by Didier Domi, he turned provider for the Frenchman, clipping back a pass which Domi knocked against the bar from 12 yards.

Newcastle must have feared then that the bad luck that saw them lose to Chelsea in the FA Cup semi-final was destined to continue. And sure enough, in the 28th minute, Shearer's header from a Nol Solano cross hit the bar, bounced back and somehow went over off Craig Forrest's arm.

By then the inevitable Di Canio flashpoint had taken place after he appeared to dive in the area. After being challenged, he seemed to confuse Rob Lee for Alcock but a brief lecture calmed things down.

Newcastle did not have to wait long after half-time for the lead they deserved. Dyer's cross struck Igor Stimac and was deflected towards the edge of the area, where Speed struck a low shot past Forrest.

West Ham threw on Wanchope and from Di Canio's free-kick Marc-Vivien Foé saw his header bounce over. Then Cole's powerful shot was tipped wide by Given and finally Wanchope equalised with a far-post header from Di Canio's cross.

fields.headline: Sibon swoops to Dons' dismay
fields.standfirst: Wednesday enjoy rare away win
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 0 - 2 Sheff Wed
fields.body:
Wonders will never cease. Sheffield Wednesday secured only their second away win of an awful season last night to keep alive their distant hopes of avoiding relegation from the Premiership.

A breakaway goal from the player they nickname Bob de Bilde set up victory and Gerald Sibon widened the cracks in the Crazy Gang's foundations. Wimbledon, hoping to pocket the three points that would have all but guaranteed their own safety, now find themselves in dire trouble with games against Liverpool and two other strugglers, Bradford and Southampton, to come.

One would never have guessed that this was such a crucial game by the atmosphere inside Selhurst Park. Fifteen minutes before kick-off the players warming up on the pitch apeared to outnumber the spectators in the stands. It did not improve much once the game got underway, with one end of the ground completely empty and the far side lightly dusted with about 200 Wednesday's most loyal fans.

The driving rain and chill air did little to improve appetites for the fare on offer and one can understand why many preferred to watch the Naked Chef at home on television rather than 22 partially clothed footballers in the flesh.

Peter Shreeves promised to meet the club's growing crisis with all-out attack last night but his players found forward momentum difficult to achieve as Wimbledon dominated the early exchanges.

Of course, the home side could never claim that the soggy conditions hindered their style of play. As ever, the ball was played forward mainly in the air, with the greatest threat to Kevin Pressman's goal coming from the flanks.

On eight minutes Walid Badir swung in a cross that found the head of Andreas Lund. The header from Wim beldon's giant Norwegian was not that powerful, but Pressman needed two attempts to grab the slippery ball.

Marcus Gayle half-hit a volley straight at the keeper, then fired in a low crentre that skidded unmolested across the face of Pressman's goal.

The visiting side's own attacks had been few and far between. Their most dangerous chance fell to Peter Atherton, who saw a close-range shot deflected wide on 34 minutes.

Which made it even more astonishing when they took the lead. Niclas Alexandersson played the ball to Gilles de Bilde, who found himself running at goal from about 30 yards out.

The Belgian international held off two defenders before sliding the ball past Neil Sullivan from about 12 yards. Wimbledon's confidence dissolved and suddenly they looked like a side who had lost their previous four Premiership games. They exited at half-time to a chorus of boos.

But they emerged after the break displaying all the signs of a side who had received a severe ear-bashing with their half-time cup of tea. Then Egil Olsen brought on Carl Cort.

Just recovered from injury, the England Under-21 striker slotted into a re-shaped three-man forward line. And Wimbledon almost equalised immediately. Hughes swung over a free-kick from the left and Gayle directed a header only inches over the bar.

But Wednesday profited on the break. First Sullivan saved from De Bilde after a great through-ball by Andy Hinchcliffe caught Wimbledon short at the back. Then Andy Booth failed to convert a skidding cross from Alexandersson. And finally Wednesday scored.

Booth broke down the left and picked out Sibon at the far post, where the Dutchman had a simple task to tap in.

fields.headline: Dodds keeps Rangers on high
fields.trailText: Hearts 1 - 2 Rangers
fields.body:
Rangers brought themselves to the verge of winning the Scottish championship last night, but Hearts will forever claim that they were denied the chance to delay that coronation by a bad decision from the hard-pressed Willie Young.

The official's refusal to spot what looked a blatant handball by Tugay Kerimoglu, which gave Rangers their first goal, was the turning point in a match played on a rainy and windswept night.

The goal, scored by Rod Wallace, gave them heart and the match was eventually won in the 64th minute with a second goal as impeccable as the first was debatable. Then, Lorenzo Amoruso's forward pass was headed by Andrei Kanchelskis into the path of Billy Dodds, leaving the striker to thunder a volley past Antii Niemi, who had done nothing to deserve to leave the field as a loser.

The retention of the title has long been taken for granted, but Rangers still had plenty to play for. They arrived as the only club in Britain with an unbeaten away record this season, and they started strongly. For the first 10 minutes they kept the ball in the Hearts half with crisp passing but could not produce an early goal, and the Edinburgh club took advantage of the first opportunity that came their way.

Lee Makel's hopeful ball into the heart of the defence was pursued by Gary McSwegan. Amoruso arrived too late to make an effective challenge and the goalkeeper Stefan Klos, for some strange reason, hurtled off his line, leaving McSwegan to loft the ball over Klos and into the net.

Having conceded a rare unnecessary goal Rangers found themselves in a quandary, and the skipper Amoruso decided to take responsibility. Four minutes later he drove a 30-yard free kick so strongly that it bounced off Niemi's chest, the Finn retrieving the ball as Dodds and Wallace closed in.

But Hearts remained in control until just before the interval, when the referee somehow failed to notice Tugay's arm control Barry Ferguson's slanted ball into the penalty area. Wallace duly hit home a stunning volley and the official retired for his cup of tea with the fans chanting "cheat, cheat, cheat".

 A first-half goal from Paul Wright was enough to give Kilmarnock all three points in the relegation battle with Aberdeen at Rugby Park last night.

webTitle: C&N ups its price for Thomson Travel

fields.headline: C&N ups its price for Thomson Travel
fields.trailText: German holiday company C&N Touristic yesterday indicated that it might be ready to offer 145p a share for Thomson Travel - up from the 130p it suggested last week.
fields.body:
German holiday company C&N Touristic yesterday indicated that it might be ready to offer 145p a share for Thomson Travel - up from the 130p it suggested last week.

Though no formal offer has yet been tabled, and there has been no contact between the senior executives of the two groups, C&N's financial advisers in London yesterday made it clear to Thomson's bankers it was ready to offer 145p, which would value the British package holiday group at £1.45bn.

However, Thomson said the offer would still not be enough. "An offer of 145p, if made, would not reflect the value of the business and its prospects," the company announced.

C&N, Germany's second largest tour operator, is a joint venture between German airline Lufthansa and retailer Karstadt Quelle. With Thomson in its stable, C&N would overtake Preussag, owner of Thomas Cook, as Europe's top travel firm.

Thomson, whose business spans the Lunn Poly travel agency and holiday names like Austravel and English Country Cottages as well as the standard Thomson brochure holidays, has had a tough couple of years since it floated on the stock exchange at 170p.

The offering was hugely oversubscribed by small investors attracted by the holiday discounts promised to shareholders. The price has since slid remorselessly amid tough competition which has forced the group into a series of profits warnings. Thomsons' chairman, chief executive and finance director have all been replaced.

Yesterday the shares added 9p to 138p.

Thomson said that its rejection of C&N's latest approach was based on anticipated annual cost savings of at least £50m over the next two years as a result of focusing on its air-inclusive holiday business. The founding Canadian Thomson family, which still owns 22.4% of the company, has also rejected the "offer".

fields.headline: Vodafone and Orange at odds
fields.standfirst: Demerger part of Mannesmann go-ahead
fields.trailText: A row is brewing between Vodafone Airtouch and Orange management over the interpretation of yesterday's ruling by the European Commission that Orange be demerged from its parent.
fields.byline: Anne Hyland and Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
A row is brewing between Vodafone Airtouch and Orange management over the interpretation of yesterday's ruling by the European Commission that Orange be demerged from its parent.

The EC gave the green light to Vodafone's takeover of Mannesmann but required as part of that deal that Orange be demerged. Mannesmann bought Orange in 1999.

Vodafone, the world's largest mobile phone operator, has maintained that the EC's ruling will still allow it to consider a trade sale of Orange. However, Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, is adamant that Britain's third biggest mobile phone company will be relisted as an indepdent FTSE-100 company by the autumn. The group may also look at listing on the Nasdaq and Frankfurt markets.

Orange is expected to return to the EC and seek a clarification on its ruling that Vodafone may only sell Orange via a demerger. A demerger would see the sale of shares in Orange to the existing shareholders of Vodafone.

Orange management had lobbied the EC strongly on a demerger from Vodafone. They have argued that a trade sale by Vodafone could see it sold to a weaker opponent making it less competitive unit.

European Commissioner Mario Monti said: "We are confident that Orange, once divested by Vodafone, will be able to constitute a viable competitor."

Vodafone has agreed a confidential deadline with the EC by which time it must demerge Orange. It is expected to have concluded the estimated £25bn-£30bn deal by autumn. An Orange demerger is a cheaper option for Vodafone as it reduces the capital gains tax which would occur under a trade sale.

Nevertheless, France Telecom has expressed interest in making a bid for Orange as has Holland's KPN Telecom.

Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent welcomed the decision on the four month investigation and said the company's priority was now to forge ahead with integrating Mannesmann.

It was the EC's first ruling on a merger between two large mobile phone operators.

One of the EC's concerns was that the merger would result in favourable treatment in roaming tariffs to business customers which use Vodafone and Mannesmann's networks that cover at least nine European countries.

Vodafone is likely to introduce a pan-European tariff and this could undercut the charges of national operators in various European countries.

Mr Monti extracted a concession from both Vodafone and Mannesmann on roaming agreements.

He said rivals would be able to access Vodafone and Mannesmann's networks for a period of three years "at a non-discriminatory price".

This would, in effect, allow rivals to charge a similar price for overseas calls within Europe "and prevent the emergence of a dominant position".

But after three years, competitors will have to fend for themselves.

Vodafone shares yesterday fell 1/2p to 312p.

fields.headline: IMF warns chancellor
fields.standfirst:
Boost for national health service denounced as a step in the wrong direction

Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The International Monetary Fund yesterday stepped into the row over the impact of Gordon Brown's Budget on interest rates and the pound when it attacked the decision to boost public spending as "regrettable" and a "step in the wrong direction."
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund yesterday stepped into the row over the impact of Gordon Brown's Budget on interest rates and the pound when it attacked the decision to boost public spending as "regrettable" and a "step in the wrong direction."

In its half-yearly health check of the global economy, the IMF said that Mr Brown's package - which included a huge boost to NHS spending - would put additional pressure on monetary policy and the exchange rate.

The criticism in the fund's world economic outlook report - repeated at a later press conference - was strongly rejected by Mr Brown, who has been trying to fend off attacks from industrialists and the Conservatives over the impact of the Budget on borrowing costs.

Mr Brown told the Guardian last night: "I have made it absolutely clear that there is a fiscal tightening next year and the year after, based on the previous Budget forecast. I think when any detailed work is done on this, which obviously has not been possible at the IMF in the short time that they have our figures, they will see that that is exactly what the position is."

The chancellor has repeatedly said since announcing the extra public spending that the increases were justified by the bigger than anticipated surplus in the government's finances built up over the year.

Mervyn King, the deputy governor of the bank of England and a member of the monetary policy committee, supported Mr Brown's view in an interview with the Financial Times. He said he agreed that the Budget did not have a significant impact on activity or inflation and therefore made no difference to decisions on interest rates.

Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor, said : "The IMF has joined a long list of organisations to say that Gordon Brown's Budget will have regrettable consequences for inflation and for interest rates.

"British business - especially manufacturing - is already feeling intense pressure from interest rates and the exchange rate. This has been made all the worse by the huge increases in taxes and red tape introduced by Labour.

"The chancellor has already intensified the pressure through his irresponsible attack on savers, which has led to interest rates being higher than they would otherwise would be. Now the IMF say that his Budget might makes things worse.

"Gordon Brown talks endlessly about prudence, but businesses and independent observers are increasingly unconvinced."

The IMF yesterday praised the performance of the British economy, saying that it was mirroring the US in experiencing the longest expansion on record. However, the IMF report added: "The risks to inflation are mainly on the upside, given the ongoing strength of private demand and some signs of tightening in the labour market."

The Bank has already raised interest rates from 5% to 6% since last autumn in an attempt to prevent inflation from exceeding its 2.5% target, but the IMF said that this was unlikely to be enough.

fields.headline: Abbey National shake-up
fields.trailText: Abbey National is expected to outline a radical upheaval of its branch network this morning in a move which could affect hundreds of jobs.
fields.body:
Abbey National is expected to outline a radical upheaval of its branch network this morning in a move which could affect hundreds of jobs.

In what will be interpreted as an attempt to cut costs and boost its share rating in the City, the bank is expected to announce changes to the management structure of its 765 branches.

Abbey National, which employs 30,000, insisted last night suggestions of mass branch closures were inaccurate. It briefed its area directors yesterday on changes to the way its sales force and branch network would be operated, who in turn will outline the changes to staff this morning. John Berry, sales director for the bank, said the group would be creating 320 new jobs in addition to ones which have been vacant since a recruitment freeze was instigated earlier this year.

Rubbishing suggestions of redundances, he insisting that it would be impossible to indicate how many jobs would be affected.

Mr Berry said the bank would recruit 100 people for a new operation to sell stakeholder pensions and another 100 managers for its regulated (in-branch) sales force. He also said managers would be installed in the 120 branches currently without senior member of staff.

Mr Berry said the move was being made as a result of changing demands from customers and comes as the bank is opening outlets in coffee shops and shopping centres.

fields.headline: Music for a lazy lunch
fields.standfirst:
Yo-Yo Ma, Edgar Meyer, Mark O'Connor
The Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Yo-Yo Ma, Edgar Meyer, Mark O'Connor
The Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
Once it might have been called new age music, folk-classical, or simply sophisticated ambient. Now it's being promoted, far more grandly, as "the new face of classical music in the 21st century". Whatever you want to call it, there's already a sizeable market for classy, folk-based fusion styles in the US, where Yo-Yo Ma, Edgar Meyer and Mark O'Connor are based.

There is growing demand for crossover work here, too. For this concert - Appalachian Journey (also the name of their new album, featuring input from Alison Krauss and James Taylor) - the trio packed out the Barbican. The audience was surprisingly young, although this was a midday, midweek event.

It was a pleasant, if sometimes soporific, way to spend the lunch hour. These are all very classy musicians, with a long history of playing, and mixing, different styles. Yo-Yo Ma, the cellist, is known both for his classical work and exploration of Asian styles. Mark O'Connor, the Grammy-winning violinist, has recorded folk and jazz pieces as well as his own compositions. Double bassist and composer Edgar Meyers has played with anyone and everyone from orchestras to bluegrass bands and country rockers like Garth Brooks.

They looked suitably "new classical" (neat dark shirts and T-shirts) and their compositions had homely titles . Many of the pieces were based around Appalachian fiddle tunes. Yo-Yo Ma's cello managed to follow O'Connor's delicate, rapid-fire playing, before veering off into elaborate arrangements in which the lead moved between all three players. There were dance tunes and hornpipes given a gentle string-trio work-over, slower lyrical pieces, passages that would make great atmospheric film music and even a little humour.

It was all gently classy stuff, though comparisons with the folk-influenced work of Bartok and Vaughan Williams in their programme notes seemed fanciful. What "new classical" seems to offer is high quality, easy listening together with passages of truly virtuoso playing, and an often intriguing mix of styles with limited emotional range. Fine for a dozy lunchtime, but I wish they'd brought Alison Krauss or even James Taylor with them.

webTitle: A&L says golden goodbye to White

fields.headline: A&L says golden goodbye to White
fields.trailText: Peter White, the former chief executive of Alliance & Leicester, yesterday secured a £200,000 golden goodbye to add to his £1.5m compensation package for being ousted from the £438,000 a year job, which has been vacant since his departure in October.
fields.body:
Peter White, the former chief executive of Alliance & Leicester, yesterday secured a £200,000 golden goodbye to add to his £1.5m compensation package for being ousted from the £438,000 a year job, which has been vacant since his departure in October.

Avoiding an embarrassing and unusual employment tribunal hearing, A&L yesterday agreed to pay part of his pension early as well as allowing him to retain his share options.

Only one set of the three tranches of options had any value - about £200,000 - at A&L's 682p share price last night.

In contrast to the terse statement announcing Mr White's departure last year, A&L's chairman and acting chief executive, John Windeler, yesterday praised his predecessor's 18-year record at the former building society.

A&L said Mr White was "actively considering a number of offers" but admitted its search for a new chief executive was "still continuing".

Mystery surrounds the reason for Mr White's departure. It has been suggested his leadership style led to clashes with his board but there has also been speculation that the bank held merger discussions with its rival Woolwich without including him.

At its annual meeting yesterday, Woolwich said the mortgage market was buoyant but admitted that pressures on profit margins remained.

fields.headline: Bad grrls live forever
fields.standfirst:
L7
Manchester University
***
fields.trailText:
L7
Manchester University
fields.body:
As everybody from Courtney Love to Nabokov will tell you, never underestimate the appeal of a bad girl. Californian hell's belles L7 will be known to most British observers for their 1992 hit, Pretend We're Dead, but the briefly reigning Riot Grrl/grunge queens have left lasting impressions in other ways, too. The band once stripped naked on The Word and hurled a used tampon at the Reading festival audience.

Well into their 30s, they show no signs of calming down. Audiences on this rare visit can participate in a special "raffle": the winning ticket-holder gets to "meet intimately" with drummer Dee Plakas. The less-than-demure singer, Donita Sparks, explained, "Rock'n'roll is prostitution. We want to give our fans more bang for their bucks!"

Good-humoured and headline-catching outrage is L7's stock-in-trade. They arrive in a blaze of pouts, dye, leather and raised middle fingers and soon one of them is swearing. When I catch the kohl-darkened stare of guitarist/dominatrix Suzi, I worry less about ending up in their dressing room than the local infirmary.

Concentrating on the music is difficult, largely because there isn't much to concentrate on. Now less grunge and more Nu Metal-meets-very old Metal (Stooges, Motorhead, New York Dolls) they don't have songs so much as different riffs. They go up a bit; they go down a bit. There is, however, rarely a dull moment. Founding bassist Jennifer Finch has left to join Moby, so the band introduce her replacement, Janice Toroca. Fabulously, her surname means L7 can sing a song about her, as in "she-likes-to-rock-ah!" Soon enough, the new girl displays her bad girl credentials. "Screw you, Manchester!" she howls. Manchester cheers. "Thank you," she beams, politely.

Pretend We're Dead is still the best moment, inciting an orgy of sweat and hair. They may never pen another hit but could well keep on attracting lustful audiences (including a sizeable contingent of young, budding bad girls) until their hairstyles finally disintegrate.

L7 play Sheffield University tonight and the Garage, London, on Friday.

webTitle: Tyrant feeds on his divine right to be cruel

fields.headline: Tyrant feeds on his divine right to be cruel
fields.standfirst:
Richard II
Gainsborough Studios, London
***
fields.trailText:
Richard II
Gainsborough Studios, London
***
fields.body:
At the moment, we have an embarrassment of Richards. At Stratford-on-Avon there is a nakedly political, modern dress production. Now at the old Gainsborough Studios in Shoreditch, east London, Ralph Fiennes gives an unequivocal star performance in a traditional, pyramidal Almeida Theatre production.

The space is astonishing. One feels as if one is in an aircraft hangar. At one end of it sits a wide stage which designer Paul Brown has turned into an image of a disintegrating medieval England. The floor is a grassy carpet implying the demi-paradise that once was. But the rear brick wall is dominated by a huge central fissure which both suggests schismatic disintegration and allows for extravagantly regal entrances.

And Fiennes himself certainly gives us a Richard swathed in kingship. This is not the artist-king created by Frank Benson exactly 100 years ago. Fiennes's Richard is a mercurial autocrat. Entering enthroned to the sound of Te Deums, he soon reveals the flawed being underneath the ceremony. He sticks his tongue out at the corrective John of Gaunt, seizes his lands with arbitrary zeal and skips off to the Irish wars as if going to a fashion parade.

Within the parameters of Jonathan Kent's production, it is a fine performance. Fiennes has a stained glass profile, a resonant voice and a mordant irony. If the lyricism of Richard's downfall is underplayed, Fiennes compensates with a mocking humour. He is at his best in the deposition scene where he exaggeratedly cocks an ear as he cries: "God Save The King" and hugs the crown to his chest as if it were a favourite toy. Stripped of monarchy's protective divinity, this Richard becomes poignantly aware of his own wastefulness and other people's cunning.

What I miss in Kent's production is much sense of the play's politics. We are magnetised by Richard. But Linus Roache's stolidly impassive Bolingbroke gives us no hint of a man who turns injustice into opportunity. And amongst the anonymous Shakespearean nobles only two performances stand out. One is David Burke's ferocious, death-haunted John of Gaunt and the other is Oliver Ford Davies's wonderfully dithering Duke of York who reacts to the dilemmas of power with the uncertainty of the liberal intellectual.

Barbara Jefford also makes an impressive late appearance as a dominatingly maternal Duchess of York. But one looks in vain for an any insight into the way Boling broke's coup d'etat breeds another kind of tyranny.

The production feels like an old-fashioned framework for Fiennes's performance and for his agonised discovery that even kings are subject to the imperatives of transience, time and death.

webTitle: Keep your staff. Send in the cleaners

fields.headline: Keep your staff. Send in the cleaners
fields.standfirst:
To stop rookies deserting for dot.coms, US banks are offering golden perks. How long before they arrive at Canary Wharf?
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It used to be glory enough for young twentysomethings to be offered a job with one of the leading investment banks. Not any longer. Such is the attraction of self-employment and the potential riches of cyberspace that the lure of Wall Street and the City is no longer enough to excite the brightest young brains.
fields.body:
It used to be glory enough for young twentysomethings to be offered a job with one of the leading investment banks. Not any longer. Such is the attraction of self-employment and the potential riches of cyberspace that the lure of Wall Street and the City is no longer enough to excite the brightest young brains.

The potential difficulty of attracting and keeping top staff means that even the biggest investment banks are having to come up with new ways to recruit staff.

Most of the new packages being offered are on Wall Street, where the brain drain to the dot.coms is well advanced. But bankers in the City of London do not believe it will be long before young graduates are offered new employment terms on this side of the Atlantic.

It started by extending "dress down Fridays" - the day when bankers throw their pin-striped suits out of the window for smart, casual attire - to the rest of the week.

Concern about the competition for the best staff has driven many firms to take the concept further. Salomon Smith Barney, the epitome of the dog-eat-dog culture depicted in "Liar's Poker", unveiled a package of perks last month which some saw as "pampering rookies to arrest the brain drain".

Young analysts, who are said to be poorly paid by City standards at around $80,000 (£50,000) a year, will now be able to get their employers to look after simple tasks such as washing, ironing and returning videos. They can demand the faster payment of expenses and up to $20,000 if they recommend a rival analyst to their firm.

Salomon said the new regime will be available to thousands of its employees in New York, many of whom work 100-hour weeks and find it impossible to get to the dry cleaners before they close. It has not ruled out offering similar arrangements in the City.

Salomon said it is not just the lure of the dot.coms but the generally tight labour market in the United States, where sandwich bars are starting to offer retirement schemes to attract staff.

Even Goldman Sachs, regarded by many young graduates as the prized employer on Wall Street, has started to come up with new enticements since ending the lure of the lucrative "partnership" status after its stock market flotation last year.

It is now spending $200m on awarding share options to 8,000 or so employees who missed out on the spoils then.

Goldman's concern is not so much graduates fresh from university but those who took the time and expense to complete an MBA. These are the brains which it is harder to prevent striking out on their own to set up in e-commerce. Recognising that it needs to retain them, Goldman set up its three-year incentive deals for new recruits.

Goldman offers a good example of the demand for fresh banking talent. It is expanding rapidly, particularly in Europe where it wants to advise on more mergers and acquisitions, and has a target to hire 5,000 new staff (an increase of 25%) by the end of the year.

Some of the battle for staff has fed through to Goldman's rival, JP Morgan, which in London has become more child-friendly.

Men are now being offered 10 days' paternity leave, up from five, while all women can demand 18 weeks' full pay, regardless of how long they have worked for the bank.

JP Morgan has even taken emergency nursery places in two City locations to help employees with childcare worries.

At the start of this month, a flexi-time regime more associated with the civil service was introduced along with telecommuting - working from home for some part of the week.

It has also set up LabMorgan, an incubator fund for e-commerce firms which received more than 900 applications when it was launched last month.

fields.headline: Gangland scandal
fields.standfirst:
Villains' Opera
Olivier Theatre, London
*
fields.trailText:
Villains' Opera
Olivier Theatre, London
fields.body:
We're used to bad musicals in the commercial theatre. Now they're starting to invade the National Theatre as well. Indeed, one spends much of the time while watching this trundling behemoth of a show wondering why anyone ever thought the world needed an update of The Beggar's Opera when Brecht and Weill did the job perfectly well.

Gay's 1728 original was chiefly an attack on the corrupt administration of Sir Robert Walpole. It also made the broader satirical point that the lowest of low life was a mirror image of high society. Update it to today's East End gangland, as Nick Dear does here, and you lose the plot. For a start, unless you're a raving Tory, we have a government more famous for prudence and caution than for sordid sleaze. Even the idea that gangland villains are a microcosm of high society now looks the oldest of hat.

Dear's ideas strike one as borrowed rather than felt: when a would-be honest cop cries to her boss "But how are we going to clean up London if we're as vile as the villains?" I couldn't help but think of Gary Mitchell's The Force of Change, where collusion is explored with genuine moral subtlety. Even as a piece of storytelling the show is feeble: it starts out as a by-the-book update of Gay, and then meanders into a mix of drug-snitching estuary fantasy and cod-Shakespeare. Dear starts out with Macheath and ends up with Macbeth.

Even musically the show is a non-starter. Where Gay had traditional ballads and Brecht had Weill, here we have sawn-off tunes by the normally reliable Stephen Warbeck that flit by unnoticed. And hard though Tim Supple's production strains to create an atmosphere of louche naughtiness, it never gets beyond cartoon decadence.

Real satire requires moral outrage: here the underworld is simply an excuse for camp sniggers. The actors do all they can but Alexander Hanson's Macheath seems little more than a bumptious Walter Mitty. David Burt as a rasping Woolwich Peachum, Clive Rowe as a garden-tending Mr Big and Elizabeth Renihan as a luscious Lucy come off best. But the show, which treats the gangland ethic as a huge joke, seems a scandalous waste of the National's precious resources.

Until June 10. Box office: 0171-452 3000. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Spiralling Spireites to call on Clough

fields.headline: Spiralling Spireites to call on Clough
fields.trailText: Nigel Clough's ambition to manage in the Football League looks likely to be fulfilled by Chesterfield.
fields.body:
Nigel Clough's ambition to manage in the Football League looks likely to be fulfilled by Chesterfield.

The Second Division strugglers have drawn up a shortlist headed by Clough and Danny Wilson after ending John Duncan's seven-year tenure yesterday with the club staring relegation in the face.

Wilson lives in Chesterfield and is keen for a quick return to the game after being sacked by Sheffield Wednesday last month. But Clough, the former England forward and son of a famously successful manager, would be cheaper and is therefore the likelier option.

The Burton Albion player-manager has made it known he wants to test himself at a higher level after a successful first year with the Dr Marten's Premier League side, who are still challenging for promotion to the Nationwide Conference.

Duncan guided Chesterfield to an FA Cup semi-final against Middlesbrough three years ago but his team have won only five of 40 league games this season and fans have demanded his removal.

fields.headline: Redknapp homes in on £4m Kanoute
fields.trailText: West Ham are close to agreeing a £4m deal for Lyon's French Under-21 international Frédéric Kanouté, 22, who is currently on loan at Upton Park.
fields.body:
West Ham are close to agreeing a £4m deal for Lyon's French Under-21 international Frédéric Kanouté, 22, who is currently on loan at Upton Park.

The striker made a big impact on his debut with a goal in the 2-1 win over Wimbledon, but Hammers' manager Harry Redknapp will have to move fast as Kanouté's arrival in England has alerted a string of Premiership clubs.

Redknapp needs to finance the deal, with Leicester believed to be interested in Paulo Wanchope. Despite 10 goals in 35 games since his arrival from Derby, the Costa Rican striker has been a target for the Upton Park boo-boys.

Redknapp said: "The deal is not done yet but we are keen to do something because Kanouté has already shown that he is a very decent player and it would be no gamble to sign him permanently.

"The problem is, as always, I have to balance the books here and that usually means selling somebody. I can't talk about Paulo Wanchope; he's still our player and it wouldn't be fair if I did. We've just got to wait and see what happens."

Redknapp also confirmed that West Ham are interested in signing the striker Davor Suker, 32, who looks certain to be told by the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger that that the club's option on him for next season will not be taken up.

Arsenal's £2m winger Jermaine Pennant will spearhead England's campaign in the European under-16 championship finals in Israel this month.

fields.headline: Big spenders Lazio make £5m loss
fields.trailText: Lazio, billed last season as the most expensive team on earth, made a loss of 16.7bn lire (£5m) in the six months to the end of 1999, the Italian club announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Lazio, billed last season as the most expensive team on earth, made a loss of 16.7bn lire (£5m) in the six months to the end of 1999, the Italian club announced yesterday.

That more than doubled the loss for the corresponding period in 1998 (£2.1m) for the only Italian club listed on the the stock market.

In recent years the Rome club have been one of the biggest spenders in history, with last season's team featuring a world-record £73m worth of signings.

Sergio Cragnotti's club are currently hotly pursuing Juventus for the league title but they will miss out on millions if they fail to reach the Champions League final. They must overcome a 5-2 deficit against Valencia in Rome next week to reach the last four.

Tonight Lazio face Internazionale in the first leg of the Italian Cup final, when Ronaldo returns to action after being injured for nearly five months.

Inter's 23-year-old Brazilian striker has been out with a knee injury since November 21 and began training again at the end of last month.

"It was hard to stay off the field for so long, but I'm back playing with no more pain in my knee," he said.

"Supporters expect a lot from me but I can't be on my best form yet."

fields.headline: Wigan weighed down by Jones
fields.trailText: Second Division Oldham 2 - 1 Wigan
fields.body:
Lightning struck twice as Oldham, having ended Wigan's 24-match unbeaten run in the league three months ago, scored a late goal to end the visitors' unbeaten away record this season.

Victory last night would have put Wigan five points clear of Bristol Rovers in the second automatic promotion spot but just as in the corresponding fixture in January, they were condemned to defeat by a headed goal from a set-piece in the dying minutes.

Oldham's defender Paul Jones was the match winner as he leapt highest to meet Steve Whitehall's corner and head it past the unsighted Roy Carroll on 87 minutes.

Wigan's general manager John Benson was advised to stay away from the match on medical grounds but there was precious little to set hearts fluttering in the opening 40 minutes, which must have seen some of the worst football of the season so far.

In mitigation the teams were playing on a quagmire, but it was hard to believe this was a relatively local derby with vital points at stake for Wigan.

Only the occasional foray from Michael Clegg, the young wing-back on loan from Manchester United, threatened to interrupt the tedium. His crisp volley in the fourth minute was well saved by Gary Kelly, who was again well placed to deny Clegg on 20 minutes after a good run.

Oldham were similarly abject. The little good work they did in that awful opening period was undone by the forward Matthew Tipton, who headed over from Scott McNiven's cross and shot wide after a goalmouth scramble.

The match came to life shortly before the interval when Wigan were awarded a penalty for Kelly's reckless challenge on Simon Haworth. Kelly was booked for his protests before being sent the wrong way from the spot by Neil Redfearn, who clearly enjoyed the moment against his former club.

Wigan's lead lasted just two minutes, however, as some sloppy defending allowed Tipton to redeem himself by scrambling an equaliser at the second attempt. In stoppage time at the end of the first half Clegg was forced to hack the ball off the line.

webTitle: The home of cricket... and betting

fields.headline: The home of cricket... and betting
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver on how it all started in this country.
fields.body:
The game's association with gambling and corruption started in this country. In the first half of the 18th century cricket began to attract a more affluent, even aristocratic, following in Kent, Surrey, Sussex and Hampshire, and with the money came the gamblers. Matches were played for huge stakes, lawsuits and affrays were common.

In 1817 the leading all-round player William Lambert was banned from Lord's in a match-fixing scandal involving a fixture between England and Nottingham. The MCC expelled the bookmakers from the ground.

Betting on cricket, though illegal, took a hold in Asia in the mid-1980s and has generated so much interest that it has an estimated turnover of £6bn.

The early one-day matches held in Sharjah between India and Pakistan, watched by expatriates and monitored by illegal bookmakers, were at the root of the current troubles.

The rise of spreadbetting has exacerbated the problem, with players being targeted to furnish bookmakers with relevant information. Some Test players, including Danny Morrison of New Zealand and England's Adam Hollioake, have said they have received such approaches.

webTitle: Clean-up in cricket must now follow, says wounded Waugh

fields.headline: Clean-up in cricket must now follow, says wounded Waugh
fields.trailText: Steve Waugh last night said that he was "shocked and disappointed" that his sacked South African counterpart Hansie Cronje had admitted receiving $10,000-15,000 from bookmakers during the one-day series with Zimbabwe and England in January.
fields.body:
Steve Waugh last night said that he was "shocked and disappointed" that his sacked South African counterpart Hansie Cronje had admitted receiving $10,000-15,000 from bookmakers during the one-day series with Zimbabwe and England in January.

"We can't sweep it under the carpet," Australia's captain added. "It's got to be cleared up. Ninety-nine per cent of people who play cricket are hurting.

"Cricket doesn't need this sort of thing. Let's hope it is all cleared up and the game can get back on to the front and back pages for all the right reasons.

"I feel sorry for [Cronje's] family and the people who supported him during the week; they are probably the worst done by. He's got to live with what he's done.

"You want young people to play the game and to know that when people go out there to play that it's all above board, and they are trying all the time. It's not been happening."

The former India captain Ajit Wadekar commented: "In future, whenever there is a close finish in a match, people will always suspect that it has been fixed."

Chandu Borde, chairman of India's selection committee, said: "Knowing Cronje's activities on the field it is very difficult to digest this kind of thing. It affects the credibility of the game.

"Regarding his career, it is up to the South African board to decide. Look at Shane Warne despite all that he said he is still playing."

Warne and Mark Waugh, Steve's twin, were each fined A$2,500 by the Australian Cricket Board in 1995 after admitting receiving cash from an Indian bookmaker for providing weather and pitch briefings in Sri Lanka. Both denied giving tactical information.

The former captain and coach of Australia Bobby Simpson, now at Lancashire, said: "I'm amazed someone like Hansie, who is respected and so highly regarded, has been caught up in something like this, but it perhaps indicates the extent of the problem. I'd be surprised if someone in every Test-playing country had not been approached at some stage."

Allan Donald, South Africa's record wicket-taker, was shocked that the Test game's longest-serving captain had gone, but commented: "If you accept money you are leaving yourself open. I hope it all gets sorted out and justice is done. If he is guilty he deserves it.

"Cronje's a very intelligent guy and I would never have thought for one second that my captain would be involved in anything like this. It's very sad, a dark day for South African people and for South African sport."

As if to darken it further Jagmohan Dalmiya, an Indian businessman and the International Cricket Council's president, said: "Any attempt to interfere with the fair conduct of our sport is totally unacceptable to the ICC and to the hundreds of millions of people who love cricket.

"Those who seek to tarnish the image of cricket must be brought to justice. We will continue to co-operate with the police and, where it is in cricket's power to take action, the ICC will do so decisively through the Code of Conduct Commission."

November: The former Pakistan captain Imran Khan tells inquiry that some team-mates had cheated and taken bribes.

December 8: Australian Cricket Board admits it secretly fined Mark Waugh and Shane Warne in February 1995 for giving what it called routine pitch and weather details to bookmakers during Australia's 1994 tour of Sri Lanka.

webTitle: A fitting tribute to a doomed force

fields.headline: A fitting tribute to a doomed force
fields.standfirst: As the politicians bicker over the presentation today of the George Cross to the RUC, Derek Brown looks back on the role of Ulster's battered police force in Northern Ireland's troubled history
fields.trailText: As the politicians bicker over the presentation today of the George Cross to the RUC, Derek Brown looks back on the role of Ulster's battered police force in Northern Ireland's troubled history.
fields.body:
The Royal Ulster Constabulary has lost 302 officers in action since 1969.Some 13,000 have been wounded, many grievously.

Having endured so much, it will seem fitting to reasonable people that the force should receive the symbolic gratitude of the nation, in the form of the George Cross presented today by the Queen.

Yet Northern Ireland is not a reasonable place. Its collective reason has been eroded and distorted by more than 30 years of ghastly violence.

The bigotry which made that violence possible is still visible, poking like broken bone through wounded flesh.

Thus Sinn Fein, which is supposed to be part of the peace process, has called today's ceremony "grossly offensive", and has organised black flag protests against it, in Belfast and Derry. They could have marked the occasion with studied silence, but instead chose petulance and gratuitous insult.

No less insulting to the Northern Ireland people is the current campaign by unionists who want to keep the RUC as a tribal protection force.

They are appalled by the proposed transformation of the 92% Protestant force into a new Police Service of Northern Ireland, recruiting Protestants and Roman Catholics in equal numbers. The Patton Report, which also recommends the removal of unionist symbols like the RUC crown-and-harp badge, has become, for the wilder backwoodsmen, an act of betrayal.

Foolishly, the Ulster Unionist party has made the rejection of the Patton proposals a condition of future participation in the Good Friday peace process. That is an unsustainable position, as is Sinn Fein's preposterous insistence that the process must go ahead without any IRA disarmament.

It was just that kind of intolerance and pigheadedness which caused the modern Troubles to erupt all those years ago. Today, of all days, it is worth remembering that the very first police officer to die, Victor Arbuckle, was shot on October 11, 1969, not by the IRA but by so-called loyalists, incensed by the Lord Hunt's report on reform of the police.

It has taken 31 years and more than 3,250 lives - one in ten of them police - to bring Northern Ireland to the brink of a just and sustainable peace. There the politicians stand, bickering and dithering, while the long-suffering people they represent must be despairing.

But politicians are not the only ones with voices. Today's Belfast Telegraph has suitably solemn coverage of the medal award. It notes that the George Cross, a rare honour indeed, has only once before been awarded collectively - to the people of Malta during the war.

The BelTel, as it is universally and more or less affectionately known in the province, recognises the solemnity and emotion of the occasion. It pays tribute to the bravery and sacrifice the battered police force of Northern Ireland. At the same time, it firmly insists that reform is not an option, but an absolute necessity for the future peace.

The Irish News, the principal voice of the nationalist community, is naturally keener on the reforms than on the George Cross. But it too has the grace today to acknowledge the courage of the RUC.

Ronnie Flanagan, the media-savvy RUC chief constable, has also risen to the occasion, accepting the royal award with humility, and nimbly rejecting all suggestions that it is politically motivated, either as a sop to unionist opinion or as a sweetener for the force to accept radical change.

All in all, the George Cross ceremony was emotional yet dignified. But the dignity of the occasion would have been greatly enhanced if the second-rate tribal politicians of Northern Ireland had marked the occasion with some gesture of reconciliation, rather than using it to yelp their old, tired, mutual insults.

The Irish News, the principal voice of the nationalist community, is naturally keener on the reforms than on the George Cross. But it too has the grace today to acknowledge the courage of the RUC. Ronnie Flanagan, the media-savvy RUC chief constable, has also risen to the occasion, accepting the royal award with humility, and nimbly rejecting all suggestions that it is politically motivated, either as a sop to unionist opinion or as a sweetener for the force to accept radical change. All in all, the George Cross ceremony was emotional yet dignified. But the dignity of the occasion would have been greatly enhanced if the second-rate tribal politicians of Northern Ireland had marked the occasion with some gesture of reconciliation, rather than using it to yelp their old, tired, mutual insults. webTitle: The collected controversies of Ken Livingstone

fields.headline: The collected controversies of Ken Livingstone
fields.standfirst: "I'm an MP. I'm paid to argue about ideas; it's my hobby. If I wasn't an MP, I'd be doing it at night for nothing. I love it."
fields.trailText: On IRA "freedom fighters"
fields.body:
On IRA "freedom fighters"

"That is how the IRA saw themselves. They were prepared to die - 10 starved themselves to death. That's not what a criminal or godfather of crime does; it's someone who believes they're fighting for the freedom of their country and you've got to deal with them on that basis."
Livingstone on ITV, April 2000, defending his 1980s comment that the IRA were "freedom fighters"

On sex and drugs

"I don't take drugs, and I don't think anyone should take drugs, but I'm also saying I think the drugs tsar is a waste of money."
Clarifying comments after his NME interview, April 2000

"I do think we could consider decriminalising things like ecstasy and cannabis, but I would never do anything to encourage people to take drugs any more than I would encourage people to drink."
Ken Livingstone in the NME, April 2000

"We are all bisexual."
Livingstone in the 1980s

"When I was leader of the GLC, for three years running I was voted by a City Limits readers' poll as the man they would most like to spend a day with on Clapham Common!"
Livingstone, November 1998

"Being a man is pretty abhorrent. Back-slapping, beer-swilling, beer-gutted men sitting around boasting. Urgh. As a man, you can never remove the conditioning that's made you what you are. The idea that women are just there to be notched up like scores on a gun is so deep you have to struggle against it all the time. It's a question of overcoming your evil."
Livingstone in the 1990s

On capitalism and direct action

"Every year the international financial system kills more people than world war two. But at least Hitler was mad."
Livingstone in the NME, April 2000

"I have always been in favour of direct action  One of my fondest memories was chasing the inspector of the Archway Road inquiry out on to the roof at Central Hall. The barrister representing the government was one Michael Howard, who interposed with his body, saying: 'Don't throw him over!' As if I was going to."
Livingstone in Face magazine, January 2000

"I've been on the record in so many interviews and articles over the last 30 years - you won't find a single time when I've ever supported violence, whether it was Irish terrorism or whether it's a thug that whacks an old lady over the head."
Livingstone, attempting to clarify his comments, January 2000

On depression

"I've had very few depressions in my life, but they follow a pattern, and I look and feel awful for a few months. One such depression was in 1979, when I didn't get elected to the Commons. Another was in 1983 when the national executive committee barred me from standing in Brent East. The other was when we lost the election in 1992  [If Tony Blair doesn't let me stand for mayor I'll] get depression with associated psoriasis, a classic stress pattern."
Livingstone in the New Statesman, 1999

Frank Dobson is "clinically depressed".
What Livingstone is alleged to have said to reporters, November 1999

fields.headline: Skating policemen
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about rollerblading policemen on the net
fields.trailText: 1. The great British bobby is today moving into pastures new. Four members of the Royal Parks constabulary are to take up posts as part of an in-line skating patrol in Kensington Gardens.
fields.body:
1. The great British bobby is today moving into pastures new. Four members of the Royal Parks constabulary are to take up posts as part of an in-line skating patrol in Kensington Gardens.

2 In-line skating is better known as the trademarked Rollerblading® to you and me.

3. London police have not always been quick to find their blades.

4. And while those ambling through the park might feel safer with the rapid reaction unit at hand, they should beware the dangers of speeding policemen.

5. Royals may fear their parks will never be the same again.

6. Kensington Gardens could start to feel more like New York's Central Park - although their policemen only have boring old bikes. But there are skating Parks Enforcement Patrol officers - who look like this.

7. Fortunately, even in the world of in-line skating, we Brits have a strict code of etiquette. In our Royal Parks, there will be, for example, no skating backwards allowed.

8. To help their manoeuvres in the park, our boys in blue can find out the answers to some FAQs before joining the UK's in-line skating community.

9. It can only be a matter of time before the (police)man's best friend is roped in too - but they should read these cautionary tales first.

10. In-line skaters can hopefully now look forward to more sympathy on legal issues. Skateboarders, though, are left in the cold waiting for a patrol of 'old school' officers. Say, why can't skaters and boarders get along?

webTitle: Still a long way to go for Jimmy

fields.headline: Still a long way to go for Jimmy
fields.standfirst: Orin Gordon examines the progress of the new West Indian captain, Jimmy Adams
fields.trailText: The news of Hansie Cronje's sacking has completely obscured everything else in cricket. This includes the quiet revival of the West Indies under Jimmy Adams, who has led his side to a sweep of the two-Test series against Zimbabwe, and both the matches between the two sides in the current triangular series also involving Pakistan. A few weeks ago this column identified five tasks for the new skipper, such as raising his own game, getting the best out of young players like his Jamaican teammates Wavell Hinds and Chris Gayle, and firing up Franklyn Rose, the wayward fast bowler. All these things have happened. I'd love to say he read the advice, but Adams alone deserves the credit for turning around the fortunes of a completely demoralised team.
fields.body:
The news of Hansie Cronje's sacking has completely obscured everything else in cricket. This includes the quiet revival of the West Indies under Jimmy Adams, who has led his side to a sweep of the two-Test series against Zimbabwe, and both the matches between the two sides in the current triangular series also involving Pakistan. A few weeks ago this column identified five tasks for the new skipper, such as raising his own game, getting the best out of young players like his Jamaican teammates Wavell Hinds and Chris Gayle, and firing up Franklyn Rose, the wayward fast bowler. All these things have happened. I'd love to say he read the advice, but Adams alone deserves the credit for turning around the fortunes of a completely demoralised team.

True, it's only Zimbabwe and they have been dismal - even by their standards. But later today West Indies meet Pakistan for the first time in the tournament. Moin Khan's men will provide a sterner test, and a truer gauge of the progress of Adams and his team. Pakistan are stronger with Wasim back, Waqar in form again, Abdur Razzaq one of the most effective allrounders in one-day cricket in recent times, Moin himself, Inzamam and the exciting young biffer Shahid Afridi. That's a lot of firepower to defend against, but as they showed in the World Cup final, you're never quite sure which Pakistan will turn up. That'll be Adams's crumb of comfort, but he'll know that the Windies are not exactly models of consistency themselves.

Zim's tour has virtually ended, as they're unlikely to feature in the three-match final. Pakistan would have to lose badly to the Windies twice and to Zimbabwe in their remaining match to be denied. The hosts are already there with their two wins. The omission of Zimbabwe lynchpins Neil Johnson and Alistair Campbell from the second one-day match against the West Indies was confirmation of the fact that some of their most important players failed badly. Much was expected of Johnson who has Test and one-day hundreds in a short career, but he has had a poor tour. This was a team that made it to the Super Six stage of the World Cup; now they are favourites to lose all their matches in the Caribbean. Their fielding has sometimes been breathtaking, and the bowlers Streak and Olonga have had their moments, but the batting has not been up to standard. Good thing their authoritarian President Robert Mugabe has only shown a passing interest in cricket

So with Zimbabwe virtually out, it'll be two new captains opposing each other. But will it be Adams or Moin lifting the Cable and Wireless Trophy? Don't bet against Moin, but make a hedge on Adams. Wasim tipped the keeper for the job some time ago. He was offered it but turned it down, and now he'll want to make his mark. At 28 he's already a veteran of 166 one-day internationals, and played in Imran's World Cup winning side of 1992. Parts of the Caribbean like Guyana and Trinidad with large Pakistani Muslim communities will also be like home territory for him and his side. Pakistan are a popular touring team even outside Georgetown and Port-of-Spain because they're reckoned to play the game the Caribbean way.

Adams on the other hand is riding high after a dream start to his captaincy, and the players have responded to him. With Chanderpaul out due to fatigue and Lara still "resting" his team looks even more green, but he's got momentum on his side. But even if he does see off Moin, the true test of his side's improvement will come in the summer against England. Their captain Nasser Hussain has said that both the touring sides - West Indies and Zimbabwe - are beatable and he's right. England showed a lot more fight against Cronje's South Africans last winter than the Windies did on the corresponding tour the year before. So for Jimmy, the jury's still very much out.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist.

webTitle: Rise in violence aimed at Chinese community

fields.headline: Rise in violence aimed at Chinese community
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Leaders of the country's largest Chinese community yesterday complained of a rising tide of racial attacks and harassment that go unpunished by the police.
fields.body:
Leaders of the country's largest Chinese community yesterday complained of a rising tide of racial attacks and harassment that go unpunished by the police.

A delegation organised by National Civil Rights Movement, met representatives of the Metropolitan police's race and violent crime task force at Scotland Yard to express fears from London's 60,000-strong Chinese that racially motivated crimes against the community were on the increase.

They also said confidence in the police had been eroded.

The NCRM handed over details of 15 cases of alleged racial violence and abuse against Chinese restauraters and other individuals in London.

In one case, the mother of the owner of a Chinese take-away was attacked.

In another, police are accused of failing to take any action after a man who was left permanently disabled following an attack on his shop. In other incidents, customers refused to pay their bills, and subjected restaurant staff to racist abuse and physical violence.

The NCRM is also involved in a further eight incidents outside London.

The delegation told the meeting that members of the Chinese community were victims of racial stereotyping by the police, and that in many cases the victims of racist crime had found themselves being arrested instead of the offenders.

The NCRM told of cases where Chinese waiters who fought off racially motivated attacks had found themselves arrested and charged.

It alleged that the Met's Chinese unit, which operates from Charing Cross police station, central London, often assumed that any crime involving a person of Chinese descent was related to Triad gangs.

"This is such a crude stereotyping of a racial group. We have asked the police to delink the so-called Triad wars from racial attacks, and they said they would do that," said Suresh Grover, chairman of the NCRM.

Jeff Brathwaite, deputy director of the violent crime task force told the delegation that the Met would respond to the allegations within a week and that an audit of attacks against people of Chinese descent across London would be completed within a fortnight.

Mr Grover said the promise to review cases from across the capital was effectively an admission that the Met had no idea of the scale of racist crime against the Chinese community.

"The Macpherson report is relevant to all communities and police procedure should be to protect the victims of crime and punish the perpetrators - but it has not been the case in the Chinese community," he said.

Jabez Lam, a project worker at the NCRM and a community leader in Chinatown, who attended the meeting, said: "This is the beginning of a long journey.

"The response from the police was positive. The proof of their resolve will come when we see how they react in the future."

A Met spokesman said the force was grateful for the opportunity to address the concerns of the capital's Chinese community.

Clash with racist gang

Fu Yon Lam and his fellow waiters at the New Diamond restaurant in central London are used to dealing with drunks who refuse to pay, verbal abuse, and occasional acts of vandalism.

Shortly before last Christmas, however, a violent clash with a white racist gang left Mr Lam, 46, in hospital, and four other waiters in police custody.

Mr Lam says the attackers, eight men who smashed crockery and screamed racist abuse, were ignored by the police and were not charged.

"I was smashed on the head. Then someone came at me while I was dizzy and I put my hand out to protect myself - the tendon in my hand was severed."

The waiters were held for 21 hours before being released. The gang visited the police by appointment to give statements.

fields.headline: Tickets, Tactics and Tangled links
fields.trailText: UEFA WAIT ON GALATASARAY RESPONSE
fields.body:
UEFA WAIT ON GALATASARAY RESPONSE

Uefa have postponed a decision on Leeds' Uefa Cup semi-final tie with Galatasaray until Friday in order to allow the Turkish club time to respond to security reports from Britain. Leeds are still pressing for the game to be played at Elland Road, and earlier today chairman Peter Ridsdale warned they might pull out of the competition if Uefa move the match to a neutral ground.

Ridsdale also said that several of his players received death threats in their hotel rooms after Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight were murdered. "The team were in no fit mental state to play the first tie," said Ridsdale. "They were understandably shaken up by, among other things, receiving death threat phone-calls to their rooms in the early hours of the morning even though we had asked for no calls to be put through."

Meanwhile Turkish MP Rasim Zaimoglu said he wants go to Leeds for the game and urged the entire Turkish parliament to do the same. Zaimoglu was quoted as saying that he hoped 10,000 Turks would be at Elland Road, even though Galatasaray have only been allocated 1,700 tickets.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SOMETHING TO WIN

Enter First Direct's Little Fella Challenge and you could win a VW Beetle or Sony Wega Widescreen TV.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DRIP DROP

Poor Didier Deschamps. After spending a sizeable chunk of the year looking about as sure-footed on English soil as Stephane Guivarc'h, Didier has finally found some form in the Premiership just as Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli is getting ready to let him go. Meanwhile Chris Sutto'n remains in situ. Is there no justice?!?

According to This Is London, V-necked Vialli wants to improve the shape of his team by drafting in two wingers - Stephane Dalmat of Marseille and Internazionale's £8m-rated Javier Zanetti. Something in Chelsea's midfield has to give - even John Barnes wouldn't be able to invent a new formation to keep everyone happy - so Deschamps is expected to be hoofed out of the Stamford Bridge door, his water carrier bouncing down the Kings Road after him.

For once, the rationale behind the rumours makes some sense - Deschamps is likely be used as a make-weight to tempt Marseille into selling the left-sided Dalmat for a bargain £7m (he's 21). The Fiver isn't convinced - Deschamps has denied the talk, insisting he has "spoken to no-one about anything like that, and I am also under contract to Chelsea". But will that have stopped an excited Sutto'n dreaming of shinning cross after cross over the bar next season? We doubt it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We have trained on lousy grounds, too muddy or too hard, and it's very bad on the muscles. It's almost dangerous" - Louis Satorra, speaking on behalf of the players of French first division side Sedan, explains why he's going on strike.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

JEEZUS IT'S JESUS

"I'm Jesus Gil, not Jesus Christ," said Jesus Gil today as he returned to work as president of Atletico Madrid. Long-time devotees of Jesus Gil will already know he is not Jesus Christ, but for the less-enlightened here's one tell-tale way of spotting the difference: while Jesus Christ sits on the right-hand side of his father in heaven, Jesus Gil sits in his office, surrounded by two supervisors legally appointed to watch his every move.

Gil has been allowed to return to work while the judge investigating financial irregularities at Atletico decides whether to take action against him. Gil has been questioned over the alleged misuse of as much as 9,427m pesetas (roughly 34m squid). He was also imprisoned last year while investigators tried to untangle links between Atletico and Marbella - one-time club sponsors whose mayor is a certain J Gil. Oh, and last week the club were found to be effectively bankrupt with debts of over £50m.

So what the club really needs is a steady hand in the till, sorry, on the tiller. And surely nobody can have a steadier hand than Jesus. The returning chairman's first trick will be to keep Atletico in the Primera Liga standing as they are in 19th position, four points away from 17th, and with only six games to play. It will be a sizeable achievement if Jesus pulls it off. And if coach Raddy Antic is still in a job come July, why, that'll be a miracle.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Sir Alex Ferguson has his eye on Aston Villa keeper David James. In what would be an extraordinary deal, James could move to United in exchange for former Villa keeper and current United number one Mark Bosnich.

Guus Hiddink is favourite to become head coach at Celtic, according to reports. Hiddink, who has managed the Dutch national side and Real Madrid, is currently in charge at Real Betis, but is believed to be out of contract at the end of the season.

Barcelona wing back Sergi, reportedly a target for Liverpool, Manchester United and Chelsea, could be on his way to Deportivo La Coruna. The Spanish international prefers to stay in the Primera Liga rather than move to the Premiership.

West Ham boss Harry Redknapp wants to buy unsettled Benfica striker Hugo Porfirio, who played on loan for the Hammers three seasons ago. Meanwhile, Redknapp has distanced himself from speculation linking him with Davor Suker. "The player is still under contract at Arsenal, end of story," said Redknapp.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Nigeria's coach Jo Bonfrere is to hold talks with European clubs over the release of players for international matches following the controversy over the selection of Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro. "Bonfrere did not return with the team after the match against Eritrea because he left for Europe to discuss with officials of the clubs of our players," a spokesman for the Nigerian FA said today.

Alex Ferguson has put his weight behind plans to limit the number of foreigners playing in the Premiership. The PFA want to see no more than five foreigners in any Premiership XI and Ferguson has joined them in presenting their case to the European Parliament today.

Portsmouth's Steve Claridge has been fined £900 by the FA's disciplinary committee for betting on Pompey to beat Barnsley in a Nationwide League game they eventually won 3-0. fields.bodyText: UEFA WAIT ON GALATASARAY RESPONSE Uefa have postponed a decision on Leeds' Uefa Cup semi-final tie with Galatasaray until Friday in order to allow the Turkish club time to respond to security reports from Britain. Leeds are still pressing for the game to be played at Elland Road, and earlier today chairman Peter Ridsdale warned they might pull out of the competition if Uefa move the match to a neutral ground. Ridsdale also said that several of his players received death threats in their hotel rooms after Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight were murdered. "The team were in no fit mental state to play the first tie," said Ridsdale. "They were understandably shaken up by, among other things, receiving death threat phone-calls to their rooms in the early hours of the morning even though we had asked for no calls to be put through." After spending a sizeable chunk of the year looking about as sure-footed on English soil as Stephane Guivarc'h, Didier has finally found some form in the Premiership just as Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli is getting ready to let him go. According to This Is London, V-necked Vialli wants to improve the shape of his team by drafting in two wingers - Stephane Dalmat of Marseille and Internazionale's £8m-rated Javier Zanetti. webTitle: Blair insists no one will lose out on benefits switch

fields.headline: Blair insists no one will lose out on benefits switch
fields.standfirst: The prime minister defends move to bank accounts as protests mount over post office closures
fields.trailText: The prime minister told benefit claimants and pensioners today that no one would be prevented from receiving their payments in cash at post offices, despite the switch to electronic transfers.
fields.body:
The prime minister told benefit claimants and pensioners today that no one would be prevented from receiving their payments in cash at post offices, despite the switch to electronic transfers.

At Commons question time, after the presentation in Downing Street of a large protest petition over post office closures and plans to switch benefit payments to bank accounts, Mr Blair said his pledge applied to weekly as well as monthly benefit payments. He insisted the Post Office must "face up to the challenges of modernisation" and referred to plans to install 3,000 cashpoints at rural offices.

The Tory leader William Hague, however, dismissed his comments as "meaningless reassurances" and called on ministers to think again by opting instead for an earlier Conservative scheme of benefit swipe cards. "We had a policy to save post offices, you have a policy to close post offices," said Mr Hague, during rowdy exchanges.

Mr Blair retorted that the Conservatives had been responsible for closing 300 post offices and still planned to privatise the service. Modernisation would bring welfare savings of £600m a year, he said, and the government fully intended to sit down with sub-postmasters and discuss the future of the service.

 Commenting on speculation that Govan shipyard would lose out on a £300m order for Royal Navy ferries, Mr Blair said: "I would stress that no decision has been taken at all. I would stress also that the UK warship orders are coming up, where Scotland can expect to benefit."

 Mr Hague paid tribute to the Royal Ulster Constabulary and congratulated them on the award of the George Cross today. He said many people would find it to hard to understand why the constabulary's name was going to change, particularly given the IRA's failure to decommission. Mr Blair stressed that it was vital to attract officers from all sections of the Northern Irish community. The change of name was one of a number of steps recommended by the Patten report. Implementing that report was, he said, the "right way forward".

fields.headline: And then there were two
fields.standfirst: Lawrence Booth on the fate of the Test teams' World Cup captains
fields.trailText: If your name is Steve or Stephen and you come from the Antipodes, chances are you won't lose your job as Test captain. If it isn't and you don't, well, bad luck. Because after yesterday's sacking of Hansie Cronje only two of the nine captains of the Test-playing nations from the 1999 World Cup - Steve Waugh of Australia and Stephen Fleming of New Zealand - are still in charge.
fields.body:
If your name is Steve or Stephen and you come from the Antipodes, chances are you won't lose your job as Test captain. If it isn't and you don't, well, bad luck. Because after yesterday's sacking of Hansie Cronje only two of the nine captains of the Test-playing nations from the 1999 World Cup - Steve Waugh of Australia and Stephen Fleming of New Zealand - are still in charge.

The first captain to lose his job was Alec Stewart, who paid the price for England's failure to qualify for the World Cup Super Sixes, and was replaced for the Test series against New Zealand by Nasser Hussain. Stewart was quickly followed by Arjuna Ranatunga, skipper of the other notable World Cup flops, holders Sri Lanka. Ranatunga was axed in favour of Sanath Jayasuriya, who took control last August.

Zimbabwe's Alistair Campbell was next to go. He fell on his stump in early November, three days before Zimbabwe's return Test against South Africa in Harare; they had lost the first game, in Bloemfontein, by an innings. Andy Flower stepped in.

In the New Year, three high-profile names departed in quick succession. Brian Lara handed in his notice following West Indies' 2-0 defeat in New Zealand, and later announced he would be taking a break from cricket (presumably to recharge his batteries for a run-fest in England this summer); Jimmy Adams took over for the successful series against Zimbabwe.

Then, in February, Wasim Akram, under pressure from wisden.com columnist Kamran Abbasi, stood down after Pakistan's dismal tour of Australia, and gave way to Saeed Anwar, who promptly injured himself and then told the selectors he didn't want the job back anyway; Moin Khan was ushered in. Just over a week later India's golden boy Sachin Tendulkar, similarly badgered by Abbasi, followed suit, but bizarrely delayed his moment of departure until after the impending series against South Africa. Not surprisingly, India lost. After much dithering, the chalice was passed to Sourav Ganguly.

Which brings us to Hansie Cronje, dumped yesterday by the South African Cricket Board after he admitted accepting money for "information and forecasting". Shaun Pollock became the seventh - or eighth if you include Moin - new Test captain since last August.

Steve Waugh and Stephen Fleming are believed to be safe in their jobs.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com
