fields.headline: Wanted!
fields.standfirst: Parents think this is public enemy number one. But the kids know best, says  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: Parents think this is public enemy number one. But the kids know best, says Emma Brockes
fields.body:
For the uninitiated parent, there is a web page put out by the Japanese games giant behind Pokémon, which tries to explain to them what their children are getting so excited about. "The world of Pokémon is a world much like our own but filled with fantastic creatures called Pokémon," it reads, with the awkwardness manufacturers reserve for explaining kids' things to dumb adults. "Certain special people in this world decide to become Pokémon trainers. Trainers capture wild Pokémon and train them to do battle with other Pokémon."

These "special people" are the children spending £2.50 on packs of five illustrated cards to trade and play elaborate battle games with.

The web page is making a a deliberately modest claim for what parents will instantly identify as a craze. Pokémon is not just a card game, but a set of computer games, soft toys and plastic figures and a soon-to-be-released feature film, which special people will be pawing at the ground to be taken to this Easter. What differentiates Pokémon from previous crazes, is not only the breadth of its product range, but the way in which children remain gripped by it for up to four years - a lifetime in terms of kids' fashion. Yet the reason for its success is relatively simple. Pokémon, like trump cards, is built around the basic premise that children love sorting things.

"It is a passport to group activity, at an age where children are starting to get into bigger groups," says Dr John Richer, consultant clinical psychologist in paediatrics at the John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford. "There is an element of combat that appeals particularly to boys in middle childhood. But there is also the trading, which is fascinating because it is all about negotiation; about trying to second guess what the other guy wants."

Children around the age of seven begin to distinguish between their own point of view and somebody else's; when Fred can not only guess what Julie is thinking, but what Julie thinks he is thinking. "This is a vital skill for negotiation and is made a nice little practice of in Pokémon," says Dr Richer.

To this extent, Pokémon is no different from the trading cards most people remember from their school days: the Aristocats, the World Cup, the Garbage Pail Kids. Instead of cartoon cats or Brazilian footballers, the Pokémon are a set of 150 critters with Dungeons-and-Dragons-type names such as Kangaskhan and Magikarp. But the real difference is that they are designed for children to progress through stages of gamesmanship and ever-advancing technology.

Leo Shirley, 8, has 50 Pokémon cards, including his most prized asset, Ninetales, a sort of flying ferret printed on shiny paper. Shirley is not interested in Pokémon trump tactics. He does not use the battle counters, small plastic discs with numbers on them, which accompany the packs and are placed on an opponent's cards to "destroy" them. Neither does he have any Pokémon GameBoy games. What Shirley is interested in, is the act of sorting.

"I've got some rare ones and my friend has" - he pauses for effect - "Aerodactyl." Pokémon was banned from Shirley's school, when a boy had his arm broken in a fight over them. "I don't use battle counters," he says. "I only have them to swap. I like to look at them."

James Swan, 10, has 300 cards and a Game Boy. He is where Shirley would like to be in two years time, a big boy playing big matches in the Pokémon league. "We play twice a week, for about an hour each time," he says. Pokémon has been banned from his school, also. "I win a lot."

"It is a very ready means of sorting out status and power in the playground," says Dr Duncan McLean, a consultant psychologist at the Anna Freud Centre. "Collecting cards gives children who might not excel by other means - football, say - a chance to advance in the hierarchy."

T he cards may have an educational value, too. Children hooked on Pokémon retain large volumes of information, much of it numerical. "You keep score in your head," says James Swan. "Sometimes you forget and have to do it on paper."

Pokémon is unlikely to make it to literacy hour, though. Part of its appeal is the private, made-up language to which its players are privy and from which dictionary-bound adults are excluded. This helps create community in the playground.

"The children playing Pokémon are doing a lot of things that contribute to adult life," says Dr Richer. "They are trying to get to a position, through trading, that is advantageous to them. They are understanding rules and establishing a reputation. They are learning the political arts of dealing with a group."

They still have a lot to learn, however. "I know someone who needs one more and he'll have all of them," boasts Leo Shirley. What happens then? "Then, that's the end." His innocence is touching. In the world of Pokémon merchandise, of course, there is no such thing as Game Over.

webTitle: Can he play football?  Jane Muir

fields.headline: Can he play football?  Jane Muir
fields.standfirst: Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. In this fortnightly column, his mother describes life with a   disabled child.
fields.trailText: Alex is eight and has cerebral palsy. In this fortnightly column, his mother describes life with a disabled child.
fields.body:
Alex loves his mainstream school, but he hates playtime. It's boring, he says. For him, it means being pushed around the playground in his wheelchair - in the cold. Watching his friends play football, unable to join in.

The other kids do take it in turns to push him, and they do chat to him and share crisps, but still, it's boring. So a powerchair would be fantastic. Suddenly, he could be independent, make his own choices, zoom off wherever he liked - invade the football pitch, choose his own company, be late in for the bell.

He tried one out at the wheelchair service, and as he took off down the corridor, he laughed aloud and called back: "Mum, buy one!" Luckily, the wheelchair service do provide powerchairs for severely disabled kids, as they cost about £4,000. All I had to do was persuade them we were eligible and fitted their 11 criteria for suitability. The main sticking point was number nine: did we have an "accessible" house? No way, unfortunately - those don't get provided. But after months of the usual fight ing and standing my ground, they suddenly agreed. It would be ready by April and Alex's ninth birthday. "Hooray!" shouted Alex.

All I had to do now was get hold of a ramp so I could get the chair up the high steps and through our front door. Easy? I had thought so. But there I made my big mistake. Occupational therapists passed messages to other occupational therapists. Social services filled in various forms and sent them off to this department and that. No one person took responsibility or followed anything up. No one contacted me for weeks. I assumed that the ramp was on its way. How lax of me. Have I not learned over the years that nothing gets done unless I make 50 phone calls, yell, cry, argue, threaten or do it myself?

At last, suspicious of the silence, I got hold of someone who knew. "Oh yes," she said. "The company don't have any in stock. We'll have to see about ordering one from elsewhere. Perhaps by June..." Watching his friends play football, unable to join in. The other kids do take it in turns to push him, and they do chat to him and share crisps, but still, it's boring. fields.headline: The Panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Britain's maternity  services are in crisis, and the health  secretary, Alan Milburn, was this  week urged to restructure them. We  ask: what single thing would most  improve maternity care?
fields.trailText: The Question: Britain's maternity services are in crisis, and the health secretary, Alan Milburn, was this week urged to restructure them. We ask: what single thing would most improve maternity care?
fields.body:
Lynn Churchill
Mother of four-month-old Abbi
 I got a lot of conflicting advice, and it was frustrating and upsetting at times. I had pre-eclampsia so was in hospital for a couple of weeks before the birth, and I'd get a doctor coming along saying we'll induce you in two days and then half an hour later another one would come and say, we'll leave you for a week. Then during labour a midwife examined me and said she wouldn't break my waters because it wasn't a good idea, then 10 minutes later a registrar arrived and broke my waters. You're so vulnerable, and it would help a lot if you got clear information from a source you knew you could trust.
Verdict: Clear information

Mandy Jones
Mother of four-month-old Michael
 I left hospital when Michael was 24 hours old. I was keen to go home, but I think when it's your first you underestimate how much support you need. I was bruised and needed help breastfeeding, but it just wasn't there. The midwives visited for the first couple of days, but then only three times in the next 10 days. It was only when I complained that they told me about the hospital's emergency helpline - what's the point of having one if they don't tell you about it? These days, more and more new mums don't have family around to call on, so we really do need professionals.
Verdict: Daily midwife visits

Frances Barnsley
Midwife at Chipping Norton maternity unit, Oxfordshire
 Staff shortages in a lot of the larger units mean they can't guarantee one-to-one care. Not all women want someone with them all the time - but they all want to know there's someone there if they call. The irony is that one-to-one care in labour results in less need for pain relief and a lower chance of an assisted delivery or Caesarean - so it's worth the NHS investing in more midwives, because it will save money on obstetricians doing complicated deliveries. This is a small unit so we are able to offer one-to-one care - but we're so short-staffed it's very difficult to take holidays.
Verdict: One-to-one care

Helen King
Mother of seven-month-old Thomas
 Continuity of care was very important to me - seeing the same midwives all the way through is invaluable. But I had six weeks in hospital before I had Thomas, and I was aware of how stretched the midwives were - you worried about asking them something because you knew how busy they were. Some nights I'd be tired and want to sleep, but I'd have to wait until midnight to have my blood pressure taken. Most of the midwives were having to work well beyond their hours of duty - if they'd been clock-watchers the service would have been seriously compromised.
Verdict: More midwives

Ita Moore
Midwife and mother of seven-week-old Rebecca
 I run my own clinic, so I get to know women really well by the time they're having their babies, and then the chances are I get to be with them for the delivery, too. It makes a huge difference to have that kind of continuity of care, but it isn't available to everyone. The pressure of staff shortages means continuity of care is the first thing to go - and seeing different midwives through your pregnancy isn't best. I really appreciated being seen myself by people I knew as friends, and I'm convinced it's one of the most important aspects of maternity care.
Verdict: Continuity of care

fields.headline: How old?
fields.standfirst: What do you do when your father hooks up with a new girlfriend who's much younger than you? Controlling the urge to throw up is a good start, says  Kate Hilpern
fields.trailText: What do you do when your father hooks up with a new girlfriend who's much younger than you? Controlling the urge to throw up is a good start, says Kate Hilpern
fields.body:
I must have been about 20. I had been upset and was being comforted by my dinner companion. Suddenly, I heard a loud, prudish female voice: "That's obscene! He's old enough to be her father." Almost a decade later, I still giggle when I remember his composed response. "Perhaps you are the one with the obscene mind, madam. I am her father."

Since then life has taken an ironic twist. Dad has taken a partner of the age that I was then and the incident no longer makes me laugh. In fact, if I'm honest, I too find myself thinking, "God, how nauseating" whenever he speaks of the woman he says he loves, 27 years his - and 10 years my own - junior. I want him to be happy, so I find myself wondering how I - of all people - became so bloody virtuous.

"The adult child feeling deeply disturbed by the parent having a younger partner than them is extremely common, and can cause huge rifts in the parent-child relationship," says Julia Cole, a relationship therapist who sees an increasing number of such clients.

Not that there are more fathers at it now than in the past, she says. "Indeed, during the Victorian era, it was quite ordinary for fathers to marry a very young women if their wife died. The recent growth in clients is caused by the fact that parents and their children now tend to be far more open with each other. The fact that mothers, too, have younger lovers now is also significant."

Jill Taylor, a 26-year-old whose mother has, for three years, been dating a man who was in Taylor's school class, claims the hardest part was coming to terms with "Mum suddenly displaying characteristics that were as far removed from parenthood as could possibly be. She'd been my role model, my rock and my moral touchstone throughout my childhood, and here she was being frivolous, unpredictable and, most importantly, immature. I felt as though our roles had been reversed. I'd grown out of the kind of relationships she was indulging in and was ready to settle down. I found it unsettling, even frightening. I almost hated her."

Whatever their age, children want parents to behave like parents, according to Dr Julia Berryman, senior lecturer in psychology at Leicester University. "You often hear mothers proudly claiming they are like a sister to their child, but in my experience that child - even when adult - doesn't like it. For the same reason that we don't want our par ents dancing at the school disco when we're teenagers, we don't want them to be involved with men of our age when we're older."

Then there's the inevitable embarrassment. My dad spent the millennium holiday snowboarding with the new girlfriend. I mean, pleeeease .

Kathleen Cox, a clinical psychologist and specialist in parenting issues, explains: "If a relationship is formed with a massive age gap, there is bound to be some kind of transformation in the endeavour to find common ground - from a change of clothes to a new taste in music. But for the child, this can feel like an invasion, a sense of 'this is what my age group is supposed to be doing'."

Frequently, an attempt to recapture lost youth is exactly what these "American Beauty syndrome" relationships are about. But the odds are stacked against success. It may be endearing at first that your partner has never heard of the Stone Roses, or, conversely, was not even born when you were at Woodstock, but this can soon turn to exasperation.

"I think knowing that they'll never last is the reason that I get so upset about my father's young things," says Lorna Mitchell, a 40-year-old whose father's latest is 29. For others, the "trophy" girlfriends are acceptable. It's the "serious" ones that are dangerous. Sonya Adwell, a 27-year-old whose father has always had young lovers, says: "I didn't grow up with Dad. He and Mum got divorced when I was a baby. He then married another woman who I don't like and has had a string of young girlfriends. In a funny sort of way, it makes me feel important, because it proves what he has always said to me - that I'm the only woman in his life who really matters."

Adwell's take on the subject may be different because of the very fact that she didn't grow up with her father. Cole says: "It's normal for those of us who were brought up by our parents to feel quite sick at the thought of them having sex. If one of them shacks up with someone youthful, it somehow accentuates that, yes, they do have sex."

For some, the situation can even feel incestuous. "My clients don't tend to use that word," says Cole. "But they'll say things such as, 'It could have been one of my best friends. It could have been me.' It is very disturbing. The adult part of you wants to be happy for your parent but the child part of you thinks 'Ugh'."

Timing is also important. Imagine you are 23 and your 50-year-old father runs off with a 17-year-old girl just after he has divorced. It's what happened to Richard Hogan, now 32. "Seventeen is so young," he says. "It seemed ridiculous for my dad to have someone living with him who had Wham! posters on the wall, such a short time after he'd been with my mum. I couldn't imagine what she saw in him. I could only assume she was a gold-digger. Even now I have my suspicions."

One of Hogan's biggest problems has been how to relate to his new "mother". "It wasn't appropriate to communicate with her as a stepparent but nor did it seem right to talk to her like a friend or a little sister. I felt great pressure about that. Would it show that I couldn't bear what she stood for?"

And that is the heart of the matter. For most grown-up children whose parents have had a cross-generational relationship, what really matters is what the new partner symbolises, rather than whether he or she is a nice person or good for your parent. At worst, this is selfish and judgmental. At best, it is simply human nature.

Some of the names have been changed.

fields.headline: Dispatches from the dinner table
fields.standfirst: As models and editors descend on Downing Street for a 'summit' on eating disorders,  Raekha Prasad discovers that the solutions may be closer to home
fields.trailText: As models and editors descend on Downing Street for a 'summit' on eating disorders, Raekha Prasad discovers that the solutions may be closer to home
fields.body:
One meal rarely changes your life - unless it's the one where you realise that your child is starving herself. When Martha Furniss sat down to a dinner of salad and brown bread with her 19-year-old daughter Amy, she asked her why she would only eat salad. Amy replied "I can't eat", over and over again.

"I realised only then," Furniss says. "Her trousers looked very baggy. And then she stopped washing and the light went out of her eyes." That meal was eight years ago. Since then, Amy, now 26, has spent time in psychiatric units and private clinics, seen a clinical psychologist and almost lost her life - twice. She is 6ft tall, but at one time she weighed only 6st. She lives at home and still has anorexia.

Her father Edward says he feels her upbringing was happy, but can't help dwelling on the month Amy refused to eat when she was 11. "Looking back," he says, "it was a herald of what was to come." He is angry, too. "Body image, body image," he says. "We can't get away from it."

Such sentiments have this week been echoed by Tessa Jowell, the minister for women, who has invited representatives of a modelling agency, an editor of a teenage girls' magazine and the writer Susie Orbach to a Downing Street summit in June with the aim of tackling the pressure young women feel to conform to images of the thin ideal. The initiative, while bringing the government accusations of running a nanny state, does make very public an illness that for parents of sufferers has for so long been a very private problem.

Support for parents of people with eating disorder is just beginning to be recognised as crucial to their child's recovery - unless, that is, family abuse is one of the causes of the illness. Alcoholism, gambling and drugs are widely recognised as having a direct effect on parents or carers, and a network of support is available. But there is no formal equivalent of Alcoholics or Gamblers Anonymous for parents of anorexia and bulimia suffers, just a few self-help groups scattered around the country. The Centre For Eating Disorders in London, in response to the increasing number of calls it has received from grandparents and parents of young sufferers, has set up an advice programme geared to children and is in the process of setting up a support group for parents.

Including parents in the process of counselling is not in order to blame them, but to make them aware that building self-esteem is central to their child's recovery, says Gilly Green, a psychotherapist at the centre. "The wider social context, where thinness is best, is extremely influential," she says. "But what goes on at home is also very important, particularly the feedback that parents give their children about how they look."

As celebrity weight-watching becomes a spectator sport, the pressure to conform to a physical ideal can crush even the most confident adult. For children, the pressure is compounded by peers and their developing, fragile sense of self that is often dependent on family example.

Green argues that children take mental photographs of their parents. "Little girls watch what mummy does with her hair, her clothes and her attitude to food," she says. "Watching parents skip meals, eating only certain foods and eating alone establishes a role model."

Ninety per cent of those suffering from eating disorders are women, and the relationship between a mother's eating patterns and her daughter's is well researched. Three children out of every five whose mothers are bulimic show evidence of an eating disorder. Research also shows that mothers of bulimics tend to weigh less than those of girls without eating disorders and, typically, are much more critical of their daughters.

Fathers, by comparison, have little effect on their daughters. Males make up 10% of those with eating disorders, but generally the cause is less connected to a son's emulation of his father's eating habits than feeling that he has failed in the public arena. "In a boy it seems to be rooted more in peer-group pressure," says Keith Chopping, a practitioner in eating disorders. "He wants to have the body of a favourite athlete or may be responding to peers who say he's too fat to play games.

"If you ask a mixed classroom of young adolescents to name what's wrong with them, boys say they're not good at maths, football or games, while girls say, 'My neck, my arms, my thighs, my breasts.'"

This emphasis on a girl's appearance begins, says Chopping, from the year dot. Children most susceptible to developing an eating disorder are obedient and compliant, eager to please both parents and peers. Although the most vulnerable age is between 15 and 25 - peaking from 14 to 18 - building a child's sense of physical self-esteem needs to start from birth. But what can parents do to let their children know that they are valued for more than the sum of their body parts, when there is a barrage of messages saying little else?

"Encourage your child to think about their character rather than what they look like," Chopping says. "Tell your daughter that we're in a blip and the ideal woman hasn't always looked like this. Encourage expression of feelings about the body."

Chopping also advises parents not to encourage a child who is unhappy with their body to go on a diet. Equally, forcing a child - even a toddler - to eat everything on their plate should be avoided. There is no point in making threats about the consequences of not eating. "If food becomes about power it's no longer a friend but an invasion," he says.

If you do think there is a problem, trust your instincts and be insistent when asking for help. Warning signs for parents worried about their child's relationship to food are a lack of concentration, fainting, collapsing, wearing baggy clothes and over-exercising. Yet many parents who realise that their child is ill have trouble convincing their GP of the seriousness of the problem.

Elsie Watchman's 15-year-old daughter Kate began to show signs of an eating disorder two years ago. She ate less and less and exercised furiously until, Watchman says, "she wouldn't keep still and jigged about on the spot". The family did not manage to get help until Kate hit 7st and "looked horrendous".

Now, Kate's weight is stable and Watchman feels positive about her recovery. Every week Kate talks to a counsellor in London on the phone and every few months travels the 100 miles to the capital for counselling. Watchman decided the trip was worthwhile after the psychiatrist Kate was referred to locally "implied my daughter was naughty and stupid and that I was letting her rule my life". She was told Kate would "pull herself together" but, she says, "I know my own, and I knew that it had gone beyond that".

Equally, forcing a child - even a toddler - to eat everything on their plate should be avoided. There is no point in making threats about the consequences of not eating. "If food becomes about power it's no longer a friend but an invasion," he says. If you do think there is a problem, trust your instincts and be insistent when asking for help. Warning signs for parents worried about their child's relationship to food are a lack of concentration, fainting, collapsing, wearing baggy clothes and over-exercising. Yet many parents who realise that their child is ill have trouble convincing their GP of the seriousness of the problem. Elsie Watchman's 15-year-old daughter Kate began to show signs of an eating disorder two years ago. She ate less and less and exercised furiously until, Watchman says, "she wouldn't keep still and jigged about on the spot". The family did not manage to get help until Kate hit 7st and "looked horrendous". Now, Kate's weight is stable and Watchman feels positive about her recovery. Every week Kate talks to a counsellor in London on the phone and every few months travels the 100 miles to the capital for counselling. Watchman decided the trip was worthwhile after the psychiatrist Kate was referred to locally "implied my daughter was naughty and stupid and that I was letting her rule my life". She was told Kate would "pull herself together" but, she says, "I know my own, and I knew that it had gone beyond that".

fields.headline: Service with a smile
fields.standfirst: Geoff Dobson on a boost for a profession that has suffered its share of public abuse
fields.trailText: Geoff Dobson on a boost for a profession that has suffered its share of public abuse
fields.body:
Yesterday probation services got some good news. At the annual meeting of the chief officers' association (Acop), the management of the 54 services in England and Wales were able to hear how they had turned around a crucial area of probation work with an 18% jump in performance in six months. The improvement relates not just to the service's sternest key performance indicator (KPI), but is also one that carries political significance.

The subject is enforcement. This is the unsentimental edge to community supervision that brings down a sanction on an offender who can't or won't adhere to the terms of their court order or the conditions of their release from prison.

Enforcement is for probation what waiting lists are for hospitals, detection rates are for the police and exam results are for schools. And like police, doctors and teachers, probation staff have had their fair share of public berating from the secretary of state and wagging ministerial fingers. No one expects offenders to be given too many chances, nor likes the idea that a court order could be flouted. The same sentiments are heard from parliament, only much louder.

For probation, the need to enforce has grown as the service has changed. With a caseload of more serious and persistent offenders, protecting the public is now a primary focus. This guides practice, like swift recall to prison.

Then there has been the drive to make sure all probation work is based on evidence of success - the initiative known as "What Works". This quiet revolution has also meant that evidence of effectiveness in reducing reoffending is the yardstick for designing programmes and supervision arrangements.

In this, compliance, the flipside of breach, applies. Court orders will not have any effect on offending if offenders do not turn up to programmes.

Then there is need to capture public and sentencer confidence by shedding the hackneyed "soft option" tag, demonstrating that there is a line that offenders cannot cross without consequences.

In May last year a plan was conceived and adopted by Acop to address probation's achilles heel of enforcement performance. The first step was an audit of 10,000 live cases to generate reliable enforcement data. The results, though not as bad as some earlier HM Inspection figures, were not good.

The bottom line was that only 44% of offenders who needed to be handed back to the courts were being dealt with correctly. Acop placed the figures in the public domain and committed itself, without prevarication, to shifting the culture of the service. The scrutiny also made probation staff more aware of problems elsewhere in the criminal justice system: delays in court proceedings and huge numbers of outstanding arrest warrants.

The audit research meant good practice was easier to detect and disseminate, and poor recording was exposed as something which probably concealed more good practice than bad. A second audit then tracked the progress of offenders for three months.

Now, nearly 12 months on, the results of the second audit show improvement on every indicator. Most first appointments are now made promptly, the requisite numbers of appointments are more likely to be made, and more formal and final warnings are being sent out after the first and second absence.

The rate of offenders being breached at their third unacceptable absence has now jumped 18%, from 44% to 62% (or, taking into account valid management authorisation to deal with the case some other way, from 51% to 66%). Variations between service performance narrowed, and weak services from the first audit turned in strong results in the second. This is a remarkable achievement for any public service, but still only a first step. The KPI sets a target of 90%.

The results are hard evidence to challenge the allegation of being too soft and too slow. More than 92% of the 4,386 offenders audited complied with their orders or were promptly breached. As an incidental finding, it also showed no differences by race in either offenders' non-compliance, or the ensuing actions of probation staff.

But has the good news come too late? There are new government proposals that many feel will take enforcement too far. The child support, pensions and social security bill plans to withdraw benefit payments to punish uncooperative offenders. The criminal justice and court services bill swings a second sledgehammer into enforcement by introducing the presumption of imprisonment for any offender who fails - under new national standards - to make two appointments without good reason.

As the audits and improving practice have shown, probation is not anti-enforcement. However, chief officers have arched a sceptical eyebrow at both measures. The withdrawal of benefits brings problems of equity and simple justice. The sanction will only apply to those offenders who are unemployed and will be triggered by an allegation from frontline probation staff, before any court hearing.

On the presumption of imprisonment for breach, the implications are starker still. The recent audit clearly links compliance with age: the young are more likely to breach. With a new national standard that invokes breach at two absences, accepting a deterrent effect, up to half the younger offenders on probation's books might go to prison.

Acop would argue that courts should retain some discretion to decide the appropriate penalty for breach. In many cases a curfew order, a financial penalty or additional hours of community service, together with a stern warning, will be sufficient to compel an offender to complete their order. A prison sentence is a necessary recourse for others and is certainly an essential ultimate sanction.

Enforcement will be a contentious issue in the current session of parliament. By putting its own house in order, probation has some authority in the subject.

The message is clear: the best deterrent to those who would flout community sentences is the certainty of a swift return to court.

 Geoff Dobson, outgoing chair of Acop, is chief probation officer for Hertfordshire.

fields.headline: Tears and joy
fields.standfirst: Geof May goes behind the lines in Chechnya to meet the beleaguered people of Ingushetia
fields.trailText: Geof May goes behind the lines in Chechnya to meet the beleaguered people of Ingushetia
fields.body:
Bear hugs and smiles, traditional Muslim hospitality and the fact that, despite great horror and suffering, people can retain their sense of purpose and hope: these are the first things that struck me about my trip to Ingushetia.

I was visiting our partner organisation, the Centre for Peacemaking and Community Development - a young, enthusiastic and dedicated team working tirelessly with thousands of people forced to leave their homes in Chechnya to live in the camps of Ingushetia. I was welcomed into their community, where they shared stories from their country - their colourful history, beliefs, struggles, joy and hopes. It was truly touching, as was their amazing humour, which brought tears and laughter.

We visited one official displaced persons' camp, a train of 105 carriages with around 65 people crammed into each carriage with their meagre belongings. They were anxious to express their feelings with me, the sadness and anger at the Russian emergency ministry, which has responsibility for feeding the displaced, using funds channelled through them by the UN.

The people had not received any of their meagre food rations for several days and blamed the authorities for diverting these resources, which often found their way on to the open market. One man said simply: "The Russian government just wants to annihilate all Chechens." Far off, above the hills, I could see plumes of smoke. "That's Grozny burning," I was told.

We also visited "spontaneous settlers", who live in crowded tents, garages, cattle sheds and barns - anything to provide shelter from the harsh winter. They huddled together in meagre clothing, their arms wrapped around themselves for warmth and consolation. Their expressions were a mixture of despair and defiance.

They were anxious to speak with me, not to complain about their current conditions, but more about the wider issues of the conflict. A much repeated plea was for me to let the world know about what has happened in Chechnya. "Does anyone know what is happening to us ? Does anyone care? Why don't governments do anything to help us?"

The children from Chechnya, just like children the world over, spontaneously smile in front of my camera. But their smiles are deceptive and hide inner feelings of what they have experienced, seen and heard. These are children whose rights have been abused. Others, less fortunate, suffer greater hardship and physical abuse in Russian detention centres, their basic rights ignored.

I spent some time with children during a counselling session in one of the camps. They were encouraged to express themselves through speaking, singing and dance. I could visibly see the benefits of these sessions in their actions and reactions.

M y sudden presence was welcomed and they bombarded me with dozens of questions - their favourite being guesses at my age. Many numbers were proposed, from a kind 36 suggested by a sweet girl to 500 volunteered by a boy with the cheekiest smile I have ever seen.

This conflict, like any conflict conspired by politicians and soldiers, destroys the lives and futures of ordinary men, women and children. It is yet another example of the depths of mankind's inhumanity. I have rarely been moved so much as I have been by being with these wonderful, sad, joyous, resilient, angry but loving people.

The last thing I remember from my trip is the plea of an elderly woman: "Please tell your people we are not all bad, yet everyone is affected in the war. There has been too much death and sorrow."

 The Christian Children's Fund of Great Britain has issued an appeal for the child victims of the conflict in Chechnya, to provide urgent psychological counselling and emergency aid. Donations can be made to their 24-hour donation line (020-8242 6000) or at www.jam.co.uk/chechnya.

fields.headline: Prized pictures
fields.standfirst: The annual Guardian/National Centre for Volunteering photographic competition
fields.trailText: The annual Guardian/National Centre for Volunteering photographic competition
fields.body:
This year's photo competition to celebrate the work of volunteers offers a high flying prize to the winner - two British Airways Club World return tickets to the US. For the fifth year running the Guardian is joining with the National Centre for Volunteering to run the contest, open to all amateur photographers. The idea is to show volunteers at work in their field.

Ruth Johnson, the head of communications at the centre, says: "We are looking for photos of volunteers in action, whether it's people digging an elderly person's garden or a teenager providing mentoring support for a child who's been bullied in school, or someone helping to provide care for a hospital patient.

"We are hoping that the pictures will reflect the diversity of volunteering activity that goes on in all sections of our society. That ranges from support for families to environmental and conservation projects, to health care, to education."

Entries have to be with the judges by May 31 and the winners will be announced during volunteers' week (June 1 to 7; tel 020-7520 8912, or call up the website at www.volunteering.org.uk) Last year 15,000 organisations across the UK took part. "The idea behind volunteers' week is to recognise, reward and recruit - to acknowledge the work that they do, say thank you to them in some way and to get more people on board," says Johnson.

The picture editor of the Guardian, Eamonn McCabe, who is one of the judges, suggests: "The pictures should concentrate on people and emotions: in the best pictures you can tell a volunteer is interacting with someone and getting great pleasure from it. The thing is to avoid the use of posters, banners and leaflets - the paraphernalia of charities - and to get away from being too literal."

Other judges will be Sean Risdale, head of development at the National Centre for Volunteering; Fiona Shadbolt, head of volunteers' week; Ruth Lewis, senior manager in community relations at British Airways.

Rules of the game

You may enter up to two black and white or colour photographs. Please provide two copies of each, and the negative, and send them to: Photographic competition, the National Centre for Volunteering, Regent's Wharf, 8 All Saints Street, London N1 9RL.

 Photos must be clearly identified on the back with your name, address, telephone number and a caption of the activity portrayed in the photo (approx 10 words) along with a brief description of the project (approx 20 words). The photos and a copy of this signed entry form must be sent in one packet clearly marked "Photographic competition". If there is too much information for the back of your photo, please attach it, clearly marking the photo it is pertaining to.

 Entries must have been taken within the last two years and must not have been previously published.

 The organisers reserve the right to free reproduction and exhibition of the prize-winning and commended entries, with full acknowledgement of the photographer.

 Winning - and a selection of commended - entries will be published in the Guardian on June 7, 2000.

 A panel of judges will choose the winners. The organisers' decision is final and no correspondence will be entered into.

 Winners will be notified by June 4.

 Those wishing their entries to be returned must enclose a SAE. Every care will be taken with entries, but we cannot accept responsibility for loss or damage, however caused.

 The closing date for entries is May 31, 2000.

 Entries without a signed entry form cannot be accepted.

fields.headline: High on ambition
fields.standfirst: It was built when central heating was 'posh' - and 44 years later it's still ahead of its time. Chris Arnot visits the block of flats that give high rise a good name
fields.trailText: It was built when central heating was 'posh' - and 44 years later it's still ahead of its time. Chris Arnot visits the block of flats that give high rise a good name
fields.body:
Olga Bayley was standing at a bus stop on the northern edge of Liverpool in 1956. One of the women standing next to her in the queue nudged her friend and pointed at the brand new block of council flats across the road. "Only posh people are allowed to live there," she proclaimed. Olga held her tongue.

She had just moved into a flat on the seventh floor of Coronation Court, the first high-rise block in the city and one of the first in the country. And she loved it. She loved having electricity, running water and a bathroom with flush toilet - very different from the gas-lit terraced house in inner-city Walton where she'd been living since 1949 with her husband, his father and grandmother.

The two women in the bus queue raised their eyes towards the top floor and one inquired of the other: "How do they get the coal up there?" Olga could take no more. "Excuse me," she butted in. "We have central heating."

The stunned silence that greeted this statement couldn't have been more pronounced had she claimed to have a wall-mounted jukebox or a teak-veneered cocktail cabinet. Central heating! Whatever next?

Fast-forward 44 years and Olga, now 74, is reminiscing in the hairdressing salon on the eighth floor of Coronation Court, which houses one of the block's three computer terminals. She has already used the internet to find out more about the Scottish town where she was stationed with the Wrens during the war. "We didn't see much of it at the time," she says. Another tenant, Eileen O'Hare, 70, is sending an email to her niece in Chicago. "I used to think the internet was beyond me," says Eileen, "but I'm finding it fascinating."

Liverpool's "silver surfers", as they are known, are evidently not going to be left behind. Heartening news then for Tony Blair, who says he wants the internet revolution to spread to all sections of society. After all, those who live in Coronation Court are tenants, not householders, and most of them are much closer to 70 than 17.

The question is: how typical is this online block of what's going on in Liverpool or, indeed, the country at large? The answer is: not very - or, at least, not yet. But every remaining high-rise block in the city will be linked by computer and closed circuit television if Paul Kelly has his way.

Kelly is the community development manager of the local housing action trust which took over the city's 67 tower blocks from the local authority. The HAT is now halfway through a 12-year programme which has involved demolishing at least 39 and refurbishing the remainder. At a particularly disruptive time, Kelly sees cutting-edge technology as "a good way of increasing tenant involvement".

Coronation Court has become home to the UK's first interactive Superchannel television station. The studio, with its white walls, potted plants and Ikea furniture, is right next door to the hairdressing salon. Three Danish artists arrived to install it one day in March.

Strictly speaking, they were part of Liverpool's latest Video Positive Exhibition, organised by the city's Foundation for Art and Creative Technology (Fact). Kelly explains: "Fact came up with this idea just at the point when we were developing an arts strategy, and it seemed to fit in well."

"Discursive rather than aesthetic," is how Fact's collaborations officer, Maria Brewster, describes the project. The artists worked with tenants, getting them used to the equipment and encouraging them to stage debates, interviews and social events for transmission on the world wide web. In the course of an afternoon tea dance, the Len Norman Quartet were somewhat taken aback to receive a request from a man in Seattle. He wanted them to play Fly Me To The Moon.

Mostly, though, online contributions to events at Coronation Court have come from terminals at the Bluecoat gallery in the city centre and, more recently, from the Royal College of Art as part of another interactive exhibition.

Superchannel will remain long after the exhibitions in Liverpool and London have finished. It is to be a permanent feature of life in Liverpool's oldest tower block. And the equipment will move with the tenants in September when they are temporarily exiled to a nearby block while their own flats are modernised. "They'll probably keep a camera trained on this place so they can keep tabs on what's going on," says Kelly. "They all want to get back in here as quickly as possible."

On the face of it, it's difficult to see why Coronation Court should require £6.5m-worth of renovation work. It was built in brick rather than concrete and has been well maintained.

It looks in much better condition than neighbouring tower blocks which were slotted together some years later. But the lift only stops at every third floor and the lay-out is such that next door neighbours have to go up one flight of steps and down another in order to visit each other. In fact, one of the liveliest Superchannel debates occurred when the architect who designed the block came along to visit the tenants from his retirement home in Dorset.

"The reality is that we have an elderly population living in housing that was not designed for them," says Kelly, who foresees new technology, as well as new lifts and new walkways, continuing to help bring tenants closer together. "We've already had a world wide web tea dance," he says. "Soon we're going to instigate world wide web bingo."

Whatever next? Coronation Court has certainly come a long way since central heating was posh technology.

The question is: how typical is this online block of what's going on in Liverpool or, indeed, the country at large? The answer is: not very - or, at least, not yet. But every remaining high-rise block in the city will be linked by computer and closed circuit television if Paul Kelly has his way. Kelly is the community development manager of the local housing action trust which took over the city's 67 tower blocks from the local authority. The HAT is now halfway through a 12-year programme which has involved demolishing at least 39 and refurbishing the remainder. At a particularly disruptive time, Kelly sees cutting-edge technology as "a good way of increasing tenant involvement". Coronation Court has become home to the UK's first interactive Superchannel television station. The studio, with its white walls, potted plants and Ikea furniture, is right next door to the hairdressing salon. Three Danish artists arrived to install it one day in March. Strictly speaking, they were part of Liverpool's latest Video Positive Exhibition, organised by the city's Foundation for Art and Creative Technology (Fact). Kelly explains: "Fact came up with this idea just at the point when we were developing an arts strategy, and it seemed to fit in well." "Discursive rather than aesthetic," is how Fact's collaborations officer, Maria Brewster, describes the project. The artists worked with tenants, getting them used to the equipment and encouraging them to stage debates, interviews and social events for transmission on the world wide web. In the course of an afternoon tea dance, the Len Norman Quartet were somewhat taken aback to receive a request from a man in Seattle. He wanted them to play Fly Me To The Moon. Mostly, though, online contributions to events at Coronation Court have come from terminals at the Bluecoat gallery in the city centre and, more recently, from the Royal College of Art as part of another interactive exhibition. Superchannel will remain long after the exhibitions in Liverpool and London have finished. It is to be a permanent feature of life in Liverpool's oldest tower block. And the equipment will move with the tenants in September when they are temporarily exiled to a nearby block while their own flats are modernised. "They'll probably keep a camera trained on this place so they can keep tabs on what's going on," says Kelly. "They all want to get back in here as quickly as possible." On the face of it, it's difficult to see why Coronation Court should require £6.5m-worth of renovation work. It was built in brick rather than concrete and has been well maintained. It looks in much better condition than neighbouring tower blocks which were slotted together some years later. But the lift only stops at every third floor and the lay-out is such that next door neighbours have to go up one flight of steps and down another in order to visit each other. In fact, one of the liveliest Superchannel debates occurred when the architect who designed the block came along to visit the tenants from his retirement home in Dorset. "The reality is that we have an elderly population living in housing that was not designed for them," says Kelly, who foresees new technology, as well as new lifts and new walkways, continuing to help bring tenants closer together. "We've already had a world wide web tea dance," he says. "Soon we're going to instigate world wide web bingo." Whatever next? Coronation Court has certainly come a long way since central heating was posh technology.

fields.headline: Grain damage
fields.standfirst: Catherine Ainger reports on the Filipino rice growers fighting for survival against the threat from landowners and seed giants
fields.trailText: Catherine Ainger reports on the Filipino rice growers fighting for survival against the threat from landowners and seed giants
fields.body:
The middle of a busy intersection in Manila in 40C heat could be the worst place in the world to hold a protest. Blocked by police from reaching the presidential palace, and blanketed by an evil fog of traffic fumes, a few hundred Filipinos from peasant farms and NGO movements lie in the middle of the road - a "die-in", they say, to symbolise their struggle for land reform and food.

Inside the palace, as guests of President Estrada, the International Rice Research Institute is holding its 40th anniversary of "scientific effort combating poverty and hunger around the world". It is the object of the protesters' scorn.

The IRRI has some of the world's leading rice scientists, and was the organisation that developed high-yielding crops for the "green revolution" of the 1960s and 1970s. But it is deeply unpopular these days at the grassroots. Rafael Mariano, leader of the powerful KMP peasant movement, charges the IRRI with locking rice farmers into dependency on the market. "Rice is a political crop," he says. "He who controls the production and distribution of rice has an invaluable weapon to control the whole of Asia."

The local NGO, Masipag Farmer-Scientist Alliance, takes the charge further, saying that the expensive chemical inputs required by the IRRI's rice varieties have forced farmers into a cycle of debt, and over the years depleted the soil, poisoned workers and caused massive loss of on-farm diversity. They argue that the costs of these inputs actually outweigh the outputs of increased yields.

Gurdev Khush, head of IRRI's plant breeding, genetics and biochemistry division, predicts that the current world rice output of 590m tonnes will have to increase by 50%, using less land and less water, to feed Asia's growing population over the coming decades. He is working on developing a high-yielding "super rice" that could improve yields by 50% to meet that need through conventional breeding.

But the great debate in the Philippines these past two weeks has been over GM rice. The IRRI's director general, Ronald Cantrell, believes that GM is the way forward, and stated that "for the [developed] countries to say 'no' to biotechnology is criminal". The institute begins its first GM rice field trials in the next few months.

The previous week, the world's leading rice biotechnologists had gathered at the IRRI Filipino HQ for a conference. It was here that Maurice Ku, of Washington State University, announced that he had developed a GM rice that could boost yields by 35% by inserting maize genes. Ku said the yields of the new GM rice approach targets the IRRI says are needed to feed the rising population in Asia over the next 20 years.

But the news had not filtered out into the paddy fields. Leopoldo Guilaran has been farming three acres of rice and corn on the Philippine island of Negros for over 20 years. When told about the new rice, he said: "We don't need this unproven genetic engineering technology or these seeds. The average production of a rice field here is 2.2 tonnes per hectare. Increasing that up to only 3.5 tonnes per hectare would make the Philippines self-sufficient in rice.

"But what keeps the farmers poor is that they don't have land or access to capital. A farmer's monthly wages barely cover half a month's living expenses."

The IRRI agrees that land reform is vital, but says it is unlikely and, therefore, GM is the best option. But where the scientists see GM as a technological issue, the Filipino farmers see it as life or death. Millions of farmers in the Philippines are tenant farmers and, on average, they hand over 60-70% of their harvest to their landlord as rent. The landlord offers credit to the tenant to buy the required seed and chemical inputs from him and he buys the rice from the tenant.

Guilaran, speaking for other farmers at Masipag, says: "Even if the scientists invented a rice that could yield 20 tonnes per hectare, it wouldn't make a difference to the farmer who grows it. If he doesn't own the land it grows on, he still won't be able to afford to feed his family."

The Ibon Foundation, a Filipino indigenous rights group, says that, as a result of the landlords and contract growing system, many of the peasant farmers face cycles of crippling debt and poverty. Often the destitute farmers turn to armed struggles for land. There are currently 80 pockets around the country.

Emmanual Yap, leader of Masipag, fears that GM rice will create the same cycle of dependency, control and environmental depletion. He says: "A rice seed engineered to increase yields, even using increased photosynthesis efficiency, will still require more from the soil and thus require bought inputs. It's a simple input-output equation."

The GM companies prefer to talk about developing "high value" crops, which usually refers to rice seed that only reproduces if the farmer applies a chemical bought from the company. For rice farmers, who currently save and replant their seed, this is their worst fear about GM.

Yap says: "They [the companies] will face a big challenge by the Filipino farmers. Rice is basic food- it is their life. This will really trigger off a protest from people, because it will marginalise the small farmers even more."

fields.headline: Help when it's needed
fields.standfirst: Dorit Braun on a scheme that recognises how difficult children can be
fields.trailText: Dorit Braun on a scheme that recognises how difficult children can be
fields.body:
We all know that babies don't always sleep, that toddlers have tantrums and that teenagers can be challenging. But do we really know how this can feel to parents, and what kind of support they really want?

Of course, the best way to find out is to listen to the parents themselves. At Parentline Plus, we collect information from service users not only to improve our own services, but also to provide information and insights to policy makers and practitioners. And the single biggest cause of concern - 40% of calls on our free, confidential helpline - is teenage behaviour.

We have now studied a sample of such calls, and the publication of the results forms part of the first phase of a new national Talking Families campaign, supported by BT and to be launched today by Lord Bassam, a home office minister.

Based on a survey of over 2,000 parents of teens, our research reveals the depths of parents' feelings towards their teens. Words like aggressive, violent, threatening, rude, abusive, rebellious, manipulative and anti-social predominate - and often these words are used to describe the young person, rather than their behaviour. Parents often feel completely stuck in their situation, but also fear being judged by the people around them to whom could turn for help.

It is clear that parents need to express their feelings before they can start to explore options for dealing with their difficulties. It is also clear that the anonymous and confidential nature of the helpline service enables parents to articulate their feelings in ways which can be very hard when talking face to face with a person.

The analysis of our calls shows that many people are uncertain of the impact of things like divorce and re-partnering on young people, as well as on themselves. Some feel ignorant about the life changes their teenagers experience and how best to support them through these changes; others lack confidence about enforcing boundaries with young people and feel unclear about what those boundaries might be.

This is significant for the way agencies work with families to provide support. Many callers to Parentline Plus had tried to ask for help from other services - such as schools, GPs, specialist services and child protection agencies - but had not felt understood or helped by them. Many agencies concentrate on providing information rather than starting by really listening to parents. This can create a feeling of being fobbed off, at a time when it has taken parents all their courage just to get in contact.

Our growing understanding of the experience of parents, the skills and understanding they want to develop, and the ways they wish to access support, sets major challenges. Parentline Plus has recently incorporated Parent Network and its parenting courses into our range of services. These will increase parents' opportunities to support one another, to realise that they are not alone with their feelings and with their difficulties. But this is still not enough.

Agencies need to understand the issues parents face and need to help staff develop the skills and time to understand what parents are feeling. We need to work towards a time when the public and local agencies recognise that families come in all shapes and sizes and that anyone caring for a child needs to feel valued and supported. If parents are to be encouraged to turn to their friends and to professionals for help, they need to feel they won't be judged. A massive culture change is needed, so that the wider community starts to recognise that parenting is very hard work; that most parents find it difficult from time to time; that they want to do the very best they can; and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not a weakness.

 Dorit Braun is chief executive of Parentline Plus. For further information about the Talking Families campaign, report survey or new materials to support parents, call Parentline Plus on 020-7284 5500 (helpline 0808 800 2222; helpline textphone 0800 783 6783; website www.parentlineplus.org.uk)

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
It's difficult to keep count of the number of people who've been queuing up to add their voice to the continuing debate about sex education which has been prompted by the row over Section 28. Nearly all these contributors have, though, made the naive assumption that education is a one-way process. There's a general belief that once the legislators have worked out a satisfactory compromise on the relative moral priority that should be accorded to homosexual and heterosexual relations, then the teachers can promptly be dispatched to the classrooms to put the new code into practice.

The almost complete absence of any reference to those on the receiving end might be excusable if there was no evidence about what children want and expect from such tuition. But only last month, Routledge Falmer published Young People's Views on Sex Education, in which Lynda Measor, Coralie Tiffin and Katrina Miller conclude - based on extended interviews and observation sessions in mixed comprehensive schools -that what 13 to 15 year olds want from sex education is not moral exhortation but explicitly relevant material.

Although this makes nonsense of all the pontificating about the precise moral components of sex education we've recently been forced to endure it is hardly surprising in view of the simple statistical news that one in five girls and one in four boys have had intercourse before the age of 16.

For many young people, this sexual experience is not an accidental or occasional phenomenon: it's a personal right that has nothing whatsoever to do with the moral sensibilities of a teacher. As one girl forcibly explained: "OK, if the teacher tries to say none of you are allowed to have sex until you are 16, everyone is just going to say, 'Fuck that! I mean, like we'd really listen to you!' So you are in a situation with some bloke, and you are really going to say, 'No, my teacher says it's wrong'? I'm sorry, but you know!"

Most teachers and health professionals readily accept that young people make their own decisions about sexuality and recognise that it is their responsibility to work within that framework. It increasingly looks as though their chance of doing so will be denied by politicians who are unable to resist this latest opportunity to clamber aboard a populist moral bandwagon.

fields.headline: Block vote
fields.standfirst: Graham Towers explodes the myth that demolition is the only way to erase the stigma from social housing estates
fields.trailText: Graham Towers explodes the myth that demolition is the only way to erase the stigma from social housing estates
fields.body:
At a time when more and more homes are needed for single people and childless households, it seems ironic that much potentially suitable housing is being knocked down.

To meet projected demand, there is an increasing focus on higher densities and multi-storey living. The urban task force emphasised the need to raise housing densities, both to reduce land take and create viable urban regeneration, while the government has just announced revised planning guidelines to require denser new developments.

Yet existing urban flats are still being pulled down on the social housing estates built, and still largely owned, by local authorities. Many have become physically degraded and socially stigmatised. While a lot of money has been put into regenerating such estates, there has been an increasing tendency to demolish.

Such destruction is both undesirable and unnecessary. Almost all these run-down estates could be successfully transformed.

The four and five storey tenement blocks built in many cities in the early 20th century have largely deteriorated and are often regarded as the least desirable form of housing. Yet there are many examples of successful modernisation, adapted to provide family maisonettes on the ground floor and small flats above for those without children. Common areas have been enclosed and secured, and bleak Tarmac courtyards have been made into communal gardens.

Many tower blocks have also been renovated, and such schemes have been particularly successful where the blocks have been re-allocated to new residents - to the elderly, to students or to those who choose to live in high rise flats.

Deck access estates have become notorious for the oppor tunities for crime and gang culture created by their labyrinthine and unsecured networks of pedestrian walkways. Yet even these estates can be transformed. This usually requires replanning to separate the blocks, making most flats entered directly from the ground or accessed in small groups around a single staircase. Coupled with improvements to the flats themselves, such replanning has turned these "hard-to-let" estates into good quality social housing.

Large slab blocks, and especially groups of such blocks linked together, have proved the most difficult type of estate to renovate. Even so, experience suggests that they could be improved by building in new lifts and stairs, and breaking the blocks themselves down into small groups of flats clustered around each access point.

Despite the trend to increasing demolition, the great majority of the multi-storey housing built by local authorities is still standing. Many estates are problematic, yet demolishing and replacing them all is prohibitively expensive. Even if it were possible, rebuilding does not provide a sure-fire solution.

The critical issue is that too many estates have become ghettos of low income tenants. This has been exacerbated by the "right to buy", which has ensured that most desirable social housing has been sold off. Multi-storey estates have become repositories of the most needy low income families.

There is plenty of evidence that concentrations of disadvantage can cause social stress, even in low rise estates, so redevelopment may simply transfer the problems elsewhere. The key issue is to release the pressure on such estates by providing new homes for the most needy and poorly housed families.

Building a considerable number of new family houses for rent is necessary to meet a social need. Given good planning and sensitive policies, this new housing could allow large families trapped on multi-storey estates to move. Once freed up, parts of the estates could be made available for adaptation for other occupants better suited to multi-storey living - such as students, single people, childless couples, the elderly.

This might mean transferring blocks to new owners - other social landlords, academic institutions or even private developers. In this way, such estates could could come to house a mixed community of young and old, families and singlets, owners and renters. They could become more typical of the population as a whole - and the once-stigmatised estates could be re-integrated into the urban fabric.

 Graham Towers is an architect and town planner. His book, Shelter Is Not Enough - Transforming Multi-storey Housing, was published by the Policy Press on March 29.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Councillors in Lancaster have made a £5,000 saving by voting to cut out the provision of cream cakes at evening meetings.
fields.body:
Cakes cut: Councillors in Lancaster have made a £5,000 saving by voting to cut out the provision of cream cakes at evening meetings.

Party lights: Parish councillors in Mickleton, County Durham, held a birthday party for a set of temporary traffic lights that are still in use four years after they were installed because of a landslide.

Sole thoughts: A man from California ordered two Dover sole on the internet and paid £190 to have them delivered after acquiring a taste for the fish while on holiday in Britain.

Brother in arms: David Schwimmer, star of the TV comedy Friends, underwent a training programme with the British army to get fit for a role in Steven Spielberg's new film, Band of Brothers.

Dry runs: Two former students have launched a business in Nottingham to deliver booze to parties that are in danger of running dry.

Alarming naivety: A young man hoping to join Kent police force ruined his chances by dialling 999 to see if his job application had been received.

fields.headline: Capital ideas
fields.standfirst: Three more candidates for mayor of London offer their solutions to the city's problems
fields.trailText: Three more candidates for mayor of London offer their solutions to the city's problems
fields.body:
Steve Norris Conservative

I want to see London's environment treated with the seriousness which it deserves. The relationship between our behaviour and the resources around us is far more important in Britain's biggest city than in any rural part of Britain.

I am committed to improving air quality in London, and to promoting biodiversity.

I want to see sustainable development in London, so I am committed to London's green belt. I will act as a broker between the boroughs, government and the private sector to identify and develop brownfield sites for development.

Cutting congestion in London is not about helping our environment at the expense of our economy; it damages both.

I will make traffic reduction a top priority by:

 Increasing the number of buses per route by day and by night;

 Banning lorries at peak daytime hours;

 Increasing the number and the safety of cycle routes;

 Increasing investment in all forms of public transport across our city.

But being serious about reducing congestion is about more than making public transport more attractive, regular and reliable.

I will pioneer green transport as mayor of London, and will encourage the use and expansion of environmentally friendly means of getting about, including the underground, cycling and walking, as well as working to reduce the emissions released by traffic.

Susan Kramer Lib Dems

Transport is key in making London a sustainable city with cleaner air, lower traffic pollution, protected open spaces and communities that work for local people.

I intend to lure Londoners out of their cars. I will keep the tube in public hands and finance accelerated improvements through a bond issue. We need a fast, reliable bus system with enforced priority lanes. Congestion charges on cars in central London during working hours will be introduced once these improvements are apparent. This will help tackle pollution and, by 2010, will reduce traffic by 15% from 1997 levels.

I will complete the London cycle network and accelerate the development of local networks. My aim is that 10% of all journeys are made by bike by 2012.

The Thames is particularly important to London's biodiversity and quality of life. I will encourage its use as a route for freight. I will ensure that any new developments along the river offer proper access and provide open space and mixed housing.

Brownfield sites must be used to cope with housing demand. Major developments must support affordable housing and encourage mixed use communities.

I will also encourage energy conservation and use of renewable energy sources through planning - for example, using planning guidance to advise that new developments are designed to take solar panels.

Within my first term I will work with private companies to bring a state-of-the-art recycling plant into London.

Darren Johnson Green Party

Reducing traffic is the top priority in this election. As well as restraining car use, congestion charging will bring in the revenue required to pay for improvements for pedestrians, cyclists and in public transport. Candidates cannot be regarded as serious if they promise more buses, better trains, less pollution and less congestion but don't at the same time support the key policy needed to achieve those aims. There needs to be a strong block of Greens on the 25-member London assembly, to ensure that these and other policies for the greening of London can go ahead. Greens will be working for:

 A spatial development strategy which restores the historic pattern of London as a network of 300 urban villages, strengthening local communities and reducing people's overall need to travel;

 The scrapping of environmentally destructive and traffic generating schemes, such as Heathrow's Terminal 5 and the proposed developments on Crystal Palace Park and Rainham Marshes;

 The appointment of a London animal rights officer;

 A "zero waste agency" to promote waste reduction, re-use and recycling;

 A ban on the growing of GM crops in the Greater London area;

 An end to the transport of nuclear waste through London;

 An economic development strategy which supports strong local economies and makes London less reliant on the global marketplace which is causing so much damage to the global environment and failing to provide Londoners with the broad range of opportunities they need.

fields.headline: Dying art
fields.standfirst: Fancy coffins are in fashion for family and friends - and galleries. Derren Hayes meets the taboo breakers
fields.trailText: Fancy coffins are in fashion for family and friends - and galleries. Derren Hayes meets the taboo breakers
fields.body:
Richard Mullard looks death in the face every day. But it's not a frightening experience. In fact, it's usually when he's relaxing, sitting in his living room listening to music with a glass of wine.You see, Mullard already owns his own coffin and, until the time comes for it to be used for what it was originally designed, he's turned it into a makeshift music box to store his CDs, records and tapes.

But this isn't the finished article; there's still a lot of work to be done on it yet. "As a hobby, I go on mini expeditions to Antarctica and I've been thinking that when I die I'd like my coffin to be painted as an expedition sledge with me wearing skis," he explains.

Mullard, a signwriter by trade, has for the past two years been working for Nottingham coffin maker Vic Fearn & Co, painting coffins to order. "Increasingly, people feel they want to do something special for a relative or friend who's just died," he says. "They think it's nice to say something personal about this individual."

The designs are generally simple, but he rarely does two the same. Some of his recent customers include a Ford Capri-loving Chelsea fan, an environmentalist who wanted her coffin depicting the four seasons, and the airplane enthusiast who had his coffin shaped and painted in the colours of a Red Arrow. But Mullard says his favourite was the AC/DC session musician who wanted a Fender Stratocaster guitar painted on his coffin.

"The trade has blossomed in the past few years and I can only see it getting more popular," Mullard says. "Perhaps in some ways it's a replacement for traditional religion."

Of course, painting and decorating coffins is not a new phenomenon. The ancient Egyptians were rather good at it. And, more recently, a whole culture developed in parts of Africa when a carpenter made a coffin in the shape of a plane for his recently died grandmother who always wanted to fly but never had the chance. But the word and concept of death has always been something the British have struggled to talk about and confront. Until now, that is.

Alan Doors, sales development manager at the Co-op funeral services, says he gets requests every week for something a little different. "Demand is doubling every year and people seem more secure about death now," he says.

He believes this is due to changes in society, with people applying the principles of consumerism to the death industry and moving away from traditional religions to look for a new spiritual identity. "People come to us knowing what they want," Doors says.

"There are price and time factors to everything, but we always try to meet the customer's request."

That might be adorning coffins with pictures and artefacts that have a connection with the individual inside or decorating it in the colours of a person's favourite football team. "One man wore a canary yellow suit for his funeral and had his coffin painted plum because that was the colour of the doors in his house," he says. "Another lady wanted a street scene from Prague painted on her coffin, so we found a French company that specialised in painting European street scenes on coffins."

While there is no particular social group that is more interested in coffin art than others, Doors believes there are certain cultures and generations that it particularly appeals to. "We see a lot of the 'flower-power' generation buying cardboard coffins and decorating them with beads," he says. And he thinks the trend will be for even more people to deviate from the norm in the future.

The Society for Allied and Independent Funeral Directors say there are now even 30-somethings planning and paying for their funerals in advance. John Weir, of the SAIF, explains: "This is beginning to break down the barriers to death as people start to think about what they want. My generation - now in late middle age - are better than my parents at taking a far more open look at death."

Laura White, a 31-year-old conceptual sculptor from London, had never really given death a second thought until last year, when she came up with the idea of using coffins as art. Six months on, she is putting the finishing touches to an exhibition - due to open next month at the Fordham Gallery, London - in which she has used infants' coffins and sculpted them in the shape of flowers.

While she admits this may have a shock value, that's not the aim. "When you talk to people about coffins their immediate reaction is something that's sinister and strange, but it's these preconceptions that affect the way we see them," she says. "When people first see the sculptures they don't know what they are. An object has to be explained for you to make a judgment about it, and because it's something different to what you think, it can change your opinion."

But she says attitudes are changing - and not just in the art world. "Artists have always confronted death, but people generally are talking about it more and the barriers are being broken down," she says.

One undertaker which certainly thinks this is Manchester-based United Norwest Co-op, which has just taken coffins into cyberspace. By accessing Norwest's website you can not only order a coffin, but customise it by choosing its colour, the headstone and even coffin furniture to turn your yard into a garden of remembrance.

"We wanted to dumb down a bit and make the site look like GAP selling coffins," Norweb marketing manager Phil Lane explains. "I don't think the country was really ready for this five years ago, but the taboo about death is being broken down now."

And the next venture Lane is looking at is the football funeral. "The coffins would be in football colours, the funeral procession would go past the ground and you'd have the team's song playing at the service," Lane enthuses, clearly excited at the thought of all those die-hard Manchester United fans seeking a special send-off.
