fields.headline: Dancing with death
fields.standfirst: Modern man's lack of respect for nature has provided fertile breeding ground for the spread of a deadly parasite that now threatens Britain's bees. Paul Evans reports
fields.trailText: Modern man's lack of respect for nature has provided fertile breeding ground for the spread of a deadly parasite that now threatens Britain's bees.
fields.body:
As the weather warms, the bees emerge to begin their dance with flowers. They evoke romantic images of humming orchard hives and summer sweetness, presided over by veiled eccentrics steeped in arcane lore. What a pity the reality is such a cock-up.

People and honeybees have a long history together. Palaeolithic wall paintings in Spain bear witness to the human lust for sweetness consummated only by robbing bees of the fruits of their magical industry. Bees may be some of the first creatures to have been domesticated and yet there is still something mysteriously wild about them. We treated them with respect not just because of their stings but because they would up sticks and leave us if we didn't. But there is another, more essential kind of respect for nature itself, which we dishonour at our peril.

Bees pollinate our crops, their ecology is essential to the whole flowering world, they provide us with honey and wax, they fascinate us. But what do they get out of it? They get a life-sucking parasitic mite, Varroa jacobsonii. The spread of Varroa in honeybee hives around the world is a consequence of globalisation, free trade, the commodification of nature and a reneging on our ancient pact with the bees.

There are around 35,000 beekeepers in Britain, most of them hobbiests, but between them they keep up to 200,000 colonies, each containing between 5,000 and 80,000 bees. Each colony can produce 100 lbs of honey which sells, at farm-gate prices, at £2.50 per lb. This does not include the 400 wholly professional bee farmers in Britain. Those beekeepers who have not got Varroa in their colonies soon will have. Its spread, like that of Dutch elm disease in the 70s, is inexorable.

Varroa came from the far east, where it was a parasite on the Asiatic race of honeybee. This bee had co-evolved with Varroa and developed ways of coping with it. Asian countries switched their honey industry from their native, mite-resistant Apis cerana to the more productive European honeybee Apis mellifera; by the 1950s Varroa had switched too.

The European bee was defenceless against Varroa and colonies were decimated. Thanks to the international trade in bees, Varroa spread through Apis mellifera-dominated beekeeping around the world and arrived in Britain in 1992. Since then it has spread through apiaries and feral colonies throughout England and Wales and is currently heading north into Scotland.

Steve Balogh, a beekeeper and interpreter, recently returned from China, where he met leading Chinese bee scientists who have been tackling their own Varroa problem. "Since the 1960s the Chinese had been working on a control for Varroa which did not hurt the bees as well," Balogh says. "In the 1970s they came up with a successful treatment, but the mites began to show signs of resistance and fallback measures were needed."

In the 1980s, Wei Hua Zhen came up with a new preparation and did field trials. Since 1996, she has saved 10,000 hives using this. "There are problems with intellectual property rights and the Chinese won't say what the preparation is made of, but it's a fraction of the price we have to pay for Varroa control in Britain. What will happen when Varroa becomes resistant to chemicals in the west, as is happening in Germany and France?"

Medwin Bew, director of the National Bee Unit at Maff's Central Science Laboratories in York, is sceptical about the Chinese solutions and happy with the regulations and treatments currently in use; even though only two of the dozen control methods used in Europe are permitted in the UK.

"I'm optimistic about the future," says Bew. "Beekeepers are resiliant and won't give up - the bees mean too much to us. Varroa may be a pain in the neck but it can be managed with enough resources and hard work."

This is a view shared by Michael Badger, president of the British Beekeepers Association who is also optimistic and thinks the existing controls are sufficient. Badger says: "I've kept bees for 50 years and won't let Varroa bother me: new people coming in to beekeeping just accept Varroa as part of the business."

This attitude angers beekeepers like Steve Balogh. "The authorities have been no kind of help whatever," says Balogh.

Either their regulations get amended or they'll have ruled bees out of existence altogether."

The lessons learned from the ancient relationship between people and bees have not entirely been lost and have even found a new lease of life in some of the poorest countries.

The charity Bees for Development has been supporting sustainable beekeeping projects around the world since 1993, encouraging the use of local strains of honeybee, local materials for hives and the protection of the local environment where bees forage.

They even have beekeeping projects where the bees forage on land riddled with landmines; people make a sustainable living from land they cannot even tread on.

"When Varroa becomes a problem for people in very poor communities it's a disaster, because they can't afford the chemicals used tocontrol it," says Helen Jackson, of Bees for Development. "It's so sad the bees have been dealt an awful blow by spreading the mite."

So, the Varroa mites plague the bees because people have cocked up natural processes to get more honey from the bees and the pharmaceutical companies exploit the beekeepers who depend on them to control the mites. Spot the real parasites.

Cold comfort for the sweet poets of summer

Wild bees
Experts claim the Varroa mite will only affect the Apis species of honey bees and won't skip to other species. Where have we heard that before?

Britain's wild bees - described byJohn Clare as "sweet poets of the summer fields" - already have enough problems. Of the 251 species of bees native to Britain, 25 are threatened with extinction, 10 are vulnerable and in serious decline, and 27 are now rare. This means that 25% of British wild bees are in serious trouble. 10 bee species have already become extinct in Britain and a further 50 are nationally scarce.

Habitat destruction is the greatest cause of bee loss. The honeybees we see buzzing about are generally a mixture of types caused by breeding bees brought in from around the world. The small brown honey bee found in North Yorkshire may be the one the Romans first used. Most of the hive bees are "Italian" bees introduced during the 19th century. Many are now imported from New Zealand and there are fears of other diseases coming in.

Bumblebees
The results of recent research reveals that the decline in Britain's bumblebees is largely due to changing agricultural practices which have done away with fields of red clover and, in so doing, destroyed vast amounts of sources of nectar and pollen.

Although red clover is still a common plant it is not found in the quantities of some years ago when it was planted as a fertiliser crop to be ploughed back into the soil. Chemical fertilisers have replaced it. Many now rare bumblebee species require a lot of red clover flowering all summer to provide enough food for the successful development of their nests. The Bumble Bee Working Group, supported by a well-known honey company, organised a survey of Britain to plot sites of red clover of use to bumblebees for future conservation work. Many of the rarest bumbles nest in coastal areas, where agriculture has become more intensive. The greatest number of bumblebee species occurs on Salisbury Plain, in the military training area - bomble bees perhaps.

 Beekeeping and the Varroa problem will be discussed at a beekeepers' convention at the Royal Agricultural Showground at Stoneleigh, Warwickshire, this weekend. Bees for Development's website is at: www.planbee.org.uk

The lessons learned from the ancient relationship between people and bees have not entirely been lost and have even found a new lease of life in some of the poorest countries. The charity Bees for Development has been supporting sustainable beekeeping projects around the world since 1993, encouraging the use of local strains of honeybee, local materials for hives and the protection of the local environment where bees forage. They even have beekeeping projects where the bees forage on land riddled with landmines; people make a sustainable living from land they cannot even tread on. "When Varroa becomes a problem for people in very poor communities it's a disaster, because they can't afford the chemicals used tocontrol it," says Helen Jackson, of Bees for Development. "It's so sad the bees have been dealt an awful blow by spreading the mite." So, the Varroa mites plague the bees because people have cocked up natural processes to get more honey from the bees and the pharmaceutical companies exploit the beekeepers who depend on them to control the mites. Spot the real parasites. Cold comfort for the sweet poets of summer Wild bees Experts claim the Varroa mite will only affect the Apis species of honey bees and won't skip to other species. Where have we heard that before? Britain's wild bees - described byJohn Clare as "sweet poets of the summer fields" - already have enough problems. Of the 251 species of bees native to Britain, 25 are threatened with extinction, 10 are vulnerable and in serious decline, and 27 are now rare. This means that 25% of British wild bees are in serious trouble. 10 bee species have already become extinct in Britain and a further 50 are nationally scarce. Habitat destruction is the greatest cause of bee loss. The honeybees we see buzzing about are generally a mixture of types caused by breeding bees brought in from around the world. The small brown honey bee found in North Yorkshire may be the one the Romans first used. Most of the hive bees are "Italian" bees introduced during the 19th century. Many are now imported from New Zealand and there are fears of other diseases coming in. Bumblebees The results of recent research reveals that the decline in Britain's bumblebees is largely due to changing agricultural practices which have done away with fields of red clover and, in so doing, destroyed vast amounts of sources of nectar and pollen. Although red clover is still a common plant it is not found in the quantities of some years ago when it was planted as a fertiliser crop to be ploughed back into the soil. Chemical fertilisers have replaced it. Many now rare bumblebee species require a lot of red clover flowering all summer to provide enough food for the successful development of their nests. The Bumble Bee Working Group, supported by a well-known honey company, organised a survey of Britain to plot sites of red clover of use to bumblebees for future conservation work. Many of the rarest bumbles nest in coastal areas, where agriculture has become more intensive. The greatest number of bumblebee species occurs on Salisbury Plain, in the military training area - bomble bees perhaps.  Beekeeping and the Varroa problem will be discussed at a beekeepers' convention at the Royal Agricultural Showground at Stoneleigh, Warwickshire, this weekend. webTitle: Yahoo in dock over Nazi auctions

fields.headline: Yahoo in dock over Nazi auctions
fields.standfirst: Nazi memorabilia for auction on Yahoo!.com
fields.trailText: A Paris-based anti-racism group is to take internet portal Yahoo! to court over the auction of Nazi memorabilia on its website.
fields.body:
A Paris-based anti-racism group is to take internet portal Yahoo! to court over the auction of Nazi memorabilia on its website.

The International League against Racism and Anti-Semitism (Licra), which called in February for a boycott of Yahoo! sites for the same reason, said it was seeking an injunction in a Paris court to force the California-based company to stop the sales in France.

"Licra demands that Yahoo! take the necessary measures to prevent the exhibition and sale on its sites of Nazi objects throughout the national territory," the group said in a statement.

"This sale of symbols of the greatest ever crime against humanity trivialises Nazism in the extreme," the group added.

"In the United States [these auctions] might not be illegal, but as soon as you cross the French border, it's absolutely illegal," said Marc Knobel, a researcher for Licra.

A spokesman for Yahoo! said the company does not comment on pending lawsuits.

Judicial sources said a hearing was set for May 15. Licra said it would ask the judge to order Yahoo! to pay a daily fine of 100,000 euros ($95,880) until it complies with the injunction.

The Yahoo.com auction site puts hundreds of Nazi, neo-Nazi and Ku Klux Klan objects up for auction each day, including films, swastikas, uniforms, daggers, photographs and medals.

There are no such Nazi items for sale on Yahoo!'s French website, but Licra did not say how access to Yahoo.com, the company's global US-based website, could be blocked in France only.

Yahoo! came under fire in February from another anti-racism group, the Anti-Defamation League, which accused the company of hosting dozens of sites that promoted messages from racist hate groups including neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan.

webTitle: Blair turns out for Dobson - at last

fields.headline: Blair turns out for Dobson - at last
fields.standfirst: The prime minister has urged Londoners to vote for the 'serious' mayoral candidate, Frank Dobson - but pledged to work with whoever was elected
fields.trailText: Tony Blair belatedly entered the London mayoral campaign today to back Frank Dobson, as the "serious candidate" for a "serious job".
fields.body:
Tony Blair belatedly entered the London mayoral campaign today to back Frank Dobson, as the "serious candidate" for a "serious job".

The prime minister's delay in making a personal appearance with Mr Dobson on his mayoral campaign trail follows speculation that Mr Blair was keen to distance himself from a losing candidate. Mr Dobson is trailing in the opinion polls to Ken Livingstone.

But the prime minister refused to repeat his past criticisms of Mr Livingstone, promising to "work with whoever is the mayor".

He said: "I am not going back into the business of attacking Ken Livingstone - everyone knows what I think of him."

Mr Blair added: "Every day it is becoming more and more clear to people that the post of mayor is a serious job and needs a serious candidate to do it. It is not a ceremonial job.

"The mayor will be a big, powerful figure with real power over the issues that matter to Londoners - issues like transport, crime and the regeneration of the inner city." Mr Blair said that Mr Dobson, Labour's official candidate, would stand up to the government if he had to and added: "His integrity, his courage and his honesty give him the qualities to do the job."

The prime minister suggested that the greatest problem facing the Dobson campaign was the media. Facing reporters, he said: "His problem is getting you guys to focus on policy, because when you focus on policy they will vote for him - when they focus on process, or what happened a few months ago, then the issues get obscured."

Asked whether he could ever work with Mr Livingstone, Mr Blair said: "I will work with whoever is the mayor. I abide by the democratic decision of the people of London, that is my duty as prime minister and of course I will carry it out."

Mr Blair and Mr Dobson attacked Mr Livingstone's plans for transport as costly and irresponsible.

Mr Blair said the future of London's transport system had become the most important issue of the campaign and said the "dividing lines" between the political parties were very clear.

He said that the Tories' plans for the privatisation of London Underground were "madness" and claimed that Mr Livingstone's plan for congestion charges would cost motorists £100 a month and delay the modernisation of the Tube.

The prime minister said: "The Livingstone proposals are irresponsible on grounds of costs, particularly on congestion-charging. That is why the only serious alternative to Mr Livingstone is Frank Dobson."

Mr Dobson also attacked congestion charging, arguing that such a policy would create "checkpoint charlies" across the capital, where cars were stopped and congestion made worse.

Mr Livingstone, standing as an independent candidate, welcomed the prime minister's assertion that he would work with whoever is elected as mayor of London and "respect the democratic wishes of Londoners".

"I also welcome his recognition that the defining policy issue in this election is the future of the London Underground," Mr Livingstone said.

"In my opinion, it is for London to decide on the future of the Tube - and every poll shows that Londoners are totally opposed to the government's plans to break up and partially privatise the underground.

"No genuinely independent study has so far vindicated the government's plans. If Londoners elect a mayor who is opposed to the planned break-up of the tube then the government will clearly have to reconsider.

"By his comments today, Tony Blair has moved some way to accepting that if I am elected the partial privatisation of the tube will have to be reconsidered."

The London Chamber of Commerce welcomed Mr Dobson's pledge to wait for improvements in public transport before imposing congestion charges.

Its campaigns director, Andrew Hawkins, said the chamber would fight "the double whammy of increased taxes combined with the costs that currently go with congestion".

Referring to Mr Livingstone's policy, he added: "The paper-based system of road-user charging that some are advocating is far too crude a weapon. In reality it is an area licence scheme, not a congestion charge."

 Leaflets outlining the views of all 11 candidates standing for mayor of London were today being sent to London's 5.1m voters. The leaflets' distribution follows the House of Lords' rebellion against government plans to block a free mailshot for all candidates earlier this year.

fields.headline: Giant step backwards
fields.standfirst: Anne Power argues that the transfer of huge blocks of council housing stock is no way to ensure that people in need get a decent home at an affordable price
fields.trailText: Anne Power argues that the transfer of huge blocks of council housing stock is no way to ensure that people in need get a decent home at an affordable price
fields.body:
About 13 million people in Britain are tenants of local authorities. So why do only 11% of the electorate turn out to vote for local government in the wards dominated by council housing? And why do 60% of tenants pay little or no rent, giving them no leverage on their landlord? No other European country runs housing for low income people this way. So why do we?

Two devastating world wars and the oldest industrial slums in the world led to the vast clearances of inner Victorian terraces and the construction of 10,000 large, difficult to manage council estates. No private body could take on a building programme on this scale, so we created a top-heavy, state-run, bureaucratic housing machine.

As a result, councils are supposed to offer a "decent home" at an affordable price to anyone in proven need. But do they? Why is one in 10 council homes hard to let even in inner London? Why are councils knocking down estates that they can no longer let or manage, while similar housing provided by other landlords lasts many generations?

Two problems beset council housing - the stock itself, and the way it is run. The stock is in large clumps of uniform housing with many unguarded, unsupervised and unused areas. It has a strong public stamp and too often a run down air that signifies lack of control or care. The basics - rubbish, graffiti, litter, security, repairs - have lower priority than the politics. Because residents do not generally vote for their council landlords, their voice is usually unheard.

The second problem is more difficult still. To become a council tenant, you queue, not knowing what home you will get or when or where. You can only choose to live near family or friends, to move when your home becomes too small or when you can afford an extra room, if you will accept the least popular estates. Thus we build social ghettos. Up to 19 out of 20 council offers are refused because housing is "allocated according to need", but not your needs. Hard pressed officials obey the strict rules that their local political bosses make in order to be "fair". They have turned a variable and personalised need into a rule-bound system to cope with the sheer volume of people and property - 300,000 new council lettings a year in England. People are voting with their feet.

Thus property and people problems are breaking up many estate communities. The ties, loyalties and links that help us to fit in and co-operate are disintegrating. Council housing, worth around £200bn, has become a political liability. At the very first opportunity, starting in 1986, local councils firmly took the initiative, and began to transfer their stock to newly created landlords with residents on the boards. Transfers attract large capital receipts, private loans to improve the homes and an overwhelming vote from tenants for more "street level" services.

For the first time tenants have a chance to vote directly for their future. About 70% of tenants turn out to vote - in sharp contrast with council elections. Nine out of 10 ballots have gone in favour of transfer. Of the 128 successful transfers, around 70% voted yes. It is the customer-orientated service and the prospect of solid repair that win support.

So far 102 local authorities have transferred nearly half a million homes. Most transfers involve around 5,000 homes. But the game is changing. In the last three years, around 50 large, run-down estates in cities, where social conditions are more extreme, have transferred to local housing companies. The new companies are local, small-scale, hands-on and strongly community focused. They offer a unique chance to change conditions on the ground.

At least 300,000 homes are in the pipeline this year, representing a landslide change in the attitude of "municipal fiefdoms". The government may see the total transfer of all council homes by 2010, planned or not.

But big is not beautiful. Birmingham and Glasgow are both planning to transfer all their stock, nearly 100,000 homes each, in one big lump. Large-scale demolitions are built in. Both cities and the government will have a fight on their hands under the present proposals. Glasgow has more tenant cooperatives and community-based housing associations than any city in the country. City leaders have so far rejected this successful model in favour of a city-wide trust, with the same stamp of gigantism and control as its council predecessor.

Birmingham also plans "a municipal housing trust" looking remarkably like the city council, bypassing the active housing associations engaged at community level. Funders may prefer less clumsy, more manageable, bite-sized bodies where innovation can drive a fresh start.

Councils have a vital political job, brokering the interests of complex and changing communities, ensuring basic order and good public services so that we can get on with our lives. Elected councillors ordering our places in the queue and running our poorest communities is no longer the only choice facing tenants.

 Anne Power is professor of social policy and deputy director of the Centre for Analysis of Social Exclusion at the London School of Economics, and is a member of the government's Urban Task Force. The National Tenants Resource Centre at Trafford Hall is running capacity building training for residents and front line staff with support from the DETR. Programme information is available from Nicky Gibbs, tel: 01244-300246.

fields.headline: Irving claims strong support
fields.trailText: An unrepentant David Irving today said he had received hundreds of supportive emails after suffering a humiliating high court libel defeat in which he was branded a racist.
fields.body:
An unrepentant David Irving today said he had received hundreds of supportive emails after suffering a humiliating high court libel defeat in which he was branded a racist.

"Over the last 24 hours or so since the judgment came out, I have had 322 emails from all over the world - I was up to 4am reading through them - from people who have read my books and saying: 'What on earth is going on here, Mr Irving?"'

Mr Irving spoke one day after his libel action against Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books ended ignominiously with the judge calling him an anti-Semite. He now faces financial ruin after seeing his credibility ripped to shreds.

Playing down Mr Irving's claims of support, Professor Lipstadt said: "You have to treat whatever he says with a tremendous grain of salt and a tremendous question mark. So I am not so worried about how many 'hits' he says he has got."

Despite his devastating courtroom defeat, Mr Irving insisted he did not regret his libel action. "I have no regrets. It's been the most exhausting phase of my life but I put up a good fight," he told the Times. "They wanted a scrap, so I gave them one."

Judge Charles Gray ruled that Prof Lipstadt was justified in branding Mr Irving a "Holocaust denier" and an associate of right-wing extremists who promote neo-Nazism. Mr Irving now faces a ruinous £2m legal bill. Penguin, owned by the Pearson media group, said it would "resolutely pursue the costs" incurred in their defence. But Mr Irving has said he simply did not have the money. "I have no doubt [the defendants] would drive me to bankruptcy," he said.

Mr Irving has dismissed any idea that he would be silenced by the verdict, although the media uniformly denounced him. The Sun, Britain's best-selling tabloid newspaper, said Irving had no place in a civilised society. "Irving is a disgrace to Britain," it said in an editorial.

webTitle: Government 'relieved' at fall in class sizes

fields.headline: Government 'relieved' at fall in class sizes
fields.standfirst: Education secretary David Blunkett promises end to oversize primary school classes by 2002
fields.trailText: Fewer than 180,000 infant school pupils remain in classes of more than 30 in English primary schools, official figures confirmed today.
fields.body:
Fewer than 180,000 infant school pupils remain in classes of more than 30 in English primary schools, official figures confirmed today.

The statistics are a relief to David Blunkett, the education secretary, who said that since the election, 300,000 children had benefited from smaller infant classes. He also announced a further £175m for cutting classes during the next year.

The government has set a target of removing oversize classes for five, six and seven-year-olds completely by 2002.

For the first time since the government announced it intended to remove oversized classes in primary schools, the average class size for older primary children has fallen marginally too, from 28.4 in January 1999 to 28.3. This January, there were 22,000 fewer eight to 11-year-old children in classes of over 30 than a year ago.

Mr Blunkett said today that the drop "gives the lie to the claim that lower infant class sizes are at the expense of older primary pupils".

Today's statistics show the number of infants in classes of over 30 halved from 356,586 in January 1999 to 177,020 this January.

Announcing the details today, Mr Blunkett also allocated a further £175 million for the year 2000/01 to continue the class size campaign.

By this September, Mr Blunkett said he expected there would be only around 50,000 infants in classes of more than 30, and none by September 2001.

In addition to smaller classes, an extra 20,000 teaching assistants were being employed, bringing the overall adult-child ratio in primary schools down from 19.5 last January to 19.0 this year, and down from 22.5 to 21.7 for eight to 11-year-olds.

All this, Mr Blunkett said, was being achieved without the predicted reduction in parental choice. Some 12,000 more pupils were getting their first choice of school, after the government put money behind expanding popular infant schools.

Today's figures also showed that the size of the average primary class fell for the second year running, from 27.5 to 27.1. There were also 1,800 more secondary school teachers in post.

However, a substantial increase in the number of secondary pupils meant a "marginal" increase in average secondary class sizes, to 22.0, although education minister Estelle Morris pointed to the extra cash allocated to secondary schools in last month's budget - up to £50,000 each for the biggest schools.

"The key thing is that the money is there for head teachers to decide how they spend it," she said. "They told us they wanted to be given the money and the power to spend it as they wish. That is what we are doing."

A list of the primary schools that will receive additional funding can be found here.

In addition to smaller classes, an extra 20,000 teaching assistants were being employed, bringing the overall adult-child ratio in primary schools down from 19.5 last January to 19.0 this year, and down from 22.5 to 21.7 for eight to 11-year-olds. All this, Mr Blunkett said, was being achieved without the predicted reduction in parental choice. Some 12,000 more pupils were getting their first choice of school, after the government put money behind expanding popular infant schools. Today's figures also showed that the size of the average primary class fell for the second year running, from 27.5 to 27.1. There were also 1,800 more secondary school teachers in post. However, a substantial increase in the number of secondary pupils meant a "marginal" increase in average secondary class sizes, to 22.0, although education minister Estelle Morris pointed to the extra cash allocated to secondary schools in last month's budget - up to £50,000 each for the biggest schools. "The key thing is that the money is there for head teachers to decide how they spend it," she said. "They told us they wanted to be given the money and the power to spend it as they wish. That is what we are doing." A list of the primary schools that will receive additional funding can be found here.

webTitle: Will cricket ever be the same again?

fields.headline: Will cricket ever be the same again?
fields.standfirst: Lawrence Booth reviews the press response to the Cronje scandal
fields.trailText: "Face of Shame" (The Sun), "Fear of God" (The Express), "Cricket in Crisis: The Cronje Affair" (The Times), "From hero to zero" (The Guardian). You name it, the headline-writers have penned it. And the nation's cricket correspondents have been having their say on the biggest scandal to rock the game since Bodyline in the 1930s.
fields.body:
"Face of Shame" (The Sun), "Fear of God" (The Express), "Cricket in Crisis: The Cronje Affair" (The Times), "From hero to zero" (The Guardian). You name it, the headline-writers have penned it. And the nation's cricket correspondents have been having their say on the biggest scandal to rock the game since Bodyline in the 1930s.

Michael Henderson of the Telegraph spoke for the vast majority of writers: "Hansie Cronje, a man of many fine qualities, has been humbled by the exposure of an all too human flaw and, having been brought low, he must suffer infamy for his moment of weakness." Ever keen to sprinkle his prose with high-brow allusions, Henderson turned to Shakespeare for a few words on the nature of corruption, quoting John O'Gaunt's warning to his nephew Richard II: "Things sweet to taste, prove indigestion sour." Not to be outdone, Hendo finished with a word of warning himself: "Yesterday was a desperately sour day for the game, and don't think there won't be a few more to come."

The Guardian's editorial drew a comparison with the World Series baseball scandal of 1919, when the Chicago White Sox deliberately lost to the Cincinnati Reds. It quoted the words of a young boy to his hero, Joe Jackson, one of the eight players involved in throwing the game. "Say it ain't so, Joe" remains a powerful expression of Innocence Lost, akin, said the Guardian, to the exposure of Cronje "as a liar".

Mike Walters of the Mirror painted the bigger picture, lamenting, "It will be remembered as the day cricket lost its soul." The Sun's John Etheridge was equally apocalyptic. "Hansie Cronje's reputation as a human being of honesty and integrity has fallen apart, in just 100 hours," he wailed. "It is one of the most anguished and damaging centuries in the game's history."

Mike Selvey, the Guardian's cricket correspondent, also began by implying that the game could never be the same again. "With the sacking of Hansie Cronje in South Africa yesterday, not just his reputation but that of cricket as a metaphor for all that is fair and true lies in tatters." Selvey went on, "Cricket has had its controversies...But nothing if all the allegations are proved, to rank with this."

In the Independent, Derek Pringle was one of many to ask the questions, "if a God-fearing man like Cronje can be tempted, who else is in the bookies' thrall?", and "why did a seemingly intelligent man, who apparently wanted for little financially or spiritually, risk all for such a modest sum?" Looking at the wider implications, Pringle noted that "people are reexamining England's victory in the Centurion Test, where Cronje set England a generous run-chase, after rain had appeared to have produced a certain draw."

Writing in the Comment & Analysis pages of the Guardian, Matthew Engel expressed surprise that Cronje was involved, but was completely underwhelmed by the news that cricket is more tainted than most people thought: "only a cricket administrator could have doubted that someone was going to be exposed sooner or later." The tone of Engel's piece was reminiscent of the broadsides against the game's authorities that made his editor's notes in Wisden Cricketers' Almanack such compulsive reading. "It's a morass", he wrote today, "and cricket is in up to its neck while pretending that its big toe is just getting a little mucky."

Peter Johnson of the Mail took a similar line. "Now the pretence is over," he thundered. "The downfall of Hansie Cronje leaves nowhere for the authorities to hide." His attack on the inactivity of the ICC was backed up by claims in the Independent by the former South African Test cricketer and current coach of Nottinghamshire Clive Rice that bribery and blackmail are rife in the world of cricket. Rice described the betting situation as "a festering sore."

But in the Telegraph, ex-Australian captain Ian Chappell pointed out that instances of foul play on the field were often hard to detect. "You could employ a panel of Sir Donald Bradman, Sir Garfield Sobers and Clyde Walcott at a game and I would defy them to detect a guy losing his wicket on purpose. There is simply no way you can prove it." Chappell added, "I commentated throughout the series in question [India v South Africa], and did not notice anything suspicious."

In the Times, Christopher Martin-Jenkins was one of the few not to express unreserved horror that a man of Cronje's religious background could have stooped so low. "It is not being wise after the event to say that there was always room for doubt about Cronje's stature as an exemplary and God-fearing leader of men," explained CMJ, "not least because of the sledging of South Africa's opponents on the field, which he did rather more than merely condone." But CMJ is nothing if not fair: "In his immediate defence it may be said that the phone call that Cronje made to Dr Ali Bacher in the darkest hour of the night, admitting his guilt up to a point, was the sign of a tormented soul wishing to make a clean breast of things rather than the reaction of one to whom wrongdoing was a habit."

In the Mail, Mike Dickson provided a fascinating insight into the changing attitude of Cronje over the last two years. "A man whose faith eschews the pursuit of material wealth has been found to be among the most vulnerable and, according to some who know him best, that can be traced back two years." The writing, it seems, may have been on the wall a while ago, in what Dickson called the "apparent elevation of Mammon over God." But Jim Holden of the Express maintained that Cronje's religious convictions never left him, saying that he "confessed his sporting sins to a church minister" before revealing all to Dr Ali Bacher.

Simon Hughes writing in the Telegraph did his best to follow what passed as Cronje's reasoning. "The top nations play a one-day match on average every 10 days (Mark Waugh, for example, played 36 last year) so it is hardly surprising if occasionally their desire and commitment appear to slip. One-day internationals are like the sun. Too much exposure tends to addle the brain."

But the overall tone was one of damnation and disillusion. Perhaps the best indicator of the effect of Cronje's actions came from a piece by John Perlman, reporting from Johannesburg for the Guardian: "One of the callers who finally got through the queue battling to get a word in on talk radio shows all over the country noted that Cronje had done some coaching at a local school. 'The kids are devastated,' he said. 'They say if Hansie isn't honest, who is?'" For the moment, it seems, no-one can be sure.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: New weapons finds: still too early to hope for justice

fields.headline: New weapons finds: still too early to hope for justice
fields.standfirst: The discovery of a knife and a metal bar at a house lived in by two of the original suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder must be treated with caution, writes the Guardian's crime correspondent, Nick Hopkins
fields.trailText: The discovery of a knife and a metal bar at a house lived in by two of the original suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder must be treated with caution, writes the Guardian's crime correspondent, Nick Hopkins.
fields.body:
On the face of it, the discovery of a knife and a metal bar at a former home of two of the original suspects in the Stephen Lawrence murder looks like a wonderful, opportunistic breakthrough. Detectives have inspected many knives but have never been satisfied that they have identified the weapon used in the racist killing. Duwayne Brooks, who was with Stephen when a gang attacked them in Eltham, south-east London, seven years ago, has said one of the thugs wielded a bar of some sort. None has ever been found. So far so good.

If forensic scientists can prove that the knife and the bar, which were found by the new owners of the house when they were digging up the patio, were the murder weapons, detectives at Scotland Yard may yet bring the killers to book.

They will also receive a great deal of carping over why the garden was not searched thoroughly before - a sweep by a metal detector would have pinpointed the location.

The Met might be on the verge of prosecutions - we all hope so, anyway - but there are reasons why the latest developments should be treated with a little caution.

The announcement of the discovery by Scotland Yard yesterday afternoon was the latest in a series of disclosures by officers from the racial and violent crimes task force, the unit investigating the murder.

They are gradually cranking up the pressure on the people they believe were behind Stephen's stabbing. Not just the suspects, but their friends and their ex-girlfriends. The yard knows the revelations will always make headline news.

These are legitimate tactics. In January, there was a fresh appeal for information on the BBC Crimewatch programme. A week later, assistant commissioner John Grieve hinted he was mining a significant seam of new information. Last month, there was another Crimewatch appeal. Mr Grieve spoke of the inquiry being at a "very, very delicate stage". The sense of anticipation rose to new heights when three men were arrested and questioned. But within 48-hours they were released without charge on police bail.

Now they have found a knife and a bar. Could either have incriminating fingerprints or DNA? Would the person who hid them not have had the sense to wipe them clean? The tests will tell us soon enough.

Until then, it is too early to hope that Doreen and Neville Lawrence are about to get justice for their son.

webTitle: Queen honours RUC with George Cross

fields.headline: Queen honours RUC with George Cross
fields.standfirst:
The Royal Ulster Constabulary has been awarded the George Cross in recognition of the 'terrible price' the force has paid during 30 years of the Troubles in Northern Ireland

RUC
fields.trailText: A police officer who lost both his legs in an IRA bomb attack received the George Cross from the Queen today on behalf of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.
fields.body:
A police officer who lost both his legs in an IRA bomb attack received the George Cross from the Queen today on behalf of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

The Queen and Prince Philip arrived at Hillsborough Castle accompanied by the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, and his deputy, Colin Cramphorn, amid tight security.

The award of the George Cross, in recognition of the bravery of the force during 30 years of the Troubles, is only the second time it has been made for collective gallantry. The people of Malta received the honour for their courage in withstanding German bombing during the second world war.

The Queen paid tribute to the "terrible price" paid by the RUC in its stand against terrorism. She said the award also recognised the courage of civilian officers and the armed forces.

"I want to take this opportunity to pay tribute to all members of the RUC, the regular officers of all ranks, the members of the full time and the part time reserve and former members who have served so loyally over the years," the Queen said.

"I salute your courage and sense of duty, I admire your determination to maintain the rule of law and provide a police service during some of the most difficult times in the history of this province.

"A terrible price has ben paid for this brave and resolute stand."

The fact that Northern Ireland was now a more peaceful and stable place to live was a tribute to the RUC, said the Queen, who said she looked forward to enmity being put aside while recognising the sacrifices of the past.

Accompanying Pc Paul Slaine to receive the award were the assistant chief constable, Bill Stewart, the longest serving chief officer in the force, and Constable Susan Wright, who joined RUC on 2 April.

Pc Slain's receipt of the George Cross on behalf of the RUC was intended to symbolise the sacrifices made by the force, which has lost 302 members to terrorist action.

He was injured in 1992 when a remote-controlled mortar was fired at an RUC patrol in Newry. A colleague, Colleen McMurray, 34, died in hospital after the attack. Pc Slaine is still a serving officer with the RUC.

Approximately 1,500 RUC officers and their families watched the ceremony. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, and the lord lieutenant of Co Down, William J Hall, were among the guests.

Mr Flanagan told the Queen: "I find it impossible to find words to adequately describe the deep sense of pride and honour that I and my officers, along with our civilian colleagues, families and friends, feel today." He thanked police and colleagues in the Irish Republic, throughout the UK for their support and added: "I would like to also pay a special tribute to our military colleagues whose selfless dedication and courage have been so freely given on behalf of all of the people of Northern Ireland."

Sir Ronnie said the RUC was now looking to "a new and exciting future" which would be built on the "wonderful foundations" laid by colleagues, past and present.

The decision to award the RUC the George Cross - at the same time as the government was preparing to implement policing reform proposals which will change the name, symbols and structure of the force - was controversial.

Unionist politicians, members of the RUC and the relatives of officers killed during the Troubles are angry at the proposal to change the force's name to the Police Service for Northern Ireland in an attempt to encourage more Roman Catholics and nationalists to join.

Republicans condemned the award as "offensive" to members of their community, who they say are not adequately represented in the force.

fields.headline: Spread betting
fields.standfirst: Hansie Cronje, South Africa's cricket team captain, has admitted receiving between £10,000 and £15,000 from an Indian bookmaker during a limited-over series with Zimbabwe and England. Mark Tran explains the world of spread betting and match fixing
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje, South Africa's cricket team captain, has admitted receiving between £10,000 and £15,000 from an Indian bookmaker during a limited-over series with Zimbabwe and England. Mark Tran explains the world of spread betting and match fixing.
fields.body:
What is spread betting?
Spread betting is the term for betting on any aspect of a particular game, rather than focusing only on who might win or lose the match. In cricket, you can bet on who will win the toss, how many runs the opening pair will make, how many catches, run-outs there will be and so on. The score of an individual batsman is a popular choice. There are internet sites, such as Sporting Index, which specialise in spread betting.

How does spread betting work?
Say a bookie predicts that a player will score between a spread of 76 and 80 runs. Punters confident that he will do better than that would "buy" him at 80, and make money for every extra run he scores. If he ends up scoring 120, the buyers would make 40 times their money. Punters who think he's going to have an off day would want to "sell" him at 76. So if he's out for a duck, the sellers would make 76 times their stake. A punter who "buys" a player at 80 would lose money if the player makes fewer than 76 runs, and a punter who "sells" at 76 would lose if the player exceeds 80 runs. In this particular scenario, it wouldn't take a whole team to fix a result. A player could decide to have an "off day" for a suitable reward and still see his side win.

Where is the centre of illegal bookmaking for cricket?
Bombay has emerged as the hub of illegal betting. It is estimated that one in every three mobile phone calls during a one-day cricket match is routinely connected with the gambling of millions of pounds. Details are never written on paper as bookmaking in India is outlawed.

When did betting on cricket become such a popular activity?
Cricket betting took off in the mid-eighties when India and Pakistan began to play one-day matches at Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates. It is now a way of life in the sub-continent. Former Pakistan skipper Wasim Akram wrote in his 1998 autobiography: "Cricket in India and Pakistan is now such a feverish, obsessive activity that if you lose a match you are blamed for also losing fortunes for people and ruining their lives."

Apart from Cronje, have other players been caught in betting activities?
Aussie stars Shane Warne and Mark Waugh were each fined A$2,500 in 1998 for providing pitch and team details to an Indian bookmaker during Australia's 1994 tour of Sri Lanka. Both players admitted to being "stupid and naive" for getting involved, but denied any involvement in match fixing. The relatively paltry fines may have acted as the green light for Cronje to provide "information and forecasting". Last year, former England all-rounder Chris Lewis claimed he was offered £300,000 to influence Alex Stewart and Alan Mullally to throw a match against New Zealand.

How serious is the Cronje affair for cricket?
Mike Selvey of the Guardian writes: "In uncovering this, the Indian police have succeeded in exposing what may prove to be the biggest scandal in cricket history and one of the biggest in sport anywhere." The International Cricket Council said: "Those who seek to tarnish the image of cricket in this manner must be brought to justice." The fear among cricket fans is that illegal bookies, armed with a fistful of money, can always find a player to tempt. That goes for other sports too.

Sporting Index
International Cricket Council

fields.headline: Rail watchdog will end bonus 'nonsense'
fields.standfirst: Audit office report finds Railtrack responsible for nearly half of all delays to passenger trains
fields.trailText: Rail regulator Tom Winsor today promised to put a stop to the "nonsense" of Railtrack receiving millions of pounds in bonuses after a damning national audit office report found the company responsible for deteriorating track standards and nearly half of train delays.
fields.body:
Rail regulator Tom Winsor today promised to put a stop to the "nonsense" of Railtrack receiving millions of pounds in bonuses after a damning national audit office report found the company responsible for deteriorating track standards and nearly half of train delays.

The NAO report found that between 1995 and 1999 Railtrack, received £139 million in performance bonuses, despite the condition of tracks declining since April 1994, when it took over the management of track, signalling and stations on the rail network from British Rail.

"The bonus system was set in place in 1995 and it cannot be changed until April 2001," said Mr Winsor, who took up his post in July last year.

"But as soon as I got in I started reviewing the whole bonus system, the entire financial structure of the railway industry, and I am going to put this right," he told the Today programme.

"The constraints on me are such that I cannot implement these decisions until April 2001, but you can be sure that from April 2001 these nonsenses are going to be swept away."

In a critical report, the NAO found that the number of broken rails had increased, and that Railtrack was responsible for nearly half of all delays to passenger trains. Most of these delays were the result of maintenance and renewal problems.

Railtrack faces fines both this year (1999-2000) and next (2000-01) unless it meets tough new train delay reduction targets set by Mr Winsor.

David Davis, chairman of the House of Commons public accounts committee, said: "Today's report shows how weak regulation has enabled Railtrack to earn substantial bonuses despite being responsible for half of delays to passenger trains and while at the same time the condition of the track is not up to 1994 levels."

It was "wholly unsatisfactory" that 3% of the track was now rated as "very poor".

Mr Davis added: "The whole system for awarding bonuses to Railtrack for these [train-delay] reductions is flawed."

The NAO said Mr Winsor's office of the rail regulator had had "difficulty in establishing how far Railtrack had discharged its obligation to maintain and renew the railway network properly".

The NAO report went on: "The information available to the ORR on the condition of Railtrack's assets remains incomplete.

"The ORR did not agree with Railtrack from the outset what work Railtrack would do in the period 1995-2001, or what would be achieved as a result of it, in terms, for example, of improved performance or asset condition."

NAO chief Sir John Bourn said: "The rail regulator needs to overcome the difficulties experienced up to now in monitoring Railtrack's performance and setting effective incentives.

"I therefore welcome the action he is taking to secure that Railtrack maintain, renew and improve the national railway network on which the public and industry depend."

The NAO recommended that the ORR should:

 Set out more clearly what it expected Railtrack to deliver from maintenance and renewal
 Set and keep to a timetable for removing deficiencies in its information on the condition of Railtrack's assets
 Ensure that key elements of the monitoring information that the ORR receives from Railtrack were independently verified
 Continue to develop appropriate targets and clearly predictable incentives for Railtrack to improve its performance on punctuality, cancellations and track condition.

webTitle: Post Office campaigners' Downing Street call

fields.headline: Post Office campaigners' Downing Street call
fields.trailText:
Post office campaigners have delivered a huge petition to Downing Street to 
back their demand for the rural network of sub-offices to be maintained.
fields.body:
Post office campaigners have delivered a huge petition to Downing Street to back their demand for the rural network of sub-offices to be maintained.

The petition, bearing a claimed 3.16 signatures is, they say, a measure of overwhelming public support for their cause.

Colin Baker, general secretary of the National Federation of Subpostmasters, said the petition was a clear demonstration of the way people feel about their local post offices. "Twenty eight million people use these offices every week. This is the biggest petition handed in since Mr Blair came in," he said.

Mr Baker warned that around 5000 local sub-offices - more than a quarter of the entire network - would close if the government goes ahead with its money-saving scheme to make benefit payments electronically into bank and building society accounts. At present, most benefits are collected over the counter at post offices, and subpostmasters and mistresses are paid to run the system.

The federation believes that the benefits account for 30% of a typical sub-office's trade. It wants the government to allow benefit recipients the choice of continuing to collect their money in person.

"Many of our customers live on the fringes of society. Their trips to the post office can be their only outing of the week. To force them into a banking system that doesn't want them, makes no sense," said Mr Baker.

The looming loss of benefits payments will hit rural areas hardest. In many smaller communities the sub-post office is the only retail outlet left, and though they supply a vital economic and social need, many of them are barely surviving as viable businesses.

Rural post office franchisees are now deeply concerned about their livelihoods. An NOP poll of rural subpostmasters for the Countryside Alliance shows that only 5% believe the government understands the value of village post offices.

webTitle: Uefa delay Leeds decision until Friday

fields.headline: Uefa delay Leeds decision until Friday
fields.standfirst: Full background
fields.trailText: Uefa have delayed a decision on whether to allow Galatasaray fans to travel to Elland Road for their club's Uefa Cup tie with Leeds until Friday.
fields.body:
Uefa have delayed a decision on whether to allow Galatasaray fans to travel to Elland Road for their club's Uefa Cup tie with Leeds until Friday.

In a statement released earlier today, Uefa said the delay was "to allow Uefa to receive and fully evaluate written submissions from both sides before making a decision".

Leeds asked Uefa to ban the Turkish club's fans from the second leg at Elland Road after two Leeds fans were killed in Istanbul before last week's first leg.

Submissions have been received from Leeds, the Football Association and the relevant local and national security authorities, and Galatasaray will now be allowed to respond and give their view.

Only after Galatasaray's report has been submitted will Uefa make a decision on whether the tie should be switched to a neutral venue.

A Uefa spokesman revealed: "We have to wait for Galatasaray's report before making a decision. But Ridsdale's view will also be taken into consideration. It's how the Uefa Cup works. There is one away leg and one home leg. It will be taken into account."

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale hinted strongly this morning that the Yorkshire club might pull out of the competition should the second-leg tie be moved away from Elland Road. "The position is that if we are told to play the game on a neutral ground we would have to consider our position with regard to further participation in the competition," he said on talkSPORT.

Ridsdale also stated that several of his young players received death threats in their hotel rooms in the hours after Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight had been murdered.

Despite asking for no calls to be put through to the rooms, Leeds players picked up the telephones to be confronted with abuse and death threats.

"The team were in no fit mental state to play the first tie", said Ridsdale. "They were understandably shaken up by, among other things, receiving death threat phone-calls to their rooms in the early hours of the morning even though we had asked for no calls to be put through.

"Normally you can laugh that sort of thing off but on this occasion it was anything but funny."

webTitle: Uefa set to back Leeds ban

fields.headline: Uefa set to back Leeds ban
fields.standfirst: Full background
fields.trailText: Leeds United were confident last night that their campaign to have Galatasaray supporters banned from the Uefa Cup semi-final second leg at Elland Road had been successful.
fields.body:
Leeds United were confident last night that their campaign to have Galatasaray supporters banned from the Uefa Cup semi-final second leg at Elland Road had been successful.

An announcement is expected from Uefa this afternoon and the indications are that Galatasaray will be ordered to return their allocation of 1,700 tickets after the death of two Leeds supporters in Istanbul last Wednesday.

High-ranking officials from the European governing body have acknowledged they would be risking a huge backlash if they refused to sanction a ban against the wishes of Leeds, the West Yorkshire police and the Football Association.

A report from Elland Road was dispatched to Uefa headquarters yesterday to emphasise the club's position, along with statements from the police detailing their fears about of reprisals if the request were refused.

They have argued it would be better to play the game behind closed doors than risk further bloodshed by allowing in fans of the Istanbul club. The matter would appear to hinge on whether Uefa endorses Galatasaray's claim that a ban on away fans would give Leeds an unfair advantage as they try to overhaul a 2-0 deficit.

Inflammatory messages from both sets of supporters have appeared on the internet

"I have every confidence Uefa will recognise that from a safety perspective the best decision is to make sure the game goes ahead without Turkish supporters," said Leeds's chairman Peter Ridsdale. "I'm confident that if they understand we have made our request on safety grounds alone, it is the only decision that makes sense."

Galatasaray's president Frank Suren yesterday backed away from earlier threats to boycott the match. "While we think it is unfair that Turkish supporters should not be allowed to travel, we will come and play without our supporters if that is what Uefa decides," he said.

He added that there was no question of asking for the match to be played at a neutral venue or seeking to overturn a ban in the European Court of Human Rights. "People have criticised us in England but all I would ask is that Uefa and Leeds can guarantee the security of the team before, during and after the match." Five Turks have been charged in connection with the murders.

Leeds United's success has been reflected in a 65% increase in profits at the end of last year with a turnover of £29.3m. The club's parent company, Leeds Sporting plc, reported an operating profit before transfer fees of £6.4m.

 The European Union commissioner for education and culture Viviane Reding will warn Sepp Blatter and Lennart Johansson not to expect changes to the Bosman ruling when she meets the Fifa and Uefa presidents in Strasbourg today. "The Bosman ruling has been based on the free movement of people and nondiscrimination. You cannot overrule a court ruling. That is the principle," she said.

fields.headline: The Darth arts
fields.standfirst: From an overweight wookie to a very hirsute Yoda, prepare to see some of the 20th century's greatest cinema icons in a bizarre new light.  Nick De Cosemo  on the Barbican's stunning Art Of Star Wars show
fields.trailText: From an overweight wookie to a very hirsute Yoda, prepare to see some of the 20th century's greatest cinema icons in a bizarre new light. Nick De Cosemo on the Barbican's stunning Art Of Star Wars show
fields.body:
A long time ago, in a graphics studio far, far away, a bearded auteur gave a Boeing aeronautical illustrator a script. The auteur in question was George Lucas. The script, Star Wars: A New Hope. The artist was Ralph McQuarrie, who'd just been commissioned to create a set of images depicting the key elements of Lucas's proposed space odyssey.

What he came up with was a selection of paintings showing light sabre duels, TIE-fighter dog fights and a certain galactic bad ass with a dark cape and helmet. In short, the foundations of what were to become some of the most enduring icons of the 20th century.

The Art Of Star Wars exhibition at the Barbican Centre aims to explore the artistic lineage of the Star Wars phenomenon. And give dads a chance to spend hours drooling over little models with the excuse that they're here with the kids.

"It's an explanation of the whole film-making process", says Conrad Bodman, the exhibition's curator. "Star Wars isn't just one man, it's about a whole team of creative people collaborating together. It reveals the careers of the artists involved in these movies."

As well as McQuarrie's conceptual drawings from the original trilogy, it includes models from all four films, costumes, artwork by Phantom Menace illustrator Doug Chiang, sound and visual effects installations, and much more - basically a Star Wars fan's wet dream. But will it fire the blasters of those with whom the force is not so strong?

"It's important for us at the Barbican to put on popular exhibitions," continues Conrad, "attracting a broad selection of the public and not be elitist about what art galleries are. There's also a lot for a traditional audience. If you were into costume design for instance there's a lot to see."

Costumes on display include original Chewbacca, Han Solo, Boba Fett, Princess Amidala and Darth Maul. A whole room is given over to celebrate Darth Vader's cosmic nastiness (complete with freaky lighting and asthmatic sound effects) and you can discover how the sound of a light sabre was created (the noise of broken fan and TV spliced together).

Elsewhere you can see how Huttese, the language of Jabba The Hutt was composed and how Jar Jar Binks came to full CGI life (no doubt annoying many die-hard fans, who still seethe at the sight of the digital roll mop). The array of models on display - including a Star Destroyer, Speeder bike, TIE fighters and Luke's landspeeder (strangely piloted by a Steve Austin doll with a GI Joe as passenger) - is very impressive, and illustrates that even in these times of computer-generated effects, there is still a need for traditional models. A fact born out by the model for The Phantom Menace's pod-racing arena. The crowd was made up from different coloured cotton wool buds and a hair dryer was moved to emulate crowd movement.

It's interesting to see how the characters developed from the page to the screen. There's an early drawing of Yoda with long hair where he looks something akin to a Grateful Dead roadie. Similarly an initial "Fat Chewbacca" sketch shows the Wookie during his Las Vegas cheeseburger years, before he slimmed down and made the transition to celluloid.

All the exhibits come from the archive at Lucas's home, Skywalker Ranch, just outside San Francisco. Each was signed off by the man himself. On some of the early sketches you can see where he stamped "wonderful" on illustrations he liked.

It's because of Lucas's care in preserving these pieces that the exhibition exists. This meticulous love for the Star Wars universe is something its creator shares with most of his fans. And there lies the key to the exhibition.

Star Wars fans consume the most minute titbits of info with fanatical zeal. Just look at the advance queuing that accompanied the launch of Episode One. And while it's doubtful there'll be a repeat of those scenes here (a shame, when you picture the image of patrons leaving a London Symphony Orchestra recital and tripping over Darth Maul sleeping rough) there are many to whom this will be a near-religious experience.

If you're one of the chosen, great. If not, then maybe this is not the exhibition you are looking for. Nevertheless, this behind-the-scenes look into the world of Luke, Chewie, Jar Jar and co could be enough to seduce you to the dark side of Star Wars obsession. Proceed with caution young padawan - you'll be swinging a pretend light sabre over your head and mimicking the sound of a broken fan and TV spliced together before you know it.

 The Art Of Star Wars exhibition runs from tomorrow until September 3. Admission: £10 adults; £6.50 children. Further information from 0171-638 8891 and at: www.theartofstarwars.co.uk

webTitle: Illingworth asked to throw England World Cup match

fields.headline: Illingworth asked to throw England World Cup match
fields.trailText: Former England chairman of selectors Ray Illingworth has revealed how he was once asked to throw a World Cup match between England and Pakistan. The admission follows the current scandal surrounding South Africa skipper Hansie Cronje.
fields.body:
Former England chairman of selectors Ray Illingworth has revealed how he was once asked to throw a World Cup match between England and Pakistan. The admission follows the current scandal surrounding South Africa skipper Hansie Cronje.

Illingworth writes in the Daily Mail: "I was offered money by a Pakistani to 'throw' our match against them in Karachi when I was manager of the England cricket team in the 1996 World Cup. I have never revealed this before and I only do so now to show how much so-called easy money is on offer in that part of the world.

"Frankly, Hansie Cronje's confession of dishonesty has destroyed my faith in human nature. For a man so devoted to cricket to succumb to such a temptation is very sad. But I know from personal experience how insistent and insidious the pressure can be.

"I was in my hotel room on that day in 1996 when the man rang and asked me to fix the match. Fortunately, I was not alone and could produce a witness if one was ever necessary. No sum was mentioned because the conversation never got as far as that. I told him I wasn't interested and next morning reported the incident to the Indian umpire Srini Venkat."

Illingworth admitted that he could see how some players fall prey to the match-riggers, but could not forgive Cronje for becoming embroiled in such an affair. "Nowadays there are so many offers floating around in that part of the world - hundreds and thousands of pounds are involved - that it doesn't surprise me when somebody is tempted," said Illingworth.

"What did stagger me was that Hansie has obviously become involved in some way. He is a wealthy man in his own right and having talked to him I know that he loves playing the game.

"Judging by the amount he has received - it's peanuts by the bookies standards - he has only been guilty of passing on hints like weather and pitch conditions. I don't even agree with doing that, although it could hardly be called betraying your side.

"After what happened to Shane Warne and Mark Waugh with Australia, I'm amazed that Hansie would even get involved in something like that."

Illingworth concluded by insisting that the ICC must take a tough stance over match-fixing in the future. "So far, players have only been found guilty of passing on snippets of information," he said. "Nobody has been accused of match-fixing. If it happens cricket should have no hesitation in banning the culprit for life. The game that once stood for fair play has lost its good name."

I have never revealed this before and I only do so now to show how much so-called easy money is on offer in that part of the world. "Frankly, Hansie Cronje's confession of dishonesty has destroyed my faith in human nature. For a man so devoted to cricket to succumb to such a temptation is very sad. But I know from personal experience how insistent and insidious the pressure can be. "I was in my hotel room on that day in 1996 when the man rang and asked me to fix the match. Fortunately, I was not alone and could produce a witness if one was ever necessary. No sum was mentioned because the conversation never got as far as that. I told him I wasn't interested and next morning reported the incident to the Indian umpire Srini Venkat." Illingworth admitted that he could see how some players fall prey to the match-riggers, but could not forgive Cronje for becoming embroiled in such an affair. "Nowadays there are so many offers floating around in that part of the world - hundreds and thousands of pounds are involved - that it doesn't surprise me when somebody is tempted," said Illingworth. "What did stagger me was that Hansie has obviously become involved in some way. He is a wealthy man in his own right and having talked to him I know that he loves playing the game. "Judging by the amount he has received - it's peanuts by the bookies standards - he has only been guilty of passing on hints like weather and pitch conditions. I don't even agree with doing that, although it could hardly be called betraying your side. "After what happened to Shane Warne and Mark Waugh with Australia, I'm amazed that Hansie would even get involved in something like that." Illingworth concluded by insisting that the ICC must take a tough stance over match-fixing in the future. "So far, players have only been found guilty of passing on snippets of information," he said. "Nobody has been accused of match-fixing. If it happens cricket should have no hesitation in banning the culprit for life. The game that once stood for fair play has lost its good name."

fields.standfirst: The Hole

fields.body:
Only two years after it was made, Tsai Ming-Liang's The Hole looks like a film very much of its time. Not that it's dated: it's just very specifically of its moment - the final two years of the 20th century. It belongs to a small, specialised genre, the late-90s millennium film, although it has precious little to do with bombastic Hollywood cash-ins like End of Days or Deep Impact (if ever a film was misnamed...).

The Hole is finally getting a limited London release, at least four months too late. But don't think April 2000 is too late to see a millennium movie - this one's for posterity. The film begins with the news announcement that, with seven days to go until the new year, a mystery virus is sweeping Taiwan: Taipei is being evacuated, the water is contaminated and will soon be cut off entirely. Plus there's trouble with the plumbing.

While torrential rain pelts down outside, a young man (Tsai's regular star Lee Kang-Sheng) gets a visit from the plumber. The flat downstairs has water leaking through, but it won't take a second to fix. Next thing you know, the woman downstairs (Yang Kuei-Mei) not only has water gushing down her walls, but also a hole in her ceiling. She goes about her daily life, mainly occupied with stockpiling toilet paper, suffering occasional interruptions from the man upstairs: cascades of plaster and the occasional stream of vomit. She retaliates by blasting him in the eye with her aerosol.

The situation is ripe with resonances: images of voyeurism, Freudian echoes of penetration by broom handles and umbrellas. But strange manifestations are also occurring on the corridors and stairways of the crumbling apartment block. The woman reappears in the lift as a chanteuse in red feathers, singing a swishy calypso number; she later returns with three backing singers to warn the man in her life (and here the subtitles come into their own): "Stop calling me a tiger lady/You're not a perfect hubby/You're penniless and you're a jealous sod/What a useless fool you are."

On one hand, The Hole gives us a grim depiction of social breakdown; on the other, a joyously lurid tribute to the popular 50s/60s Hong Kong chanteuse Grace Chang, whose original hits these all are. The contrast is unnerving between the light, peppy staging of the dances, and the slow, sombre treatment of the rest: long takes, hardly any dialogue, a constant sound of falling rain. But this kitchen-sink apocalypse is portrayed with poker-faced humour. In one scene, the man slips his bare leg through the hole and wobbles about uncomfortably for a bit, as if he's had it amputated. Downstairs, we see his leg dangling from the ceiling; the woman walks past, but doesn't see it. Then, just as she's about to spot it, the leg slowly, delicately extricates itself and vanishes.

Plumbing problems have been a constant in Tsai's work since Rebels of the Neon God (1992). Leaky ceilings also featured in The River (1997), in which a young man developed a mystery illness after working as a film extra, playing a corpse floating in a river. In The Hole, body and apartment are both fatally porous, open to every ill that can seep in from the outside world - an anxiety that, Tsai has explained, has much to do with the everyday experiences of pollution and political instability in Taiwan.

But the film also has theatrical echoes - the two flats could be settings from an absurdist playwright such as Eugène Ionesco or the British writer NF Simpson, whose own 1957 play The Hole had a group of characters peering into just such a mysterious cavity. As a former dramatist and stage director, this was very much the world that Tsai inhabited: the best-known of his own claustrophobic plays featured a dialogue between a man and a wardrobe.

The Hole is rivetingly mysterious, right up to its ambivalent closing shots. Tsai Ming-Liang signs off with a note: "In the year 2000, we are grateful that we still have Grace Chang's songs to comfort us." But then this is the same man who declared: "I am a pessimist and have no optimistic thoughts about the future." People can always take refuge in the deathless, cheery old songs; but those songs can never do justice to, or dispel, life's horrific realities. Tsai Ming-Liang, in fact, has come remarkably close to Dennis Potter here. The Hole's message may be that every time it rains, it rains pennies from heaven - well, perhaps - but it still buckets it down.

 The Hole is at the ICA, London SW1 (0171-930 3647) from Friday till April 27.

fields.headline: No: 1613 Peter Kindersley
fields.body:
Age: 58.

Occupation: Farmer.

Looks pretty happy for a farmer. He's only just become a full-time farmer. He used to be a millionaire publisher.

In that case, he looks extremely happy. What happened to the publishing? He was forced to sell Dorling Kindersley, the company he co-founded, to the media group Pearson after losing $40m in the last year.

So that's what happened to his millions. Well, no. He personally made £100m from the sale. It's just that he wants to give most of it away.

To starving journalists typing away in their garrets? Unlucky. More like underprivileged children and the environment.

It's no wonder he had to sell the company if he keeps giving money away. His loss of DK was down to more otherworldly forces, alas.

Explain? He was menaced by the phantom, mauled by Darth. The force was decidedly not with him.

I'm lost. So was Kindersley. His company got rather carried away in the hype for last year's Star Wars epic, the Phantom Menace, overestimating on a galactic scale the demand for merchandise. It made 13m books, but sold only 3m.

And the remaining 10m? Lost in space, along with the £25m they represented to the company.

Bet he felt like a bit of a Wookie. "I will never understand what led to that decision," he said.

Makes you wonder how he built up such a big company. That's easy. Illustrated books.

Oh, like the Mr Men? No, like the Joy of Sex. The 70s classic was helped to its phenomenal success by the use of illustrations, which became Dorling Kindersley's trademark. There is, however, no evidence that the book's famously hirsute protagonist was the inspiration for the Ewoks in Return of the Jedi.

Underprivileged children say: "We can feel your presents!"

Pearson's management say: "We are here to save you!"

Dorling Kindersley's shareholders say: "Can you feel the farce?"

fields.standfirst: Our daily guide to everything that isn't true
fields.trailText: The Mirror Sir Alex Ferguson has his eye on bringing another high-profile goalkeeper to Old Trafford this summer - Aston Villa's David James. In what would be an extraordinary deal, James would move to United in exchange for former Villa keeper, and current United number one, Mark Bosnich.
fields.body:
The Mirror Sir Alex Ferguson has his eye on bringing another high-profile goalkeeper to Old Trafford this summer - Aston Villa's David James. In what would be an extraordinary deal, James would move to United in exchange for former Villa keeper, and current United number one, Mark Bosnich.

Wimbledon boss Egil Olsen is planning a mass clear out at the club this summer. Robbie Earle, Jason Euell, Ben Thatcher, John Hartson and Michael Hughes are all set to leave. "I will be selling some players and allowing others to move in because things have to change", Olsen said.

Planet football Celtic chief Allan McDonald has travelled to Spain to open talks with Real Betis coach Guus Hiddink. Hiddink coached the Dutch national side in France 98, but subsequently spent an unhappy six months at Real Madrid.

The Express West Ham are on the verge of signing on-loan French striker Frederic Kanoute for £3.5m. Harry Redknapp is also closely monitoring Davor Suker and Teddy Sheringham - and could bid for both this summer.

The Star Nicky Summerbee is on the way out of Sunderland and heading for Celtic in a £2m move.

Teamtalk Newcastle have joined Coventry in the hunt for Espanyol's Romanian international midfielder Constantin Galca. Galca's contract with the Primera Liga side expires in the summer.
