webTitle: US libel trial to test net's immunity

fields.headline: US libel trial to test net's immunity
fields.trailText: A libel case with major implications for what can be published on the internet is due to go to trial in San Francisco today. At stake is how far scurrilous websites should be protected from the libel laws.
fields.body:
A libel case with major implications for what can be published on the internet is due to go to trial in San Francisco today. At stake is how far scurrilous websites should be protected from the libel laws.

The precedent-setting test case involves an English professor, Daniel Curzon Brown, who teaches at the City College in San Francisco. Since 1997, a website has operated which allowed students at the college to post anonymous reviews of their teachers. The reviews include a "bottom 10" of the teachers who have received the most negative reviews. Prof Brown ranks fifth on that list.

Most of the 1,700 teaching staff at the college have learned to ignore the rude comments, or avoid the website itself. But Prof Brown, who is gay and a published author, has been the subject of some particularly vicious, anonymous attacks and has decided that he can no longer allow them to be posted with impunity.

The professor is described on the site as "homomanic, racist and mentally ill", all of which he vehemently denies. He has described the attacks as "evil" and says he does not understand how anyone can justify them.

As a result, he has brought a lawsuit against the operator of the website, Ryan Lathouwers, which is due to start today at the city's superior court.

Prof Brown, who has been teaching at the college for 20 years, said that the attacks had made him "depressed and afraid" and says that it is time to challenge the idea that the internet is "holy" and somehow above the law.

Mr Lathouwers, whose website contains a disclaimer about the views expressed, is fighting the case and has the support of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), which is anxious to uphold the first amendment's protection of free speech and fearful of what a libel victory might bring to the internet industry.

A spokeswoman for the ACLU, which has had to defend the views of racist groups on similar first amendment grounds, says that free speech means "that sometimes feelings get hurt".

Its position is that the value of preserving free speech outweighs hurt feelings.

The college itself is unwilling to try to have the site closed, also on first amendment grounds.

The case has many parallels with that of Demon Internet in the UK, which recently agreed to pay £15,000 in damages to a physicist who claimed he had been defamed by two anonymous postings on the net. The case appeared to establish that internet providers in the UK are subject to the same libel laws as other media.

In the US, where the libel laws are much less powerful than in the UK, the internet receives protection under the 1996 Communications Decency Act, which essentially allows the internet service provider immunity from the libel laws.

Victory for Prof Brown would send providers scurrying to their sites, some of which contain graphic and unsubstantiated libels.

The action has provoked further action on the website (teacherreview.com) with former students of Prof Brown weighing in on both sides of the argument.

One anonymous contributor attacks both Prof Brown and the attacker who called him "homomanic" saying: "his [Brown's] being a horrible instructor has nothing to do with his personal life".

webTitle: A small boy bails out the old dictator

fields.headline: A small boy bails out the old dictator
fields.standfirst:
Elian's 'kidnapping' is a magic pill for Castro's suffering citizens
More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The people who have been holding their children over the fence of that house in Miami in the belief that the six-year-old shipwrecked boy, Elian Gonzales, has magical healing powers, are acting no more oddly than many others in the Elian affair.
fields.body:
The people who have been holding their children over the fence of that house in Miami in the belief that the six-year-old shipwrecked boy, Elian Gonzales, has magical healing powers, are acting no more oddly than many others in the Elian affair.

His Miami relatives, die-hard anti-Castro Cubans, seem to think that Elian has magic powers that will change the laws of the United States - and even the laws of decent behaviour - to permit them to stop the child's father from claiming him.

George W Bush seems to think that Elian's magic powers will allow him to support the child's relatives in this absurd proposition and gain votes by it.

Even less creditably, so does Al Gore, who broke with what has been the reasonable position of the Clinton administration - that US law and the rights of this little family should prevail over the opportunity to make political capital out of a six-year-old's tragedy.

Meanwhile, back in Havana, Fidel Castro must be even more convinced of Elian's magic powers.

After all, he has provided Castro with a cause that - even at this late stage in history - has enabled him to rally millions to his side in defiance, yet again, of their bullying neighbour.

Never mind that a third of the island might prefer to be living in the US, and the equivalent of another third already is.

The effective kidnapping of Elian has proved a magic reviving pill for the jaded indignation of Castro's suffering citizens.

When the boy was exhibited on US television talking about his dead mother, Castro could rightly denounce it as an abuse.

When a raft of congressmen, with an eye to Miami votes in this election year, declined to insist that the boy be returned to his father and instead lined up in his diminutive shadow and claimed they were protecting his "freedom", Castro could mock them without fear of contradiction.

Elian's freedom, by this code, does not appear to include the freedom to be reunited with his surviving parent because, these congressmen say, Elian should not be returned to the "jail" that is Castro's Cuba.

This is nonsense. Cuba may not be a model of freedom but nor is it a prison. Most of its children still get a better deal, impoverished though their country is since the collapse of the Soviet Union, than children in the US's client states elsewhere in Latin America.

Children in Cuba have, on the whole, had the luxury of eating, sleeping, attending decent schools and living beyond their fifth birthday, which is more than many can do in Brazil or Peru. It's not six-year-olds who see Cuba as a prison, though it would not be hard to find an adolescent who did. Since Cuba's economic collapse, it's hard to make an honest living and the economy has steadily submitted to the power of the dollar.

It makes a mockery of ambition and self-respect and heroic efforts are required to keep teenagers on the rails. It's not wise to complain, though. Cuba is still a place where you are wise to keep your political thoughts to yourself.

But Castro is ageing and Cuba is changing. By the time Elian grows up, it will have changed beyond recognition. If the boy wants to leave then, it's more likely he will have more trouble getting a US entry visa than a legal Cuban exit permit.

Every year, Cuba grows more open and accessible; every year, increased contact creates new possibilities for a peaceful transition to a post-Castro Cuba.

That, of course, is not what Miami's revanchists want. They are after blood and revenge, not constructive engagement, and for more than 40 years they have made a nonsense out of US foreign policy.

If the Helsinki process helped bring about the collapse of the Berlin wall, where is the Helsinki process for Cuba - a much smaller and easier target for a charm offensive?

Any thought of such a process is strangled at birth by the Cuban American Foundation - an outcome that delights no one more than Castro.

His brand of government always needs an enemy and thrives on confrontation. If the US were to lift the embargo against Cuba tomorrow, who would Castro be able to blame for the state of the Cuban economy, the lack of telephones, the pot-holed roads and the crumbling buildings?

If there was no external threat, how many of the crowd demonstrating for Elian's return would be demonstrating instead for religious freedoms or political change.

Each time the US allows Miami to dictate policy, it guarantees Castro another few years of security and his people another few years of painful uncertainty.

Elian's relatives spent much of Sunday on television talk shows arguing, with no evidence, that Elian's father - who has now arrived in the US to try to bring this circus to an end - is not fit to bring up his own child.

The courts have ruled he must go back and now it should only be a matter of how to arrange it with the least upset for the child. The game is up, but they won't face up to it.

The game is up, too, for a cold war confrontation that is nothing more than a ridiculous anachronism at the beginning of the 21st century.

fields.headline: André Deutsch
fields.standfirst: Idiosyncratic publisher who enlivened a staid British profession with an outsider's flair, charm and insight
fields.trailText: André Deutsch, who has died aged 82, belonged to a breed of publishers that existed, and occasionally flourished, before accountants and computers took over - in an age when publishers were entrepreneurs of the imagination, seeking quality, proud of the influence and longevity of their discoveries, exultant if lucky enough to be associated with a genius.
fields.body:
André Deutsch, who has died aged 82, belonged to a breed of publishers that existed, and occasionally flourished, before accountants and computers took over - in an age when publishers were entrepreneurs of the imagination, seeking quality, proud of the influence and longevity of their discoveries, exultant if lucky enough to be associated with a genius.

He frequently came up with surprises during crises. His quite frequent mistakes stemmed from his being, as a foreigner, never quite sure of his status in the eyes of others.

He was swimming in a sea with different currents from those to be found in European publishing, with its respectful gravity - in contrast to the insular, post-war British scene, with its tendency to frivolity.

He was quick to sense a slight, suspicious with strangers, and unable to conceal a certain arrogance toward those less quick-witted than himself.

Born in Budapest, Deutsch was educated there and in Vienna. With the Anschluss, and because he was Jewish, he left for Zürich, where he had an uncle who eventually helped him get to England.

At the outbreak of the second world war, he was interned on the Isle of Man as an enemy alien, and a meeting there with a European publisher persuaded him to enter the profession.

When released in 1942, he went to work for Nicholson and Watson, transferred to the technical book and trade journal publisher Ernest Benn, where he became sales manager, and started his own company, Allan Wingate, in 1945.

He was backed by private investors and, having underestimated his capital needs, kept bringing new members on to the board. These tended to be public school or bridge party types, contemptuous of Deutsch's accented English and East European background. Anthony Gibb, son of historian Sir Philip, became chairman and, having his own publishing ambitions, ousted him.

In 1951, with help and advice from Stanley Rubinstein, the publishing solicitor, he started André Deutsch Ltd. At Wingate's, he had successfully published his compatriot George Mikes's light-hearted satire on the English, How To Be An Alien, with illustrations by Nicholas Bentley; the former remained with him as an author, the latter as a board member. Diana Athill joined as general editorial and managerial assistant.

Deutsch's big break came with the von Papen Memoirs, the diary of Hitler's most able diplomat, and he sold serial rights to a Sunday newspaper for £30,000, which made it a bestseller. He followed with other books from Germany, - he had a great advantage over his monoglot English rivals - but received some criticism for his willingness to publish books by Britain's recent enemy.

At the Frankfurt Book Fair he was a star, the British publisher that Europeans knew best. The prestige went to his head and he undertook to publish in English the official biography of the German President Theodor Heuss, who was unknown outside Germany. The president visited his stand at the fair, but the British sales were only to a few libraries.

Needing some bestsellers, Deutsch began to look to America, where refugees like himself were numerous in New York publishing, and came up with Norman Mailer's The Naked And The Dead, a soldier's account of the Korean War; what made it sell, however, was the soldier's expletive - printed throughout, however, as "fug".

American authors dominated the list for the next two decades, many of them becoming contemporary classics. At one point, again in financial difficulties, Deutsch sold himself out to Time-Life Books, with a contract to stay on as publisher, but the arrangement did not work and he bought himself out again.

When he felt the time had come to retire (and the 1980s were not a happy time for independent publishers, with the banks increasingly unhelpful), he accepted an offer from Tom Rosenthal. Deutsch expected to remain as a consultant, but soon found his presence was not welcome.

Deutsch never married, but had a close relationship with a sympathetic lady for many years. His main relaxation was skiing, until age and illness made it no longer possible. He received the OBE in 1989.

Frank Keating writes:
Dear André. Think of a mid-European leprechaun and you've got the picture. He was already well into his 50s when he published my first two books. They were about cricket, of which he knew nothing, but he read the Guardian and had heard of Ian Botham.

The paper would pay my hotel bills for daily reports on England's 1980 tour of the West Indies, and André would stump up all travel expenses for the main wheeze - a spoof, ghosted autobiography by an imagined 17th member of the England party called Desmond (ie me), who would spill the beans on the tour.

The day before we left, André gave me my "expenses" - in the form of copies of personal letters he had already sent to, among others, Eric Williams, Forbes Burnham and Michael Manley, former black movement student authors of his, now prime ministers of respectively Trinidad, Guyana, and Jamaica.

I feared the worst publisher's double-cross. Not a bit of it. From day one in Trinidad, chauffeured cars were at my disposal, and the odd private plane. In return, I was fast into my stride with Another Bloody Day In Paradise - till the tour began to fall apart with the team being thrown out of Guyana on the back of South African apartheid and the death of England's manager Ken Barrington. Back home, André panicked. "Drop Desmond and play it straight," he wired.

Twelve months later, with another England team, this time in India, a beaming André arrived with some 30-odd copies of ABD in P and arranged a "launch" party at the pricey Taj Mahal in Bombay. When the time came to leave, a week or so later, all party charges had been referred to my bill - and dear old André was back in London.

But I loved him. I last saw him a couple of years ago, looking sad, hunched, lonely. "We should really do that spoof tour book again," he said - and his leprechaun's eyes were glistening with pleasure and anticipation once again.

André Deutsch, publisher, born November 15 1917; died April 10 2000.

Born in Budapest, Deutsch was educated there and in Vienna. With the Anschluss, and because he was Jewish, he left for Zürich, where he had an uncle who eventually helped him get to England. At the outbreak of the second world war, he was interned on the Isle of Man as an enemy alien, and a meeting there with a European publisher persuaded him to enter the profession. When released in 1942, he went to work for Nicholson and Watson, transferred to the technical book and trade journal publisher Ernest Benn, where he became sales manager, and started his own company, Allan Wingate, in 1945. He was backed by private investors and, having underestimated his capital needs, kept bringing new members on to the board. These tended to be public school or bridge party types, contemptuous of Deutsch's accented English and East European background. Anthony Gibb, son of historian Sir Philip, became chairman and, having his own publishing ambitions, ousted him. In 1951, with help and advice from Stanley Rubinstein, the publishing solicitor, he started André Deutsch Ltd. At Wingate's, he had successfully published his compatriot George Mikes's light-hearted satire on the English, How To Be An Alien, with illustrations by Nicholas Bentley; the former remained with him as an author, the latter as a board member. Diana Athill joined as general editorial and managerial assistant. Deutsch's big break came with the von Papen Memoirs, the diary of Hitler's most able diplomat, and he sold serial rights to a Sunday newspaper for £30,000, which made it a bestseller. He followed with other books from Germany, - he had a great advantage over his monoglot English rivals - but received some criticism for his willingness to publish books by Britain's recent enemy. At the Frankfurt Book Fair he was a star, the British publisher that Europeans knew best. The prestige went to his head and he undertook to publish in English the official biography of the German President Theodor Heuss, who was unknown outside Germany. The president visited his stand at the fair, but the British sales were only to a few libraries. Needing some bestsellers, Deutsch began to look to America, where refugees like himself were numerous in New York publishing, and came up with Norman Mailer's The Naked And The Dead, a soldier's account of the Korean War; what made it sell, however, was the soldier's expletive - printed throughout, however, as "fug". American authors dominated the list for the next two decades, many of them becoming contemporary classics. At one point, again in financial difficulties, Deutsch sold himself out to Time-Life Books, with a contract to stay on as publisher, but the arrangement did not work and he bought himself out again. When he felt the time had come to retire (and the 1980s were not a happy time for independent publishers, with the banks increasingly unhelpful), he accepted an offer from Tom Rosenthal. Deutsch expected to remain as a consultant, but soon found his presence was not welcome. Deutsch never married, but had a close relationship with a sympathetic lady for many years. His main relaxation was skiing, until age and illness made it no longer possible. He received the OBE in 1989. Frank Keating writes: Dear André. Think of a mid-European leprechaun and you've got the picture. He was already well into his 50s when he published my first two books. They were about cricket, of which he knew nothing, but he read the Guardian and had heard of Ian Botham. The paper would pay my hotel bills for daily reports on England's 1980 tour of the West Indies, and André would stump up all travel expenses for the main wheeze - a spoof, ghosted autobiography by an imagined 17th member of the England party called Desmond (ie me), who would spill the beans on the tour. The day before we left, André gave me my "expenses" - in the form of copies of personal letters he had already sent to, among others, Eric Williams, Forbes Burnham and Michael Manley, former black movement student authors of his, now prime ministers of respectively Trinidad, Guyana, and Jamaica. I feared the worst publisher's double-cross. Not a bit of it. From day one in Trinidad, chauffeured cars were at my disposal, and the odd private plane. In return, I was fast into my stride with Another Bloody Day In Paradise - till the tour began to fall apart with the team being thrown out of Guyana on the back of South African apartheid and the death of England's manager Ken Barrington. Back home, André panicked. "Drop Desmond and play it straight," he wired. Twelve months later, with another England team, this time in India, a beaming André arrived with some 30-odd copies of ABD in P and arranged a "launch" party at the pricey Taj Mahal in Bombay. When the time came to leave, a week or so later, all party charges had been referred to my bill - and dear old André was back in London. But I loved him. I last saw him a couple of years ago, looking sad, hunched, lonely. "We should really do that spoof tour book again," he said - and his leprechaun's eyes were glistening with pleasure and anticipation once again. André Deutsch, publisher, born November 15 1917; died April 10 2000.

fields.headline: Schools win £600m for repairs
fields.trailText: The government yesterday named more than 6,000 schools in England which will benefit from improvements over the next two years, including the replacement of 1,500 of the worst temporary classrooms.
fields.body:
The government yesterday named more than 6,000 schools in England which will benefit from improvements over the next two years, including the replacement of 1,500 of the worst temporary classrooms.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, committed £600m to classroom construction at 528 schools, roof repairs at 907, window repairs at 666, new heating and boiler systems at 974, new electrical systems at 512, and toilet facilities at 233. Other schools will get extensions, laboratories and internal repairs.

After criticism that ministers were announcing spending plans several times for maximum publicity value, Mr Blunkett said the money would come from existing Treasury allocations, including £250m from last month's budget. This was the first time the government had identified the schools.

The grants are part of a £5.9bn investment over three years for schools. "I am confident the new deal for schools will make a big dent in the backlog that has developed over the last 20 years," said Mr Blunkett.

fields.headline: Rover taskforce denies conflict claims
fields.trailText: Alex Stephenson, chairman of the government's Rover taskforce, yesterday denied that his brother's involvement with a possible counter bid for the struggling car company had created a conflict of interest.
fields.body:
Alex Stephenson, chairman of the government's Rover taskforce, yesterday denied that his brother's involvement with a possible counter bid for the struggling car company had created a conflict of interest.

Alchemy, the venture capital group buying Rover from BMW, has stopped cooperating with the taskforce because of the Stephenson connection.

Its managing partner, Jon Moulton, has twice written to Stephen Byers, the secretary of state, expressing concern about the possible conflict.

Alchemy fears that information about its negotiations with BMW, Rover's present owner, could work its way back to the consortium striving to table a counter bid.

Mr Stephenson said yesterday: "The taskforce is not involved in accessing or promoting any bids and therefore there is no conflict of interest. Our job is to access the impact of changes at Longbridge and advise the secretary of state.

"At our private meeting, Jon Moulton and I discussed a great many issues, including likely candidates for the proposed executive of the new MG Car Company.

"A number of names were mentioned, including my brother, Nick Stephenson, who was previously engineering director of Rover for four years. He was responsible for the business planning and design of cars such as Freelander, MGF and Rover 75.

"There is no business relationship between myself and any potential bidder for Rover and the DTI have advised me of no conflict of interest."

fields.headline: Huddled hungry
fields.standfirst:
Aid agencies increase food pleas for Ethiopia

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations World Food Programme director Catherine Bertini arrived in Ethiopia yesterday to assess the food crisis there amid claims that even more food aid than previously requested will be needed to avert starvation.
fields.body:
The United Nations World Food Programme director Catherine Bertini arrived in Ethiopia yesterday to assess the food crisis there amid claims that even more food aid than previously requested will be needed to avert starvation.

The Ethiopian government has already appealed for 800,000 tonnes of food aid to feed some 8m people threatened by starvation, but unless some rain falls soon more than a million tonnes will be needed, according to aid organisations.

The Save the Children Fund said yesterday that a further 1.2m people would be at risk if, as is expected, the June harvest fails.

The World Food Programme's (WFP) regional representative in Ethiopia, Judith Lewis, said the WFP had already revised its estimates of the number of people at risk five times in the past year.

"I've never seen a country plagued by so many problems," said Ms Lewis. "At the end of 1998 the food situation in Ethiopia looked good, but since then we have seen one disaster after another."

Ms Bertini will assess one of the worst hit areas of the country today when she visits the south-eastern town of Gode.

Tens of thousands of people are said to be at risk there, but according to Ms Lewis there are signs of improvement.

"Food is getting to the right places and people suffering from malnutrition are responding well to our feeding programmes" she said.

The greatest problem facing the aid agencies is the logistics of getting food to the hungry.

Infrastructure in many parts of the country is woefully inadequate, and acts of banditry in the worst affected region, near Ethiopia's border with Somalia, are common enough to prevent the WFP basing any of its international staff there.

The drivers of the food convoys have to be carefully chosen to ensure that they belong to the same clan that dominates any region they have to pass through.

Several drivers have been killed in the last few months because the clans controlling the areas they travel through did not accept them.

However, the biggest obstacle to the relief effort is the border war that Ethiopia has been fighting for the last two years against its northern neighbour, Eritrea.

Ethiopia is landlocked and until the war broke out relied on the Eritrean ports of Assab and Massawa for trade.

Since then it has had to rely on the port of Djibouti, which UN logistics experts say cannot cope.

Eritrea offered Ethiopia the use of its ports last week but Ethiopia rejected the offer, calling it a "gimmick".

fields.headline: 'Lapsed' Jews pray for exodus
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's interior minister Natan Sharansky is in Ethiopia, holding out hope for thousands of its dispossessed and suffering citizens. But these are not famine victims. They are the so-called Falash Mura, descendants of local Jews who converted to Christianity and now want to embrace Judaism again as their ticket to Israel.
fields.body:
Israel's interior minister Natan Sharansky is in Ethiopia, holding out hope for thousands of its dispossessed and suffering citizens. But these are not famine victims. They are the so-called Falash Mura, descendants of local Jews who converted to Christianity and now want to embrace Judaism again as their ticket to Israel.

There are an estimated 26,000 Falash Mura, of whom some 18,000 have abandoned their homes for squalid transit camps in Addis Ababa and the northern city of Gondar.

Their status is controversial in Israel, where more than 50,000 Ethiopian Jews already live. Although they have been officially welcomed and given citizenship, most live in visibly poorer circumstances than other Israelis.

That does not deter the Falash Mura, who are determined to escape infinitely worse conditions. Many have relatives already in Israel, but proving their relationship is desperately hard in a land where identity documents are scarce or non-existent.

Mr Sharansky, himself an immigrant, has expressed sympathy with their plight. "I was in jail in Russia for nine years because I wanted to reach Israel," he said. But, he added, Israel could not accept everyone who wanted to come.

Israel's Law of Return, which lies at the core of the state's very existence, says that anyone with a Jewish grandparent can settle in the Jewish state.

But halachic, or religious, law specifies that a person can be Jewish only if he or she has a Jewish mother.

To complicate the issue further, there are bitter disputes between rabbinical authorities about the conversion of gentiles. Some orthodox Jews believe that conversion is impossible. Liberal opinion holds it to be perfectly permissible.

Underlying the debates is an uncomfortable if rarely voiced suspicion that Israel is holding the Falash Mura at arm's length because they are poor - and black.

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday mistake
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The only soldier wounded during Bloody Sunday shot himself in the foot, the Saville inquiry in Londonderry was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The only soldier wounded during Bloody Sunday shot himself in the foot, the Saville inquiry in Londonderry was told yesterday.

Christopher Clarke QC, counsel for the inquiry, said the tribunal, at the city's Guildhall, would have to decide whether troops could have confused the accidental shot for suspected sniper fire.

The gunner, from 22nd Light Air Defence Regiment, said that he had been unaware his sergeant had cocked his rifle.

He was resting the gun barrel on his foot to stop the muzzle getting dirty, and was playing with the safety catch.

The gunner, fined £35 for accidentally discharging his weapon, said: "There was a loud bang and an empty cartridge hit my sergeant in the back.

"At first we thought he had been shot, but I felt the pain in my foot and quickly realised that I had fired the shot."

Mr Clarke said it had been suggested that the sniper's bullet soldiers say was fired towards them in a nearby churchyard may have been the shot the gunner fired into his foot.

Paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed Roman Catholics on an illegal anti-internment march in the city on January 30, 1972.

Corporal A, in the machine gun platoon of the 1st battalion of the Parachute Regiment, was with colleagues in a derelict building when some demonstrators spotted them and began throwing stones and bottles.

Two nail or blast bombs had exploded. He then saw a man beginning to light what he believed was another device. "There was not time to shout and ask for permission before I fired."

webTitle: Black peasants have waited for 110 years, says white minister

fields.headline: Black peasants have waited for 110 years, says white minister
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: It is simplistic to say that Zimbabwe's land crisis has divided the country completely along racial lines. Dr Timothy Stamps is white, Welsh and the minister of health. He is also one of the most persuasive advocates of President Robert Mugabe's government.
fields.body:
It is simplistic to say that Zimbabwe's land crisis has divided the country completely along racial lines. Dr Timothy Stamps is white, Welsh and the minister of health. He is also one of the most persuasive advocates of President Robert Mugabe's government.

"At last reality has begun to be faced in regard to the land situation," he said in his office yesterday. "The current upheaval may well pave the way for a peaceful and progressive resolution of the problem. Land has been this country's most crucial question for 110 years. What is surprising is that it has taken so long for there to be this push for redistribution."

Land seizures are not new. Smaller groups of land-hungry Zimbabweans have invaded white-owned farms numerous times since 1980. "Each time the government has told the people to wait for land redistribution," he said. "How long can the government's credibility be maintained when people are told repeatedly to wait?"

Dr Stamps, 63, born and raised in Wales, has been health minister for nearly 15 years, for much of that time the only white in Robert Mugabe's cabinet.

He moved to this country in 1968, when it was Rhodesia, and worked as deputy medical officer for the municipality of Salisbury (now Harare). He became the chief medical officer in 1970, but was ousted in 1974 by Ian Smith's government, which objected to his efforts to improve health care for black Rhodesians.

As health minister he has championed open discussion of Zimbabwe's Aids crisis. It is estimated that the country has one of the world's highest HIV rates, with 25% of the sexually active population believed to be infected.

As chairman of the Freedom from Hunger campaign, Dr Stamps - who owns a small dairy farm - organised a land resettlement project for 2,000 people in the early 1980s. "It is called Vuti farm and we got a grant of DM3m from AgroAction in Germany," he said. "A great deal of work needed to be done, but after seven or eight years it became self-supporting."

He said his experience showed it would take much more than simply providing new land to end grinding rural poverty. "It's hardly surprising that people are angry. Rural people are facing extreme poverty, where a man cannot provide for his family."

But he hoped the current farm occupations, now affecting 1,000 farms, would be temporary. "Provided the strong emotions on all sides are put away in a cabinet for a while, I think we can find a solution that will bring a fair and orderly redistribution process. The international community has a responsibility because it has the capacity to recognise that this is the fundamental issue."

Zimbabwe's race relations are not being destroyed by farm invasions or by the divisive rhetoric used by Mr Mugabe and cabinet ministers. "Whites are the face of the problem, but the causes go deeper than that," Dr Stamps said.

"In general, our race relations are good - certainly much better than those of our neighbour, South Africa. We have the opportunity to improve on the solid black/white relationship that has been built over the past 20 years. It is the extremists who are creating divisions."

fields.headline: Uneasy Zimbabwe waits for polls
fields.standfirst:
Parliament was dissolved yesterday but there is no sign of an election being called

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's parliament was formally dissolved last night amid renewed confusion about when President Robert Mugabe will call a general election that is expected to see a surge in support for the opposition.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's parliament was formally dissolved last night amid renewed confusion about when President Robert Mugabe will call a general election that is expected to see a surge in support for the opposition.

Although the president has told Britain that the ballot will be held in May, a senior Zimbabwean official has warned that it will take at least until July to draw up new constituency boundaries. The law allows Mr Mugabe to delay the vote by up to four months after the dissolution of parliament.

The uncertainty about the polls is fuelling political instability amid continuing land invasions, with more than 1,000 farms at least partially occupied by poor black squatters, and a looming court ruling on whether the police can be compelled to act against the squatters. Political violence is also spreading, with 63 people arrested after houses were looted and cars torched after clashes in a Harare suburb.

The final decision on an election date lies with Mr Mugabe, who is in Cuba for a meeting of the Group of 77 developing nations. But Wilson Sandura, the head of the country's delimitation commission which decides constituency boundaries, said he had not been given enough time to prepare for an early election and will not be ready for months.

Although the opposition believes it could benefit from a delay in the elections, there is widespread concern among ordinary Zimbabweans that if the election is delayed for several months it will lead to worse political violence and further damage the battered economy.

Mr Mugabe's party, Zanu-PF, has dominated the fourth parliament since independence, holding all but three of 150 seats. But the party is facing humiliation if not outright loss of control amid growing public discontent at soaring inflation, rampant corruption and the government's evident contempt for the rule of law.

However, with many constituencies gerrymandered and a constitutional provision allowing Mr Mugabe to hand-pick 20% of all MPs, there would have to be a massive swing to the opposition for it to be able to take control of parliament.

The main opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, said yesterday that were his Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) to win an outright majority, it would bring the presidential election forward from 2002 in an effort to unseat Mr Mugabe.

"If we get enough of a majority to amend the constitution, we are likely to bring forward the (presidential) election by a constitutional amendment," Mr Tsvangirai said.

Mr Tsvangirai is in South Africa to raise funds before a visit to Britain on Friday. He called on the South African government to take a stronger stand "for democracy" in Zimbabwe.

"South Africa cannot stand by and watch Zimbabwe go down in flames. If the Zimbabwe economy collapses, a lot of jobs will be lost," he said. "Mugabe should be prevented from degenerating any further than he has done as a dictator."

The Zimbabwean opposition leader has asked to meet the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, or the foreign office minister Peter Hain when he arrives in Britain at the end of the week.

However, the Foreign Office has warned that it may not be able to accommodate Mr Tsvangirai's request because Friday is constituency day for MPs and both Mr Cook and Mr Hain are expected to be out of London.

The occupation of farms continued yesterday, when at least six more were taken over. Farmers are awaiting a ruling from Zimbabwe's high court tomorrow on whether the police can be forced to obey a court order requiring them to remove the men and women who have invaded more than 1,000 farms.

At a hearing on Monday, the attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, admitted to the court that the occupations were "a racially and politically charged powder keg ready to explode". But he claimed the 20,000-strong police force lacks the resources to obey the order and that to do so would exacerbate tensions.

But the Commercial Farmers' Union, which is seeking to compel the police to act, dismissed the attorney general's claim.

"This is a political issue," said the CFU lawyer, Adrian de Bourbon. "They have got the resources. They just chose not to use them against supporters of one political party."

Zimbabwe's minister of land and agriculture, Kumbirai Kangai, almost fell victim to the invasions after a large group attempted to occupy his farm in Nyabira.

They were eventually driven off by security guards. Mr Kangai described the potential squatters as "thugs".

But the party is facing humiliation if not outright loss of control amid growing public discontent at soaring inflation, rampant corruption and the government's evident contempt for the rule of law. However, with many constituencies gerrymandered and a constitutional provision allowing Mr Mugabe to hand-pick 20% of all MPs, there would have to be a massive swing to the opposition for it to be able to take control of parliament. The main opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, said yesterday that were his Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) to win an outright majority, it would bring the presidential election forward from 2002 in an effort to unseat Mr Mugabe. "If we get enough of a majority to amend the constitution, we are likely to bring forward the (presidential) election by a constitutional amendment," Mr Tsvangirai said. Mr Tsvangirai is in South Africa to raise funds before a visit to Britain on Friday. He called on the South African government to take a stronger stand "for democracy" in Zimbabwe. "South Africa cannot stand by and watch Zimbabwe go down in flames. If the Zimbabwe economy collapses, a lot of jobs will be lost," he said. "Mugabe should be prevented from degenerating any further than he has done as a dictator." The Zimbabwean opposition leader has asked to meet the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, or the foreign office minister Peter Hain when he arrives in Britain at the end of the week. However, the Foreign Office has warned that it may not be able to accommodate Mr Tsvangirai's request because Friday is constituency day for MPs and both Mr Cook and Mr Hain are expected to be out of London. The occupation of farms continued yesterday, when at least six more were taken over. Farmers are awaiting a ruling from Zimbabwe's high court tomorrow on whether the police can be forced to obey a court order requiring them to remove the men and women who have invaded more than 1,000 farms. At a hearing on Monday, the attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, admitted to the court that the occupations were "a racially and politically charged powder keg ready to explode". But he claimed the 20,000-strong police force lacks the resources to obey the order and that to do so would exacerbate tensions. But the Commercial Farmers' Union, which is seeking to compel the police to act, dismissed the attorney general's claim. "This is a political issue," said the CFU lawyer, Adrian de Bourbon. "They have got the resources. They just chose not to use them against supporters of one political party." Zimbabwe's minister of land and agriculture, Kumbirai Kangai, almost fell victim to the invasions after a large group attempted to occupy his farm in Nyabira. They were eventually driven off by security guards. Mr Kangai described the potential squatters as "thugs".

fields.headline: Microsoft hires Bush aide
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft has hired Ralph Reed, a senior consultant to George W Bush, to lobby the presidential contender in the run-up to the elections.
fields.body:
Microsoft has hired Ralph Reed, a senior consultant to George W Bush, to lobby the presidential contender in the run-up to the elections.

Mr Reed is understood to have been asked to encourage influential supporters to write to Mr Bush supporting the software group's appeal against the district court decision that it breached anti-trust laws.

Mark Murray, a spokesman for Microsoft, said yesterday the company had been working with Mr Reed's firm, Century Strategies, for about 18 months.

"We work with a number of firms representing both Republicans and Democrats in Washington DC to get our side of the story out," he said. However, political analysts believe that the company's chances of overturning any legal decision will be greater under a Bush administration than one headed by the Democrat contender, Al Gore.

fields.headline: Nasdaq's woes benefit industrial stocks
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Technology shares continued to fall on Wall Street yesterday as investors switched to blue-chip members of the old economy.
fields.body:
Technology shares continued to fall on Wall Street yesterday as investors switched to blue-chip members of the old economy.

The Nasdaq composite index, a benchmark for hi-tech companies, was down 179 points at one point yesterday morning following the second-biggest points drop in its history on Monday. The index looked set to erase gains made since the beginning of the year before rebounding. By lunchtime in New York it was down 1% at 4145.

Yesterday's Nasdaq decline exacerbated a fall of more than 17% since an all-time high was reached in mid March.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average has benefited from the Nasdaq's woes. It was up more than 150 points at lunchtime yesterday.

To add to the tech market's woes, a board member of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the parent company of Nasdaq, called for Frank Zarb, its chairman, to resign. Alan Davidson, who represents small brokers, cited a lawsuit unrelated to the NASD which alleged Mr Zarb lied. The plaintiff was awarded $10m.

Mr Davidson is trying to delay Mr Zarb's attempt to spin off the Nasdaq stock market into a separate company. NASD members are to vote on the restructuring on Friday.

An NASD spokesman offered a sharp response to Mr Davidson's comments: "It is a transparent and desperate attempt to serve his own purposes and no serious person who is familiar with the facts would be misled by it."

fields.headline: Mobile alliance to set standard
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola yesterday joined forces to create a standard for delivering secure transactions on mobile handsets by 2001.
fields.body:
Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola yesterday joined forces to create a standard for delivering secure transactions on mobile handsets by 2001.

The move is designed to fuel the rise of m-commerce, such as banking or buying train tickets with a mobile phone - a process the three companies say is being stifled by fragmented technologies.

M-commerce in Europe is predicted by consultants McKinsey & Company to be worth between $9bn and $16bn by 2002. The number of mobile phone users globally is expected to exceed one billion by 2004.

Once m-commerce becomes popular, it is likely that financial institutions will begin loyalty programmes similar to those offered for credit cards.

The standard being developed will be open and based on the Wireless Application Protocol.

Wireless Identification Module and Mobile Public Key Infrastructure technologies will provide the security functions while connectivity will be based on Bluetooth technology. Bluetooth can be fired from a mobile phone, much like an infrared beam, to handle nearby transactions such as paying for a parking meter.

Matti Alahuhta, the president of Nokia, said: "Integrating security and transaction applications on a common core standard and platform will create a global mass market for mobile e-business."

Jan Ahrenbring, Ericsson vice president for marketing, said: "Ericsson estimates that by 2004 there will be around one billion users of mobile telephony and 60m mobile internet subscribers worldwide.

"The most important thing that is needed to get all these consumers to start using mobile e-commerce is a standard which makes it safe and easy to use."

None of the companies would say what operating system would be used for mobile phones. However, they are working with Psion in a software consortium known as Symbian to adapt Psion's operating system, Epoc, into a platform for handheld internet computers and mobile phones.

The three companies expect to have a standards framework ready by the summer. After that they will invite other companies such as financial institutions to provide input.

They declined to say how much they would invest in developing the framework. "It's more about bringing together the know-how than the investment," Rick Darnaby, Motorola's general manager for Europe, said.

fields.headline: Stay at home, Mr Putin
fields.standfirst: Menzies Campbell
fields.trailText: When the Queen meets Mr Putin at the weekend the conversation will no doubt be confined to pleasantries. It is a reasonable bet that the words "Council of Europe" will not pass anyone's lips. References to "Mrs Robinson" may even be taken to refer to Kathleen Turner's current role on the London stage.
fields.body:
When the Queen meets Mr Putin at the weekend the conversation will no doubt be confined to pleasantries. It is a reasonable bet that the words "Council of Europe" will not pass anyone's lips. References to "Mrs Robinson" may even be taken to refer to Kathleen Turner's current role on the London stage.

But when Mr Putin meets the prime minister and other government ministers, should not someone feel some embarrassment for the alacrity with which Mr Putin is being received in London after an election campaign which exploited the brutality of the Russian onslaught in Chechnya? Will no one ask why it is that the Council of Europe, not renowned for stern action, should have put Russia on notice of suspension for its callous disregard of civilian lives in Chechnya? Will anyone question the fact that Russia, a permanent member of the Security Council, should have humiliated the UN's own Mrs Robinson by denying her the access to which her office as high commissioner for human rights entitled her? Will no one argue that when it comes to human rights it is not the rhetoric which counts but the reality?

None of this is to deny that Russia should be a focus of British foreign policy; or that its stability is essential for the security of Europe; nor that in the end it played an important part in the settlement in Kosovo. But a foreign policy with an "ethical dimension" cannot ignore the indiscriminate use of military force such as Mr Putin presided over in Chechnya.

Chechen terrorists and rebels have done some terrible things, but countries whose leaders aspire to be received in the United Kingdom should not be lightly excused the use of such disproportionate force.

Men, women and children are not the legitimate targets of military operations whose avowed purpose is counter terrorism. When serious allegations are made by respected organisations, governments which claim a commitment to human rights have a duty to investigate and if necessary put perpetrators on trial. When the UN high commissioner came to call, the Putin government had a duty to afford her every assistance.

Some argue that so urgent are Britain's interests in relation to Russia that "engagement" is necessary, and there is force in that argument. But has anyone thought how Mr Putin's early invitation to London will be seen in Moscow? No matter how many qualifications, caveats, or conditions, the visit will be seen as an endorsement of the policy towards Chechnya which he has pursued with such ruthless determination. It will also reinforce the humiliation handed out to Mary Robinson. If the Council of Europe proceeds to suspension how will our alacrity look to our European allies?

Even if "critical engagement" has replaced "ethical dimension", that is still no basis for this precipitate visit.

Here is a "critical" approach to Russia, but one which recognises the primacy of human rights and does not confer unqualified approval. We recognise your importance in the world. You have the nuclear weapons and the influence to prove it. Europe will not be secure unless you feel secure. Your internal stability depends very heavily on economic progress. We understand your concerns about Nato and about the American proposal for a missile defence system for which they may be prepared to breach the ABM treaty. We can help with the economy but you must root out corruption and curtail the activities of the Mafia. There is not likely to be any further enlargement of Nato for some time. Nato is still digesting the three who joined last year. We in the UK are concerned about the ABM treaty and will do our best to persuade America not to do anything which breaches it, or at the very least to offer you the technology so that your national interests are not prejudiced and you do not feel the need to abandon any hopes of nuclear reductions.

But human rights are important to us - we are about to adopt the European Convention into English law -and you cannot expect the kind of full partnership which would benefit us both unless you show a regard for them. You can do that immediately by reining in the brutality in Chechnya and by conducting your own investigations into abuses with sufficient transparency as to satisfy Mary Robinson, and sufficient regard for the rule of law as to put people on trial if it is justified to do so.

There is the proper basis for a constructive relationship, and when the deeds of both of us match our undertakings then we can see about a trip to London and the Palace. But not before.

Menzies Campbell MP is the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesperson: libdems@cix.co.uk

webTitle: OnDigital offers deal to keep clients

fields.headline: OnDigital offers deal to keep clients
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: OnDigital is offering customers who attempt to end their pay television contracts three months' service including premium channels at just £1 a month.
fields.body:
OnDigital is offering customers who attempt to end their pay television contracts three months' service including premium channels at just £1 a month.

The pay-TV operator, which is jointly owned by ITV companies Granada and Carlton, has designed the offer to head off losses among the first waves of customers reaching the end of their 12 month contracts. This is a critical time for OnDigital, which launched in November 1998, as it attempts to build subscriber numbers toward the forecast 1m by the end of the year.

The company yesterday announced that it had increased its subscriber base by 22% in the first quarter to 673,000 homes. A spokesman said the offer was one of several being tied out to test their efficacy in keeping hold of customers.

Granada is understood to hold the 1m mark as the trigger point for a stock market flotation of the business. Carlton has already employed investment bank Morgan Stanley to prepare an outline of options for the company moving forward.

Stuart Prebble, OnDigital's chief executive, said the business was going from strength to strength. "We are right on course to achieve our target of 1m customers by the end of this year and 2m by the end of 2002."

OnDigital has launched two sports channels and is likely to appear among the bidders for Premier league broadcasting rights. Mr Prebble said talks had been held with NTL and ITV companies about joint bids.

Earlier this month, OnDigital launched its email service via the TV and plans to have full Internet access later this year.

webTitle: Diabetics face serious risks as NHS care fails

fields.headline: Diabetics face serious risks as NHS care fails
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The NHS is struggling to keep up with the fast-rising tide of people with diabetes
fields.body:
The NHS is struggling to keep up with the fast-rising tide of people with diabetes, some of whom are suffering unnecessary blindness, amputations, kidney damage and strokes because of complications not detected early enough.

The shocking state of services for diabetics is exposed in a report published today by the audit commission.

It finds wide variations in standards of care around the country.

In some areas, it reports, patients are not properly taught how to manage their diabetes, and GP surgeries and hospitals are failing to carry out the routine checks that can stave off complications such as diabetes-related eye and kidney diseases.

"We have evidence of gaps in current services. For instance, half the health authorities do not have full eye screening services, but we know that with proper screening and early laser treatment we can prevent new cases of blindness," said Tara Lamont, one of the report's authors.

Better management of diabetes could reduce eye disease by a quarter and kidney disease by a half, says the report.

Effective eye screening and treatment could cut blindness by half and early intervention for foot problems could reduce amputations by two thirds.

The Department of Health said: "The report highlights unacceptable variations in the quality of diabetes services. If some local health services can provide first-class care then all should be able to."

The government has commissioned a national health service framework for diabetes - a blueprint for best practice within the NHS.

Paul Streets, the chief executive of the British Diabetic Association, said: "It is time that the gaps in the diabetes service provided by the NHS were dealt with.

"Without the proper care people with diabetes are at risk of long-term complications such as blindness, heart disease and kidney disease. It is unacceptable that everything possible is not being done to reduce this risk."

Too many diabetics are sent for routine checks to hospital when their condition could be better managed by GP practices, says the commission.

Between 6% and 16% of hospital beds are occupied by diabetics, and once they are in hospital their diabetes control tends to worsen. Many are not allowed by ward staff to administer their own insulin injections.

A survey by the commission found that a third of wards did not have proper guidelines for managing diabetes.

A fifth of hospital case notes had no record of a foot examination, even though diabetes is the commonest reason for amputation.

Many GP practices did not offer routine access to chiropodists or dieticians.

"We suspect patients are falling through the net. Patients are picked up too late," Ms Lamont said. "Half of all people have complications by the time they are diagnosed.

"And once they are diagnosed not everybody is getting the care they require. Two thirds of patients said they had not received any support or education about their condition in the last year."

The number of people with diabetes is expected to increase from 1.4m to 3m by 2010 because of the ageing population and a rise in obesity. Diabetes is three to four times more common in people of Asian or African-Caribbean origin.

Almost half the patients from ethnic minority groups said they knew little or nothing about the impact on their diabetes of illnesses such as influenza. More than a quarter had no idea what to do if their blood glucose level dropped too low.

The commission recommends funding GPs to reflect the amount and the quality of care they give to people suffering from diabetes.

A disease for life

 1.4m people in the UK suffer diabetes. The number is expected to more than double in the next 10 years. One person is newly diagnosed with the disease every five minutes.

 Diabetes and complications arising from it cost the NHS £4.9bn a year: about a tenth of its entire budget.

 Diabetes is a lifelong chronic condition caused by the body's inability to control the amount of sugar in the blood. Type 1, also called insulin-dependent diabetes, can start early in life and is controlled by insulin injections. Up to 80% of cases are of type 2, which develops slowly in later life and can be associated with obesity.

 Complications can include heart disease, stroke, foot ulceration and amputation, kidney failure and blindness.

webTitle: China turns up heat on Taiwan

fields.headline: China turns up heat on Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Beijing increased the pressure on Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, yesterday by saying that he must give a "full answer" to China's demands when he is inaugurated next month.
fields.body:
Beijing increased the pressure on Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, yesterday by saying that he must give a "full answer" to China's demands when he is inaugurated next month.

"Taiwan's new leader cannot merely take a posture but can only win trust by taking actions," a foreign ministry spokesman said in Beijing.

Mr Chen's efforts to avoid the question of "one China" have been undercut by his elected vice-president, Annette Lu, who infuriated Beijing last week by referring to Taiwan's independence.

Yesterday he warned against unrealistic expectations of his inaugural speech on May 20 while promising to show "sincerity and goodwill" to China, but the question is whether goodwill will be enough.

webTitle: No 10 hits back in asylum row

fields.headline: No 10 hits back in asylum row
fields.trailText: Downing Street last night hit back at claims that the overwhelming majority of refugees seeking asylum in Britain are "bogus" - or evade deportation when their claims have been rejected.
fields.body:
Downing Street last night hit back at claims that the overwhelming majority of refugees seeking asylum in Britain are "bogus" - or evade deportation when their claims have been rejected.

As William Hague insisted that he has an "absolute duty" to expose the government's mismanagement of the current crisis, senior ministers privately acknowledge the issue may tell against them in next month's local elections if the Tories and their media allies keep up their attack.

Tony Blair has appealed for calmer language, though yesterday Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, accused the home secretary, Jack Straw, of being equally "obnoxious".

Last night Downing Street issued a detailed breakdown of last year's asylum figures - when the war for Kosovo and other conflicts helped create a big rise in applications - though they included efforts to deal with the backlog in unprocessed cases.

There were 71,160 applications in 1999, and 32,330 decisions were made, including 12,460 backlog cases dating from before 1995. Of the backlog cases 11,230 were given exceptional leave to stay, the technical term for a temporary haven until conditions become safer at home, and 1,230 were rejected.

In the main group 7,075 applicants - 33% - were given asylum, while a further 10% were given exceptional leave to stay. That meant 56% of cases were rejected.

Mr Kennedy yesterday renewed the attack on both the Tories and Labour, saying: "What is being stoked up by a combination of Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe is particularly obnoxious."

Asked if they were bordering on racism, Mr Kennedy said: "I think the two of them are bordering on irresponsibility."

webTitle: We can't learn from the US

fields.headline: We can't learn from the US
fields.trailText: As an Englishwoman who has lived in the US for 25 years and who has a daughter in her final year at a New York City school, I am dismayed that the Department for Education thinks substituting US-style SATs for A-levels will be a quick fix in its attempt to increase educational opportunity for working-class children (Plea for US-style university entrance tests to end 'bias' against poor, April 11). Top US colleges do not accept students based on SATs alone. They require both multiple-choice Sats in maths and verbal ability (known as SAT 1s), and SAT 2s and/or advanced placement examinations, both of which resemble British A-levels in form and content.
fields.body:
As an Englishwoman who has lived in the US for 25 years and who has a daughter in her final year at a New York City school, I am dismayed that the Department for Education thinks substituting US-style SATs for A-levels will be a quick fix in its attempt to increase educational opportunity for working-class children (Plea for US-style university entrance tests to end 'bias' against poor, April 11). Top US colleges do not accept students based on SATs alone. They require both multiple-choice Sats in maths and verbal ability (known as SAT 1s), and SAT 2s and/or advanced placement examinations, both of which resemble British A-levels in form and content.

Children from more privileged backgrounds do far better on these tests: indeed, most children from poorer homes - and schools - do not even take them. Despite this additional requirement, the SAT 1s are indeed important. Therefore, those who can afford it take SAT 1 preparation courses, often for several years before the test. The cost of such courses can be well over $5,000, a sum clearly unaffordable by most people. Again, the more privileged tend to excel.

American colleges achieve somewhat greater diversity than do British universities despite the SAT tests, not because of them. They do this by sometimes choosing to ignore test scores in favour of other attributes, such as community service, extra-curricular activities and motivation. Nevertheless, SAT 1 test scores are still the deciding factor for most students, even though there is increasing doubt on many levels about their validity. The government must face the fact that there is no easy solution to this problem. The only possibility is to revamp the education system by ensuring small classes and good teachers at every level.

Carole Mosco, Yonkers, US carole@datacap.com

 At present most UK university degree courses require a great deal of prior knowledge, gained during secondary school. If candidates were admitted based on their potential rather than existing academic achievement, this would result in longer degree courses, starting from a much lower knowledge base. Consequently, the courses would cost the students more in loans and thus dissuade poorer students. An attempt to encourage poorer students to go to university may have the opposite effect.

Doug Futers, West Bridgford, Notts

 David Hart claims "discrimination is inevitable as long as universities base admission mainly on A-level achievement". The US has wrestled for decades with the issue of whether SATs are culturally biased or otherwise discriminate against the poor. It would be incredibly naive to imagine this issue will go away if we swap A-levels for any form of intelligence test, thus giving up any notion that students should enter university knowing anything systematic at all.

National systems come as wholes, not just the bits you fancy, and if we take on SATs we will inevitably have to assume students, as in the US, know virtually nothing at entry to university: it would no longer be possible to run a university French course, for example, assuming any knowledge of French, as UK universities do now. Is this really what we want to happen to the UK undergraduate programme?

Your article refers to those who enter university knowing something, from A-levels perhaps, as having been "coached". How depressing that any school success is now to be seen as the socially suspect notion of coaching. What wreckage our state school system has become if that view is widely held.

Prof Yorick Wilks, Sheffield y.wilks@dcs.shef.ac.uk

webTitle: Blair is now going all out to tackle the concrete jungle

fields.headline: Blair is now going all out to tackle the concrete jungle
fields.standfirst: Expect a high degree of central control on this new assault on poverty
fields.trailText: A month after Labour won the election, Tony Blair stood in the grey concrete of a vast estate in South London - as miserable a place as any - and promised "no forgotten people, no one left out".
fields.body:
A month after Labour won the election, Tony Blair stood in the grey concrete of a vast estate in South London - as miserable a place as any - and promised "no forgotten people, no one left out".

Today the government starts to redeem that pledge. The National Strategy for Neighbourhood Renewal plans social engineering on a giant scale, rolling out into the worst 3,000 districts.

The scale and ambition of this is monumental - by far the most difficult task the government has attempted, or is ever likely to.

The risk of failure is frightening because if it doesn't work it may be years - if ever - that any government dares embark again on an assault on the roots of poverty.

This takes us back to the days when Labour believed it could change society fundamentally. With good policies and enough money, people's lives can be transformed.

The forces of conservatism drove all these neighbourhoods to far worse despair and degradation through unemployment and neglect.

Now the forces of progress will show how to free them: the very word "renewal" signifies the left's old faith in redemption.

It's all been tried before, the right says, with that "nothing works" cynicism they so relish. The poor are always with us, it's the human condition. Remember the slum clearances, they chuckle?

Only look at the rhetoric that surrounded the "cities in the sky", the hated tower blocks. There was the Urban Programme in 1968, whatever happened to that? Only look, says the right, at the squillions squandered in the poorest places over the years.

Renovation schemes, enveloping, decanting, recanting, it's all been done and what happens? Things fall apart again. Why will anything be different now?

This stands a better chance than any programme yet. Eighteen policy action teams have burrowed into every cause and every solution to socially excluded neighbourhoods.

Not a stone is left unturned in their dissection of bad estates, half empty as everyone escapes who can, while shops, banks, GPs and services flee. Crime and drugs make life hell.

Using all these reports, today's renewal strategy will draw them together in a template for breathing life into urban deserts.

As ever, employment comes first. Every expert on deprivation says it is what counts. Can work be found?

Many new jobs will be created in the process of regeneration, as businesses and shops are brought back, new squads of neighbourhood wardens created, redoubled services of every kind employing residents, plus transport bringing outside jobs within reach.

More money will pour in than ever before, the sum not revealed until July's spending review.

This mighty programme will stretch the power of government to its very limit. The social exclusion unit (SEU) has produced some of the best reports from any government, drawing up new policy on many causes of poverty: teenage pregnancy, rough sleepers, school exclusions, children in care.

Each report has been sent out to a cross-departmental committee to take action, but their success can't be judged for a long time.

Do the SEU's levers work when pulled? It's one thing to frame perfect policy, quite another to reach down into the messy confusion of life out there and make it happen.

The brightest young brains in government delight in the intellectual clarity of research, number-crunching and problem solving.

Policy designers are not the ones who dirty their own hands with the frustrating, messy business of implementation.

That's left to the local infantry on the ground, where it's far harder to recruit the same calibre.

However, the Whitehall designers have set themselves public targets with public monitoring to check the success of every plan. Eventually transparent facts will hang out there for all to see and they will take the blame for failure.

They have devised a self-punishing system, trying to change the most intractable of human behaviour, reaching into the puzzling heart of teenage girls' sex lives, or care-home runaways. Of all the tasks they have set themselves, today's is the mega one incorporating all the others: it will be the making or breaking of all the government's social policy.

It may test the power of government to destruction, but it has every chance of being the best social programme ever.

How is the implementation to work? They started with the key question: who's in charge here? These sprawling estates have dozens of departments providing every sort of service but who coordinates it all?

Seventeen pilot schemes already up and running have tried to create an answer, with various degrees of success.

The government's instinct was to seek out local community movers and shakers - vicars, head teachers, community leaders - hoping to turn them into engines of renewal. The idea was to avoid local authorities: isn't it they who sucked up vast funds and failed time and again?

They wanted local partnerships with communities, councils and businesses working under some charismatic leader. The trouble is local community leaders are thin on the ground in such places. The bureaucratic burden is enormous.

It takes force to bang heads together in all the local departments to make them pool resources. It often asks too much of local activists, so today's strategy will include a new institute to train up a new breed of energetic community workers.

Meanwhile, for lack of anyone else, local authorities are often taking the lead. (In one pilot local residents chose to exclude the local authority but, rightly, Whitehall panicked and insisted they be a partner.) As for joined-up government, a Cabinet Office report is damning about results so far: it will be very difficult.

Places like Middlesbrough and Manchester now have a lattice of new action zones and schemes, not co-terminous, criss-crossing their patch, all of them good but hard to synchronise.

So today expect a surprising degree of Whitehall control over all this renewal: if their research shows "what works", they'll be loth to let local authorities or even local residents choose what they want.

In one pilot, residents wanted to spend on housing improvements but this scheme is not mainly for bricks and mortar (which has failed too often before) but for people: arts, sports, skills-training, after-school clubs, extra police, refuse collectors or wardens and the like.

Since it is the government which will be judged in the end, letting go is very hard to do - even when research shows community enthusiasm is the vital ingredient.

This will be hard going: there'll be endless such disputes. But this is the best chance there has ever been.

It will take years, billions of pounds and a government undeterred when some of it fails and fails again. It will often feel thankless, and rarely excite even the mildest interest from the press.

But this is what must deliver the promise to abolish child poverty.

fields.headline: Cricket in crisis
fields.standfirst:
The squeaky-clean captain of South Africa has thrown the game into chaos. I'm not entirely bowled over
Hansie Cronje profile
How the scandal was exposed
South Africa's captain sacked
Mike Selvey asks: Where now?
Reaction in South Africa
Wisden Verdict
fields.trailText: Either the game's rulers are wilfully stupid or they know far more than they have ever admitted; either explanation is contemptible.
fields.body:
It was, as one sage put it yesterday, as if the Queen had been caught fiddling her taxes. If anyone was making a book on the next cricketer to be exposed in a betting scandal, Hansie Cronje would have been available at 500 to 1.

Cronje (as of yesterday, the ex-captain of South Africa) comes from Bloemfontein in the Boer heartland, where betting, like illicit sex, booze and racial fraternisation, could until recently still draw the full, thundering wrath of an old-fashioned Afrikaans Calvinist minister of a Sunday morning. He was regarded as upright and a little uptight, the last man anyone would have suspected of fiddling.

But only a cricket administrator could have doubted that someone was going to be exposed sooner or later. Match-rigging scandals have erupted at intervals since the first allegations against the former Pakistan captain, Salim Malik, in 1995. And every time the volcano has blown, the game's rulers have provided the minimum possible response. Either they are wilfully stupid or they know far more than they have ever admitted; either explanation is contemptible.

South Africa will become the fourth country to hold an investigation of some kind into the connection between betting and cricketing corruption, following India, Pakistan and Australia. Not once has anyone drawn the obvious conclusion: that international cricket is now rotten to the core, and that only an investigation drawing together all the strands of evidence from across the globe is going to have any credibility whatever.

Sometimes, medical researchers cannot pinpoint the existence of an epidemic but they can identify a likely breeding ground. And cricket has now become the equivalent of a San Francisco bathhouse or a malarial swamp.

Everyone knows that poorly-paid stable lads will sometimes be tempted by rich bookmakers or gamblers to dole out inside information or nobble a favourite. Horse racing limits the problem by eternal vigilance. Cricketers are now in exactly the same position as the lads. By the standards of famous sportsmen generally, they are not well-paid. They know their life expectancy at the top is limited. Many of them come from countries with weedy currencies: the once-mighty rand has been in a terrible state since apartheid first began to totter more than a decade ago. And they now spend much of their time playing a form of the game that is absolutely ripe for manipulation: endless one-day internationals organised primarily for TV. These have little sporting credibility and offer minimal prize money. Experienced players (and journalists) approach them wearily, and often cynically.

The participants are often under-motivated and bored - in contrast to the unregulated bookmakers based in the subcontinent and the Gulf, who find these occasions absolutely entrancing. Cronje, according to Ali Bacher, chief executive of South Africa's United Cricket Board, was "harassed almost continually by bookmakers" on South Africa's recent tour of India. If he has been led into temptation, who can be surprised?

Cronje yesterday admitted taking money but denied ever being involved in rigging a match. Both these propositions could be true once you take into account the form of gambling known in this country as "spread betting" which has become wildly popular within the past four years. This involves treating a sporting proposition as a share price, which can be bought and sold. Thus not merely can you "buy" and back a horse to do well in a race, you can "sell" it and collect if it fails.

Under British law, these deals are not subject to the betting tax that afflict other forms of gambling. And they offer far more scope for imaginative punting than is possible down the local bookies. In cricket, you can buy or sell individual batsmen, the number of wides in a match, the time of the first boundary; one firm offered a spread on how many times John Major would be seen on TV watching World Cup matches. Last night, Sporting Index, one of the market leaders, was offering match bets enabling you to choose whether Trap 4 would beat Trap 5 in a greyhound race at Peterborough, and by how much. In football, they have had spreads on the time of the first throw-in, which one Premiership team laughingly took up and punted the ball off the field straight from the kick-off. You see, no match-rigging there either. As such.

There is a lot of harmless fun here, and we have little evidence of corruption inside Britain. However, the big-money operators in Asia - notionally illegal - are, in fact, able to bet on anything with impunity and zero regulation. Naturally, they try and suborn cricketers to try and shift the odds in their favour. It's a morass, and cricket is in it up to its neck while pretending that its big toe is just getting a little mucky.

In the 18th century, cricket was primarily a gambling game. The scandals multiplied until, in 1817, one William Lambert was chucked out of the game, and the bookmakers were kicked out from Lord's. The ban remained for the next 150 years. The time has come to expel the money-changers from the temple once again. It will take concerted, worldwide, action to achieve that. Otherwise, these scandals are just going to keep on coming.

matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk
