Match-rigging scandals have erupted at intervals since the first allegations against the former Pakistan captain, Salim Malik, in 1995. And every time the volcano has blown, the game's rulers have provided the minimum possible response. Either they are wilfully stupid or they know far more than they have ever admitted; either explanation is contemptible. South Africa will become the fourth country to hold an investigation of some kind into the connection between betting and cricketing corruption, following India, Pakistan and Australia. Not once has anyone drawn the obvious conclusion: that international cricket is now rotten to the core, and that only an investigation drawing together all the strands of evidence from across the globe is going to have any credibility whatever. Sometimes, medical researchers cannot pinpoint the existence of an epidemic but they can identify a likely breeding ground. And cricket has now become the equivalent of a San Francisco bathhouse or a malarial swamp. Everyone knows that poorly-paid stable lads will sometimes be tempted by rich bookmakers or gamblers to dole out inside information or nobble a favourite. Horse racing limits the problem by eternal vigilance. Cricketers are now in exactly the same position as the lads. By the standards of famous sportsmen generally, they are not well-paid. They know their life expectancy at the top is limited. Many of them come from countries with weedy currencies: the once-mighty rand has been in a terrible state since apartheid first began to totter more than a decade ago. And they now spend much of their time playing a form of the game that is absolutely ripe for manipulation: endless one-day internationals organised primarily for TV. These have little sporting credibility and offer minimal prize money. Experienced players (and journalists) approach them wearily, and often cynically. The participants are often under-motivated and bored - in contrast to the unregulated bookmakers based in the subcontinent and the Gulf, who find these occasions absolutely entrancing. Cronje, according to Ali Bacher, chief executive of South Africa's United Cricket Board, was "harassed almost continually by bookmakers" on South Africa's recent tour of India. If he has been led into temptation, who can be surprised? Cronje yesterday admitted taking money but denied ever being involved in rigging a match. Both these propositions could be true once you take into account the form of gambling known in this country as "spread betting" which has become wildly popular within the past four years. This involves treating a sporting proposition as a share price, which can be bought and sold. Thus not merely can you "buy" and back a horse to do well in a race, you can "sell" it and collect if it fails. Under British law, these deals are not subject to the betting tax that afflict other forms of gambling. And they offer far more scope for imaginative punting than is possible down the local bookies. In cricket, you can buy or sell individual batsmen, the number of wides in a match, the time of the first boundary; one firm offered a spread on how many times John Major would be seen on TV watching World Cup matches. Last night, Sporting Index, one of the market leaders, was offering match bets enabling you to choose whether Trap 4 would beat Trap 5 in a greyhound race at Peterborough, and by how much. In football, they have had spreads on the time of the first throw-in, which one Premiership team laughingly took up and punted the ball off the field straight from the kick-off. You see, no match-rigging there either. As such. There is a lot of harmless fun here, and we have little evidence of corruption inside Britain. However, the big-money operators in Asia - notionally illegal - are, in fact, able to bet on anything with impunity and zero regulation. Naturally, they try and suborn cricketers to try and shift the odds in their favour. It's a morass, and cricket is in it up to its neck while pretending that its big toe is just getting a little mucky. In the 18th century, cricket was primarily a gambling game. The scandals multiplied until, in 1817, one William Lambert was chucked out of the game, and the bookmakers were kicked out from Lord's. The ban remained for the next 150 years. The time has come to expel the money-changers from the temple once again. It will take concerted, worldwide, action to achieve that. Otherwise, these scandals are just going to keep on coming. matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

fields.headline: Why the Sun's warm
fields.trailText: Paul Whiteley argues (Paper politics, April 11) Labour must continue to cuddle up to Murdoch because it was the Sun's change which caused its readership to stop voting Conservative. It seems to me rather more likely the Sun was reacting to a change in the opinion of its readership and moved towards Labour to keep its sales figures up. A rather different explanation requiring a different strategy.

A rather different explanation requiring a different strategy.

Angela Phillips, Goldsmiths College a.phillips@gold.ac.uk

 An increasingly common theme in letters (April 10) is "come the next election ..." Where have these people been for the last 20 years? I will happily consider the alternatives, but from my viewpoint there don't seem to be many.

Peter Manwaring, Bognor Regis, W Sussex

 It's not unexpected that the government is refusing to endorse European car-free day (Letters, April 11). In fact the car-free day idea originated in Bath, actually from some of my neighbours. Another case of UK officialdom refusing to back a British innovation?

B Jones, Bath hssbj@bath.ac.uk

 Not all pallas's warblers have yet been lured to their death (English Nature deflects birds at risk, April 10). A warbler has been feeding in my garden since mid-March.

Mike O'Brien, Peterborough mobee@blaisdon.fsnet.co.uk

 I would like to express my great sadness that Damien Hirst (Inside Britart, G2. April 10) is willing to jeopardise his great talent for imbibing drink and drugs by contemplating a return to the sleazy art habits of his past.

Melvin Goldsmith, Chelmsford, Essex

 Isn't it rather touching that the singer Heinz (Obituaries, April 11) has died at 57.

Lesley Walker, Manchester

fields.headline: What Bernie meant to us
fields.trailText: For over 25 years Bernie Grant (Obituary, April 10) represented his community as an activist, trade unionist, councillor and MP. He did this with energy and enthusiasm, and with a clarity of vision and unflinching leadership. The tributes from so many sources show what an important contribution to the development of a multicultural Britain he has made: always willing to listen, engage and challenge whatever situation and whoever he encountered
fields.body:
For over 25 years Bernie Grant (Obituary, April 10) represented his community as an activist, trade unionist, councillor and MP. He did this with energy and enthusiasm, and with a clarity of vision and unflinching leadership. The tributes from so many sources show what an important contribution to the development of a multicultural Britain he has made: always willing to listen, engage and challenge whatever situation and whoever he encountered

I worked closely with him for nearly 20 years to bring black and ethnic minority politics into the mainstream. This involved a searching analysis of history and geography, the impact of migration and colonialism, and how power is gained and exercised in favour of oppressed people. This led Bernie to conclude that the unity and purpose of the black and ethnic minority communities had to be harnessed: only then could we be in a position to be taken seriously. He united workers in industries and the public services through the Black Trade Unionist Solidarity Movement in the early 80s; pulled together the Labour party black section in pursuing seats in councils and in parliament; improved the bargaining position of agriculture workers in the Carribbean. The list could go on - the project needs to go on.

Cllr Narendra Makanji, London Borough of Haringey

 Bernie Grant MP remained his own man. He was prepared to criticise education standards in his own borough and refused to be muzzled. He was unfailingly polite whenever we met and was an outspoken champion on behalf of his Tottenham constituents. Voters have lost one of the few MPs on the Labour benches to stick to their principles.

Cllr Peter Forrest

fields.headline: Abundant blame for Ethiopia's famine
fields.trailText: Your headline of April 5, "Race to save 16m from starvation, EU faces obstacles of war as it steps up aid to Africa," is misleading in that it implies that the war between Ethiopia and Eritrea is impeding shipment of aid. But port access is not the issue - there is access through the ports of Djibouti and potentially through Berbera in Somalia, which are, in any case, closest to the area hit hardest by the drought. The drought and food shortages are caused by the failure of the rains, sporadic heavy rains, climactic change, and the consequent crop failures. The problem we face is that the aid is simply not there.
fields.body:
Your headline of April 5, "Race to save 16m from starvation, EU faces obstacles of war as it steps up aid to Africa," is misleading in that it implies that the war between Ethiopia and Eritrea is impeding shipment of aid. But port access is not the issue - there is access through the ports of Djibouti and potentially through Berbera in Somalia, which are, in any case, closest to the area hit hardest by the drought. The drought and food shortages are caused by the failure of the rains, sporadic heavy rains, climactic change, and the consequent crop failures. The problem we face is that the aid is simply not there.

In April 1999, Ethiopian Disaster Prevention and Preparedness Commission officials briefed the British government and UK-based aid agencies about the probable effect of the drought. Foreign minister Seyoum Mesfin issued an appeal for food aid last December and another in January this year. There was little response.

The EU spokesman you quote inadvertently exposes the problem. He says: "We are getting organised, and if we can now plan to move 800,000 tonnes that's a good start" - why were preparations not begun months if not years ago? As he admits, European Commission representatives have only recently arrived in Ethiopia, to check the situation for themselves - again, why only now?

Beyene Negewo, Ethiopian ambassador

 What evidence does Jonathan Steele have ("A doubled population and no aid," April 10) that the Eritrean government is to blame for starting the war? A peace package drawn by the Organisation for African Unity, the UN and the US has been accepted by Eritrea while Ethiopia has been prevaricating on the issue of technical arrangements. The war has nothing to do with borders as we are led to believe, but a wider agenda by the Ethiopian government. The government in Addis has spent an estimated $2bn on acquiring sophisticated weaponry for the war against Eritrea while people are starving all around it. How could the west be expected to give aid while huge amounts are going down the drain in this unnecessary war?

Mussie Marcos, London: mmarcos@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Adopt a new system
fields.trailText: The proposal for a national register (Blair to help parents adopt, April 10) is likely to help match approved adopters with children waiting to be adopted. Whilst there are a large number of approved adopters waiting for babies, our biggest need is for families prepared to take older children, many of whom have difficult and challenging behaviour. In addition, many adopters are not prepared to take children whose families have severe mental health, drug or alcohol problems.
fields.body:
The proposal for a national register (Blair to help parents adopt, April 10) is likely to help match approved adopters with children waiting to be adopted. Whilst there are a large number of approved adopters waiting for babies, our biggest need is for families prepared to take older children, many of whom have difficult and challenging behaviour. In addition, many adopters are not prepared to take children whose families have severe mental health, drug or alcohol problems.

It is therefore simplistic to just compare numbers of adopters waiting with children waiting. But this makes it more, not less, important that a system is found to ensure that the precious resources of applicants for difficult children is not wasted. Social services directors are examining different ways in which resources can be shared at their conference this week, but it is likely that government financial support will be needed to attract and recruit more adoptive applicants.

Rob Hutchinson, Association of Directors of Social Services

 Producing national standards and a database run the risk of creating yet more centralisation without addressing the key issues. One is the need to change our outdated adoption law which, in its thinking, is some 40 years old. It needs to recognise the reality that adoption today is not based on babies voluntarily given up by young mothers, but older children subject to care orders who have often been neglected or abused. We need a law which gives powers to the courts to review regularly the way plans have or have not been implemented on individual children. The other area is to redress the growing lack of adoption expertise. This could be tackled by making the existing two-year course one year longer and turning out social workers with the skills and enthusiasm to work within a new act.

JM Richards, Catholic Children's Society

 It is thrilling that the government is at last considering national computer registers for children and adopters to aid matching. But it quite took our breath away to read Felicity Collier claiming the idea for the British Agencies for Adopting and Fostering. We proprosed it in 1997, along with other vital reforms, and BAAF's response was a pompous flea in the ear. We continue to demand the establishment of such registers along with an independent watchdog. Now we're desperately hoping Felicity adopts this policing principle with similar enthusiasm.

Liv O'Hanlon, The Adoption Forum livoh@globalnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Cliff's tops
fields.trailText: It was with sorrow and disbelief that I read of Tony Cliff's death (Obituary, April 11). Cliff has left a legacy of inspiration, to young people especially, for he encouraged them to realise that they were empowered to bring about change in any unjust or cruel matters. He stressed that lasting change only came about from individuals themselves, who, as soon as they became aware of the problem, could seek out others of like minds and start to fight together.
fields.body:
It was with sorrow and disbelief that I read of Tony Cliff's death (Obituary, April 11). Cliff has left a legacy of inspiration, to young people especially, for he encouraged them to realise that they were empowered to bring about change in any unjust or cruel matters. He stressed that lasting change only came about from individuals themselves, who, as soon as they became aware of the problem, could seek out others of like minds and start to fight together.

He was the ideal guest, only desiring to be able to listen and to watch news bulletins, perhaps whilst munching a bit of cake! To attend a public meeting when he was speaking - often standing room only - was a great experience. You came away having learnt a lot and determined to work even harder against oppression of any sort. He was colour and religious blind, as he only saw the important parts of people.

M Tennison, Hull

 Paul Foot describes Tony Cliff's theory of state capitalism as his "unique contribution" to Socialism. Maria Spiradnova of the Left Social Revolutionary's was advancing that thesis in Russia 1918. Lenin himself said that state capitalism was the way forward for Russia, in 1921. Even here in Britain the case for the state capitalist thesis had been put forward by the Socialist party long before Cliff turned to it. Worse, though, is Foot's attempt to pass off the Wobblie martyr Joe Hill's will - "Don't mourn, organise" - as an aphorism of Cliff's.

Bill Martin, Redcar, Cleveland

reddeathy@yahoo.co.uk

fields.headline: From hero to zero
fields.standfirst: Cronje's sacking threatens cricket itself
fields.trailText: "It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of 50m people, with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe." Thus did F Scott Fitzgerald, in The Great Gatsby, express his astonishment at the greatest example of sporting corruption of all time - the fixing of baseball's World Series in 1919, when the Chicago White Sox deliberately lost to the Cincinatti Reds. The words of one boy to his hero, the legendary "Shoeless" Joe Jackson, who with seven other players was implicated in the scandal, have resonated down the years: "Say it ain't so, Joe."
fields.body:
"It never occurred to me that one man could start to play with the faith of 50m people, with the single-mindedness of a burglar blowing a safe." Thus did F Scott Fitzgerald, in The Great Gatsby, express his astonishment at the greatest example of sporting corruption of all time - the fixing of baseball's World Series in 1919, when the Chicago White Sox deliberately lost to the Cincinatti Reds. The words of one boy to his hero, the legendary "Shoeless" Joe Jackson, who with seven other players was implicated in the scandal, have resonated down the years: "Say it ain't so, Joe."

The words, later turned into a song, stand as a child's lament for the end of innocence. "Say it ain't so, Hansie," might not scan quite so well, but the betting scandal which yesterday led to the South African captain Hansie Cronje's sacking is potentially every bit as lethal as the World Series debacle, which resonates in the US even today. Cronje was the player who had brought South Africa back into world cricket and made them one of the strongest teams in the world; he was a hero at home and had won respect abroad. Now he is exposed as a liar: a person who, despite his proclaimed Christian code, was willing to accept money from Indian bookmakers and then lied about it.

It has not yet been established what the money was for - information, as Cronje now claims, or something more sinister - but South African cricket, as its chief executive Dr Ali Bacher said yesterday, is already "shattered". The transcript of the tape released by the Indian police suggests that Cronje had encouraged his team-mates to make scores agreed in advance with bookmakers, enabling them to cash in on the spread betting market, where wagers are placed not on the result of a match but on individual performances. If that is true, Cronje's career and that of the other three players implicated in the scandal will end in ignominy, and cricket itself will be in disgrace. Say it ain't so.

webTitle: Barak's US peace visit upstaged by Golan homes

fields.headline: Barak's US peace visit upstaged by Golan homes
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: As the bulldozers ploughed up the earth for yet more settlers' homes in the occupied Golan Heights yesterday, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, arrived in Washington for a one-day summit with President Bill Clinton intended to nudge forward twin peace processes that now seem hopelessly stalled.
fields.body:
As the bulldozers ploughed up the earth for yet more settlers' homes in the occupied Golan Heights yesterday, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, arrived in Washington for a one-day summit with President Bill Clinton intended to nudge forward twin peace processes that now seem hopelessly stalled.

The decision to construct another 200 homes at Katzrin, the largest settlement on the strategic plateau that was captured from Syria in the 1967 war, was the most visible sign yet that Mr Barak has given up hope of reviving peace talks with Damascus. It means that the withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon - which he has pledged to complete by July - will be conducted under fire from Hizbullah guerrillas.

"We checked and we tried, and the answer today from the Syrians is that they are not ready yet for peace," Israel's foreign minister, David Levy, told Israel army radio.

The report of new settlement activity is bound to draw a hostile response from Mr Clinton in talks that were due to get under way yesterday evening.

Although Mr Barak's sudden trip to Washington was undertaken ostensibly to unblock negotiations with the Palestinians and clear the way for the declaration of an independent state in September, the expansion of the settlement at Katzrin now takes centre stage.

"As long as the Syrians continue to express their positions the way they have been expressing in the past few days - then there is no point to negotiations," Haim Ramon, the minister for Jerusalem, told Israeli radio.

"We must allow the residents of the Golan Heights to work, to develop, to approve housing if necessary."

The message from Katzrin is intended for multiple audiences. It could be last-minute brinkmanship intended to concentrate the mind of Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, on reopening negotiations, and spare Israel the prospect of embarking on a promised withdrawal from south Lebanon that will leave its northern villages vulnerable to attack.

It is equally aimed at appeasing Mr Barak's domestic audience. In recent weeks, even liberal Israelis have despaired at Mr Assad's determination to hold out for nothing less than a complete withdrawal from the occupied Golan Heights.

So too has Mr Clinton, who failed in a meeting with President Assad in Geneva last month to persuade him to consider proposals that would have allowed Israel to retain a sliver of the coastline around the lake.

But the scenario created by the absence of a Syrian peace deal is alarming. In recent days Israeli authorities have begun to seek international support for its withdrawal from southern Lebanon.

The lobbying is aimed at securing international commitments to a monitoring body - possibly drawn from the United Nations already in Lebanon - to provide stability in south Lebanon after the Israeli departure.

Israel is also worried about international condemnation should it launch reprisals for any attacks on its territory from south Lebanon after Israeli troops have left.

"Barak is going to try to mobilise American support for having the UN or some kind of multilateral force - maybe French or Canadian - in Lebanon to legitimise Israel's withdrawal," said Efraim Inbar, a political scientist at Bar Ilan university.

"We must allow the residents of the Golan Heights to work, to develop, to approve housing if necessary." The message from Katzrin is intended for multiple audiences. It could be last-minute brinkmanship intended to concentrate the mind of Syria's president, Hafez al-Assad, on reopening negotiations, and spare Israel the prospect of embarking on a promised withdrawal from south Lebanon that will leave its northern villages vulnerable to attack. It is equally aimed at appeasing Mr Barak's domestic audience. In recent weeks, even liberal Israelis have despaired at Mr Assad's determination to hold out for nothing less than a complete withdrawal from the occupied Golan Heights. So too has Mr Clinton, who failed in a meeting with President Assad in Geneva last month to persuade him to consider proposals that would have allowed Israel to retain a sliver of the coastline around the lake. But the scenario created by the absence of a Syrian peace deal is alarming. In recent days Israeli authorities have begun to seek international support for its withdrawal from southern Lebanon. The lobbying is aimed at securing international commitments to a monitoring body - possibly drawn from the United Nations already in Lebanon - to provide stability in south Lebanon after the Israeli departure. Israel is also worried about international condemnation should it launch reprisals for any attacks on its territory from south Lebanon after Israeli troops have left. "Barak is going to try to mobilise American support for having the UN or some kind of multilateral force - maybe French or Canadian - in Lebanon to legitimise Israel's withdrawal," said Efraim Inbar, a political scientist at Bar Ilan university.

fields.headline: Leading from the right
fields.standfirst: Germany looks afresh at Europe
fields.trailText: From the new leader of Germany's conservatives comes a shifting German perspective on Europe: what is needed, says Angela Merkel, is a transfer of power to national, regional and local level, less decision-making in Brussels, incentives for enterprise and greater deregulation.
fields.body:
From the new leader of Germany's conservatives comes a shifting German perspective on Europe: what is needed, says Angela Merkel, is a transfer of power to national, regional and local level, less decision-making in Brussels, incentives for enterprise and greater deregulation.

Ms Merkel was addressing this week's CDU party conference in Essen. But she might have been talking to the Tories in Blackpool, or New Labour in Brighton, so blurred have the battlelines of the European Mitte become.

"Centralisation is the same as egalitarianism and egalitarianism means standstill," declared the successor but one to the former Mr Europe, Helmut Kohl.

Mr Kohl used to call her "my little girl". Now he languishes in disgrace while Ms Merkel, who led the push to dispose of him, walks tall.

While Ms Merkel's outlook remains firmly pro-European, her remarks denote a change of emphasis for the CDU and will feed the wider debate.

Her ideas will be linked to the trend towards "governmentalism" within the EU - put simply, curbing the Commission's federalist ambitions. They speak directly to the devolution question, a live issue in much of the EU.

In pledging "a Europe of the people", she appears to turn away, unsurprisingly, from the cosy, corrupt machine politics and welfarism of the Mitterrand-Kohl-Delors era, towards a limited, safety-netted version of a shareholder society and an EU that just works better.

There are messages here aplenty: positive for ardent Euro-reformers like Tony Blair and José Maria Aznar of Spain, less so perhaps for Romano Prodi and Lionel Jospin. Already bemoaning the rustication of the Franco-German axis, Mr Jospin clings fondly to social-market models even as he cuts taxes and red tape as Ms Merkel urges.

For the lacklustre SPD Chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, who is more "new muddle" than "new middle" these days, Ms Merkel presages a different kind of dislocation. She has energy. She is young-ish. She is new. "Everybody is in love with Angela now," crooned the Rheinische Post yesterday. "Except for Schröder."

Less adorable in Essen were Ms Merkel's suggestions that Jörg Haider's Austrian Freedom party is much wronged; that Turkey be barred from joining the EU; and her silence on anti-immigrant laws and rising racial violence. But this is still the CDU after all, plus its xenophobic Bavarian CSU cronies. Things do not change that much.

webTitle: Objectors to clog path to crop trials

fields.headline: Objectors to clog path to crop trials
fields.standfirst:
Ministers face further GM revolt with crop trials stalled by appeals system and risk of giant US salmon breeding with British species
GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Campaigners against genetically modified crops are planning to clog the government machinery for approving the new technology by taking advantage of rarely used official procedures.
fields.body:
Campaigners against genetically modified crops are planning to clog the government machinery for approving the new technology by taking advantage of rarely used official procedures.

Ministers may have to sanction scores of local hearings on plans to sell GM seeds to farmers - a process which will fuel the revolt against modified foods that has already prompted supermarkets to drop GM ingredients in many products and sparked direct action, with protesters trashing trial sites in the countryside.

Yesterday, it emerged that after strong local protest, one farmer - Richard Thompson, who applied to grow GM sugar beet near Tittleshall, Norfolk - pulled out of the national crop trial, saying he felt it was wrong to force the experiment on the community.

Government technical committees have already passed one GM seed type as posing no threat to the environment.

But GM opponents believe that widespread use of the process will prove a time-consuming bureaucratic nightmare for the government, drawing detailed challenges to safety decisions made in private.

Friends of the Earth said last night it was entering "a new uncharted area of democracy", and said that though it could not pay the fees of thousands who might want to lodge individual objections, it would encourage those who wanted to make the challenge.

Members of the public have until April 25 to register objections to ministers' proposals to allow a form of GM maize, used for animal feed, on to the national seed list.

An approval would mean the product has just one more legal stage to pass, although the manufacturers have agreed, under a voluntary code, not to use the product commercially until at least the spring of 2003, after completion of the farm trials.

Civil servants have already notified 4,000 groups and individuals. They admit the appeals system, which allows written objections costing £30 a piece, public hearings costing £60, and further appeals costing £10, could prove lengthy.

They cannot yet assess how it would work in practice and the fees would only cover a small part of the total cost to the government.

Aventis is the first company to apply for national listing for a GM seed, for which it already has EU marketing approval.

Pete Riley, FoE's biotechnology campaigner, said: "Anyone with a concern for the rush towards commercialisation of GM crops should take up this statutory opportunity."

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: 'Loos' with a view of modern art
fields.body:
'Loos' with a view of modern art

The art gallery concept of a private view is about to get a whole new meaning through an exhibition appropriately called Engaged.

Visitors will slide cubicle locks from "vacant" to study work by nine artists in the country's first show to be mounted exclusively in public lavatories.

The unorthodox chain of temporary galleries has been organised to highlight a lack of exhibition space in Newcastle upon Tyne, where Engaged runs from next Thursday.

Cath Campbell, 27, one of two artists behind the scheme, said: "We were looking for somewhere interesting where lots of people go, including those not familiar with contemporary art."

The mini-galleries have been loaned free by pubs and clubs in the city centre and range from a single-cubicle ladies under the stairs at the Telegraph club to what Ms Campbell described as "plush toilet suites" at the Head of Steam pub.

The most adventurous venue is the public gents' lavatory at Bigg Market, where work by Gillian Nichol "will bring something feminine into the domain of the male public toilet", according to the catalogue.

The exhibition will include paintings, sculpture and "events".

Men will theoretically be unable to view the exhibits in the ladies, and vice versa, but Ms Campbell said: "We have an idea that this rule may get broken, particularly on Friday evenings, because of the attractions of art."

Engaged is backed by Northern Arts and runs until May 1, with timed tours available, including commentary by the artists.
Martin Wainwright

School bus boy badly hurt in crash

A boy was being treated for serious head injuries at a specialist neurological unit yesterday after a crash involving a school bus in which 12 other pupils were injured.

Another schoolboy was in hospital suffering from head and shoulder injuries, although his condition was less critical.

The single-decker bus was badly damaged after a collision with a van at Broom, near Bedford. It was on a regular run collecting pupils attending three Catholic schools in Bedford, and had 13 children on board, all thought to be aged between 13 and 15.

Police said a rear section of the bus was extensively damaged. One of the seriously injured boys had to be freed by the fire service. "Apart from the other serious injury, the other children were extremely shocked, and some were cut by flying glass."

They were taken to Bedford general hospital, where only the two most seriously injured children were detained. The boy suffering head injuries was later transferred to Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridge.

New inquiry into kidney blunder

An independent investigation was ordered yesterday into the work of the health trust which runs a hospital where a patient had the wrong kidney removed.

The commission for health improvement has been asked to conduct an inquiry into the Carmarthenshire NHS Trust following the death of Graham Reeves.

Mr Reeves, 70, of Burry Port, died five weeks after surgeons at Prince Philip hospital, Llanelli, removed the wrong kidney, leaving him just a diseased kidney.

The Royal College of Surgeons and the trust have already carried out their own investigations. Dyfed Powys police are investigating Mr Reeves's death on behalf of the coroner.

The Welsh health and social services secretary, Jane Hutt, yesterday said she had asked the CHI to carry out an investigation into the running of the trust.

It will be the commission's first inquiry in Wales and only its second in the UK since it was launched earlier this month.

Man denied sleep 'tried to kill wife'

A tired husband "snapped" and tried to strangle and suffocate his wife after she kept him awake by eating a mint, reading and complaining, Leeds crown court heard yesterday.

Raymond Bentley, 49, a father of two, put a cushion over the face of his wife Colleen, put his hand around her neck and squeezed, telling her: "I need to kill you, I want you to die, I've had enough of you."

Finally he released his wife and she escaped to neighbours, who called the police.

Bentley, a kitchen worker, from Normanton, West Yorkshire, was initially charged with attempted murder but pleaded guilty to causing his wife actual bodily harm.

Robin Denny, prosecuting, told the court that the defendant, whom he described as somewhat "slow", was prevented from sleeping on June 6 last year and "snapped" at around 4am after his 48-year-old wife kept the light on and started to eat. He decided to sleep on the settee and when she followed him he "went for her".

Mr Denny said: "She describes Raymond being astride her, holding her down - she felt she was passing out and couldn't breathe."

Mrs Bentley made a complaint to police but later withdrew it. When Bentley was arrested he told police: "I tried to kill her."

Mr Denny said the couple wanted to be reunited. A psychologist's report on Bentley described him as "a neurotic introvert with a high propensity towards criminality, who has a tendency to express anger and doesn't always have the ability to control it".

The recorder of Leeds, Judge Brian Walsh QC, released Bentley on bail, lifted a condition not to contact prosecution witnesses, and adjourned the case for pre-sentence reports.

Chipperfield gets animal licence

A licence to keep wild animals at the family farm of the circus trainer Mary Chipperfield was granted yesterday despite opposition from animal welfare campaigners.

The move sparked anger from Animal Defenders, whose undercover investigation at the Hampshire farm triggered an animal cruelty prosecution last year.

Test Valley borough council said permission had been given to keep four camels and two zebras at Croft Farm in Over Wallop, near Andover, Hampshire.

A thorough investigation had been launched into the application and there was "no supportable reason" why the licence should not be granted.

The application is understood to have been made by Mrs Chipperfield's daughter, Suzanne, but the council refused to confirm or deny the name of the individual.

Mary Chipperfield, 62, was convicted of cruelty to a chimpanzee in January last year and was fined £7,500 last April.

Her husband, Roger Cawley, was fined £1,000 for cruelty towards a sick elephant, but no orders were made to prevent them from keeping or working with animals.

Animal Defenders said 4,000 of their supporters, including the actresses Jenny Seagrove and Annette Crosbie and the former Take That singer Mark Owen, had objected to the application.

They claimed the licence should have been denied because Suzanne Chipperfield was a director of Mary Chipperfield Promotions Ltd at the time of the trial.

Ms Chipperfield, a circus performer, was unavailable for comment because of work commitments.

webTitle: London TV calls in dubbers to tone down Scots accent

fields.headline: London TV calls in dubbers to tone down Scots accent
fields.trailText: The voice of one of Scotland's best loved singers has been dubbed over in a new Scottish drama by London television executives because it sounded too Scottish for viewers south of the border.
fields.body:
The voice of one of Scotland's best loved singers has been dubbed over in a new Scottish drama by London television executives because it sounded too Scottish for viewers south of the border.

Tam White, an Edinburgh-born singer and actor whose gravelly tones took over Robbie Coltrane's singing duties in Tutti Frutti and landed him the role of the MacGregor clan chief in Braveheart, was deemed to have too strong an accent.

In Black and Blue, an adaptation of Ian Rankin's crime thriller to be broadcast next month, London-based TV executives had the Scottish musician's lines redubbed, using the voice of an unnamed actor on the grounds that English viewers might not understand his Scots tones.

White plays debt collector Rico Briggs alongside John Hanna as Rankin's hard drinking Detective Inspector John Rebus.

A London-based spokeswoman for STV and Clerkenwell Productions confirmed that White's lines were dubbed by another actor with "less of an accent".

She said: "Unfortunately we had to redub Tam White's lines. This is not unusual and it was purely for reasons of clarity. Tam was in Australia at the time the decision was made.

"We contacted him there and we understand he is perfectly content."

White is on tour in Germany and was unavailable for comment yesterday.

webTitle: Monster salmon scare for fish farmers

fields.headline: Monster salmon scare for fish farmers
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Genetically modified salmon which grow 10 times faster than normal fish and could reach 12ft long and weigh 200lb are ready to be sold in US supermarkets, according to the company that has developed them.
fields.body:
Genetically modified salmon which grow 10 times faster than normal fish and could reach 12ft long and weigh 200lb are ready to be sold in US supermarkets, according to the company that has developed them.

But the prospect of potentially giant salmon escaping into the wild and attempting to interbreed with native populations has alarmed both environmentalists and the industry.

The developer, A/F Protein of Massachusetts, said there was no risk because the fish would be sterile. However, objectors dispute this.

Any interbreeding with native stock would wreck the normal life cycle of the species which has to drift down river from its spawning grounds and then return after maturing at sea. The growth rate of the GM fish would make this life cycle almost impossible not least because they would eat almost everything in the river.

The Food Standards Agency said yesterday that it had not received an application from the company to market the fish in the UK but could process the application within 90 days if asked to do so. As long as it was clear the fish were safe and no EU partners objected, the salmon could go on sale.

The Department of Environment said that anyone wishing to import super-salmon eggs would need a licence and would not get one unless the department was assured there was no threat to native species. A spokesman pointed out that an experiment on Loch Fyne on GM salmon was abandoned eight years ago because of fears of what the fish might do to other species if it escaped into the environment.

David King, editor of GenEthics News, said it was well documented that farmed salmon did escape and the scientific data showed that not all GM fish were sterile.

"It is not 100% certain you could stop them breeding with wild salmon. The research shows that this company has managed to grow fish 40 times faster than wild ones but they developed deformities, so they have had to slow the growth rate down to produce fish that appear normal.

"In the wild size is important, the biggest fish is top fish, so goodness knows what would happen to the wild population if these bred."

Julie Edgar from Scottish Quality Assurance, which represents salmon farms north of the border, said she did not believe that there was any market for GM salmon in Britain. "The consumer won't want them and certainly the salmon producers do not. We would also worry about these things escaping, there is no doubt that it happens. Fish like this are just not needed. There would be a lot of objections if someone applied for a licence to grow them in Scotland."

 The European Parliament will today vote on a number of tough measures to control GM crops. MEPs are being asked to make GM companies liable in law if there are adverse environmental or health affects from their crops.

Another resolution demands that antibiotics marker genes should be banned. There are fears that these genes when used in crops and fed to cattle might allow super-bugs to breed in animals and be passed on to humans.

Some MEPs are asking for the setting up of a public register of all GM sites in Europe.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Racists target Turkish man
fields.body:
Racists target Turkish man

Three racists beat a Turkish restaurant owner, Ibrahim Ercelyan, with a bottle and a club on Sunday, then set light to his restaurant in Sheffield, South Yorkshire, in a suspected revenge attack motivated by the murders of two Leeds United fans in Istanbul last week.

Police said the incident was racially motivated.

Dutch grant extradition

Judges in the Netherlands yesterday granted the extradition to Scotland of William Beggs, 36, who is wanted in connection with the murder of Barry Wallace, 18, from Kilmarnock, whose remains were found in Loch Lomond, Dunbartonshire, and Troon, Ayrshire, in December. Beggs has 14 days to appeal.

Two in court on £1m art theft

Two men appeared in court yesterday charged with stealing two paintings by John Constable worth £1m from the Victoria and Albert Museum, in London.

Kevin Gande, 34, from Laindon, Essex, and Kevin Jones, 38, from Bow, east London, will appear again on April 19.

Redesign for 'ecstasy' mint

The Birmingham sweet company Trebor Bassett is to launch a new version of its Mighty Mints brand this month after drugs campaigners said they looked like ecstasy pills. The mints were the same shape as tablets of the class A drug.

Shrimps thrive on battlefield

Rare fairy shrimps are thriving in the water-filled ruts made by army tanks on Salisbury Plain, Wiltshire.

webTitle: Age Concern refused man job because he was too old

fields.headline: Age Concern refused man job because he was too old
fields.trailText: Yesterday an Age Concern spokesman conceded that it might have to reconsider its own employment practices
fields.body:
There have been few sterner critics of age discrimination by employers than Age Concern, the lobbyist and charity for the elderly, which last year condemned the government for failing to outlaw the practice in the workplace.

But yesterday an Age Concern spokesman conceded that it might have to reconsider its own employment practices after it emerged that it had rejected a well-qualified applicant for a job because he was too old.

Hector McDonald, 69, a former architect from Surrey, answered a recent advertisement to be Age Concern's parliamentary officer, citing his experience as a former local Conservative councillor, Greater London council member, copywriter and political consultant.

"When I saw the advert, I thought a lively 69-year-old would be in with a shout," he said.

But three days later he was telephoned by Valerie Purchase, of Age Concern's human resources department, who explained that she had had to put his application aside because the charity was unable to employ anyone over 70.

"I told her I was gobsmacked. I thought of all people Age Concern wouldn't have a barrier on age, especially since they made a big noise about being an equal opportunities employer."

He sent a further letter, pleading for an interview and offering to work on a self-employed basis, but has had no reply. His case has now been taken up by IDF50, an internet magazine for over-50s.

Age Concern's spokesman, Rory Hegarty, yesterday defended the charity's policy. "We do want to encourage people to retire and enjoy later life. It's something we might look at again. Cases like this give you pause for thought."

When the government last year published its code of practice against ageism Age Concern complained that it had failed to stick to an earlier pledge to legislate.

The charity said then: "Older workers will still have no legal recourse if they think they have suffered age discrimination. Only comprehensive equal opportunities legislation will enable the victims to challenge employers effectively."

fields.headline: Murder inquiry over Metro baby
fields.trailText: Police launched a murder inquiry yesterday after the death of a baby who was found with horrific facial and head injuries in his pram at a city centre railway station.
fields.body:
Police launched a murder inquiry yesterday after the death of a baby who was found with horrific facial and head injuries in his pram at a city centre railway station.

Magistrates yesterday gave detectives an additional 36 hours to question the child's 24-year-old father, who was with the baby when the alarm was raised by passengers on the Metro rapid transit net work in Newcastle upon Tyne.

Three youths arrested after claims that a gang had been involved in the incident were released on bail shortly after the five-month-old baby died in the intensive care unit of Newcastle general hospital.

Detective Superintendent Chris Symonds, leading the investigation, said: "The death of this baby is now being treated as murder."

The boy was found battered and bleeding by police officers called to Manors station on the Metro, five minutes' walk from Newcastle city centre, on Sunday afternoon.

He died with his mother by his bedside after efforts to revive him and treat skull and brain injuries failed.

Robert Bullock, intensive care specialist, said that the child had shown no signs of improvement during treatment and it had never been likely that he would pull through.

Police appealed for witnesses after studying station security camera tapes handed over by Nexus, the Metro's operators, which are understood to have caught most of the incident.

The station remained closed yesterday while forensic teams combed platforms and approach areas.

webTitle: Controls eased on 'too costly' cancer drugs

fields.headline: Controls eased on 'too costly' cancer drugs
fields.trailText: Two new life saving cancer drugs are expected to be recommended by the national institute
fields.body:
Two new life saving cancer drugs, which some health authorities have rejected on grounds of cost, are expected to be recommended by the national institute for clinical excellence as standard treatments for women with breast and ovarian cancer.

Cancer patients and charities greeted with delight yesterday the news, leaked to the BBC, of Nice's intentions.

The body, set up by the government "to end the lottery of postcode prescribing" by comparing drugs and other treatments and issuing guidelines on what works best and is most cost-effective, is due to report on the group of cancer drugs known as the taxanes at the end of the month.

The two drugs that seem set to get the green light are Taxol for early and late-stage ovarian cancer and Taxotere for advanced breast cancer.

But whatever the recommendation from Nice, there are still doubts over whether all health authorities will be prepared to pay for the drugs, which cost £10,000 a year per patient - even though the health secretary, Alan Milburn, has said that some of the £2bn rise on health spending should go to funding Nice guidance.

Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said the guidance on the taxanes would leave health authorities "with nowhere to hide. Hopefully, it will end the discrimination that has existed against NHS patients in favour of the private sector."

The drugs have long been available in the United States. "We are expecting any day now some sort of papal announcement from Nice that what is happening in the rest of the world can be allowed to happen in Britain too," said Professor McVie.

He believed the drugs could benefit 4,000 to 5,000 ovarian cancer patients and 15,000 to 20,000 women with breast cancer.

Both drugs have been licensed for some time - Taxol is licensed for both ovarian and advanced breast cancer but Nice is said to want more evidence of its effect on breast cancer before it will recommend that use. Professor McVie suggested Nice was lagging behind the research, which showed both drugs could prolong life if they were used in early-stage cancers.

Jackie O'Donnell, 55, from Middlesbrough, who was diagnosed with ovarian cancer in November 1998, said the news was wonderful. She did not know of Taxol until she read about it.

When she asked her consultant, he said he was not supposed to mention it to her because Tees health authority would not pay.

"If I had lived just two miles away, I could have had Taxol because the health authority in North Yorkshire did pay for it. I really didn't believe the postcode lottery existed until it happened to me," she said.

After a long campaign, Mrs O'Donnell was given the drug and the health authority later changed its policy. At her last check-up, she was clear of the cancer.

Nice would not confirm the leaked reports and the Department of Health said only that there would be extra funds available to health authorities to help fund the institute's recommendations

webTitle: Eye spy a crowd puller  Cities worldwide want giant wheel

fields.headline: Eye spy a crowd puller  Cities worldwide want giant wheel
fields.trailText: The London Eye is proving so popular at least six other cities around the world - including Boston, Toronto, Johannesburg and Sydney - are interested in building replicas of it.
fields.body:
The London Eye is proving so popular at least six other cities around the world - including Boston, Toronto, Johannesburg and Sydney - are interested in building replicas of it.

Yesterday the giant ferris wheel's owners, British Airways, confirmed that several cities had been in contact, showing an interest in developing their own version of the 450ft tourist attraction.

"There's no reason in principle why we could not build an identical Eye in other cities," a BA spokeswoman said.

Paul Bates, BA's London Eye project director, said: "All being well, we would be very interested in building and running overseas wheels ourselves. People have realised there is something unique about this kind of observation wheel."

The London Tourist Board, however, was less enthusiastic. "Like the Eiffel Tower and the Empire State building, the Eye is rapidly becoming an icon, so it would be nice to keep it exclusive to London," said Rachel Dibsdale, a spokeswoman for the board.

Visitors riding on the 2,100-tonne wheel, open since March 1, get a panoramic view - over 25 miles - of the city and the home counties. Situated on the south bank of the Thames, the wheel's 32 passenger capsules are also a good spot for gazing at the Houses of Parliament.

About 70,000 tourists a week are enjoying the 30-minute ride, and almost 1m tickets have been sold.

BA hopes to carry more than 2m visitors on the £35m wheel in the first 12 months. The airline has planning permission for the wheel to remain for five years, although it is likely that it will become a permanent attraction.

webTitle: Tomato growers put feng shui to the test

fields.headline: Tomato growers put feng shui to the test
fields.trailText: Britain's tomato growers are hoping to turn the tables on cheap imports and a strong pound by experimenting with feng shui - the psychology of interior decoration - to grow larger trusses of fatter fruit.
fields.body:
Britain's tomato growers are hoping to turn the tables on cheap imports and a strong pound by experimenting with feng shui - the psychology of interior decoration - to grow larger trusses of fatter fruit.

Advisers in the oriental art of rearranging furniture to create "inner harmony" toured 11 leading market gardens yesterday to advise on where to position tomato pots for the maximum crop.

The consultants also plotted yin and yang patterns for beehives in the glasshouses, housing some 2,500,000 imported bumblebees which have become the industry's main pollinator over the past decade.

Experimental feng shui systems will be monitored in the pilot projects in Hull, Cheshire and nine other sites and compared with the coming season's production figures.

"I know a lot of people are sceptical about feng shui," said Peter Lansdale, chairman of the British Tomato Growers' Association which produces 120,000 tonnes of the fruit every year. "But we are not afraid to think laterally and try new ideas - and we need to with the strength of sterling and the flood of cheap, long-life, foreign tomatoes."

The experiment follows a pilot scheme last year which saw loud rock music played to flowering tomatoes, to encourage pollination by increasing air wave vibrations.

Philip Pearson, whose eight acre nursery at Alderley Edge, Cheshire, is one of the pilot sites, said that his yin and yang consultant had expressed delight with his glasshouses' "chi".

"That's their word for energy," he said. "But she immediately rearranged our straight lines of hives into zig-zags - and I have to say you could see the bees zigging and zagging naturally between them and the plants."

fields.headline: 'Kind' Noye weeps in court
fields.trailText: Kenneth Noye, who is accused of murder in a road rage attack on the M25, put his head in his hands and wept yesterday as the Old Bailey heard a statement from a disabled man who testified to his kindness and patience.
fields.body:
Kenneth Noye, who is accused of murder in a road rage attack on the M25, put his head in his hands and wept yesterday as the Old Bailey heard a statement from a disabled man who testified to his kindness and patience.

David Williams, who broke his back in a car accident in 1973, described how Noye and his wife Brenda took him out for meals and treated him "as one of the family" when they met by chance during a holiday in northern Cyprus six years ago.

"Most people shy away from me but he was just the opposite," said Mr Williams, who uses a wheelchair. As Stephen Batten QC continued to read from the statement, Noye began to cry.

The testimony came as the defence finished its case. Noye, 52, has denied murdering 21-year-old Stephen Cameron at the Swanley interchange of the M25 in May 1996.

Noye, of Sevenoaks, Kent, has claimed he stabbed Cameron in self-defence.

Earlier, the jury heard evidence from James Hutton, a retired computer engineer, who said he was involved in a road rage incident in April 1996 with a man he believed to be Stephen Cameron.

Mr Hutton said he was heading to work near Heathrow when he was cut up by a red Rascal van. When he flashed his lights, the van pulled over and a man got out. "He walked towards my car.

"I immediately thought he seemed to be in a rage. I thought 'This guy's crazy'. He stood there for about six seconds. I was extremely relieved when the person got back in the van."

Julian Bevan, QC, began his closing speech for the prosecution by insisting Noye had not feared for his life when he stabbed Mr Cameron.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Strike closes pit run by miners in 'silly' dispute

fields.headline: Strike closes pit run by miners in 'silly' dispute
fields.trailText: In what must rate as one of the more bizarre industrial disputes, a coal mine owned by its workforce was closed yesterday by a strike.
fields.body:
In what must rate as one of the more bizarre industrial disputes, a coal mine owned by its workforce was closed yesterday by a strike.

Around 100 miners at the last deep pit in Wales, Tower Colliery, walked out after a row with managers who told two employees to change their work schedule.

The colliery, near Merthyr Tydfil, became a workers' cooperative five years ago. When it was put up for sale in 1995 after British Coal said it should close, 239 of the pit's workers chipped in £8,000 each from their redundancy money and kept it open.

Tower was traditionally one of the most militant collieries in Britain - absolute solidarity made a picket line unnecessary during the strike of 1984-1985.

The latest trouble surfaced when coalface workers were told they would be transferred to another part of the mine to carry out dust suppression work. They refused, prompting a walkout by the morning shift early yesterday.

Officials for the National Union of Mineworkers urged miners who were due to clock on for the afternoon shift to resume work. But at a meeting in the pit canteen they also decided to strike.

Face workers at Tower earn around £400 a week. Annual bonuses are distributed and at the end of the first year there was a £3,000 payout.

Tyrone O'Sullivan, a director of the cooperative and a former NUM official, said: "There comes a time when men have got to grow up.

"This is the first time muscles have been flexed at Tower since we took over. Under British Coal there would have been an agreement to enable work to continue."

Mr O'Sullivan said production had stopped, although coal already brought to the surface was being delivered to customers.

He added that the two workers had been told to do jobs that they were trained to do, but refused and then decided to go home.

He said about 14 workers left the morning shift yesterday in support and most of the afternoon shift also went on strike.

About 80 of the colliery's 400-strong workforce were working to provide orders for the pit's two main customers, including Aberthaw power station, he added.

Mr O'Sullivan said: "The union is discussing it with the men and we are waiting for them to come back. I think the men will resolve this. They will realise what's happened and how silly they have been."

The pit produces up to 3,000 tonnes of coal a day.

The survival of Tower is important in an area largely untouched by the electronics era. Unemployment in the valley is around 10% and health and housing problems abound.

It is estimated that without the colliery the local economy would lose up to £10m a year.

The success of the mine has attracted widespread praise. The workers' buyout was even recently turned into an opera.

webTitle: Knife found in garden of Lawrence suspects

fields.headline: Knife found in garden of Lawrence suspects
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting the racist killers of Stephen Lawrence revealed yesterday that they have recovered a knife and a metal bar in the garden of the former home of two of the five original suspects.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting the racist killers of Stephen Lawrence revealed yesterday that they have recovered a knife and a metal bar in the garden of the former home of two of the five original suspects.

The discovery was made in the grounds of the former Acourt family home in Bournbrook Road, Eltham, close to where the teenager was stabbed to death in south-east London seven years ago.

The house where the items were found is listed in the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report as the home of suspects Jamie and Neil Acourt in 1993. It now has new occupants.

Scotland Yard refused to say when the weapons were discovered or give details of who tipped it off.

But deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, head of the racial and violent crimes taskforce, confirmed the knife and the bar had been sent for forensic analysis.

The tests could take weeks.

Although the police examined many knives in the aftermath of Stephen's murder on May 7 1993, they were never confident that they had identified the murder weapon.

A red-handled kitchen knife with a 10in (25cm) blade was handed to police by the mother of Gaynor Cullen, who was the girlfriend of Gary Dobson, one of the original suspects.

The weapon was shown again recently on a Crimewatch programme and is also being re-examined by scientists.

The knife found recently is a similar size.

If this were the weapon used to kill Stephen Lawrence, it would be a significant breakthrough for the Metropolitan police, which has never given up hope of successfully prosecuting the men who stabbed the 18-year-old student.

Gary Dobson, Neil Acourt and Luke Knight were acquitted in 1996 of Stephen's murder when a private prosecution brought by the Lawrence family collapsed.

The case against Jamie Acourt and David Norris was dropped before it reached court.

Mr Grieve said yesterday: "Not only are people now willing to speak to us, but there could also be new evidence.

"We know there are people out there who know exactly what happened to Stephen Lawrence and can give important evidence.

"They know that we are going to get justice for Stephen. What happened has preyed on their consciences for seven years. Now is the time to come and speak to us.

"Tell us what you know. It could just prove to be the final piece of the puzzle."

Scotland Yard has been hinting for weeks that detectives are closer than ever to discovering what happened to Lawrence and seem confident they know who was responsible for his murder.

But Mr Grieve has been loth to be too specific, saying the inquiry is at a very delicate stage. He has a team of officers working from a secret location in south London.

The squad believes the ties that bound the gang which was responsible for the murder have loosened over time.

Last month three men were questioned in connection with the murder. They were arrested on the day that Lawrence's parents, Doreen and Neville, made a fresh appeal on BBC's Crimewatch for witnesses to come forward.

The men were bailed to appear at police stations in south London.

But deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, head of the racial and violent crimes taskforce, confirmed the knife and the bar had been sent for forensic analysis. The tests could take weeks. Although the police examined many knives in the aftermath of Stephen's murder on May 7 1993, they were never confident that they had identified the murder weapon. A red-handled kitchen knife with a 10in (25cm) blade was handed to police by the mother of Gaynor Cullen, who was the girlfriend of Gary Dobson, one of the original suspects. The weapon was shown again recently on a Crimewatch programme and is also being re-examined by scientists. The knife found recently is a similar size. If this were the weapon used to kill Stephen Lawrence, it would be a significant breakthrough for the Metropolitan police, which has never given up hope of successfully prosecuting the men who stabbed the 18-year-old student. Gary Dobson, Neil Acourt and Luke Knight were acquitted in 1996 of Stephen's murder when a private prosecution brought by the Lawrence family collapsed. The case against Jamie Acourt and David Norris was dropped before it reached court. Mr Grieve said yesterday: "Not only are people now willing to speak to us, but there could also be new evidence. "We know there are people out there who know exactly what happened to Stephen Lawrence and can give important evidence. "They know that we are going to get justice for Stephen. What happened has preyed on their consciences for seven years. Now is the time to come and speak to us. "Tell us what you know. It could just prove to be the final piece of the puzzle." Scotland Yard has been hinting for weeks that detectives are closer than ever to discovering what happened to Lawrence and seem confident they know who was responsible for his murder. But Mr Grieve has been loth to be too specific, saying the inquiry is at a very delicate stage. He has a team of officers working from a secret location in south London. The squad believes the ties that bound the gang which was responsible for the murder have loosened over time. Last month three men were questioned in connection with the murder. They were arrested on the day that Lawrence's parents, Doreen and Neville, made a fresh appeal on BBC's Crimewatch for witnesses to come forward. The men were bailed to appear at police stations in south London.

webTitle: Prescott's 10-year plan to boost deprived areas

fields.headline: Prescott's 10-year plan to boost deprived areas
fields.trailText: John Prescott will today unveil a 10-year strategy to turn round some of England's 3,000 poorest communities with the hint of billions of pounds extra to modernise homes, improve health, create jobs and fight crime.
fields.body:
John Prescott will today unveil a 10-year strategy to turn round some of England's 3,000 poorest communities with the hint of billions of pounds extra to modernise homes, improve health, create jobs and fight crime.

His initiative will be combined with plans to monitor poverty at local level using government statisticians to develop on-the-ground indicators of need.

This means agencies, or councils, would be held to account if targets for reducing deprivation are not met. A ministerial group could be established to co-ordinate policy.

Mr Prescott will also announce an immediate extension of the £800m New Deal for Communities programme from 17 pilot projects on some of the country's poorest estates to seven new areas.

He will visit a rebuilt estate in Leytonstone, north-east London, to stress that neighbourhoods can be brought back to life with a renewal programme involving tenants, local agencies, government departments and town halls.

Mr Prescott will signal a radical programme aimed at bringing the poorest communities up the prosperity league over the next decade by launching a national strategy for neighbourhood renewal.

It talks of "bridging the gap between the most deprived neighbourhoods and the rest of England"

It is based on the most detailed analysis of poverty yet undertaken in England following recommendations from a string of "cross-cutting" policy action teams working under the government's social exclusion unit.

They have examined ways of curbing anti-social behaviour, creating new jobs, improving schools and creating more demand for homes in unpopular areas.

In a preliminary report from the unit 18 months ago, ministers were told that the gap between the poorest communities and the rest of the country had grown dramatically over the past two decades.

It highlighted 44 local authority districts which had the highest concentrations of deprivation in England with two thirds more unemployment than average, mortality rates 30% above the norm and three times the level of poor housing.

But ministers have been keen to encourage local partnerships and "active citizens" with new community enterprises.

The SEU has talked of "dynamic local leaders with the power and resources to turn their community around".

The local government and regeneration minister, Hilary Armstrong, will today endorse plans for neighbourhood managers to handle complaints.

fields.headline: No 10 caught in 'spinning' row
fields.standfirst: Downing Street 'misled' objectors to science project
fields.trailText: Tony Blair faced embarrassment last night when it emerged that Downing Street had given a misleading account of the government's decision to base a multi-million pound science project in Oxfordshire, rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.
fields.body:
Tony Blair faced embarrassment last night when it emerged that Downing Street had given a misleading account of the government's decision to base a multi-million pound science project in Oxfordshire, rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.

In a move which raised fresh questions about government "spinning", one of the project's backers released a letter which directly challenged Downing Street's claim that ministers had been forced to abandon the northern laboratory.

Ministers faced a backbench rebellion from north-west Labour MPs last month when the government decided to site the £500m synchrotron project at the Rutherford Appleton laboratory at Didcot, instead of at the Daresbury laboratory in Cheshire.

Downing Street attempted to quell the revolt by claiming that its hand had been forced by the Wellcome Trust and the French government - the project's two other backers - who had demanded that the project be based in Oxfordshire.

The Wellcome Trust yesterday rejected Downing Street's account by pointing out that it had only thrown its weight behind the Oxfordshire laboratory under pressure from the government.

Michael Dexter, the trust's director, said that the government's Office for Science and Technology (OST) had "persuaded" him to support the Oxfordshire site at a meeting in April last year. "Prior to the OST's recommendation we had not seriously considered any locations," Mr Dexter said in a letter to the leaders of Warrington and Halton borough councils. "Government persuaded us that locating the synchrotron [in Oxfordshire] was the best way forward and we agreed to this in June 1999."

Mr Dexter admitted, however, that the Wellcome Trust was reluctant to change its mind once it had opted for the Oxfordshire site.

His account raised questions about a Downing Street briefing last month in which the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said: "The French and Wellcome were very clearly of the view that they wanted the new synchrotron at Didcot. Wellcome had said publicly in advance that if the decision was taken to locate the new synchrotron [in Cheshire] they would withdraw."

Labour MPs from the north-west last night called on the government to clarify its position.

Mr Campbell was right to say that the Wellcome Trust had insisted on the synchrotron being based in Oxfordshire. Having accepted the recommendation of the OST, the trust was furious in November when the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, rejected its recommendation and called for the project to be based in Cheshire. In his account, however, Mr Campbell made no mention that the OST had favoured the project being based in Oxfordshire.

Louise Ellman, the Labour MP for Liverpool Riverside, said last night: "I am extremely disturbed by the Wellcome Trust's letter. We need to know whether it is Wellcome or the government who is telling the truth."

Sir Robert Atkins, the Tory MEP for the north-west, accused ministers of misleading scientists in Cheshire.

"The decision was bad enough in itself and wrong in principle. But for Labour ministers to have pretended that they cared about the north-west when all along they were stringing everybody along is a disgrace."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
This year's Reith Lectures take on a new format when five eminent speakers tackle the same theme from different perspectives. Chris Patten, former governor of Hong Kong, now in Brussels as head of the EU's external relations commission, launches Respect For The Earth (Radio 4, 8.0pm) by asking how the environment fits in with the political agenda and wonders if, as experience suggests, dictators are bad news for the planet's health, what evidence is there that democracy is any better?

Nightwaves (Radio 3, 9.30pm) drops into the first night of Shakespeare In Shoreditch. For a limited period, before the old Gainsborough Film Studios get turned into luxury lofts, Hitchcock's old sound stage has been taken over by the Almeida theatre for a new production of Richard II. Ralph Fiennes (pictured) stars and Sarah Dunnant hears the first night reactions.

fields.headline: Closed hearts, open minds
fields.trailText: Cutting Edge: The Five Of Us | Home Ground: The Kindness Of A Stranger | Task Force
fields.body:
'She wanted me not in the house... She had a new boyfriend." So spoke Mary, on the subject of her mother. Her relatives, visiting for Mary's birthday, glossed over this painful revelation, but as Cutting Edge: The Five Of Us (C4) demonstrated, being mentally handicapped doesn't stop people having strong feelings.

Mary and four other adults with similar disabilities share a flat. If the standard flatmate wrangles - Who Ate My Cheese? and Who's Nicked The Hairdryer? - were absent, this didn't mean perpetual harmony prevailed. Between Mary and the turbulent Kwok, for instance, there existed a fraught relationship. "Put her out of the room", Kwok kept insisting, without much provocation. "Plonker!" was one of Mary's memorable retorts. The high emotion was not confined to rows, nor eased by the presence of cameras.

The amiable lynchpin of the group, Luke, had to cope with his father's death - and a microphone in his face. "What do you feel, Luke?" the interviewer asked. "My heart is closed", he replied, with a dignity that hopefully shamed the prat interrogating him. As Luke swallowed tears, and his flatmates rallied round, it felt wrong to watch. The scrutiny defeated the point of the programme. One only needed minutes watching the flatmates to understand that they were just like us, with lives full of intrigue, jealousy and loss. Few of us needed a documentary team to point that out. And pointing a camera at people as they go about their most trivial business implies the opposite - that they are different to us, curious exhibits. This was docu-soap at its worst: intrusive and unkind.

Unkind sums up the treatment dished out to 23-year-old Helen Smith by her local health authority (Home Ground: The Kindness Of A Stranger, BBC 2). Struck by meningitis, the gifted pianist underwent a quadruple amputation to save her life. Left with hooks instead of hands, and painful plastic legs, Helen petitioned her NHS doctors to refer her to a specialist prosthetic clinic. They refused. Her consultant sounded unrepentant - though his eyes avoided the camera. He expressed regret at her "negative" attitude. Cheerful optimism, we assume, would have made his job easier - though it would still have not resulted in a referral. "It's equally unfair to everybody," he noted, "but at least it's consistent." Well, thank God for that.

Fortunately, the story took a fairytale twist when an Essex businessman came up with the cash. Helen was fitted with new limbs, and progressed from being suicidal to displaying stoical courage. "Maybe that's why it happened to me and no one else," she said, applying mascara with a hi-tech hand, "because I am able to cope." Her transformation was inspiring. Less satisfying, particularly in light of the title, was the sketchy appearance of her benefactor, Danny Watts, at the very end. Clearly, anyone who gives £25,000 to a complete stranger has their own story, but Danny wasn't telling.

Shouting is a tactic cherished by South Africa's Task Force (Channel 5). "It allows them to dominate a room with their voices, rather than guns." Teachers have been doing this for centuries, of course, but few of the STF look like they spent long in the classroom. Using a combination of bellowing and bullets, this crack squad is taking on South Africa's increasingly violent criminals, as corruption rots the traditional police force.

The average bobby makes £50 a month, before bribes. The STF, who train with live ammo, make much more. This is only fair. Many, like Inspector Ashley Crooks, have spiritual dilemmas to contend with. "Thou shalt not kill is written in the Bible", he mused, after slaying several hijackers. Then a new call came in on the radio, and Ashley abandoned his theological deliberations to fetch some armour-piercing bullets.

But later, after more crims were pushing up daisies, Ashley confided his greatest fear. This is neither divine wrath, nor dying in a hail of bullets - which the STF regard as a form of promotion. It is ghosts - which apparently haunt the STF's headquarters. "I'd raatha run intew the bush_ than 'ave to sleep in yur one night", asserted Ashley, shivering. A chorus of nods came from his burly colleagues. The STF might sleep easier if they executed fewer people - but understandably, none of the film crew felt bold enough to point this out.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
The Naked Chef 8.30pm, BBC2
He's back, so get ready for cooking on a hyperactive scale. He, of course, is Jamie Oliver, aka the 24-year-old Essex boy who's done good by making cooking appear as frenetic as possible and saying things like "You're so sweet darling" in a cheeky I-was-Dick-Van-Dyke-in-a-previous-life voice. Tonight, Jamie's "gotta get a party together quick" for a mate who's visiting from Germany. He chooses Italian and slings together an elegantly simple meal that would have Fern Britton cooing with gluttonous delight. And here, far more than in the gimmicky presentation, is what makes the show work: the recipes look achievable for even the most untalented amateur cook. Mind you, that still doesn't excuse the way Jamie pretends to be knackered after beating a few eggs.

Journeys To The Bottom Of The Sea 9pm, BBC2
In 1678, a French fleet foundered on the treacherous reefs of Las Aves off the Venezuelan coast. Thirteen ships went down and hundreds of men lost their lives. Over 300 years later, adventurer Barry Clifford (who previously discovered the final resting place of treasure-laden pirate ship Wydah) went to the site to see if a map of the area made by a French admiral accurately showed the final resting place of the ships. It did, and this documentary shows how Clifford and his team carefully mapped the area for archaeological purposes - a complex job made no easier by the close attentions of suspicious local coastguards, who tried to prevent the team from diving.

Porno Goes Pop 10.45pm, Channel 5
"Consumerism is like this virus that works its way through everything eventually." So says writer Susan Faludi as she neatly and unwittingly sums up the paradoxes of this film. On occasion, this look at the way pornography is infiltrating the mainstream has some serious things to say about the way our values are changing. Yet, despite references to Jeff Koons's art and Robert Mapplethorpe's photos, it's still difficult not to view it as an elaborate excuse to peddle flesh.
