webTitle: A bookie, a fixer and a corrupt captain

fields.headline: A bookie, a fixer and a corrupt captain
fields.standfirst:
How a chance police phone tap exposed a network of international match-fixing and bribery in a game that might never recover
Hansie Cronje profile
Matthew Engel
South Africa's captain sacked
Mike Selvey asks: Where now?
Reaction in South Africa
Wisden Verdict
fields.trailText: Luke Harding in New Delhi on how a chance police phone tap exposed a network of international match-fixing and bribery in a game that might never recover
fields.body:
The voice at the end of the phone was faint. "Hello, hi Hansie," said the voice. "Hello, hi Sanjay," came the reply. The accent was curious - South African perhaps? Detectives from Delhi police, who had been monitoring the cellphones of several businessmen as part of a low-key extortion investigation, were baffled. Why was an Indian bookmaker called Sanjay Chawla talking to a South African man on his mobile phone? And who was he?

Over the next three weeks the answer became clear. Officers from the Indian police crime branch had sought authorisation last month for phone taps as part of the extortion inquiry. Listening in, they swiftly realised they had stumbled upon something much bigger. Both "Hansie" and "Sanjay" kept referring to the "pitch" and "players". Other names were mentioned too - Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje, Pieter Strydom, and Henry Williams. This was not about extortion but cricket, the officers concluded, dazed.

Almost immediately after transcribing the first telephone call on March 13, crime branch officers identified Chawla's interlocutor. He was none other than South Africa's cricket captain, Hansie Cronje.

Cronje's side had arrived in India on March 9 for a series of one-day matches. The man with the curious accent had identified himself as being in room 346 of the Taj Palace hotel in Delhi. "You can come in," he had told Chawla, who was in the lobby. "See you in two minutes."

Detectives checked the hotel's records. There could be no mistake. Cronje, regarded as one of the game's most honest players, with a spiritual side unusual in a modern cricketer, was staying in room 346.

Betrayal
As the series went on, the crime branch pieced together an astonishing picture of what appeared to be match-fixing, bribery, corruption and betrayal at the highest levels of cricket. The web stretched across continents - from India, where the games were being played, to London, where Chawla had lived for the past eight years, and to South Africa.

Millions of pounds are routinely bet across Asia on the outcome of one-day matches. But the big money, for those in the know, was to be made on forecasting - accurately predicting, for example, how many runs a player would score.

"And how many runs for Gibbs?" Chawla asked Cronje in one of at least 10 conversations taped during the series. "Less than 20," he replied. "Less than 20?" Sanjay queried. "Yeah," Cronje said.

Detectives put together more pieces of the jigsaw. The transcripts of what would become the Cronje tapes yielded other names. They included Rajesh Kalra, an Indian contact of Chawla's who helped arrange the bookmaker's frequent trips to the sub-continent from his home in London. Another name was that of Krishan Kumar, a failed Bollywood actor. Kumar raised funds to pay bribes for match-fixing, police believed. The funds came from a series of shadowy moneybrokers, or hawalas, who operate across Asia and the Gulf. Money is lent on the basis of trust; there is no documentation. As many as 200 hawalas could be involved in a single transaction.

By March 19, when the series ended with South Africa's 3-2 defeat, the head of Delhi police's crime branch, KK Paul, felt he was on solid ground. He had obtained "compelling evidence" of Cronje's involvement in match-fixing. Nearly 40 pages of transcripts had been recorded. In the most damning section, Cronje refers to the guys "wanting" 25 each. "So that's 75 for those three ... and what can you pay me? I do not know how much you pay me." "You say," is Sanjay's reply. The two men agree on "140 for everybody". The "140" amounted to £320,000, police allege.

Officers had also discovered that Chawla had trailed the South Africans around the country during the series. He had booked into the same hotels as the team: at Cochin, the venue for the first one-day international, now under suspicion; Faridabad, the third match, also suspect; at Bombay, the centre of India's illegal betting industry; and Bangalore.

Chawla and Kalra had fallen out, officers discovered, after the match at Cochin did not go to plan, with the South Africans scoring more than 300 runs. "It's a complete script written before the match and each part of the script has money on it. It appears part of this script went wrong," one officer said. Chawla had also travelled to South Africa in December, it emerged. The jigsaw was almost complete.

On April 7, Dr Paul let off his bombshell. The crime branch of Delhi police formally registered a case of cheating, forgery and criminal conspiracy against Cronje and Chawla, on the basis of their taped telephone calls. It was the first time an international cricketer had ever been charged with match-fixing. "We have unearthed an international racket in match-fixing and betting," Dr Paul said.

"The conversation reveals that money was paid. Indications are that the money was paid in London." The tapes, he insisted, were "quite explicit". Four other South African players - Gibbs, Boje, Stry dom, and Williams - were also named as being part of the conspiracy. Rajesh Kalra was arrested at his plush home in an upmarket Delhi colony. Chawla had skipped back to Britain, where he vanished.

The reaction from South Africa was pained and incredulous. "I have spoken to Cronje and he says it is absolute rubbish," Ali Bacher, the managing director of South Africa's cricket board declared. "There is nothing in it at all."

webTitle: The sudden fall of Hansie Cronje

fields.headline: The sudden fall of Hansie Cronje
fields.standfirst:
How a cricketer used religion as his 'secret weapon'
Matthew Engel
How the scandal was exposed
South Africa's captain sacked
Mike Selvey asks: Where now?
Reaction in South Africa
Wisden Verdict
fields.trailText: When Hansie Cronje finally chose to confess his entanglement in cricket's match-rigging scandal, it was wholly in keeping with a man professing to a strong religious faith that he turned first to a minister of the church.
fields.body:
When Hansie Cronje finally chose to confess his entanglement in cricket's match-rigging scandal, it was wholly in keeping with a man professing to a strong religious faith that he turned first to a minister of the church.

Ray McCauley, a former bodybuilder, is a minister of the Rhema Church, which operates from its own television station, broadcasting on the VSTV satellite. McCauley is the unofficial pastor to the South African team, and has regular access to the dressing room. The most committed might be expected to contribute a percentage of their annual income.

Cronje has never paraded his religious virtue like some in his team. "I won't walk around with a Bible under my arm," he said when he arrived in England with his South African two years ago. "But I read it every day and try to spend some quiet time alone. I am happy if I set an example, but I am not perfect. I say and do the wrong things sometime."

From 1994, when he became captain, his religion was almost a secret weapon as his country struggled to find an identity in the post-apartheid era. In partnership with the innovative English coach Bob Woolmer, Cronje built a side capable of beating anyone but Australia.

Then things started to go wrong. Nothing has inflamed Cronje more than the imposition of non-white quotas on the South African side. He famously stormed out of a meeting a year ago with Ali Bacher, managing director of the South African cricket board, threatening to resign. Many sensed a deepening disillusionment from that moment.

He offered to resign a second time when his form deserted him in the recent series against England and then he accepted a job to coach Glamorgan this year, even though it clashed with South African commitments. The move was vetoed by the South African cricket board and an angry Cronje had to be talked round by friends.

But such misjudgments only strengthened the image of Cronje as the dedicated captain striving for victory. He was seen as a captain who, if he could not win a match, would make sure that South Africa did not lose it. All the odder then that, in January, he and the England captain Nasser Hussain should contrive to keep the final match of the series alive when three days had been lost to rain. For the first time in history two captains agreed to alter the parameters of a Test match.

They forfeited two innings and reduced the final day to a run chase which England won by two wickets. He justified the gamble by saying: "When I arrived at the ground I found there were 22 players who wanted to get involved in a game. Both sides were in with a good chance of winning with seven balls of the match remaining, and if this is what the game is about then I feel we have given the spectator something for their support."

But cricket has served 30-year-old Hansie well. In a really good year - and South Africa have had a few - he could anticipate direct cricket earnings of about £75,000 a year. As well as the family home in a wealthy area of Bloemfontein, where he was born, he retreated at the weekend to his £300,000 holiday home on the Fancourt golf estate near East London.

webTitle: Business is booming for illegal industry worth millions

fields.headline: Business is booming for illegal industry worth millions
fields.trailText: Jamie Reid gets to the bottom of the spread betting business.
fields.body:
A tumultuous and massively corrupt illegal gambling industry in which sums of up to £3m are wagered flourishes on the Indian sub-continent despite an official ban on all forms of gambling.

Business has boomed over the past decade. It is conducted by mobile phone with odds offered throughout matches on every aspect of the game. The majority of money changes hands away from the grounds.

Bombay has emerged as the hub of the industry, although the network of gambling stretches to Pakistan and the Gulf, where regular one-day tournaments are held in Sharjah.

The essence of spread betting is simple. Predictions are made not simply on the outcome but, say, on how many runs they think a batsman will score overall or in each innings. Clients do not have to be so precise. They merely have to decide whether to go high or low or whether, in the jargon of the markets, to buy or sell.

For example, bookies predict that a player will score between a spread of 76 and 80 runs. Punters confident that he will do better than that would buy him at 80. If he ended up scoring 120 the buyers would have made 40 times their stake money. But punters who feel he is unlikely to perform that well would want to sell him - for anything from £1 to £1,000 a point - at 76. And if he ended up getting a duck the sellers would have made 76 times their stake.

A spokesman for Sporting Index, which specialises in the field in the UK, said that it was "always in the back of our mind" that individual markets on cricket could be "unusually vulnerable" to rigging or manipulation.

Alan Alger, of City Index, said: "Suspicions are always aroused when you get a sudden collapse like Pakistan's in last year's World Cup final. And it doesn't take a whole team to fix a particular market. One or two players can decide to have an off day and benefit accordingly but their side can still go on to win the match."

webTitle: South Africa's captain in bribes scandal

fields.headline: South Africa's captain in bribes scandal
fields.standfirst:
How the scandal was exposed
Hansie Cronje profile
Matthew Engel
Mike Selvey asks: Where now?
Reaction in South Africa
Wisden Verdict
fields.trailText: The world of cricket was plunged into turmoil yesterday when Hansie Cronje was sacked as South African captain after he admitted receiving between $10,000-15,000 from an Indian bookmaker during a limited over series with Zimbabwe and England.
fields.body:
The world of cricket was plunged into turmoil yesterday when Hansie Cronje was sacked as South African captain after he admitted receiving between $10,000-15,000 from an Indian bookmaker during a limited over series with Zimbabwe and England.

Cronje said he "had not been entirely honest" with the cricket board over match-fixing allegations which surfaced last week following an Indian police investigation. "We in South Africa are shattered," said Ali Bacher, managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa. "He has not been honest. The UCBSA and the government have been deceived."

Cronje, one of the most high-profile figures in cricket, made his admission to Mr Bacher by phone at 3am yesterday. Mr Bacher said that although Cronje denied allegations of match-fixing, he admitted "providing information and forecasting".

He said Cronje had received an approach from a local South African and a bookmaker of Indian origin based in London, after South Africa's victory over Zimbabwe at the Wanderers on January 21. Mr Bacher said Cronje had received money, which he took back to his house in Bloemfontein but did not deposit in his bank account.

Cronje later issued a statement via the South African sports minister, Ngconde Balfour, who said the player denied receiving financial reward from match-fixing.

The statement said: "For the sake of my Christian convictions, I have decided to reveal my involvement in this matter. I admit that I made an error of judgment and I never thought it would lead to such serious implications.

"I wish to apologise to all South Africans, the team, especially the particular players singled out, the United Cricket Board of South Africa, the government, as well as my wife and family for my involvement in the matter as spelt out."

Mr Balfour said Cronje, who sat beside him at the press conference but did not speak, had told him that earlier in the year he had been contacted by a South African during the triangular one-day series with England and South Africa - some three weeks before the tour to India. Mr Balfour said Cronje was again contacted while in India. He said Cronje confirmed that he had "played along" with the contact and lied to him about trying to influence matches. "I mentioned names of players, but, in fact, I never spoke to a single player about throwing a match. I never received any financial rewards."

At the weekend Cronje claimed allegations of match-fixing were "absolute rubbish" after New Delhi police charged him with criminal conspiracy, fraud and cheating in relation to last month's one-day series with India.

Cronje was charged alongside Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Peter Strydom. Cronje maintains his team mates are innocent of any wrongdoing.

Charges have also been laid against London-based bookmaker Sanjeev Chawla, whose solicitors yesterday issued a statement denying any involvement.

News of the revelations about Cronje sent shock waves round the world of cricket. "We do have a crisis on our hands in South African cricket," said Mr Bacher. "He was a role model, a fantastic ambassador for cricket in this country."

President of the International Cricket Council, Jagmohan Dalmiya, said: "We're awaiting a detailed report from the United Cricket Board of South Africa and only then we will act upon it."

webTitle: Parents of brain-damaged children launch payments protest

fields.headline: Parents of brain-damaged children launch payments protest
fields.trailText: Parents of children severely brain damaged by vaccines under government-promoted immunisation programmes will today accuse ministers of inaction over compensation.
fields.body:
Parents of children severely brain damaged by vaccines under government-promoted immunisation programmes will today accuse ministers of inaction over compensation.

Over 100 victims and campaigners for justice will march on the Department of Health, claiming that the original £10,000 interim payments they received when their children were left disabled after receiving jabs for whooping cough, measles, smallpox and polio are inadequate to pay for round-the-clock care.

Parents from the 300-strong Vaccine Victims Support Group will warn that their children, many of whom are now in their 20s and 30s, are dying, or that they are themselves are too elderly to provide full-time care.

The demonstration comes days after health ministers disclosed to MPs that talks with drugs companies over securing contributions to a payments fund had broken down.

The pharmaceutical industry claims that its £40m annual profit from vaccines in the UK does not leave sufficient margins to allow it to pay a levy into a fund for the families of damaged children.

Under the 1979 vaccine damage payments act, some families of children suffering 80% or more brain damage following immunisation received a one-off payment of £10,000, a sum which has now risen to a maximum of £40,000. Parents claim the payouts are still "paltry" compared with the cost of 24-hour care.

Olivia Price, chairwoman of the vaccine victims' support group, said: "Where there is vaccination, there are going to be casualties. But for the benefit of the majority, our children have suffered and we feel as though nobody cares."

webTitle: Lords investigate air rage and flight health risks

fields.headline: Lords investigate air rage and flight health risks
fields.trailText: A parliamentary committee is to investigate the phenomenon of air rage following allegations that passengers are not being warned of the health risks involved in long-haul travel.
fields.body:
A parliamentary committee is to investigate the phenomenon of air rage following allegations that passengers are not being warned of the health risks involved in long-haul travel.

The Lords science committee is to call executives from British airlines and ask them to answer accusations that they have been reducing leg room and lowering the quality of air in cabins to boost profits.

Increasing scientific evidence suggests lower cabin air quality, the ever closer cramming of passengers, and excessive supply of alcohol are adding to air travel stress and illnesses.

The inquiry follows growing complaints that airlines and doctors are doing next to nothing to explain the dangers of lengthy air travel, especially to passengers prone to hardening of the blood or respiratory diseases.

The inquiry has in part been prompted by the 75-year-old Lord Graham of Edmonton, who spent a week in hospital and six weeks on medication following a flight from New Zealand.

Lord Graham, who is to give evidence to the six-month inquiry, contracted deep vein thrombosis, a potentially fatal illness. He said yesterday: "Blood thickens at 30,000 feet, especially if the space between seats is tight, no one is encouraged to walk around, and passengers are offered more and more alcohol the whole time rather than water."

He claimed leg room in British-owned airlines, especially on charter flights, was lower than elsewhere.

He said economists had provided evidence showing the overall cost to the health service from air travel-induced sickness was well in excess of that of providing basic advice on how to avoid illnesses, including taking aspirin as a blood thinner.

The chairwoman of the inquiry, Lady Wilcox, said yesterday: "There is more and more anecdotal evidence that people get off planes thinking there are things wrong with them.

"Our job will be to separate the science from the fiction. It comes at a time when the airlines are planning to build these new super jumbos big enough to take 1,000 people non-stop to Australia. There is clearly more stress because people are less willing to be to be herded about and messed around."

Her view has been echoed by Helen Muir at Cranfield University's college of aeronautics. She claims that the stress of longer and more frequent flights leads to disruptive passengers.

Consumer campaigners point out that fresh air in the cabin requires more fuel and airlines are free to save on fuel costs by setting their own rates of circulation in the passenger cabin as long as they conform with the requirement on air quality.

On Airbus aircraft, a high air flow setting increases fuel costs by 1%.

Airbus and Boeing claim they change air quality once every two minutes, far more than occurs in offices.

However, the space in aircraft cabins is much more confined and the flow can reduce when the plane is on the ground.

Air pressure is normally equivalent to the atmospheric pressure at 8,000 feet. The effect has been reported as equivalent to breathing air containing around 15% oxygen compared with 21% at sea level.

The Lords science committee is to call executives from British airlines and ask them to answer accusations that they have been reducing leg room and lowering the quality of air in cabins to boost profits. Increasing scientific evidence suggests lower cabin air quality, the ever closer cramming of passengers, and excessive supply of alcohol are adding to air travel stress and illnesses. The inquiry follows growing complaints that airlines and doctors are doing next to nothing to explain the dangers of lengthy air travel, especially to passengers prone to hardening of the blood or respiratory diseases. The inquiry has in part been prompted by the 75-year-old Lord Graham of Edmonton, who spent a week in hospital and six weeks on medication following a flight from New Zealand. Lord Graham, who is to give evidence to the six-month inquiry, contracted deep vein thrombosis, a potentially fatal illness. He said yesterday: "Blood thickens at 30,000 feet, especially if the space between seats is tight, no one is encouraged to walk around, and passengers are offered more and more alcohol the whole time rather than water." He claimed leg room in British-owned airlines, especially on charter flights, was lower than elsewhere. He said economists had provided evidence showing the overall cost to the health service from air travel-induced sickness was well in excess of that of providing basic advice on how to avoid illnesses, including taking aspirin as a blood thinner. The chairwoman of the inquiry, Lady Wilcox, said yesterday: "There is more and more anecdotal evidence that people get off planes thinking there are things wrong with them. "Our job will be to separate the science from the fiction. It comes at a time when the airlines are planning to build these new super jumbos big enough to take 1,000 people non-stop to Australia. There is clearly more stress because people are less willing to be to be herded about and messed around." Her view has been echoed by Helen Muir at Cranfield University's college of aeronautics. She claims that the stress of longer and more frequent flights leads to disruptive passengers. Consumer campaigners point out that fresh air in the cabin requires more fuel and airlines are free to save on fuel costs by setting their own rates of circulation in the passenger cabin as long as they conform with the requirement on air quality. On Airbus aircraft, a high air flow setting increases fuel costs by 1%. Airbus and Boeing claim they change air quality once every two minutes, far more than occurs in offices. However, the space in aircraft cabins is much more confined and the flow can reduce when the plane is on the ground. Air pressure is normally equivalent to the atmospheric pressure at 8,000 feet. The effect has been reported as equivalent to breathing air containing around 15% oxygen compared with 21% at sea level.

webTitle: Tory peers renew battle on gay rights

fields.headline: Tory peers renew battle on gay rights
fields.trailText: The government yesterday made clear its intention to press on with reforms affecting gay rights as Tory peers launched a fresh attempt to block the equalisation of the age of consent.
fields.body:
The government yesterday made clear its intention to press on with reforms affecting gay rights as Tory peers launched a fresh attempt to block the equalisation of the age of consent.

However, with Conservatives in the House of Lords determined to hold out against the lowering of the homosexual age of consent from 18 to 16, ministers may have to wait until the autumn to force the legislation on to the statute book.

Despite a late government concession offering possible stronger safeguards to protect youngsters vulnerable to abuse from adults in a "position of trust", Tory peers spoke out against reform during the second reading of the sexual offences (amendment) bill.

Meanwhile in the Commons, the government paved the way for fresh clashes over moves to repeal section 28, which prevents local authorities "promoting" homosexuality.

During the second reading debate of the local government bill, the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, pledged to overturn a defeat inflicted by peers last month.

Ministers are ready to use the Parliament Acts to push through the legislation on the age of consent.

Opponents' strategy is to avoid forcing a vote in favour of laying down amendments which could mean the government cannot force the bill on to the statute book until the end of the parliamentary session in the autumn.

webTitle: MPs call for new firearms controls

fields.headline: MPs call for new firearms controls
fields.standfirst:
Committee wants tougher curbs on airguns
Gun violence: special report
fields.trailText: An influential group of MPs will today call for a nationwide licencing scheme for airguns after being presented with conclusive evidence that the guns are now the single biggest cause of firearms crime in Britain.
fields.body:
An influential group of MPs will today call for a nationwide licencing scheme for airguns after being presented with conclusive evidence that the guns are now the single biggest cause of firearms crime in Britain.

The home affairs select committee will today publish a wide-ranging report in which it calls for tighter controls on the weapons as well as a rationalisation of the different legal age minimums for the possesion, sale and unsupervised use of airguns.

The MPs are also expected to recommend a tightening of the procedures surrounding shotgun licences.

The committee is calling for for a further attack on Britain's gun culture since the emergency legislation following the Dunblane school massacre.

As many as 4m airguns are in circulation in Britain but only the most powerful have to be licenced. Home Office statistics show a 56% increase in reported crimes involving airguns from 4,813 in 1988 to 8,665 in 1997. They now represent two thirds of firearms offences, mainly causing criminal damage.

Typically, they have been used by youths on urban estates in attacks on pets or property. But they have also been responsible for deaths, including the murder of a 13-year-old boy last summer. The child's mother urged the committee to insist such weapons in future be kept in approved secure and locked cupboards.

At present anyone over 14 can own and use an airgun below a permitted level without possessing a licence, although no one under 18 can buy an airgun. The committeee has been shown newspapers advertising airguns in which the applicants are advised to say they are over 18.

Shotgun owners need only one licence even if they own numerous shotguns. They are also not required to give good reason for owning the gun although in the case of most other firearms, police have to be satisfied that the applicant has good reason for owning the weapon. Police authorities have been pressing for a tightening of the laws on shotguns.

The home office minister, Charles Clarke, told the comittee he thought it would be "highly desirable" for such weapons to be "inhibited more effectively by the law".

But Mr Clarke also told MPs he believed the biggest threat to safety from guns came from illegally held guns. A national register of firearms is due to be implemented by 2002. He also conceded there was a strong case for tightening the law on shotguns, including requiring a licence for each shotgun.

He told the committee: "The fact is that shotguns are dangerous things, they can do damage and there is a case for saying that before having a shotgun you should have a good reason to do so."

webTitle: Fast cars, fast women, faster weapons

fields.headline: Fast cars, fast women, faster weapons
fields.trailText: We are here to debate weapons of mass destruction.  Weapons of mass destruction!  Terrific!!  The boys on the select committee try to look po-faced, but they've come over all tingly. Fast cars, fast women, faster weapons. This is the life. Last week, we did the nuclear stuff, now we're on to their less celebrated chemical and biological cousins.
fields.body:
We are here to debate weapons of mass destruction. Weapons of mass destruction! Terrific!! The boys on the select committee try to look po-faced, but they've come over all tingly. Fast cars, fast women, faster weapons. This is the life. Last week, we did the nuclear stuff, now we're on to their less celebrated chemical and biological cousins.

Two senior CND boys sit at the back of class, distinguished by badges and corduroys. The badges have a strange emotional resonance; a comforting reminder from simple days when we all wanted to kick nuclear warheads off the planet, when we walked for miles and miles and shared smiles with wise people on walking sticks. Nowadays Labour politicians talk about non-proliferation, ratification and verification.

One of the men from CND, Sam Akaki, says that in the 70s it had 80,000 members, but now it's down to 40,000. He talks about the false perception - how people believed that the end of the Soviet Union heralded the end of the nuclear threat. "They were wrong," he says bluntly. Weapons of mass destruction have had an image revamp. Now we talk about the national missile defence system, America's proud follow up to star wars.

But on to chemicological business. Three witnesses sit in front of the committee. Academics, serious people, two of them all the way from Bradford.

There must be a greater political will to make these treaties work, they say. We have to tackle the country making verification impossible. The US, of course. America doesn't like the idea of the world peering into its labs.

Diane Abbott makes her entrance 40 minutes late. She sits down, takes out her bag. From that bag she produces the red purse. From the red purse emerges the compact. She licks her lips and applies the stick.

These chemical things; if they're so damn good, why aren't they used more often, asks Sir Somebody. Never heard that one applied to nuclear weapons.

Facts, we want facts, chorus the committee. So the stooges oblige - chemicals went down a treat in the first world war, the Italians tried them out on Ethiopians in the 30s, and Saddam spent the 80s firing chemical weapons over Iran.

Diane's rummaging through her letters, a notette from the bank, something formal from Labour Women. Then she gets to the Filofax.

"I want to move now to ter rorism," says Sir David Madel. Giggles all round. Terrorists love these weapons, nasty and cheap. Or as Colonel Terry Taylor, the assistant director of the Institute for Strategic studies and weapons inspector, says, they give a good return on the pound. If anyone fancies remaking Dr Strangelove, Col Terry's your man.

The red purse is out again. Saks, Fifth Avenue. Sir John Stanley gets moist around the collar. He takes out his papers, almost waves them in the air. We need to be told about these weapons. "Do the public have knowledge of the sheer horror of these weapons?" He quotes Robin Cook from February 4 1998: "If 100kg of anthrax were released from the top of a tall building in a densely populated area it could kill three million people."

Oh come off it, say Col Terry and his sidekick Dr Trevor. This is just scaremongering, an unfortunate statement from the foreign secretary. Why is it unfortunate, ask the committee. "You're stretching the limits of credibility technically and scientifically." He says this is nothing more than a guesstimate dependent on any number of variables - like the weather and our lungs' ability to absorb the poison.

Diane looks up from her nails. What's all this about collusion between the weapons inspectors and the CIA? Haven't got a clue, answers Col Terry. Back to the Filofax.

fields.headline: Anna Sokolow
fields.standfirst: As dancer and choreographer she expressed the passions of rebellious youth
fields.trailText: Anna Sokolow, who has died aged 90, was a major figure in the development of American modern dance.
fields.body:
Anna Sokolow, who has died aged 90, was a major figure in the development of American modern dance.

She danced with Martha Graham for most of the 1930s, when Graham created her expressive movement style. She was also drawn to the more explicitly contemporary leftist dance movement in New York.

In the 1950s and 60s, she became a choreographic spokesman for disaffected youth, depicting their rebellion and existential despair in several dances with modern jazz scores by Teo Macero.

Sokolow was born in Hartford, Connecticut, to Russian immigrant parents, the third of four children. The family moved to Manhattan when Anna was two, and she called New York home for the rest of her life.

She had a difficult childhood; her father was hospitalised with Parkinson's disease, and to support the family her mother worked in the garment industry, becoming active as a union organiser.

Anna took dance classes from about the age of 10. She disliked school, and never completed her secondary ed ucation. But she was recognised as a gifted dancer, and was sent by her first teachers to the Neighborhood Playhouse, on the Lower East Side.

By the time she was invited to join the Martha Graham company at the end of 1929, Sokolow had studied with the modern-dance precursors Blanche Talmud and Bird Larson, and with Graham's partner and musical director, Louis Horst.

With her as one of his first assistants, Horst codified a method of training young choreographers in the emerging field of modern dance.

In 1939, Sokolow and her longtime partner, the composer Alex North, were invited to Mexico where modern dance was beginning to take hold, with the Dance Unit, which she had formed, working collaboratively with the New Dance League on dances condemning political injustice, fascism and the exploitation of workers.

She stayed for 10 years, mentoring Mexican dancers, and in 1953 began a similar relationship with Inbal, the first indigenous dance company of Israel.

Sokolow said her own tense, theatrical choreographic style did not fully emerge until the 1950s, with Lyric Suite (1953), set to Alban Berg's music. Like Martha Graham, she made movement from the centre of the body, prodding dancers to go deeper, to attain an emotional honesty that they often found painful.

"I don't work in the abstract," she said in 1969, "and I don't work from the outside looking on. I get very involved in the thing. I'm not afraid to let an emotion take over completely."

Unlike Graham, Sokolow did not develop a set vocabulary of movements or a classroom technique. She would begin a choreographic phrase with an action that intensifed or repeated obsessively, until the dancer was almost out of control.

Each impulse would play itself out and then explode into a new action. Her dancers often seemed self- absorbed, unable to interact with others.

Sokolow's dances were often called alienated; she wanted to show the loneliness and anxieties of modern life. She demanded a strong technique, stamina and a willingness to push beyond perfectly formed steps, into risk and emotional exposure.

She understood the inherent drama of simple actions: a hand reaching out to touch, a restless tapping of a foot, an unseeing gaze, a silent scream.

She was respected as a teacher of movement for actors as much as dancers. In the 1940s, she choreographed for off-Broadway shows, and gave classes at the Herbert Berghof acting studio and the Juilliard School.

She created her pieces in a succession of professional and student groups, rather than maintaining a permanent company.

Her best-known works in the 1950s and 60s - Rooms (1955), Dreams (1961), Odes (1964), Ballade (1965) and Deserts (1967) - were interpreted by committed young dancers, many of whom have continued in her footsteps to create starkly beautiful, intensely moving theatre.

Her aesthetic persists today in the work of Paul Sanasardo, Martha Clarke, Pina Bausch, and others.

An evolving unit, The Players Project, was started in 1971 to produce her new work and oversee productions of her repertory.

At her death the rights to her dances, films, and notated dance scores were passed to Lorry May and Jim May, her last leading dancers.

fields.headline: George Batchelor
fields.standfirst: Marrying maths and mechanics in Cambridge
fields.trailText: Professor George Batchelor, who has died aged 80, was a towering figure in the field of fluid mechanics - the science of how matter flows - and had an enormous influence on engineering science and, in Britain and the Commonwealth, applied mathematics.
fields.body:
Professor George Batchelor, who has died aged 80, was a towering figure in the field of fluid mechanics - the science of how matter flows - and had an enormous influence on engineering science and, in Britain and the Commonwealth, applied mathematics.

He made major contributions to the theories of the random fluid motions known as turbulence, and of the effect on the flow of a fluid of large numbers of small particles suspended in it.

Also significant were his institutional creations, notably the department of applied mathematics and theoretical physics (DAMTP) at Cambridge University and the Journal of Fluid Mechanics.

Born in Melbourne, Australia, Batchelor studied at Essendon and Melbourne high schools, and later at Melbourne University, obtaining his MSc in 1941. He then worked for four years at the Australian Aeronautical Research Laboratory, where his interest in fluid mechanics was kindled.

Batchelor realised that the problem of turbulence was central to many practical applications (especially in aeronautics and meteorology), and that the scientist with the most profound understanding of it was Sir Geoffrey (GI) Taylor, at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge.

So, with his colleague Alan Townsend, he arranged funding to come to work with "GI". The pair were disconcerted to discover that Taylor did not want to work on turbulence himself, though he was happy to give them the benefit of his own understanding.

By 1948, Batchelor had made major theoretical advances, and his essay describing them won him a fellowship at Trinity College, Cambridge, a PhD, the Adams Prize, publication as a book (The Theory Of Homogeneous Turbulence, 1953), a lectureship in the mathematics faculty at Cambridge and, later, fellowship of the Royal Society (1957).

He became reader in 1959 and professor of applied mathematics in 1965.

Batchelor encouraged other researchers to come to Cambridge, and the group rapidly became the leading international centre for theoretical fluid mechanics. He started a series of weekly seminars (4.30pm on Fridays, to provide light relief after a hard week's research), which celebrated their 50th anniversary last year. He co-edited an influential book to celebrate GI Taylor's 70th birthday (Surveys In Mechanics, 1956).

Indeed, it is largely through George that the work and spirit of GI has become widely known today: he edited GI's scientific papers in four volumes, organised a conference to celebrate his centenary, raised the money for a GI Taylor chair of fluid mechanics, and wrote a fine biography in 1996.

In 1956, Batchelor founded (and edited for the next 44 years) the Journal of Fluid Mechanics, universally acknowledged as the primary journal in the field.

During the 1950s, he had the foresight to see the importance of fluid mechanics to oceanography and meteorology, and helped others to initiate a major branch of the subject.

His 1967 textbook, An Introduction To Fluid Dynamics, has been translated into many languages.

During the 1950s, Batchelor became frustrated with the faculty structure in Cambridge. Whereas experimental science departments had their own buildings, mathematicians were expected to sit in their college rooms with pencil and paper.

To do good science together scientists need to be together, so, in 1959, George persuaded the university to establish DAMTP as a separate department within the faculty of mathematics, and, in 1964, to let it develop the old Cambridge University Press building. Always careful with the budget, he got research students to move the furniture.

Not only did mathematical scientists and research students have offices for the first time, they also had a fluid mechanics laboratory.

This was unprecedented for a maths department, but Batchelor had learnt from Taylor that theoretical science must not be allowed to wander far from its experimental roots, and that the nature of fluid mechanics in particular, with its variety of photogenic but hard-to-understand phenomena, makes it an ideal subject for fruitful collaboration. More than 30 scientists now use the lab, many of them originally trained only in mathematics.

Over the years DAMTP's pre-eminence has been guaranteed by the many outstanding scientists attracted to work there - not only in fluid mechanics, but in solid mechanics, astrophysics, particle physics, relativity and cosmology (the most famous current member of staff is Stephen Hawking), and there have even been a few real mathematicians.

As a scientist, George was admired for the depth and precision of his thinking. To students and colleagues, he was a rock on which they could rely for clear guidance, given with warmth and humour. As an administrator, he kept his clear vision while attending meticulously to detail.

Batchelor also had international influence. In the late 1960s, he founded the Euromech committee (now a society) to foster the study of mechanics in Europe through the organisation of small workshops.

fields.bodyText: Professor George Batchelor, who has died aged 80, was a towering figure in the field of fluid mechanics - the science of how matter flows - and had an enormous influence on engineering science and, in Britain and the Commonwealth, applied mathematics. He made major contributions to the theories of the random fluid motions known as turbulence, and of the effect on the flow of a fluid of large numbers of small particles suspended in it. Also significant were his institutional creations, notably the department of applied mathematics and theoretical physics (DAMTP) at Cambridge University and the Journal of Fluid Mechanics. Born in Melbourne, Australia, Batchelor studied at Essendon and Melbourne high schools, and later at Melbourne University, obtaining his MSc in 1941. He then worked for four years at the Australian Aeronautical Research Laboratory, where his interest in fluid mechanics was kindled. Batchelor realised that the problem of turbulence was central to many practical applications (especially in aeronautics and meteorology), and that the scientist with the most profound understanding of it was Sir Geoffrey (GI) Taylor, at the Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge. So, with his colleague Alan Townsend, he arranged funding to come to work with "GI". The pair were disconcerted to discover that Taylor did not want to work on turbulence himself, though he was happy to give them the benefit of his own understanding. By 1948, Batchelor had made major theoretical advances, and his essay describing them won him a fellowship at Trinity College, Cambridge, a PhD, the Adams Prize, publication as a book (The Theory Of Homogeneous Turbulence, 1953), a lectureship in the mathematics faculty at Cambridge and, later, fellowship of the Royal Society (1957). He became reader in 1959 and professor of applied mathematics in 1965. webTitle: Corruption reverses role of Philippines' Robin Hood

fields.headline: Corruption reverses role of Philippines' Robin Hood
fields.standfirst: Actor-turned-president sees popularity slide from 60% to 5%
fields.trailText: Christine Tan, who lives surrounded by young children in an unpainted house in the middle of a Manila slum, is hardly the archetypal whistle-blower on presidential corruption and cronyism.
fields.body:
Christine Tan, who lives surrounded by young children in an unpainted house in the middle of a Manila slum, is hardly the archetypal whistle-blower on presidential corruption and cronyism.

But this diminutive 69-year-old Catholic nun who rarely raises her voice above a lilting whisper, has generated such public outrage against the Philippines' film star-turned-president, Joseph Estrada, that many Filipinos are arguing over when, not if, a change of power will come.

"In a sense it's worse than [Ferdinand] Marcos now," she said, referring to the dictator who ruled the country for 21 years before being ousted in 1986. "It took Marcos a few years to become really corrupt. Estrada has taken only a few months."

A recent survey shows growing public opprobrium against the 62-year-old "people's champion", who made his name playing Robin Hood roles in more than 70 films before moving into politics. When Mr Estrada, known as Erap to his devotees, took office in May 1998 his approval rating was 60%. This month it was 5%.

Nepotism and cronyism are proving his downfall. His seven wives (according to most estimates), 10 children (at the latest count) and numerous movie star pals have won dubious contracts - one actor recently won the right to provide Manila's fire engines.

"It's so blatant and lacks so much finesse it disgusts me," said Narzalina Lim, a cabinet minister under the previous two presidents.

Enter Sister Christine, a veteran campaigner against injustice and corruption. Last month she was fired as a director of the Philippine charity sweepstake office. She immediately went public, claiming she was sacked because she refused to approve the disbursement of millions of pounds to foundations controlled by Mr Estrada, his first lady, his eldest son and other cronies. "They thought the people believed in them so much they could do what they want," Sister Christine said.

This furore came hard on the heels of a stock market scandal in which Mr Estrada was accused of ordering the authorities to back off an insider dealing investigation involving a company owned by one of Mr Estrada's friends and in which his relations, and he himself according to many rumours, had invested vast sums.

"Filipinos understand nepotism and corruption but their tolerance for perfidy only goes so far," said the respected newspaper columnist Conrad Dequiros. "Coming from such a widely respected person, the sweepstake scandal tipped the scales from tamana, or enough, to sobrana, or too much. After she spoke out [Estrada's position] suddenly went boom."

Calls for Mr Estrada to resign are now daily fare in the media, as are reports of heightened separatist violence in the southern island of Mindanao. "Erap's opponents, from the secessionists, to the revolutionaries and coup plotters, are using his unpopularity to make further demands, which in turn is undermining his position," Mr Dequiros said.

Last Monday a number of groups launched the Exclamation Mark Movement, with a logo of an angled exclamation mark to "demonstrate to Mr Estrada that he has to either shape up or ship out", Maria Olaguer, one of the convenors, said.

Mr Estrada has not taken the storm lying down. At a meeting of American businesspeople last week, he came out with all guns blazing: "Overall, our economic performance is superior to that of the past two administrations. And yet, in the face of this record, some of my headline-grabbing opponents are asking me to resign! Hello!

"No wonder their exclamation point is reclining diagonally. It is too embarrassed to stand up for a cause that substitutes fantasies for facts and lunacy for logic. It is part of the hollow acoustics of a bankrupt and leaderless opposition. It has no political, legal or moral basis behind it."

He argued that the Philippines had recovered from the 1997 Asian economic crisis faster than its neighbours.

That, however, is only half the truth, according to Mr Dequiros. "The reality is that the Philippines was in such trouble before the crisis, it had practically no collapsing to do."

Mr Estrada still controls congress and the loyalty of his vice president, the opposition leader, Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo. And despite rumours of a coup last weekend, most people believe the military has been sufficiently depoliticised to make a takeover unlikely.

But the situation is changing. "Six months ago I thought there was no possibility of violent transition," Mr Dequiros said. "Now I just don't know. I can't rule it out any longer."

fields.headline: German neo-Nazis get 'deterrent' terms
fields.trailText: In what was intended as a landmark verdict to deter mounting neo-Nazi violence in east Germany, a court yesterday sentenced five skinhead youths to jail terms of between four and six years for "jumping on the heads" of two Vietnamese men in an attack which put one of their victims into a coma for 10 days.
fields.body:
In what was intended as a landmark verdict to deter mounting neo-Nazi violence in east Germany, a court yesterday sentenced five skinhead youths to jail terms of between four and six years for "jumping on the heads" of two Vietnamese men in an attack which put one of their victims into a coma for 10 days.

Judges in the east German city of Stralsund followed the advice of federal state prosecutors and imprisoned the five, aged between 17 and 20, to near maximum terms for young offenders after concluding that they had been motivated by sheer "hatred of foreigners".

It was the first time that federal prosecutors had taken over the prosecution from the local judiciary.

Both the government and the federal prosecutor's office have been alarmed by an increase in attacks on foreigners in the east and the comparatively lenient sentences passed down by local courts.

Germany's image abroad is considered to have suffered as a result.

The federal prosecutor Kay Nehm declared last January that he would take over the case because the accused and their like "threatened the internal security of Germany".

The court heard how the five youths got drunk at a fair in the east German town of Eggesin last year and chased two Vietnamese men aged 28 and 29 through the streets.

Two of the five then attacked their victims, kicking them with their boots and punching them to the ground before "jumping repeatedly on their heads".

Experts doubted whether yesterday's verdicts would have any long term deterrent effect.

"The consensus in Germany is still that foreigners are undesirable," said the journalist and neo-Nazi expert Burkardt Schröder.

"These youths see themselves simply as the executors of the public's will. There are many like them."

fields.headline: No smokes without fire
fields.standfirst: George Sand cigarettes may face ban
fields.trailText: The cigar-puffing feminist, George Sand, will be deprived of her smokes from today if a court action succeeds in stopping the sale of a Polish brand using her name. Nearly 125 years after Frederick Chopin's muse stubbed out her last, her family is to claim that the writer's image should not be exploited to sell a product that causes respiratory diseases.
fields.body:
The cigar-puffing feminist, George Sand, will be deprived of her smokes from today if a court action succeeds in stopping the sale of a Polish brand using her name. Nearly 125 years after Frederick Chopin's muse stubbed out her last, her family is to claim that the writer's image should not be exploited to sell a product that causes respiratory diseases.

The case will be heard in a Poznan court in an action led by a women's group called SOS George Sand headed by one of her heirs, Christiane Sand. Curator of the author's museum, she has been fuming since being presented with a pack of George Sand cigarettes wrapped in brown paper to look like cigars.

"It is shocking when you consider that she was an environmental pioneer," Christiane Sand said. "The tobacco firm has linked an emblematic figure in French literature with an image of death."

Descendants of George Sand, whose maiden name was Armandine Dupin, were not consulted when Reemtsma Polska, the subsidiary of a German firm, seized on her reputation as a smoker to pitch their new product at women.

In October, judges at Poznan ordered the company to remove the writer's signature from their packets. Today the court will be asked to hand down a complete ban, or at least to remove her portrait copying a 19th century study.

fields.headline: Battle that took lives of 200,000
fields.trailText: The American presence in Okinawa dates from the spring of 1945, when the only land battle of the war on Japanese soil began. It lasted 90 days and claimed more than 200,000 Japanese and US lives.
fields.body:
The American presence in Okinawa dates from the spring of 1945, when the only land battle of the war on Japanese soil began. It lasted 90 days and claimed more than 200,000 Japanese and US lives.

In Okinawa, local people, including girls as young as 11, were armed with hand grenades and ordered to kill themselves in the name of the emperor rather than be taken prisoner by the Americans, who would certainly rape them.

Hundreds of girls committed suicide as the US soldiers approached.

Toshiko Yabiku, who was 17 at the time and a nurse in the Japanese army, describes her first encounter with a US soldier:

"I am not afraid of dying. Kill me now, please, I said, bringing the muzzle of the rifle of an American soldier to my chest. 'No! No!' he said.

"He was trying to tell me something with his gesture. Then he started to cut my uniform with his scissors. I was sure he was going to strip me, so I bit his hand as hard as I could.

"Why do you take my clothes off? I'm telling you to kill me. You can't even kill me and now you're trying to put me to shame, I shouted. But the American soldier was just smiling.

"I tried to bite him again. 'No, no,' he said, and started cutting one of my trouser legs lengthwise from the bottom up to the thigh, where I had a gash. He poured disinfectant into the maggot-infested wound and out came many wriggling worms.

"After treating the wound, he took a stick of chewing gum from his pocket and offered it to me. I refused to take it. He then showed me a canteen and I drank water from it.

"If they were going to kill me anyway, I thought, I might as well drink the water and be killed. And I drank from his canteen."

webTitle: End of the affair as Okinawa cools to US bases

fields.headline: End of the affair as Okinawa cools to US bases
fields.trailText: The story of Okinawa is written on Kiyomi Shimamoto's face. Her hair is brown, her eyes hazel and framed by long eyelashes. Her features lack the pronounced cheekbones characteristic of the southern Japanese; in a crowd she is liable to be mistaken for a tourist.
fields.body:
The story of Okinawa is written on Kiyomi Shimamoto's face. Her hair is brown, her eyes hazel and framed by long eyelashes. Her features lack the pronounced cheekbones characteristic of the southern Japanese; in a crowd she is liable to be mistaken for a tourist.

She first became aware that she looked unusual at school, where she was dubbed "Ainoko", or halves. Children would throw stones at her as she walked home after class.

In the evenings she and her friends would wave Japanese flags at the trucks passing in and out of the local American military base, and somehow that further underlined her otherness. "I couldn't understand why, but it made me feel foolish," she said.

Her mother is an Okinawan seamstress. Her father is an American, Harrison Mullen, who was stationed in the late 1950s in Camp Schwab, a US airbase close to her mother's house.

In 1961, when Mr Mullen's superiors found out that Kiyomi's mother was pregnant, he was posted back to the US and told he would never be allowed to return. For 38 years his daughter's only contact with her father has been through a clutch of fading photographs.

Kiyomi is the product of one of the unresolved epics of the second world war. Her parents represent two sides of an occupation that began on April 1 1945, and continues to this day in all but name.

This summer it is certain to be brought to the attention of the world's most powerful leaders, including Bill Clinton and the new Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori. In July the G8 summit of the seven leading industrial countries and Russia will assemble on Okinawa's idyllic western shore. While the three-day event is likely to be dominated by questions of trade, security and Asian economic instability, local people are determined to highlight matters closer to home.

Since 1945, when Okinawa became the only Japanese land territory to be invaded by the allies, the island has been turned into a massive military fortress. It was a crucial staging post in the Vietnam war, and is now home to 75% of US personnel in Japan, including 17,000 marines - the most intense concentration of US firepower outside America. The writer and Japan expert Murray Sayle calls Okinawa America's 51st state - its aircraft carier.

For Washington and Tokyo, the relationship has been largely of mutual benefit. On its side, the US has been able to preserve its dominance in the Asia-Pacific region against the perceived threats of China and North Korea, at relatively little expense. The Japanese government's subsidy to the US military reached $2.5bn (£1.6bn) last year and pays for virtually all non-military costs for the Okinawan bases, from cutting the lawn and running bowling alleys to providing water and electricity, and educating the marines' children.

As John Metterle, commanding officer of Futenma, one of the largest marine bases in Okinawa, put it: "Were the community to decide we weren't a friendly neighbour, I suppose they could cut us off and then we'd be in a hum."

Subsidy

For its part, Japan has had its security needs catered for by an outside power. Though there is increasing grumbling in Tokyo about the size of the subsidy (Japan pays about three times as much as Germany to host the American bases), there is an acceptance that the economic success story of post-war Japan has in part been thanks to the relative peacefulness of the region that the Americans have helped to sustain.

But for the Okinawans themselves the story is not that simple. With about a fifth of the island swallowed up by 37 American military installations, local people are constantly reminded that the first US troops landed in Okinawa 55 years ago and have never left.

"It is often said that the bases are not located in Okinawa, but Okinawa [is] located among the bases," said Tateo Kishimoto, the mayor of Nago where the G8 summit will be held. Some 8,000 Okinawans work in the bases and that figure rises to 36,000 if service providers dependent to varying degrees on the Americans, such as shopkeepers and bar owners, are included.

But against that is the disadvantage of having a fifth of Okinawa's most fertile land taken up by the bases, hindering the growth in local businesses. The value of the bases to the local economy has also declined over time, from about 35% of GDP in the 1950s to barely 5% today, calculates Professor Moritake Tomikawa, an economist at Okinawa International University.

Socially, too, there are subterranean tensions. They exploded in 1995 when three US marines raped a 12-year-old local girl on her way home from school. Huge protests followed. Since then the marine command has imposed tough restrictions on off-base drinking, and a curfew on personnel entering the red-light districts of central Okinawa, where fighting had become a fixture of GI life. "We've also introduced a new dress code, as a marine who dresses well is more likely to behave well," said Lieutenant Colonel Kurt Owermohle. "Now an off-duty marine has to wear clothing suitable for a young professional, rather than a high-school student."

In an effort to assuage local feeling, the Americans are making further concessions by proposing to relocate the Futenma airbase to a new site offshore. Recent polls suggest that about 60% of Okinawans are opposed to the plans unless a time limit of 15 years is placed on the new heliport. Otherwise, they fear the relocation will merely be used to extend the US presence indefinitely.

When Mr Clinton visits he will find it difficult to avoid these underlying resentments. "It is true that Japan has enjoyed its post-war prosperity because of the US-Japanese peace treaty, but we would like President Clinton to see that we shoulder an excessive burden," said Keiichi Inamine, governor of Okinawa.

Kiyomi Shimamoto made the same point from a more personal perspective. "I don't know if the bases have been good or bad; I just felt over the years that my individuality had been denied," she said.

A few weeks ago she finally tracked down her father in Illinois, where he is a fire brigade captain. When she asked him whether he would accept her as his daughter, he broke down and cried. He had waited a long time for her call, he said, and yes of course she was his child.

"He says he wants me to visit him in America. But he warned me that if I do he may never let me come back to Okinawa. This time he says he won't let me go."

It was a crucial staging post in the Vietnam war, and is now home to 75% of US personnel in Japan, including 17,000 marines - the most intense concentration of US firepower outside America. The writer and Japan expert Murray Sayle calls Okinawa America's 51st state - its aircraft carier. For Washington and Tokyo, the relationship has been largely of mutual benefit. On its side, the US has been able to preserve its dominance in the Asia-Pacific region against the perceived threats of China and North Korea, at relatively little expense. The Japanese government's subsidy to the US military reached $2.5bn (£1.6bn) last year and pays for virtually all non-military costs for the Okinawan bases, from cutting the lawn and running bowling alleys to providing water and electricity, and educating the marines' children. As John Metterle, commanding officer of Futenma, one of the largest marine bases in Okinawa, put it: "Were the community to decide we weren't a friendly neighbour, I suppose they could cut us off and then we'd be in a hum." Subsidy For its part, Japan has had its security needs catered for by an outside power. Though there is increasing grumbling in Tokyo about the size of the subsidy (Japan pays about three times as much as Germany to host the American bases), there is an acceptance that the economic success story of post-war Japan has in part been thanks to the relative peacefulness of the region that the Americans have helped to sustain. But for the Okinawans themselves the story is not that simple. With about a fifth of the island swallowed up by 37 American military installations, local people are constantly reminded that the first US troops landed in Okinawa 55 years ago and have never left. "It is often said that the bases are not located in Okinawa, but Okinawa [is] located among the bases," said Tateo Kishimoto, the mayor of Nago where the G8 summit will be held. Some 8,000 Okinawans work in the bases and that figure rises to 36,000 if service providers dependent to varying degrees on the Americans, such as shopkeepers and bar owners, are included. But against that is the disadvantage of having a fifth of Okinawa's most fertile land taken up by the bases, hindering the growth in local businesses. The value of the bases to the local economy has also declined over time, from about 35% of GDP in the 1950s to barely 5% today, calculates Professor Moritake Tomikawa, an economist at Okinawa International University. Socially, too, there are subterranean tensions. They exploded in 1995 when three US marines raped a 12-year-old local girl on her way home from school. Huge protests followed. Since then the marine command has imposed tough restrictions on off-base drinking, and a curfew on personnel entering the red-light districts of central Okinawa, where fighting had become a fixture of GI life. "We've also introduced a new dress code, as a marine who dresses well is more likely to behave well," said Lieutenant Colonel Kurt Owermohle. "Now an off-duty marine has to wear clothing suitable for a young professional, rather than a high-school student." In an effort to assuage local feeling, the Americans are making further concessions by proposing to relocate the Futenma airbase to a new site offshore. Recent polls suggest that about 60% of Okinawans are opposed to the plans unless a time limit of 15 years is placed on the new heliport. Otherwise, they fear the relocation will merely be used to extend the US presence indefinitely. When Mr Clinton visits he will find it difficult to avoid these underlying resentments. "It is true that Japan has enjoyed its post-war prosperity because of the US-Japanese peace treaty, but we would like President Clinton to see that we shoulder an excessive burden," said Keiichi Inamine, governor of Okinawa. Kiyomi Shimamoto made the same point from a more personal perspective. "I don't know if the bases have been good or bad; I just felt over the years that my individuality had been denied," she said. A few weeks ago she finally tracked down her father in Illinois, where he is a fire brigade captain. When she asked him whether he would accept her as his daughter, he broke down and cried. He had waited a long time for her call, he said, and yes of course she was his child. "He says he wants me to visit him in America. But he warned me that if I do he may never let me come back to Okinawa. This time he says he won't let me go."

webTitle: CNN let army staff into newsroom

fields.headline: CNN let army staff into newsroom
fields.trailText: Two leading US news channels have admitted that they allowed psychological operations officers from the military to work as placement interns at their headquarters during the Kosovo war.
fields.body:
Two leading US news channels have admitted that they allowed psychological operations officers from the military to work as placement interns at their headquarters during the Kosovo war.

Cable Network News (CNN) and National Public Radio, (NPR) denied that the "psy-ops" officers influenced news coverage and said the internships had been stopped as soon as senior managers found out . For its part, the army said the programme was only intended to give young army media specialists some experience of how the news industry functioned.

The interns were restricted to mainly menial tasks such as answering phones, but the fact that military propaganda experts were even present in newsrooms as reports from the Kosovo conflict were being broadcast has triggered a storm of criticism and raised questions about the independence of these networks.

"Maybe CNN was the target of a psy-ops penetration and is still too naive to figure out what was going on," wrote Alexander Cockburn, a liberal newspaper commentator. "In the Kosovo conflict, as with other recent wars, CNN's screen was filled with an unending procession of bellicose advocates of bombing, many of them retired US generals."

CNN hosted five psy-ops officers as temporary, unpaid workers last year, while NPR took three, all from the army's 4th Psychological Operations Group, based at Fort Bragg, North Carolina. The army's psychological operations are prohibited by law from manipulating the US media.

After the existence of the CNN internship programme was published in the Dutch newspaper, Trouw, the network immediately cancelled it.

Susan Binford, the head of CNN public relations said: "Is the whole thing embarrassing? Yes. Did it compromise us journalistically? No."

However, the independent watchdog group, Fairness & Accuracy in Reporting asked in a press release: "Even if the psy-ops officers working in the newsroom did not influence news reporting, did the network allow the military to conduct an intelligence-gathering mission against CNN itself?"

webTitle: Police swoop on Sealand crime ring

fields.headline: Police swoop on Sealand crime ring
fields.trailText: Spanish police have broken up an international crime syndicate selling fake documents on the internet which claim to represent the self-proclaimed principality of Sealand - a disused anti-aircraft platform off the Suffolk coast.
fields.body:
Spanish police have broken up an international crime syndicate selling fake documents on the internet which claim to represent the self-proclaimed principality of Sealand - a disused anti-aircraft platform off the Suffolk coast.

The paramilitary Civil Guard, which began investigating the ring in November, confirmed yesterday that it had arrested the alleged leader and one other man. The documents are thought to have been used in money laundering and drug trafficking.

Up to 60 people are thought to be involved in the ring, which sold diplomatic passports, driving licences, nationality documents and university titles through a website bearing the Sealand name.

Sealand's true founder, Roy Bates, a former major, annexed the platform in 1966 as a joke. He installed himself as Prince Roy and his wife as Princess Joan. He has fought for decades to have the principality recognised. But there has never been any suggestion that he was involved in criminal activity.

The alleged ringleader, Federico Trujillo Ruiz was described yesterday as a former civil guard, aged 48, who was expelled from the corps 12 years ago on suspicion of theft.

According to the Civil Guard, working with Interpol, the syndicate's tentacles stretched wide: other members under investigation include Germans, Austrians, Cypriots, Italians, Armenians, Russians, Chileans, North Americans and Chinese. Many used fake Sealand titles such as ambassador or even minister and travelled with false diplomatic number plates.

In a raid on the ring's offices, a bingo hall in Madrid, and a lawyer's chambers presented as a Sealand embassy, Spanish police seized hundreds of blank passports and a document issued by a German neo-Nazi organisation recognising Sealand's existence.

Other documents related to money laundering operations involving Russians and Iraqis. Investigators believe that more than 4,000 fake Sealand passports were sold to Hong Kong citizens for $1,000 each before the former colony was handed over to China in 1997.

Andrew Cunanan, the man who murdered the Italian fashion designer Gianni Versace in Miami in July 1997, was carrying a Sealand passport when he was arrested.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Boycott ends
fields.body:
Boycott ends

Kosovo's Serb minority ended a six-month boycott of multi-ethnic institutions yesterday, when their representative took part in a council meeting with ethnic Albanian leaders.

The UN hailed the attendance of Rada Trajkovic at a meeting of Kosovo's interim council as a historic step in building cooperation.
Reuters, Pristina

Anwar wife held

Malaysian police called in the wife of the jailed former finance minister Anwar Ibrahim for questioning yesterday, a week before an anti-government march.

Police questioned Wan Azizah, head of the opposition Parti Keadilan Nasional, for more than two hours about her participation at a party gathering on Sunday. Police broke up the gathering in the capital, saying the participants had no permit.
Reuters, Kuala Lumpur

Titles dropped

New Zealand's prime minister, Helen Clark, has announced that the Queen has agreed to end the titles of Sir and Dame in the annual honours system. No British honours will now be given in New Zealand, for the first time since a colony was founded there in 1840. Current knights and dames will keep their titles.
Reuters, Wellington

webTitle: New bid to snare Clinton over affair

fields.headline: New bid to snare Clinton over affair
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton could face immediate prosecution on charges arising out of the Monica Lewinsky affair when he leaves the White House next year, Kenneth Starr's successor as independent counsel has said in Washington.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton could face immediate prosecution on charges arising out of the Monica Lewinsky affair when he leaves the White House next year, Kenneth Starr's successor as independent counsel has said in Washington.

Robert Ray, who took over the investigations into Mr Clinton when Mr Starr stepped down last October, said yesterday that the investigation into the Lewinsky affair remained open and that he was "actively" considering bringing criminal charges against Mr Clinton when he became an ordinary citizen again on January 20 2001.

The news that the Lewinsky affair may end up blighting not just Mr Clinton's presidency but also his ex-presidency, too, brought a mixture of resignation and condemnation from the White House. "Nearly $100m [£60m] has been spent on investigations into this administration and not one member of it has faced a felony charge as a result," an official said.

Among the criminal charges that Mr Ray is still considering are obstruction of justice and perjury, exactly the same charges on which Mr Clinton was unsuccessfully impeached last year after the Starr report on the Lewinsky affair in 1998. Other possible charges include making false statements and conspiracy to commit the other crimes.

As a sign that he means business and is not winding down his activities, Mr Ray has recruited six new lawyers on to his payroll, as well as a new investigator, to replace others who have left. Another FBI agent has been seconded to the continuing investigation.

Mr Ray said yesterday that he intended to spend a further $3.5m on the investigation over the next six months, on top of the more than $52m spent by Mr Starr, who spent four years on the case.

A White House source said these sums meant that Mr Clinton's opponents had now spent almost as much money trying to get him out of office since 1996 as they did in attempting to defeat him in the 1996 presidential election.

"It is an open investigation," Mr Ray said in yesterday's Washington Post. "There is a principle to be vindicated, and that principle is that no person is above the law, even the president of the United States. That is what we have been charged with doing."

In the past, Mr Ray has only said that he would not make any final decisions about whether to bring further charges against Mr Clinton until after November. Mr Ray says he is anxious not to allow his work to become intertwined with elections in which Mr Clinton's successor will be chosen and in which Hillary Clinton is running for the senate.

Prosecution of a sitting president has been widely seen as unconstitutional. If attempted, such a move would inevitably be the subject of court challenges which would last for years, because of the importance of the issues it would raise. Mr Ray, whose terms of reference require him to act promptly, has therefore decided to delay until January 2001.

"By waiting, I am being prompt," Mr Ray said yesterday. "There is a process, and a prosecutorial judgment has to be made. Even with the president of the United States, that process should be followed and that is what I intend to do."

Mr Ray has already closed Mr Starr's investigation into the alleged improper handling of FBI files, and is scheduled to close the Whitewater and White House travel office investigations later this year. No prosecutions are expected in either case.

That leaves the seemingly unsinkable Lewinsky affair. The former White House intern may have carved out a new career promoting handbags and diet programmes. Her nemesis, Linda Tripp, may have had a facelift. Mr Starr may be back in private life. But Mr Clinton, on the other hand, seems doomed to be haunted by the Lewinsky affair for ever.
