fields.headline: Let's keep drinking special
fields.standfirst:
Next year's change in the licensing
laws will mean an end to the 11pm
closing time. Legendary pub landlord
Al Murray fears for the future
of a great British institution
fields.trailText:
Next year's change in the licensing laws will mean an end to the 11pm
closing time. Legendary pub landlord
Al Murray fears for the future
of a great British institution
fields.body:
The relaxed licensing laws announced by Jack Straw this week are an outrage. They are ghastly, terrible, awful. It's not just that the government is trying to kill publicans with long hours - I haven't slept for seven years on account of the current opening hours. It is a question of the overall, long-term impact on Great Britain.

You have to look at the wider picture. Pubs shut at 11pm; that gives people an hour between leaving the pub and getting to their nightclub of choice. That's an important hour of fighting. Without that hour of fighting, during which people sustain minor cuts, abrasions and other such low-level wounds, there would be no reason for people to go to casualty. And if there's no reason to go to casualty, there's nothing for the nurses to do. They'll have to lay off the nurses, and you'll end up with nurses begging on the street, like in France. And as everyone knows, this country has nothing to do with Europe, as our long line of French, Dutch, German and Scottish kings indicates.

That is one reason why longer licensing hours are a bad thing. The other is that they are going to take away the pleasure that is the lock-in. The lock-in is a secret, beautiful thing, the conspiracy between publican and policeman. It unites the great British drinker with his fellow drinker. They are going to strip that away, and for what? The whole point of the lock-in is that it's breaking the law. By making the law more relaxed, they are stopping us breaking the law, and that is wrong. I require tighter laws. I might continue to hold lock-ins anyway.

More importantly, let us not forget that closing time was invented to help us win the first world war. As we know, that was a good thing. We should show the old people who were in the war more respect. What have young people ever done? Nothing. If the licensing laws won us the first world war, then why should we tamper with them?

You may wonder, at this point, what qualifies me to lecture on the subject of opening hours. Drinking is not just a job to me, or a pastime. It is a vocation, a calling. I am like a priest. I was raised by pub dogs - a whippet and a greyhound - so it was fairly natural that I should become a publican, and a good one.

The thing that I have observed about the British pub is that it is a great leveller. The pub is the cradle of British democracy. What, after all, is parliament? It is middle-aged men, half pissed, shouting about politics at half past two in the morning. It is a lock-in. It's obvious. This is something that New Labour has yet to understand. The problem with New Labour is that they drink too much coffee, so they are always thinking up stupid ideas. Ordinary people have got a pint in hand and not a thought in their heads, and that's the way it should be.

Of course, I see the new laws as part of a general trend to erode the British pub in favour of the wine bar. The British pub, remember, is a beautiful place where a man can go and drink on his own, escape from the buffeting of the world, experience true solace and solitude. (A woman who goes to the pub, of course, is some kind of whore.) That is the British pub. It is characterised by lager, ales, a bit of stout, the occasional fight for a Friday night, sticky floors, saloon doors, and a glass of white wine for the lady. No work clothes, no boots. I expect these new laws will be the nail in the coffin for several of my regular drinkers.

Lately the brewery has put a graduate trainee in charge of my pub and I'm not very happy about it, since it is part of this all-pervading European influence. They want to put in a mezzanine floor. I don't want a mezzanine floor. They're not British. Spitfires didn't have mezzanine floors; HMS Victory didn't have a mezzanine floor. Sophistication is not a look I'm aiming for. The word sophisticated betrays ambition and pretentiousness. It is like the word ambience. Pubs don't have ambience, they have atmosphere, created by a nice pub jukebox playing some Queen in the background, or maybe the sound of darts, thudding into a dartboard, or a pub dog by the beautiful, blue roaring fire. And of course, the call for last orders.

In an ambience pub, on the other hand, there is probably some jazz on in the background, and they'll have olives on the bar somewhere. Always remember the rule: if it doesn't grow in Great Britain, we don't serve it in the pubs here (there's obviously a loophole for peanuts). Ambience pubs are the sort of places that have names like Slug and Lettuce. They're trouble. They are wine bars in sheep's clothing.

I'm going to fight to keep the atmosphere of my pub by moaning to my regular drinkers about it. I won't protest, because it's up to the brewery, not up to me. We're working on becoming a nation of alcoholics, but what is important is that we continue to make drinking special. Pubs abroad are open all the time, and that means that drinking's not special. In the old days in Australia, the pubs used to shut at six, so that you tried to drink as much as you could before closing. That made it special.

These new laws put us only one step away from anarchy. It's the thin end of the wedge. We are stood on the edge of a wedge, a thin one, that is one step away from anarchy. That sums up the situation in a beautiful metaphor. There are rules, and those that break them are corrected. It's a pint, and a white wine or a fruit-based drink for the lady. Rules is rules. If we didn't have rules, where would we be? France, that's where.

 Al Murray - the Pub Landlord is performing at the Playhouse Theatre, Northumberland Avenue, London, until May 6

fields.headline: This time it's personal
fields.standfirst: Seventy-year-old pensioner David Braybrook is the first victim of new strain of direct action: the doorstepping of the anonymous investor.  John Vidal reveals how anti-vivisectionists found a way to reach a target other activists had failed to hit: the financial powerhouse that is the City
fields.trailText: Seventy-year-old pensioner David Braybrook is the first victim of new strain of direct action: the doorstepping of the anonymous investor.  John Vidal reveals how anti-vivisectionists found a way to reach a target other activists had failed to hit: the financial powerhouse that is the City
fields.body:
Pity anyone still involved however remotely with Huntingdon Life Sciences. The company, which tests animals for the pharmaceutical industry, has been under extreme physical and financial siege for several years. Exposed on TV and in this newspaper for its treatment of puppies, it has been taken to court and heavily fined, told to clean up its act by the government, seen its share price drop to an all-time low and its scientists vilified and threatened. Its major shareholder, the financial house Phillips and Drew, has received bomb threats and now the remaining investors are not just being targeted by individual letter, but by personal protest outside their houses.

This week, the attention turned to the formerly anonymous David Braybrook, a pensioner aged 70. Like 1,700 other investors - whose names and addresses are easily found in Company House in London - he had been sent a letter some months ago by the British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection Reform Group (AVRG). Unless he sold his shares within a week, he was told, he was liable to have his home picketed. Although several hundred investors sold up on receipt of the letter, Braybrook did nothing and on Monday, after receiving a telephone call warning him that the protest would take place, he opened his door to be met by a crowd of protesters including a man dressed as a beagle.

The protest was short, sharp, peaceful and made its point. Braybrook, clearly shocked, had a series of 5ft-tall photographs, showing animal cruelty at Huntingdon Life Sciences some years ago, plastered across his walls and underwent a separate ordeal by press. By yesterday, the protesters had moved on.

But if Braybrook was shocked, so too, says Niel Hansen, one of the protesters outside his house, were many of the Huntingdon investors who received the AVRG's letter. "Many had no idea that they had money invested in a vivisection company and were only too happy to sell. Many had no idea what Huntingdon Life Sciences did; in fact, one old lady phoned me up in tears because she was unaware she had invested in such a company. We had lots of replies to our letter with the vast majority in support of what we were doing. Only a few people were angry."

Hansen now promises to expand the campaign to other Huntingdon investors. "This was the first in a series of demonstrations with eight more planned. We will be circulating the names and addresses of shareholders to other independent groups and we hope they will start their own protests."

Taking protest to individuals is not new, but taking it to anonymous members of the public rather than corporate chiefs or government ministers is. In the very old days - in the 80s - concerned investors or campaigners would most likely have written to the managing director and, reasonably politely, pointed out the error of his company's ways. A request would be made that something be done and mostly the company would duck and do nothing.

By the late 80s, environment, consumer, human rights and animal campaigners were increasingly frustrated. They changed tack and began to get more actively involved. One of the tactics was to buy shares in companies, attend annual meetings in force and cause mayhem or deep embarrassment by asking awkward questions of the board of directors. It worked up to a point. Companies loathed the attention, but environmental and other issues were accepted marginally on to the corporate agenda.

But in the 90s, direct action by individuals came of age, first at Twyford Down and then at Newbury. Environmentalists and other groups had no hesitation in naming names and exposing directors and government officials responsible for what they saw as destructive road-building policies. Activists in turn began taking their protests directly to the homes of chief executives and corporate chiefs. Arms dealers were outed, road-builders had their houses draped with banners, people sat on the roofs of the then transport minister Ian McGregor, and the head of Tarmac was "visited" by several hundred protesters.

The personal approach became more common. In the US, the head of a large Japanese corporation which was responsible for much deforestation in the far east was reportedly so shocked about the scale of what his company was doing that he immediately changed the policy. Similarly, a direct approach to Malcolm Walker, the head of Iceland Foods, started the corporate flight from GM foods.

Walker received six individually addressed letters from a group in Blackburn asking him what he was going to do about the novel foods and was intrigued because he had not even heard of genetic modification. Almost as soon as he found out, he asked his technical director to steer clear of them. The other supermarkets followed suit.

Meanwhile, ethical investments were becoming increasingly important, largely because of personal lobbying of groups and individuals. A campaign by People and the Planet, an umbrella group of students which is present now in every university, has managed to get the universities' pension funds to turn to ethical investments. Now, the pressure on other companies and local authorities which profess public accountability and social responsibility is extreme.

But in the past few years the pressure to act in a socially and ethically responsible way has been turning to anyone who deals in money. With stockmarkets booming in an increasingly globalised world, and trillions of dollars now being moved every day between financial centres, the link between finance and environmental destruction and human rights abuses has been made with a vengeance. Protest has moved to those who have it, those who control it and those who influence where and how it is invested. The City, traditionally aloof or unaware of its power, has became a prime target.

No one in the world of money, it seems, is now immune from protest. The World Bank and International Monetary Fund, the World Trade organisation, the giant regional development banks, stockbrokers, fund managers and now individuals are all being called to account. Protesters, in the US and the UK, are even turning to throwing pastries at anyone with unaccountable financial power.

Jonathan Porritt, having run Friends of the Earth in the 80s, has seen the money protests develop over 20 years and has long campaigned to make the City more ethical. He sees a ratcheting up of the pressure being brought to bear. "The City has argued for years that all that they are doing is investing other people's money, that they are just middlemen. That whole illusion is eroding fast." Part of the reason, he says, is that ethical or green funds are now doing as well as most conventional portfolios, and that new government regulations will force all companies to declare their policies on the environment and social issues, but some has been because of the campaigners.

"People don't like their names in lights. They're more sensitive now, more open to the impact on their reputations. I suspect that the sort of protests against Huntingdon, the personalising of the protest, will become much more common. The animal rights campaigners are drawing on a huge hinterland of support.

"This is the logical extension of direct action protest," says Tony Juniper, policy director of Friends of the Earth, which has recently targeted Norwich Union and helped organise the Newbury protests against individuals.

"The City is an important bastion, a source of enormous power that campaigners and activists have not been able to influence very much. But it's just sitting there. Most people have a stake in the City through their pension or insurance funds. But it's not the City's money, it's ours. This sort of protest turns faceless people into individuals."

The City does not like the attention. In the past few years it has tried, unsuccessfully so far, to snuff out protest at shareholder meetings by preventing investors with only a few shares from attending. But after the June 18 riots last year and then the Huntingdon bomb threats, it has responded vitriolically.

But the investors are beginning to pay attention to the criticisms levelled at it. The Prudential, with hundreds of billions of pounds worth of pension funds, has recently undertaken to pay more attention to ethics, and yesterday the Association of British Insurers, whose 450 members control £940bn of investments, said that companies are becoming more aware of their public images.

"They are now taking ethical considerations into account [when they invest in companies]," said a spokeswoman. "The protests seem eccentric rather than threatening. Protest is a factor now in investment, but not necessarily the most important."

But the companies and industries that have been targeted are also appealing to higher authority. In the past few months, the pharmaceutical industry has called on the government to have legislation to clamp down on what it calls "economic terrorism". Huntingdon itself has written to Tony Blair urging him to bring "extremist animal rights groups" within the remit of terrorist legislation. The City, too, has also welcomed the massive police attention being paid to groups such as Reclaim the Streets which is planning to hold a weekend of protest over May day which may include action against City institutions.

Yesterday, Braybrook was unrepentant, and becoming something of a hero for the City, which likes people not to bow to pressure. "I won't have a man dressed as a beagle making up my mind for me," he told reporters. "I am at liberty to buy what I like and it is my intention to leave the money where it is."

This is not altogether surprising. Huntingdon shares have plummeted so deeply in the past year or two that investors can barely give them away.

 Additional reporting by Graham Diggines.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A column on football violence in Sport, page 2, April 8, stated that a Fulham supporter had been knifed to death outside Gillingham's Priestfield stadium in March 1998. Although this was the supposition on the day, and recorded as such in Rothman's Football Yearbook 1998-99, it was established soon afterwards that a punch to the head by an apparently unarmed attacker had killed the victim. Oliver James was wrongly described, by us, not him, as a psychiatrist in the introduction to a piece he wrote for G2, page 4, March 28 (I've only had one affair. Am I abnormal?) He is a clinical psychologist.

webTitle: Yes TV loses large part of its trade just before flotation

fields.headline: Yes TV loses large part of its trade just before flotation
fields.standfirst: NTL cable operation terminates video-on-demand agreement
fields.trailText: Yes Television has lost one of the key planks of its business just two weeks ahead of a stock market flotation which is expected to value the video-on-demand outfit at £600m.
fields.body:
Yes Television has lost one of the key planks of its business just two weeks ahead of a stock market flotation which is expected to value the video-on-demand outfit at £600m.

Britain's biggest cable company, NTL, is understood to have terminated its agreement with Yes to provide video-on-demand services over its networks.

The pair had been running commercial trials together in Cardiff since the beginning of the year and the relationship is flagged in the Yes TV prospectus as one of only three existing operations.

The end of the agreement could not have been worse timed for Yes TV, which closes its retail offer for shares today.

Yes TV has not yet made a public statement to investors about the end of the NTL deal but is expected to clarify its position today.

Yes TV, which is advised by investment bank Robert Fleming, is understood to have been aware of NTL's decision at least since the beginning of the week.

Yes TV's other operations are for the provision of video-on-demand services to the customers of Kingston Communications in Hull and another pilot scheme with Eircom, the Irish telecoms company.

Its prospectus admits that the opportunity for working with the UK's other cable company, Telewest, are limited, because it is already working with Andersen Consulting to develop its own video-on-demand services.

Yes TV aims to offer a range of movies, music video and sports which can be ordered, paused or rewound at the viewer's whim.

It has begun talks with conventional television channels in the hope of gaining carriage agreements for a total pay-TV package which would be offered via BT's network when it is opened for competition next year. In doing so it would become a full-scale rival to NTL.

NTL has also been testing a video-on-demand service with a rival firm called Diva which is supplying hardware and software for the service.

NTL is thought to prefer Diva because it enables the company to use its own content and movie brand Front Row - although the door has been left ajar for Yes TV as NTL is seeking a second supplier before rolling its service out nationwide.

An agreement is in place to offer a co-branded service between Yes TV and British Telecom over its network using ADSL technology which upgrades copper telephone wires for broadband applications such as multi-channel TV or high speed internet.

The BT agreement is also based on a three-month contract which can be terminated by either side at the end of a pilot offer in west London.

The Yes TV share price range has been set between 225p and 275p per share and the company hopes to raise around £193m.

Institutional investors have until Friday to buy shares, with dealing scheduled to begin on Wednesday April 26.

fields.headline: OECD hits at bank secrecy
fields.standfirst: Western governments to step up the war against international tax evasion
fields.trailText: Western governments today step up the war against international tax evasion by backing moves to eradicate the use of banking secrecy laws to hide fiscal crime.
fields.body:
Western governments today step up the war against international tax evasion by backing moves to eradicate the use of banking secrecy laws to hide fiscal crime.

In a development which appears to open the doors to banks in Switzerland and Luxembourg suspected of protecting tax evaders, the 29 members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development will endorse a high-level report committing national tax authorities to a greater degree of cooperation when attempting to track revenue across borders.

Treasury sources said the report marked the "beginning of the end" for banking secrecy laws being used as a cover for criminal activity.

The move was also seen as vindicating Gordon Brown's opposition to a minimum tax on savings through a withholding tax, which has been championed by France and Germany as a key measure in the fight against tax evasion.

"Banking secrecy has its place in the sense that there is no reason why bank accounts should not be kept private, but this document establishes the overriding principle that it is wrong for banking secrecy laws to be used to hide tax evasion," said a Treasury insider.

With new technology making possible the transfer of billions of pounds between countries at the touch of a button, the OECD has become increasingly concerned about the loss of legitimate tax revenue abroad.

It believes the leakage of revenue is placing an unfair burden on honest tax payers when it comes to financing the cost of public services such as education and health.

To combat the problem, the Paris-based think-tank is drawing up a blacklist of offshore centres whose object is to attract capital through artificially low taxes.

But the moral authority of the exercise has been called into question by the secretive banking laws of some member countries such as Luxembourg and Switzerland.

For the first time, all 29 OECD members have agreed to work together towards the elimination of secrecy laws which prohibit the exchange of information between jurisdictions in cases of suspected tax evasion by rich individuals and corporate entities.

Specifically, the document - seen by the Guardian in advance of official publication later today - urges member countries to:

 "undertake the necessary measures to prevent financial institutions from maintaining anonymous accounts and to require identification of their usual or occasional customers"; and

 "re-examine any domestic tax interest requirement that prevents their tax authorities from obtaining and providing to a treaty partner, in the context of a specific request, information they are otherwise able to obtain for domestic tax purposes."

fields.headline: Telewest chief takes £6m pay-off
fields.trailText: Tony Illsley, chief executive of Telewest, yesterday quit the cable company with a pay-off of £6m. He will leave when its merger with pay-television group Flextech is complete.
fields.body:
Tony Illsley, chief executive of Telewest, yesterday quit the cable company with a pay-off of £6m. He will leave when its merger with pay-television group Flextech is complete.

Mr Illsley's departure was widely expected because he faced the humiliating prospect of playing second fiddle in the merged company to Adam Singer, chief executive of Flextech, which is a quarter the size of Telewest.

The pay-off includes a year's salary of £500,000 plus share options and long-term incentives payable on Mr Illsley's departure at the end of June. He has been with the company for 18 months.

At the time of the merger announcement, Mr Illsley said he felt "pretty positive" about the job.

He is regarded as a strong operational manager but his reputation took a bruising over the mishandling of Telewest's attempted merger with Cable & Wireless Communications last year. NTL snatched CWC from Telewest's grasp.

The styles of Mr Illsley and Mr Singer were also at odds, insiders said. Mr Illsley, 42, is a measured character while Mr Singer is more flamboyant.

One observer said: "There was no row but there's only room for one chief executive and he just didn't want to play second fiddle to Adam."

fields.headline: Scottish Radio ups Border bid
fields.trailText: Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday made a significant increase to its offer for Border Television, valuing the company at £141m, in the hope of preventing the emergence of a rival bid.
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday made a significant increase to its offer for Border Television, valuing the company at £141m, in the hope of preventing the emergence of a rival bid.

Capital Radio, which had been planning a £140m offer for Border, was last night cpnsidering whether to proceed with an amended offer. Chrysalis was also reviewing its position.

Richard Findlay, Scottish Radio's chief executive, said "cordial relations have been resumed" with Border after meeting his opposite number, Paul Corley. Border had rejected Scottish Radio's former offer.

Directors of Scottish Radio and Border are flying to London this morning to continue their discussions.

The revised Scottish Radio offer is five new shares for every six Border shares, which values the stock at £13.02. A fall in the Scottish Radio share price had caused the previous offer to tumble in value to little more than 900p a share.

The cash alternative on offer from Scottish Radio has also been increased from £10.25 a share to £12.75 a share.

Capital is understood to have been planning a paper offer of around £13 a share and a cash alternative of £12.50.

Border said it was considering the Scottish Radio offer with its advisers. The Border share price gained 107p to close at £12.90, suggesting that the market is doubtful of a higher offer coming in.

webTitle: Dresdner board faces shake-out in restructuring

fields.headline: Dresdner board faces shake-out in restructuring
fields.trailText: Dresdner Bank is this week expected to unveil changes designed to give its merchant banking arm Dresdner Kleinwort Benson more autonomy.
fields.body:
Dresdner Bank is this week expected to unveil changes designed to give its merchant banking arm Dresdner Kleinwort Benson more autonomy.

They will include a restructuring of top management to streamline links between the investment bank and Dresdner's managing board.

The changes are expected to be approved at a board meeting this week, which will be overshadowed by the fall-out from the cancelled merger of Dresdner and Deutsche Bank.

The merger failed after the two banks could not agree on the future of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

There is speculation in Frankfurt that a number of directors will lose their jobs in a radical shake-up of Dresdner's board.

The German daily Handelsblatt reported yesterday that the supervisory board was poised to oust as many as six of the top 10 executives. The bank declined to comment.

Dresdner's chief executive Bernhard Walter has already said he will step down at the end of this month because of the merger's collapse.

His opposite number at Deutsche Bank, Rolf Breuer, yesterday received a vote of confidence from his boardroom colleagues.

In a letter to staff signed by all managing board members - including Mr Breuer - the board said Mr Breuer would remain its spokesman and that he had the "unrestricted support" of the chairman of the supervisory board.

Changes at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson have been under consideration for some time but are thought to have been put on hold by the merger talks with Deutsche.

"Dresdner Kleinwort Benson is such an important and profitable part of the bank the feeling is that the investment banking business should be recognised as such," according to one source.

The collapse of the deal with Deutsche is believed to have left Germany's third largest bank vulnerable to a takeover bid, with America's Citigroup and France's BNP as the most likely suitors.

Speculation about a link-up with Commerzbank is also gaining ground, and banking sources say there were contacts between the banks earlier this year.

However, Dresdner is unlikely to begin merger moves until the dust has settled on its last attempt.

webTitle: Retailers should scan the Tesco textbook

fields.headline: Retailers should scan the Tesco textbook
fields.standfirst: Terry Leahy shows the way
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer, Sainsbury, Safeway and all you other high street laggards - pay attention please. Terry Leahy, chief executive of Tesco and the Mr Big of the British grocery business, yesterday provided a masterclass in how to run a retailing empire.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer, Sainsbury, Safeway and all you other high street laggards - pay attention please. Terry Leahy, chief executive of Tesco and the Mr Big of the British grocery business, yesterday provided a masterclass in how to run a retailing empire.

British shopkeepers have had an undeniably tough 12 months. Competition is intense, inflation hovers around zero, shoppers have become more discerning and demanding.

The government has been banging on about rip-off Britain and there is the constant threat that bricks and mortar businesses will be undermined by e-commerce.

There have been regular profit warnings from even the biggest chains, prompting even more regular takeover speculation and a steady stream of top bosses being forced through the checkout as shareholders have realised they are past their sell-by dates.

Then there is Tesco, which has experienced none of the above. Yesterday the chain revealed its savage price cutting had cost £380m last year.

Yet its sales hit a record £20.4bn and its profits climbed 10.8% to £955m. It increased its same-store sales by 4.2% last year and drove up its market share.

Despite the price cuts its margins held steady as the group turned the screw to cut costs.

At the same time it is expanding abroad rapidly, targeting central Europe and Asia. Within two years 45% of the store's selling space will be overseas.

Some £800m - or nearly half of the group's planned investment for 2000 - is being directed overseas as the company increases its 38 foreign hypermarkets to 130 by the end of 2002.

Meanwhile, back in the UK, the £75bn non-food market is being targeted. Three years ago Tesco had 1% of that cake. Today it has 3% and it reckons on having 6% within the next three years.

The grocer has already snaffled 8% of the UK market for CDs, and nothing is out of bounds. Cars could be next.

It now has Britain's fastest-growing credit card business - in January it received 250,000 card applications and accounted for one in five of new cards. Analysts reckon its personal finance operation will move into the black this year.

Then there is the internet. Tesco Direct has stolen a march on its rivals and is now the world's biggest online grocery business.

It will now be run as a separate subsidiary and although there is no plan to float it off, Freeserve-style, it probably has a value of some £4bn.

Long term there are unanswered questions. If the internet business does take off, for example, it will have to invest heavily in "picking centre" warehouses.

Its stores are designed for shoppers meandering the aisles, not a super-efficient order fulfilment and delivery system. Online shopping could pose a huge question mark over the future of out-of-town retailing.

But, on current performance - remorseless growth in the toughest of conditions - there is no reason to bet against the Tesco team.

Still uncemented

Lafarge received quite a few pats on the back when, back at the beginning of February, the French building materials group stepped across the Channel once again and slapped in a £3.4bn hostile offer for British rival Blue Circle.

The timing looked so perfect, arriving just as investors were trampling each other underfoot in their haste to get out of such "old economy" stocks.

But markets move quicker than takeover bid timetables, and 10 weeks later Lafarge is having to face up to the irritating fact that those skittish shareholders are now trampling each other to get back in to old economy companies like Blue Circle.

This week real businesses, where the shares trade on low-figure multiples of earnings rather than moon-bound multiples of sales, are back in fashion.

What is more, in their response to the attack from the French, the Blue Circle management have shown no sign of getting their feet stuck in their own product.

The market seems to have taken on board chief executive Rick Haythornthwaite's arguments that the group's Asian businesses are recovering faster than most outsiders realised and that Blue Circle's own cost savings plan will yield more than Lafarge even envisaged initially.

As things stand, the 420p in cash on the table from Lafarge (worth 409p if the non-payment of the due Blue Circle dividend is taken into account) is set to stay right there unless the terms are sweetened. The French have until next Wednesday to raise the stakes.

It is widely assumed that Lafarge will have to pay something rather closer to 500p a share if it wants to pursue its version of global consolidation in the industry.

The only reason the shares (sitting at 427p last night) have not moved to a higher premium to the current offer is the risk that the bidder, faced with its own gearing problems, might simply walk away.

Raise or walk: the only other option for Lafarge might be to pray that the old economy bubble bursts.

webTitle: 'If you've got a big mouth, the stage is the place to be'

fields.headline: 'If you've got a big mouth, the stage is the place to be'
fields.standfirst: Finally, one of the Royal Court's angry young playwrights has been let into the National.  Brian Logan  talks to Joe Penhall
fields.trailText: Finally, one of the Royal Court's angry young playwrights has been let into the National. Brian Logan talks to Joe Penhall
fields.body:
Of the generation of incendiary Royal Court playwrights who rejuvenated British theatre in the mid-90s - Sarah Kane, Mark Ravenhill, Anthony Neilson, Jez Butterworth - Joe Penhall hardly seemed the talent most likely to succeed. A stranger to front pages - at least since he quit as crime correspondent for the Hammersmith Guardian - 32-year-old Penhall has made quiet progress since his electrifying 1994 debut Some Voices, which cast Ray Winstone as the mild-mannered elder brother of a young schizophrenic. Yet this week, the affable west Londoner becomes, officially, the first of that Bratpack to grow up, premiering his latest play, Blue/Orange, at the National Theatre.

It's a turnaround. In the introduction to Methuen's edition of his Plays One - "an optimistic title", Penhall laughingly admits - he describes snubbing an invite from the National in 1997, because "I couldn't think of a subject with Land Rovers and boulders in it." So what's changed? "I thought, perhaps naively, that that was what was expected when one did a play at the National." Not so. When the theatre persevered, Penhall offered it one of two plays. "One had lots of scenes, lots of characters, lots of story - it was very big and had a bit of everything. The other had three blokes and an orange." The latter got the nod.

Penhall is a reluctant interviewee, not least because, last time we spoke his tongue wagged regrettably free. That was spring 1998, the time of his Donmar Warehouse drama of job insecurity, The Bullet. Elaborating on an observation, by Guardian critic Michael Billington that he was the most "warm-hearted" writer of his generation, Penhall slammed "the notion that desperation is some sort of spiritual release which strikes a chord in all of us. What I'm saying is: no it fucking doesn't." His plays - which include 1995's Pale Horse and 1997's Love and Understanding - tend to explore what it means to be "good, well-adjusted and unassuming" in an age when, "if you've got one shred of idealism... the shorthand for it is pedantic, anally retentive."

There's a raging idealism at play in Blue/Orange, which should satisfy those who lament the absence of political theatre from the British stage. And that's political with a small "p": for Penhall, the political is always best dramatised by the personal. Blue/Orange returns to territory staked out by Some Voices, only this time, it assails care in the community - "an exercise in cruelty and greed unparalleled in post-war England", Penhall has written - not from the patient's perspective, but from the doctors'. "The thing about the medical profession that fascinates me," says Penhall, "is that, while I grew up with this idea that doctors were somehow unimpeachable, in fact there's as much salaciousness and dishonesty there as anywhere else."

Blue/Orange demonstrates real anger at how that frailty is brought to the surface by NHS bureaucracy and low morale. "I wanted to explore," says Penhall, "the absurdity of legislating the criteria for providing care," which he describes as "like holding a river in a sieve". To do so, he propels the play's three characters into a whirlwind of bureaucracy, perverted political correctness and "ugly, surreal, ungovernable, horrifying mental illness" that recalls, and may surpass, Mamet's Oleanna.

We have the statistics, and Joe Penhall's real-life experience of them, to thank for the addition of race into that potent brew. Black people are 12 times more likely to be diagnosed schizophrenic than whites. When Penhall worked with psychiatric patients in the US, "one of the fellas I was looking after was this black guy who would wake up convinced he was white. I couldn't resist writing about that." In Blue/Orange, Chris thinks his dad is Idi Amin - and that oranges are blue. The racial theme was refined by an article Penhall read, "saying 'Thank God for Prince Philip', because right-thinking white liberals secretly breathe a sigh of relief every time he unleashes one of his absurd racial gaffes. I was outraged," says the writer, although the duke's brand of bumbling chauvinism has been incorporated into Blue/Orange in an intriguingly ambiguous way.

The main characters in the drama are a careerist senior doctor and the idealist underling with whom he's at war. Theirs has the making of a devastating on-stage confrontation - the more so because Penhall has wooed his favourite actor to star in it. "I wrote Bill Nighy a letter. 'I hope I'm not being over-familiar, but, Bill, this is your play. I don't want anyone else to do it. There are notes you can only hear on a Steinway. There are songs that only Elvis can sing.' " Clearly flattered, Nighy - erstwhile star of Stoppard's Arcadia - accepted, taking his place in a production overseen by Notting Hill director Roger Michell.

There's fate at work here, because Penhall is involved in a film that's been dubbed - much to his disgust - "the anti-Notting Hill". His own adaptation of Some Voices, set in Shepherds Bush - a mile from the scene of Hugh and Julia's love-in - is due to debut at Cannes in May. "One article said we were going to drive the house prices down," remarks Penhall of a movie - starring Daniel Craig, Kelly McDonald and David Morrissey - that realises the writer's ambition to bring schizophrenia, in all its grim complexity, to the screen. "I spent a fair few years trying to get that film made," says Penhall, who based the original play's protagonist, Ray, on a friend with the illness. "It was quite clear why it took so long: you can make a film about junkies, or a man beating his wife until there are bubbles coming out of her nose, but schizophrenia scares people or baffles them."

Having waited half a decade, of course, two films come along at once: the producers of Wonderland and This Year's Love are set to bring Love and Understanding to the screen. Their writer is pleased, in his breezy, blokey way, about this; but thanks to Blue/Orange, which he's greatly enjoyed working on, Penhall is committed to writing for the stage. "If you've got a big mouth," he says, with the widest smile, "theatre, not the cinema, is the place to be."

So can he handle the burden of expectation imposed by the National Theatre's recent run of ropey new plays? "I do think about it," he admits, "because it's quite clear that certain theatres are better than others at doing new work: some are the A-team, others can't even get off the bench."

"The thought of anyone depending on me is kind of horrific," he shudders. "But I think they're big boys. They can look after themselves." It's that "Land Rovers and boulders" attitude again, the ambivalence of an instinctive subversive towards a pillar of the establishment. "What I'm writing about in this play," says Penhall, "is the arrogance and self-assurance of bourgeois liberalism. I think you can take it as read that those in positions of authority are almost invariably inadequate."

 Blue/Orange opens on Thursday. Box office: 0171-452 3000.

fields.headline: Molly alone
fields.standfirst: A new production of Brian Friel's Molly Sweeney has won a big European prize. So why can't we see it here, asks  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: A new production of Brian Friel's Molly Sweeney has won a big European prize. So why can't we see it here, asks Michael Billington
fields.body:
'Theatre is friendship.It's nothing to do with show-business." The words, predictably enough, come not from a British director. They were spoken by Lev Dodin, director of the Maly Theatre of St Petersburg, in Taormina, Sicily last weekend where he won the eighth annual European Theatre Prize.

No award could be more richly deserved. At the moment, however, it is uncertain whether anyone here will get to see Dodin's new production of Brian Friel's Molly Sweeney, given its world premiere in Taormina. Partly it's a matter of cost: the Arts Council's National Touring panel initially jibbed at the application from a British producer for a £140,000 grant though they are now re-examining a lower figure. What is staggering is that they expressed doubts about the "artistic qualities" of Dodin's recent work. This seems mind-boggling. Alas, poor Lev: good enough for Europe and the world but not, it seems, for the Arts Council of England.

Certainly Dodin is more famous for big ensemble productions such as Brothers and Sisters, an enveloping saga of Russian peasant life. Friel's play, in contrast, is an intimate three-hander about a blind woman who regains her sight after an operation and finds her world falling apart. Using intercut monologues delivered by Molly, her bumptious husband, and a whiskey-driven opthalmologist, it bears a strong resemblance to Friel's Faith Healer. But that, I suspect, explains Dodin's fascination with the play: its themes of spirituality, vision, the distinction between real and imaginary worlds are exactly those that animate his own work.

webTitle: Lending an ear to social services

fields.headline: Lending an ear to social services
fields.standfirst: A bank which regards growth as secondary to making ethical loans
fields.trailText: Bankers are not exactly flavour of the month. Barclays has upset customers and shareholders by closing branches and overpaying its bosses. NatWest has been sold out by its disgruntled shareholders. The clearing banks are accused of ripping off customers.
fields.body:
Bankers are not exactly flavour of the month. Barclays has upset customers and shareholders by closing branches and overpaying its bosses. NatWest has been sold out by its disgruntled shareholders. The clearing banks are accused of ripping off customers.

Yet Glen Saunders, the UK managing director of Triodos Bank, got a warm reception from customers and shareholders at his annual meeting last week, and it's not surprising when you look at his record.

The group's balance sheet and profits increased by almost a third last year as the loan portfolio grew by more than half (the UK figure was an astonishing 89%).

Far from sacking staff, Mr Saunders is struggling to recruit enough. While others worry about internationalisation, his institution already operates in three European countries and is ready to move into Germany and Spain.

And instead of asking for multi-million pound bonuses, this 46-year-old former Marxist and chartered accountant settled for the £1,000 given to all the staff at Christmas, on top of his modest £55,000 salary.

Triodos, Mr Saunders disarmingly told the meeting, is "not even yet a small bank".

Even after more than tripling in size over the past five years the balance sheet is still only £287m - not much more than the value of the option schemes just handed out to Barclays' top brass.

The UK will overtake the Netherlands this year to become the biggest of the three legs (Belgium is the other), yet there are still only about 30 UK staff.

Triodos is different not only in the scale of its operations. It is a social bank. Mr Saunders will not lend to any old business which looks like a good credit risk - borrowers must be socially, ethically and environmentally sound.

About one in four loan applicants are turned down on the grounds that their product or service is bogus, or their commitment to social and environmental change is superficial.

Triodos does big business (by its standards) with organic farmers and food companies, wind farms and other renewable energy businesses, social and community organisations.

While the figures have been growing, the managing director told his annual meeting that growth was not the objective (imagine that at Barclays). "We see it as a symptom that we are doing things right and meeting people's needs," Mr Saunders said.

"It is not the main point. It is a secondary phenomenon. The main point is to finance the right things."

Charges and choices

The bank was founded in the Netherlands in 1980. It came to the UK in 1995 when it acquired Mercury Provident, a similar organisation which emerged from the Steiner movement in the 1970s but had failed to grow beyond those narrow boundaries.

Mr Saunders was instrumental in bringing the bank here. That was after a career which began at the computer company ICL, continued at the accountancy firm Price Waterhouse, and took in a few years of consultancy work in the social finance field.

He describes consultancy as working for "people standing round a swimming pool asking what it would be like if they jumped in". Now he helps them to jump in and does his best to keep them afloat.

It isn't always possible, and Mr Saunders told his audience on Saturday that sometimes even social bankers have to be tough. But he is not ashamed to reschedule loans, and accuses mainstream banks of being too ready to pull the rug from understruggling customers.

He is less critical of his gigantic competitors than might be expected. "Would customers really pay the real cost of a small local branch?" he says of Barclays' rural predicament.

"It is the banks' own fault for a lack of transparency in charges but it is quite clear that customers' choices are forcing a big restructuring."

But then the social activist emerges: "Barclays is basically out to maximise shareholder value. It is not a social service. The question is: there are social services in a bank's operations. How do you organise that? Just blaming people and shouting about obscene salaries isn't enough."

The frustration spreads to the government's failure to address social finance issues. Mr Saunders is no longer "very left wing" in the Marxist sense of believing in state control, but he believes Labour has missed a golden opportunity to help social and environmental initiatives.

"Labour has been disappointingly timid. For example I would have hoped they would look much more actively at tax regimes to support environmental initiatives. Labour has been radical in some areas. Why not in this area too? People would like it."

Triodos does not depend on government support or tax breaks. It depends on a steady flow of savings, and the only serious threat to that is if clever marketing by mainstream banks convinces people that they have adopted the socio-environmental cause.

He cites the example of the LloydsTSB campaign highlighting its charitable giving. "It is making a big play on what is really small change in the context of their profits and the impact of their restructuring and investments."

There is no whingeing - he accepts the logic of the market. "We have to show what we do is different, and we have to keep coming up with something new."

And he believes the world is moving in his direction: "I have a feeling there is some sort of paradigm shift going on. People are expecting more from business."

fields.headline: It's one for the ballet...
fields.standfirst: Elvis Presley coming to Sadler's Wells?  Maddy Costa had to find out more
fields.trailText: Elvis Presley coming to Sadler's Wells? Maddy Costa had to find out more
fields.body:
It's routine to be bombarded with flyers at gigs, but something bewildering happened after Elvis - The Concert at Wembley Arena, at which Presley briefly lived again, albeit only as a giant video projection. The leaflets weren't advertising the return of Frank Sinatra or Freddie Mercury; instead they pointed audiences to Sadler's Wells and a ballet called The King. The idea of a 23-years-dead Elvis touring Britain was weird enough, but Elvis in blue suede point shoes?

Peter Schaufuss, the Danish choreographer behind this odd event, talks in the matter-of-fact tones of one who feels his idea is so obvious that it doesn't merit an explanation. He was attracted to Elvis because "he's a very well-known person - probably the best known human being". There must be more to it than that, but the more Schaufuss speaks, the less enlightening he is. "Elvis gives you a good story," he offers, "a sad story of a multi-talented person who unfortunately became a drug addict."

So Schaufuss didn't spend his childhood hunting out gold lamé suits and bopping to Jailhouse Rock? Well, no: he was too busy dancing with the Royal Danish Ballet, where he began his career at the age of seven.

Schaufuss's work on The King hasn't turned him into a fan, but he does admire some sides of Elvis's persona. "Not only did he have a phenomenal music talent, he was also not afraid of a day's work. He would record an album in a week. Fantastic!"

It's easy to see why that attracts Schaufuss: he set up his own ballet company less than three years ago (having, in the previous decade, departed from the English National Ballet, the Berlin Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet), and since then has created eight full-length ballets. These include a version of Hamlet choreographed to recordings of John Gielgud reading the monologues, and a staging of the film Midnight Express. He's now planning a piece based on the life and works of Hans Christian Andersen.

Point out the unusual nature of these works and Schaufuss bristles. "I make pieces for a large, general audience and I can't see why anyone would have a problem with that. They're not going to see men in white tights with big sleeves, no. You can walk in straight from the street without having seen a play before, sit down and understand what you are seeing on stage and be entertained.

"You should always challenge your audiences," he continues, "but not in such a way that they don't know what they've seen." Certainly, large, general audiences seem to have no problem with this: The King has been selling out venues wherever it tours.

Schaufuss calls the piece a "dansical", explaining that it's a work where movement replaces singing, then quickly adds, "We have got the best singer in the world singing his original songs." Like Elvis's later concerts, the show opens with Richard Strauss's Thus Spake Zarathustra (the 2001 theme). It then follows Elvis's life chronologically through his music.

"I've listened to the 460 songs Elvis recorded," Schaufuss states blankly, "and I've picked music mirroring what took place in Elvis's life at a particular time."

We do get to see Elvis in gold lamé rocking and rolling to That's Alright, Mama, but also more tender scenes to gospel numbers and Are You Lonesome Tonight?, a song that, for Schaufuss, summarises the whole Elvis story. "I did consider calling the ballet Are You Lonesome Tonight?" he says. "That is a very appropriate title for something inspired by the legend of Elvis Presley. I've seen a clip from one of his last shows where he sings that song and actually cries: it shows a side of him that is very sad. I think it's a great tragedy that someone who had talent, good looks, a fortune, everything he wanted, ended up so lonely." Unsurprisingly, the hilarious recording of Elvis changing the lyrics to the song to mention baldness, as shown at Elvis - The Concert, doesn't come up.

Off-putting sternness aside, it's good to see someone treating Elvis's later years with respect, when the tendency is to view him as a monstrous aberration gobbling fried peanut butter sandwiches. The King doesn't stint on white jumpsuited excess, but it does place Elvis in the context of serious art. The only music not directly related to Elvis in the piece is by Wagner - the Liebestod from Tristan und Isolde. "That sounds outrageous," Schaufuss concedes, "but Wagner's music is about gods and icons, and Elvis is a modern icon. It works very well." And if you thought you had no interest in the singer, Schaufuss is convinced that you'll walk out of his ballet with "a very different opinion about Elvis".

 The King is at the Festival Theatre, Edinburgh (0131-529 6000), from April 17 to 22 and Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (0171-863 8000), from April 27 to May 6.

fields.headline: Putin pledges funds for Mir
fields.standfirst: Mir Space Station homepage
fields.trailText: President-elect Vladimir Putin pledged today to fund Russia's ageing Mir space station as well as sticking to agreements to build a much-delayed International Space Station.
fields.body:
President-elect Vladimir Putin pledged today to fund Russia's ageing Mir space station as well as sticking to agreements to build a much-delayed International Space Station.

The 14-year-old Mir had been due to be scuttled this year, but foreign funds kept the space station alive and the lights were turned back on last week by two cosmonauts on a mission to put the mothballed station into operation.

The United States has voiced concern that extending Mir's life might cause Moscow to drag its feet over the $60 billion International Space Station (ISS).

"We will fulfil our commitments to the ISS," Putin said during a Kremlin meeting with cosmonauts to mark Russia's Cosmonauts' Day.

"But one must not forget national industry. National industry has to be our priority."

Cosmonauts' Day falls on the anniversary of Yuri Gagarin's 1961 flight around the Earth in Vostok I - which shattered the United States' hopes of being first to put a man in space.

"The space sector is not only a prestigious sector which makes our country a great power, but it is also linked to economic and scientific development," Putin said.

RIA news agency also quoted Putin as saying Mir would be included in the 2001 space budget.

Russian television showed pictures of the two cosmonauts aboard Mir, floating in front of a large Russian tricolour flag. They had earlier used boosters on a Progress M1-1 cargo ship to correct the space station's orbit.

"It's alright now here, we're comfortable. The temperature is 25 degrees (77 Fahrenheit)," said cosmonaut Sergei Zalyotin.

Mir was originally designed to last just five years, and orbited the Earth empty for almost a year prior to its planned scrapping. In January, a company of foreign investors called MirCorp offered $20 million in funds to revive the station.

MirCorp has said it plans to invest up to $200 million in the station and has talked of converting Mir into a "space hotel".

Russia's state space programme now runs on a shoestring compared to its Soviet-era glory days and many see keeping Mir as an important reminder of past prowess. Moscow's contribution to the ISS, which it is working on with the United States, the European Union and Japan, is based on Russia's position as the only country with experience of running a space station for a long time.

Colonel-General Pyotr Klimuk, the head of the Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Centre in Star City outside Moscow, told Wednesday's issue of the military daily Krasnaya Zvezda that it was this that made Russia crucial to the project.

"It's no secret that without Russia, the Americans would not be able to build the ISS. We've gathered huge experience in long-term space flight and done unique technical, scientific and medical work to make it possible," he said.

Unmanned segments of the station are already orbiting Earth, but cannot be put into operation until Russia sends up living quarters. The launch is scheduled for July, two years late.

webTitle: Cheat stain that will not wash away

fields.headline: Cheat stain that will not wash away
fields.standfirst:
South Africa is left reeling
Mike Selvey asks: Where now?
South Africa's captain sacked
How the scandal was exposed
Hansie Cronje profile
Matthew Engel
Wisden Verdict
fields.trailText: John Perlman in Johannesburg on how a proud sporting nation must come to terms with the word 'cheat'.
fields.body:
As Steve Waugh walks out at the head of the Australian team in Durban today, some South Africans will for a moment be reminded that some disappointments are hard to stomach. But when Shaun Pollock leads South Africa on to the field, we will all be forced to recognise that no matter how many disappointments you get over, defeat can never prepare you for disgrace.

Pollock takes the place of his captain Hansie Cronje for the three one-day internationals against Australia, a series that one South African TV channel is stupidly promoting as "unfinished business".

What's unfinished? The Australians settled matters in that dramatic semi-final at Edgbaston. They are the world champions. This little series is just a nice little earner for them. But the shame that South African sport is landed with now... well, we're probably talking unfinishable business here. No such thing as redemption by seven wickets in this series.

The damage done to South African sport is already immense, and the serious inquiry into the sordid details has not even begun. Many South Africans will have woken up this morning feeling an intensely personal hurt.

I have a niece who has recently become hooked on cricket. She watched the first TV news bulletin that talked of cheating in cricket, of Cronje and crooked men, and she burst into tears.

I have a friend whose son is cricket-crazy. I said I'd take a miniature bat round to net practice and get the South African team to sign it. He suggested yesterday that I should not go to any special trouble.

Someone got through the queue of callers battling to get a word in on talk radio shows up and down the country and said he did some coaching at a local school. "The kids are devastated," he said. "They say if Hansie isn't honest, who is?"

When the news first broke last week, the reaction in South Africa was combative to say the least. Ali Bacher wondered how the Indian cricket public would feel if South African police tapped Sachin Tendulkar's phone. South Africa's deputy minister of foreign affairs Aziz Pahad said the government would press India to release the incriminating tapes.

"Steve Waugh and his team are scared of our boys, and they've paid the Indian government to do this," said one caller to a national station. She wasn't the weirdest caller.

And then Cronje made his dead-of-night confession to the cricket bosses, triggering the slow seep of shame. Oh, there will be "Hansie, we love you" banners at Kingsmead today - and at Newlands and the Wanderers too. Though they might fill a TV screen for a few seconds, they won't cover much else.

After years of going out into the world acutely aware of the stains on our shirts, South Africans once again will find themselves hanging their heads. South African cricket has had its crises and its conflicts. But it has put in place changes that will last. Soweto may not have produced a national team player but it has six teams at every level, and the players who coach the township talent are themselves the products of the first development initiatives back in the 80s. There are similar stories up and down South Africa.

The United Cricket Board of South Africa recently announced a massively increased budget for development, and though politicians have sometimes questioned the all-too-white character of the men in white, there has been general acceptance that the essentials for spreading the game to all South Africans are in place. Add in the fact that sponsorship has hit record levels and the consistent success of the team... what could go wrong?

Nobody could have expected that the skipper would sink the ship, that the damage would be done by South Africa's highly competitive but invariably courteous captain, an ambitious man but one acutely aware that the responsibilities of captaining South Africa involved more than just winning the toss and getting the bowling changes right.

Cronje was everywhere he was supposed to be: at media launches of new cricket facilities in townships, at lunches with Nelson Mandela. But he also did some fine work out of the limelight: coaching promising black players when he had the time, visiting townships unannounced to lend a hand and spark some dreams.

Cronje was widely seen as a person of substance and dignity, and it was that sense of him which helped South Africans share that World Cup disappointment rather than hold it against him. A fiercely proud sporting nation has been getting a bit better at accepting the tag of loser from time to time. But how does it begin coming to terms with the label "cheat"?

webTitle: We can no longer say it's not cricket

fields.headline: We can no longer say it's not cricket
fields.standfirst:
South Africa's captain sacked
How the scandal was exposed
Hansie Cronje profile
Matthew Engel
Reaction in South Africa
Wisden Verdict
fields.trailText: The reputation of cricket as a metaphor for all that is fair and true lies in tatters. Mike Selvey asks: 'Where does this leave England?'
fields.body:
With the sacking of Hansie Cronje in South Africa yesterday, not just his reputation but that of cricket as a metaphor for all that is fair and true lies in tatters.

Dark, brooding, beetle-browed Hansie, seen by colleagues and opponents alike as a man of absolute integrity and honesty, stands accused, along with three members of his team that toured India recently, of rigging matches, a scandal so deep that it would have been unimaginable a decade ago before the first rumbles began to emerge from the subcontinent.

If he were to be found guilty, nailed by the evidence compiled painstakingly by the New Delhi police, he would be a ruined man, perhaps doubly so in a country that places its sports stars on the highest of pedestals.

Already he has coughed to accepting between $10,000 and $15,000 (£6,300-£9,500) for providing "information and forecasting" to a bookmaker and, though he continues to maintain his innocence of match-fixing, his credibility is shot to pieces. He has lied until he could do so no longer, and doubtless the whole truth will out in dribs and drabs.

"Unequivocally, we are shattered," Ali Bacher, chief executive of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, said yesterday. "The UCB and the government have been deceived."

He might have added that a sports-obsessed nation has been betrayed. One feels for Bacher and South African cricket, for they have striven so hard for recognition and success and believed that they were almost there. The forthcoming one-day series against Australia has little meaning for them now.

In uncovering this the Indian police have succeeded in exposing what may prove to be the biggest scandal in cricket history and one of the biggest in sport anywhere.

Cricket has had its controversies - bodyline, throwing, the D'Oliveira affair and Packer - even down to the allegations of corruption levelled at Pakistani cricketers and the money accepted by the Australians Mark Waugh and Shane Warne for supplying insipid information about weather and ground conditions to a bookmaker. But nothing, if all the allegations are proved, to rank with this.

Few people can believe, or want to believe, that it is true. To some extent, before yesterday's press conference cricket had begun to close ranks - as the Australian Cricket Board to its detriment did when dealing with Warne and Waugh - which in the circumstances is shameful.

The charges were fabricated, lies, figments of the imagination. And they would go away. No one, in fact, apart from those in India, actually turned round when the allegations first surfaced late last week and asked themselves, "What if?"

The trouble is that if someone as respected as Cronje has been within the cricket community can do even what he has confessed thus far to doing and, for a period of time at least, get away with it, then what does it say about the rest of the game? Who else is involved, for others there surely must be?

Pakistanis, we know already, have dipped their hands in the till, and one, Salim Malik, has paid a price of sorts (although some suspect he is carrying the can for others still playing). Indians are under investigation and the Australians, unwittingly they say, have dabbled on the fringes of legality. And now South Africans.

Where does this leave England? Well, we all joke about England and the notion that anyone would be daft enough to consider paying them to lose when they do it so well without incentive. But approaches have been made: to Adam Hollioake when he was leading the side in Sharjah and to Chris Lewis. On each occasion the incidents were reported forthwith. Have there been others who have kept things to themselves?

The England and Wales Cricket Board will issue statements saying that it is confident such things do not go on in its own domain, but it will do so in the knowledge that until Cronje got his cards that is precisely the stance that the South Africans took.

Cricket lends itself readily to bookmaking scams. Altering the outcome of a match is hard, although Cronje as captain had greater scope than others. But it is in spread-betting and the possibility of manipulating events during a game that real scope for skulduggery lies.

An example: before a one-day game in England last year, one firm was offering a spread on the number of balls into the match that the first wide would be signalled. It does not take much imagination to see the potential in that situation.

It is alleged in the Delhi police tape transcripts that Herschelle Gibbs, one of the three implicated along with Cronje, had been expected, in a match in Faridabad, to score fewer than 20 runs and to do so slowly. He made 19 from 36 balls. Coincidence?

Perhaps good will come from this case, for in pinning down such a high-profile figure as Cronje a warning will be sent out worldwide that there is a price to be paid.
